SSO.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Jagajaga moving forthwith to defer consideration of the Bills in the Aged Care legislative package (orders of the day Nos 1 to 3, government business) until details relating to the implementation of the bills are resolved, including:
(1) the provision of an adequate capital subsidy for concessional residents instead of the Government's much‐derided proposed rate of $5 per day;
(2) agreed specific prudential arrangements for safeguarding residents' up‐front entry fees;
(3) details of the residential subsidy classification instrument and arrangements for training staff in its use;

(4) the establishment of an independent body to monitor the numbers of concessional residents and exempt beds by region and facility, waiting periods for entry into and transfer to nursing homes and hostels by resident status, sums paid as accommodation bonds by facility, places provided by metropolitan/rural/remote location and socio‐economic status, etc, and other appropriate details relating to the provision of health care; and

(5) appropriate mechanisms for accountability for the use of funds, particularly to ensure that high quality nursing and personal care staff are employed to care for the residents of aged care homes, and that capital funds are used to upgrade nursing homes.
This aged care legislation is discriminatory and ill-prepared.

PARA.TAB: That the member be not further heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the corrigendum to the explanatory memorandum for the Aged Care Bill 1997. This corrigendum is required as a result of a printing error at the AGPS, which saw the last page of the original explanatory memorandum inadvertently left off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aged Care Bill 1997 has been described as `discriminatory and ill prepared' and as `short‐sighted', its passage lamented as `seriously risking undermining the current standard of aged care in Australia', its impact assessed as certain to `punish Australia's most vulnerable older people' and its legacy `a two‐tiered system of health care'—a system that will condemn older Australians without money or assets to second‐rate levels of care in older and increasingly run‐down accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: These are not the words of the opposition, nor are they the words of any fringe anti-government group. They are the words of the Catholic, Uniting and Anglican churches, of Over 50s Focus, Aged Care Australia, the Older Women's Network and the Alzheimers Association of Australia. They are also the words of the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association. These organisations represent the full spectrum of private and not‐for‐profit aged care providers as well as older Australians and their families. These reactions have been provoked by a bill which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) describes as `first class' and which the government claims is aimed at cleaning up a `mess' in aged care—a `mess' that the government claims is the legacy of Labor in government.

There is a view that if you say something often enough it will become true, throw enough mud around and some of it will stick, and in politics attempt to create a sense of crisis and confusion to justify or smokescreen hidden agendas. Of course, what we see here is the government doing exactly that in relation to aged care.

What we have heard from the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), and no doubt we will hear from other speakers from the government side on this subject, is one of the most extraordinary litanies of exaggeration, half truths and outright misrepresentation of the facts ever heard in this chamber.

What is the truth about Labor's record in government and what did Labor inherit in terms of aged care from the Fraser govern ment? In 1983 Labor inherited an aged care system that had seen numerous attempts at reform by previous governments of both political persuasions. However, the system provided standards of care that varied widely over the nation. Some of it was appalling. I will not go on about all that now because it is a very long time ago.

What did Labor do about it? One thing they did not do is sit on their hands. Rather than give you my words, let us have a look at what Australia's welfare said about our aged care system. Australia's welfare is a detailed report about Australia's health and welfare systems that has been undertaken by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, a body that is independent of government and political parties. I recommend to the minister that she read these reports and stop misleading the public and the parliament about what Labor did. The 1993 report describes the major restructuring of aged care services that started in 1985. It makes the point:
It was not until the mid‐1980s that a substantial overhaul of the aged care system—the Aged Care Reform Strategy—was implemented. Changes since that time have been considerable.
Labor's Aged Care Reform Strategy had major social justice objectives—access, equity and participation.

It is worth just pausing here for a minute to compare these objectives with the Howard government's central driving tenet of user pays, which means that you get into a nursing home if you have the money, and the money will determine the type of nursing home bed you get as well.

The Howard government has proved extremely creative at developing policies that will increase the number of users who can pay through such things as accommodation bonds or up-front fees. But its policies are most threadbare when coping with the situation where a user cannot pay. We have seen the most glaring example of this in the last week with the government's `derisory' and `insulting' offer of $5 per bed day for the financially disadvantaged. Again, these are the words of the churches.

BREAK.PARA: By way of contrast, Labor's aged care reform strategy sought to properly target services to levels of need. Thus we had the development of a system of care, with the level of care offered determined by need as opposed to how much money one has. That is the Howard government approach of user pays. The type of care was determined by independent aged care assessment teams that were made up of doctors, nurses and social workers. These teams worked to a classification instrument which specified the types of care to be offered and made sure that the more highly dependent residents got greater resources. These important changes were put in place by Labor, not by any previous Liberal government.

Nursing homes offered higher levels of care while the development of hostels offered a lower level of care. That was encouraged to stop a trend that had emerged under successive Liberal governments of increasing institutionalisation in nursing homes of people with lower care needs. There was a further diversification of the type of care offered with the introduction in 1985 of home and community care and, later, community aged care packages, both of which allowed older Australians with increasing dependency to continue living in their own homes. User rights, including a charter of residents rights, were developed from 1989 to 1991. Labor's strategy also introduced standards monitoring in 1987. Australia's welfare comments:

The results of a 4 year evaluation of the Standards Monitoring Program in nursing homes . . . included international comparisons, and places the Australian program at the forefront of aged care regulatory practices.

This point needs to be stressed if only to counter the wave of strident and irresponsible rot being promoted by the Minister for Family Services and the Prime Minister. Australia under Labor had an excellent standard of aged care and was a world leader in the levels of care provided. This is not just my view; it is the view of delegates to international conferences such as the Alzheimer's International Conference in Scotland in 1994, just to give one example.

Things were not perfect. They did need ongoing reform. But this trend of ongoing reform, of continuous improvement, was the Labor approach. I might just mention for the purposes of informing the minister that I personally had nothing to do with this process of reform. I am very happy to give the credit to others for this excellent program of reform. In fact, I was not working for the federal government and of course was not in the federal parliament. The minister might stop misleading everybody on that score as well.

Let us have a look at the capital funding issues for aged care institutions. Under Labor, capital expenditure on nursing homes and hostels increased from $46 million in 1984-85 to total $1.2 billion over the 10-year period after that. These are the facts that all those opposite should comprehend. As Australia's welfare comments:
The system which emerged by the early 1980's was a consequence of incremental change which took little account of the inter‐relationships between different sectors of provision.
Commenting in 1995, the report says:
Australia has come to recognise the importance of a more holistic approach to service delivery.
‐ the best balance of care amongst domiciliary services, long term residential care, supported accommodation, short term respite services, support for carers and cash assistance.

But what do this government give us? They are giving us in this Aged Care Bill a return to the incremental approach with the addition of user pays and a significant cut of $500 million to government support for aged care.

In preparing for today I could not find any evidence of any other government that put the aged care sector under such budgetary pressure. None. This government has done a first as far as that is concerned. In comparing in real terms what Labor spent on aged care, we find real recurrent expenditure increased by 54 per cent in the nine years 1985-86 to 1993-94; in HACC, home and community care, by 134 per cent; in hostels by 283 per cent; and in nursing homes by 22 per cent.

Compare this picture of ordered, systematic, evolutionary reform to the mess this government has managed to make of its attempts at aged care reform over the last 12 months. Along the way the Howard government have caused an enormous amount of worry and concern amongst the majority of older Australians and their families and a great deal of worry to the providers of aged care. In fact, what this government have managed to do is unite in opposition to their proposals all those involved in aged care—the providers, both private and not for profit, the workers and representatives of nursing home residents.

This opposition has developed as the full implications of the government's plans have been revealed. Let us have a look at the piecemeal and confused approach that the government has adopted. Even in the last few days, just before we were supposed to debate this bill, we have seen an announcement that the implementation of the bill is to be delayed for three months—something that the opposition and the aged care sector have been calling for—but three months is far too short a time to unravel the mess this government has created.

Secondly, we have had the final and belated revelation of one of the bill's key measures: the amount of subsidy to be paid to nursing homes for taking those who cannot pay an entry fee, an amount described by the Uniting Church as `an insult to our elderly and a slap in the face for charitable service providers' and by the Catholic Church as `a cruel joke'. These comments should be noted by all those opposite.

We have the consultative group responsible for funding details still discussing—I am here debating this bill in the House and we still have people having discussions with the departments—the descriptors to be used to assess nursing home residents. Until these are provided, it is impossible for nursing homes to use the new classification instrument or to have any idea about how their finances will look under the government's new system. They have no way of knowing whether or not they will be better or worse off, and here we are debating the bill.

We have once again had the cancellation of training workshops at the last moment. This is an extremely important issue because those who work in nursing homes have to be able to understand how they are to put this new system in place, how they are to assess residents and how they are to know who will be employed in nursing homes. Labor's aged care strategy was accompanied by almost a year of intensive training by teams of trainers. Without proper training of nursing home staff, there will be total chaos when this bill is implemented—and that too is the view of the nursing home sector.

We have had the minister blame in media releases the Senate for obstructing the bill. As people can see, we are actually debating this bill in the House of Representatives today. So I cannot quite see how it has anything to do with obstruction in the Senate.

In an answer to a question in the House last week, the Minister for Family Services made much of the so-called crisis in aged care, claiming that the government had to act and act now. It might be suggested that this minister has a bit of a predilection for detecting the odd crisis in her portfolio, and of course it is a fairly standard tactic for beating up support for measures which the minister has failed to sell through rational explanation and debate.

In child care, for example, she has also recently discovered a crisis: increases in child-care fees. Instead of recognising they are the result of her budget cuts last year, she accuses private child‐care providers of overcharging parents by millions of dollars. Regardless of whether there is any truth to her accusation, what is her urgent response to this `crisis', as she calls it? The minister is going to wait for the report of a committee that will report in the year 2000. Some crisis!

She and the Prime Minister have been up to their misleading ways again this week. The minister claimed yesterday that the Labor Party offered only $3 per nursing home resident to carry out capital upgrades. I hope she will be better briefed before she comes in to respond to this second reading debate. For the record it must be stated that, firstly, Labor spent more than a billion dollars in the last 10 years on nursing home and hostel upgrades and new buildings. Secondly, let us just look at the facts in relation to this $3 that is being talked about. In the 1995-96 budget Labor proposed a $7 top‐up on top of the $8 per resident capital grant for any new or rebuilt nursing homes—a total of $15. So you can forget the $3 that she is talking about as far as that is concerned.

But let us see where the $3 comes in. For nursing homes that were spending $20,000 or more on capital upgrades, Labor offered a $3 top‐up on top of the $8 per patient capital grant—a total of $11. The minister said on radio this morning, `This was going to be available only if people spent $20,000.' That is exactly right. This was supposed to be an incentive to get people to upgrade their nursing homes. That was the whole point. This government is basically saying to nursing homes, `You can raise accommodation bonds, then you don't have to spend it on upgrades. There's nothing in the legislation that requires you to do so.'

The government cites a crisis caused by the physical decline of aged care facilities, mainly nursing homes. It is true that in the Gregory report there was an identification of the need to spend considerably more money to bring nursing homes up to an acceptable standard. But I repeat: Labor spent over $1 billion on nursing homes and hostels in the 10 years to 1994 and had allocated $245 million in its budget forward estimates—money for direct capital upgrade of nursing home stock that of course fell victim to the cuts of Treasurer Costello in the Howard government's first budget. So, rather than retaining Labor's allocation for capital upgrading of nursing homes, the Howard government has different plans—plans more in keeping with its view of the world. To meet these capital needs the Howard government proposes a move to a user‐pays system. That is its system. That is the system that it wants to put in place.

Let us look at what the bill actually proposes. Firstly, there is an up-front entry fee, an accommodation bond, supposedly to pay for capital upgrades. Secondly, there is a new daily fee for nursing homes and hostels to replace part of the recurrent subsidy previously paid by government. Thirdly, there is the granting of a power to the minister to transfer responsibility for aged care to the states without any reference to the parliament. Fourthly, there is no longer any decent accountability in this bill for the funds provided as recurrent subsidies or for capital. There is no requirement that the money raised from entry fees will be used to upgrade nursing homes. There is no requirement that subsidies paid for the care of residents will guarantee that nurses will be employed in nursing homes.

Fifthly, the payment of the daily subsidy for people without assets, termed `concessional residents' in this bill, to compensate nursing homes for the fact that these people cannot pay up-front fees is only $5 a day. Sixthly, there is no hostel subsidy for those residents on the lowest classification level. Lastly, there is the amalgamation of nursing homes and hostels into a single system of aged care institutions.

What are Labor's significant problems with this bill? Let us have a look at the entry fee, or accommodation bond. The bill requires all future nursing home residents to pay an entry fee subject to an assets test. There is no upper limit to the size of the entry fee. The only requirement is that a person be left with $22,500 in assets. For many people the annual interest on $22,500, around $4 a day on current interest rates, will be all they have to pay for the many extras required by nursing home residents—things like toiletries, fruit, stamps and phone calls.

Whether a person has to pay an entry fee will be determined by an assets test that includes the family home as an asset. Only those who share their home with a spouse or a person who has been a carer for more than five years and who is a full pensioner will not have to sell. Ninety per cent of people who go to a nursing home live alone before they need to go into that home. Most people have only one significant asset: their home. Most people will have no option. They will have to sell their home to get a nursing home bed. The minister has guaranteed that no-one will be forced to sell their home. Everybody on this side of this parliament will be keeping her to that promise. The money collected from these bonds must be held in trust by the nursing home and the proprietors get to keep the interest and an annual draw down of $2,600 for five years—a total of $13,000.

But of critical importance is the fact that the entry fee has to be paid up-front. That means people who need a nursing home bed and are living alone will have to find, according to the nursing homes, around $88,000 to get that bed. That is the price nursing homes are now saying will be the norm. Professor Gregory, the author of the Gregory report into the structure of nursing home funding, totally rejected entry fees as a means of raising the capital necessary for upgrades. After careful evaluation of entry fees as an option for capital raising, he wrote:
The sheer size of entry contributions and the impact on a client's life of having to agree to sell assets to receive care would be a considerable barrier to entry.
In short, he felt:
. . . allowing entry contributions seems too harsh a measure.

The Prime Minister does not agree. He thinks he knows better. He believes and has said in the parliament that his government's plan to make people sell their homes to get nursing home care is `the repayment of a debt'. Prime Minister, on behalf of all of those who have written or spoken to me about this issue, I will let you know what they think. The people who have raised families, paid their taxes and battled the Depression and the Second World War feel that the debt obligation runs the other way.

The minister has claimed that people need not necessarily sell their homes; they could rent them out and use the rent to pay the bond in periodic payments. This will not be an option for the vast majority of people because if you are a pensioner and the only asset you have is your home and you rent it out, you will be receiving income so you will lose your pension and be subjected to a new daily fee. It is a false option that this minister has put before the elderly community.

There is also considerable doubt as to whether the system of up-front entry fees will actually raise the money necessary for capital upgrades. The Department of Health and Family Services estimates that entry fees will raise $130 million a year, but not until the year 2000‐2001. In each of the three years the amounts raised for capital for nursing homes will be considerably less than would have been provided under Labor. In 1997-98 the department estimates that only $26.1 million will be raised; in 1998-99, $72.3 million; in 1999-2000, $102.3 million—considerably less than the average provided by Labor over the 10 years 1984 to 1994.

A catch-22 also seems to exist in the bill. Only certified homes will be able to be charged an entry fee but, to get certification, homes will have to have a minimum standard of buildings and services, so will not be able to get the upgrades they need to get the capital required.

This bill introduces a new daily fee. At the moment all residents pay 87.5 per cent of their pension. Now residents will pay 85 per cent of the pension and there will be an extra daily fee of 25c in the dollar for those who have income above the pension-free area, up to a maximum of $60 a day. Nursing home residents who have to pay this new income tested fee will have effective marginal tax rates of almost 100 per cent. This measure will impact on the 35 per cent of residents who are part pensioners or self-funded retirees. All residents will be income tested by the Department of Social Security. Nursing home owners will have to collect the fee, effectively becoming tax collectors for this government and the recurrent care subsidies they get from the government will be reduced by whatever they collect in fees.

The introduction of this daily fee will see divisions arise in nursing homes. Those who pay the extra fees will demand extra and better care. This is a recipe for two classes of care in our nursing homes. It is further evidence of the government's muddle. The Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association, which represents a large number of private nursing homes, yesterday advised the government that delays in applying the DSS means testing of new nursing home residents will mean that all new entrants will be invoiced for two months at the maximum rate of $63.30 per day. The association warns the government that this `will result in a negative political backlash for the government'—an understatement, I would suggest.

There are many other issues. Given the time, I will quickly move to the other signifi cant concern we have with this bill, which is the limit of the subsidy for concessional residents to just $5. The total inadequacy of this subsidy will inevitably result in a two-tiered system of aged care, with good access and care for those who can afford to pay an entry fee and poor access and care for those who cannot. This low level of subsidy is one of the two main factors that will lead to a two-tiered system. The other factor is the up-front entry fee accommodation bonds.

The $5 a day is ridiculously low because it has to be compared with what a nursing home will get from a resident who pays $88,000 in an accommodation bond. That is effectively the same as $20 a day—four times what this government is offering for a concessional resident. Nursing homes have made it clear already to the government that they will not be able to provide the same level of or access to care for all residents. For the representatives of older Australians, this figure of $5 a day has critically defined this government's total disregard for older Australians. I am sure the strength of their feelings has brought considerable discomfort to members opposite.

A final unpalatable point about this $5 a day subsidy, which the minister does not draw attention to, is that this is not coming from new money, from extra capital money from the government; it is coming from the pool of funds allocated for the care of nursing home residents. So it will actually reduce the money that is available for care. By contrast, Labor's capital funding was targeted, and targeted to those in need.

We face a serious number of changes to the aged care system in Australia. Like the churches and other aged care groups, Labor believes that the bill is discriminatory and ill-prepared and, like the churches, we believe that it must not pass through this parliament. For all these reasons we oppose this bill and will move a series of amendments both in this House and in the Senate to make this bill a fair bill, to make sure that we do not have a two-tiered system and to make sure that access to nursing homes is entirely on the basis of a person's health care needs—not on the basis of how much money they have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before embarking on what I was going to say, I think I should touch on some of the matters referred to by the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin). I was interested to see the motion for the suspension of standing orders in so far as it refers to a number of points in the Aged Care Bill 1997, on which basis the member was saying that the matter should be deferred. Fair enough, she referred to the $5 a day point, of which much has been made by the opposition.
—And the churches.

—Yes, and I will have more to say about that shortly. Her second point is agreed specific prudential arrangements for safeguarding residents' up‐front entry fees. That is how strong her argument was for suspension of standing orders, a question of trust funds. That is how high she rates that. That matter can be attended to very simply, as the member knows. We have trust accounts that operate—solicitors' trust funds, prudential arrangements—which are quite simple to arrange, yet that was the major point that was raised by the member for Jagajaga.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point talks about residential subsidy classification, instrument and arrangements for training staff in use. Is that really the major thrust of the opposition's argument about these measures? Then we get into the fourth point which talks a lot about matters in relation to establishing an independent body to monitor various things. That is how significant the matters are that are raised by the honourable member to defer these particular measures. Then we go to the fifth point, which is, again, some mumbo jumbo about accountability of the use of funds, and so forth.

It really is absolute rhetoric without substance. The only point that raises any substance at all is the first point, on which the government and the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) have said they are prepared to continue talking with those relevant groups. It must be remembered that the government is already subsidising—on top of that $5—at $100 a day which the govern ment pays for people to live in residential aged care facilities.

It is important then to splice what was said in that motion to suspend standing orders with what the honourable member said along the way. In particular, she spoke a lot about real increased expenditure between 1984 and 1994. She made passing reference to Professor Gregory and it was perhaps just as well that she did. I am going to remind her what Professor Gregory said about what all that spending had not in fact done and had not achieved. In May 1994 Professor Gregory estimated that upgrading nursing homes to an appropriate standard would cost as much as $520 million. He attributed the problem directly to the nursing home funding system which was introduced by the Labor government in 1987. The Gregory report states:

The lack of incentive to maintain good quality nursing home stock is a result of the funding system, under which nursing homes receive a set amount for each resident, based on resident frailty, which is the same regardless of the age and condition of the building.

A further evaluation study of 150 nursing homes produced some alarming findings, including that 75 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Australian design standards, 70 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet the Commonwealth outcomes standards, 13 per cent did not meet fire authority standards and 39 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more beds. Most honourable members who have had the misfortune to visit some of those run‐down nursing homes and see the appalling conditions in which older people find themselves would realise that all of the overblown rhetoric about the real increase in spending in the 10 years is seen for what it is—just overblown rhetoric.

I pose one other matter. It was said by the honourable member that really the figure is $88,000. Let me pose this question: is the opposition saying that Australian taxpayers should put money into the pockets of the beneficiaries of those old people when they pass away? Is that what the opposition is saying? No answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe in death duties?

—Answer the question. The fact of the matter is, the opposition's proposal is to put money into the pockets of the beneficiaries of these old people. That is what they are really saying, rather than the reasonable position of the Australian taxpayer, that is, a system of user pays.

BREAK.PARA: Let me turn now to the bill itself. The reforms that were announced in the 1996‐97 budget will take effect from 1 July this year. They will align nursing home and hostel systems. The measures include a single resident classification scale which determines the level of subsidy for each person, relaxation of previous detailed acquittal requirements for nursing homes, income testing of residential care benefits, adoption of refundable resident entry contributions across all residential care and creation of an aged care standards agency. These measures have to be seen in the context of a very significant ageing population. The aged care program aims to provide care at a benchmark of 100 aged care places per 1,000 persons aged 70‐plus in my region of Dickson and also in the region of the adjoining electorate of Longman for which the honourable Mr Mal Brough is the member. That particular program is designed to amount to 86 places per 1,000 persons aged 70, which is slightly under the national average of 93 places per 1,000 persons aged 70‐plus.

Recently on behalf of the minister I opened the Inverpine Retirement Village, which is a 52‐place hostel in the area of Murrumba Downs. Forty places have been built and construction is about to start on another 12 places. There will be a 12‐ place special care unit. Inverpine Retirement Village also includes 32 self-contained units funded solely by the RSL War Veterans' Homes Ltd. There are a number other such places in my electorate for older people, such as the Maranatha Retirement Village at Kallangur, the Pine Woods Hostel at Lawnton, Albany Gardens Nursing Home at Albany Creek, Forest Place Retirement Village at Albany Creek, Keperra Sanctuary Retirement Village at Keperra, Madonna Village Nursing Home at Mitchel ton, St Joseph's Villa, Mitchelton and Oxford Park Retirement Village is also in the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who paid for those? Not the Liberals!
—As I said, the population of Australia is not only growing, it is ageing. That is something that the honourable member for Jagajaga closes her eyes to.
—I don't close my eyes.

—The eyes were closed for the period between 1984 to 1994, because in actual fact we need a $520 million injection to improve the facilities in those homes. In 1971 there were a million Australians aged 65 and over. Now there are two million. By 2031 there will be five million in this group. In Queensland about seven per cent of the population is aged over 65, and I am well aware of this trend in my electorate. It is interesting also to mention these figures: from across OECD countries the ratio of people aged over 65 to those in the work force is 19 to 100. By the year 2030, that ratio in Australia is expected to be 33 to 100. That is an alarming statistic, and it is important for all members to address that statistic. While it is not addressed we are going to have a continuing run-down in the nursing home system in this country.

BREAK.PARA: This bill is not about the government imposing a $26,000 entry contribution. The proposition is essentially no different from that of pre‐nursing homes. Those in their own homes have provided an investment. Their return is shelter and comfort. They pay their rates, electricity and other outgoings, including maintenance to the dwelling. Once they leave their own home, they require shelter and generally a far more intensive system of care. If you move from one house to another, generally you sell your house and buy another house. That is all that is happening here under this bill.

The government is not imposing a $26,000 entry contribution. Existing nursing home residents are not required to make entry contributions. Entry contributions are negotiated between the proprietor and the resident. As to the comment which rolls beautifully off the tongue of the member for Jagajaga about there being no upper limit in the fee, obviously it is market determined. That is the simple answer.

Entry contributions are not compulsory. Full pensioners who have not owned their own homes in the past two years are not required to pay entry contributions. The government receives no portion of funds raised by entry contributions. Not all nursing homes are eligible to charge entry contributions. To be eligible to charge, facilities will be required to reach a prescribed government standard.

The maximum amount deducted from residents' entry contributions has been mentioned many times as being $2,600 per year for five years, to a total of $13,000. The balance is held on account of residents and is refunded if they vacate the nursing home or is paid into the resident's estate. As to the size of the entry contribution, the resident must always be left with assets of at least 250 per cent of pension, some $22,000.

Residents are not required to pay entry contributions as an up-front fee. There is six months before any contribution is payable. Residents who remain in care for less than six months are exempted from entry contributions. Individual nursing homes will determine their policy on whether to charge such contributions.

If a person goes to a nursing home and pays a capital contribution as a lump sum to the provider, that remains on trust until the resident leaves. A similar system in hostels had been operating under the previous government for some years. Obviously, the contributions are protected and will be protected by a proper trust system, a prudential system, if the proprietor becomes insolvent.

People on low incomes will be protected. They will not have to pay an entry fee if they cannot afford it. The government has to pay and will pay a higher level of recurrent subsidy to nursing homes to encourage them to accept financially disadvantaged people as residents.

Governments will ensure that pensioner couples whose only asset is their home do not have to sell it when one of those persons enters a nursing home. There is no requirement for anyone to sell their home. The tactics of scaring old people in relation to this matter are really to be deplored.

The purpose and direction of the legislation is that the changes will bring about a future regime of quality nursing home care, because of the very nature of the growing population. I say again and again that those statistics are quite alarming when we look at the fact that we are going to have those incredible increases by 2041 when one in three Australians will be over age 65. It is something that cannot be ignored in this debate. That is the whole basis for many of these changes. There will be safe, appropriate and comfortable accommodation.

In trying to read between the lines of what the honourable member opposite said in her speech, there seems to be some sort of suggestion that the government wants to somehow frighten people out of going into nursing home care. Is the opposition suggesting that the government wants to lose many, many votes by adopting a measure that is anathema to older people? It really beggars logic to suggest such a thing.

The user pays system will bring a better standard of living in institutions that have been run down. I have already referred to the comments of Professor Gregory in his report in 1994. It is important to remember that the situation did not occur in the last 12 months: it has been occurring over a number of years. While that is a regrettable problem we do, as a government, undertake responsibility to fix it. That is what is behind the legislation. The objectives of the legislation are to provide a funding injection to upgrade nursing home capital stock. That is important. It will ensure that those who can afford to do contribute and it will correct subsidy inequities between nursing home and hostel residents to protect the financially disadvantaged.

In so far as fees and charges are concerned, full pensioners will not be required to pay one cent over the $26.05 that they currently pay. There is no income test on full‐rate pensioners. The first $49 per week of non‐pension income is exempt from the nursing home income test. People on part pensions, which amount to 25 per cent of residents, and those on private incomes, which amount to 10 per cent of residents, will be asked to make a modest contribution. The maximum that can be charged is an additional $34 a day but to reach this a person would need a private income of $61,000 per annum. So for a non‐pensioner with a $500 per week income the daily increase will be from $26.05 a day to $42.15 per day. There will be a cap of $60 per day on the maximum amount that the nursing home or hostel resident can pay.

It can be seen that those measures are reasonable in terms of the current climate of a blow‐out in the cost and a blow‐out in the aging of the population, which have to be addressed in some way. The way that is being proposed by the member for Jagajaga is to spend more and more money and put money in the pockets of the beneficiaries of people who pass away. But the attitude of the government is to make sure that the user pays and that those who happen to be in this sort of care get the best care available. The legislation provides a framework and a direction for one of the most important policy areas the country has to face; that is, the aging population and the capacity of the Australian economy to deal with this significant issue.

In my view, the measures will upgrade accommodation and ensure better living conditions. They will progress the philosophy so neglected in the past of ensuring that those who can afford to pay do pay and that those who cannot afford to will be provided with a decent home in their later years. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The senior members of our community are going to be very relieved after hearing the speech from my friend the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith). He criticised the opposition, as indeed the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has done, for manufacturing a scare campaign. The senior members of our community are going to be very relieved to hear there was no need for fear or concern. The some 5,000 members of my electorate who have signed a petition expressing their very grave concerns about this bill are going to be relieved indeed tonight. They will sleep very comfortably because they have been told that the size of the entry fee—or entry bond—into these nursing homes is going to be determined by market forces. That is great news for them. This holy icon, a thing that never creates injustice and that always reflects equity, is going to determine whether or not they have to sell their homes. With respect, that is an outrageous proposition and one which will do nothing whatsoever to relieve the fear and concern that so many senior members of our community have and should not have.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Dickson indicated, at the commencement of his speech, that the notice of motion moved earlier by the shadow minister seeking a deferral of the bill, was without foundation. Let us leave aside the shadow minister's comments but let us consider the representations from the Aged Services Association of NSW & ACT Inc. They say, in a letter dated 3 June 1997:

. . . the Government's intention to debate the new legislation in the Lower House in the absence of subordinate legislation and without knowing whether the model can be viable means that there can be no informed debate.
They quite properly say that for there to be an informed debate the minister needs to reveal:

. . . details on the new prudential arrangements, the guidelines on the new classification scale, the cost of funding the new accreditation process, and how she will honour her commitment to review the effectiveness of the reform process.
I will be paying attention to this debate and I will be curious to see how many government members can properly inform the House and the Australian people of those matters.

Of course prudential arrangements are vitally important. There are obviously going to be significant differences between those which are acceptable to the charitable sector and those which are acceptable to the private sector. For instance, will it mean that the charitable sector—the non‐profit sector—is going to have to subsidise the profit sector? The member for Dickson knows the consequences and blow‐outs caused by defaulting contributors to a prudential scheme from the experience of the Law Society scheme, where the prudential insurance requirements are really quite exorbitant as a result of the amount of money which has gone astray. Will the charitable sector have to compensate the private sector for that money when, regrettably and inevitably, some of it goes astray?

The shadow minister indicated her concerns about the absence of auditing requirements and the complete absence of detail as to the quality of care which will be provided in nursing homes—in particular, whether qualified nurses will be required to be engaged in those homes. Further, the minister has not got given any details at all about what the transitional arrangements are going to be for nursing homes which have currently either received or applied for funding grants under parts VAB and VAC of the National Health Act. A number have already made commitments and a number have already prepared their forward budgets, anticipating that existing capital grants will be paid and that contracts they have made—often with builders—will be able to be fulfilled. Are those contracts going to be frustrated because of this legislation? The minister has not considered that, and those transitional arrangements are of vital concern.

The member for Dickson quite openly and frankly said that this is part of the new regime, part of the government's new policy of user pays—the user paying according to what has been determined by market forces, not what has been determined as a result of the needs of our citizens. That is entirely consistent with the National Commission of Audit report which recommended greater reliance on user charging and recommended not only entry fees but also exit fees. It remains to be seen whether that is somewhere in the government's armoury for a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exit fees?

—Yes. The other point it recommended was the complete devolution to the states of responsibility in respect of nursing homes. As a result of the government's obsession with contracting the role of the federal government, one wonders how far away that may be.

SPEECH.PARA: It is dishonest of members on the other side of the House to use the hostel situation as an appropriate example for nursing homes to follow. The situation in respect of hostels is quite different. When someone enters a hostel it is a voluntary arrangement; they can negotiate, shop around and compare the service they are going to receive. As the Gregory report indicated, some 60 per cent of nursing home entries are straight out of hospital, frequently straight after an acute illness such as a stroke or some other form of debilitating disease.

As the shadow minister indicated, 90 per cent of those people who are admitted live on their own, and the assumption that those chronically ill who live on their own have the capacity to go and negotiate one of these entry fees or bonds is nonsensical. They are at the most frail, most vulnerable stage of their life. Before they can get the care they require, they are being compelled to sit down to negotiate an entry fee with businesspeople who are, quite frequently, pretty hard‐nosed. It will not happen. They are going to be victims of the whole process. To say that they have the opportunity of fairly negotiating the so‐called fair market price is fanciful in the extreme. It will not happen, and it is unfair.

I paid particular attention to the member for Dickson's comments—and indeed accusations—that the Labor Party was favouring a situation where the money which will be taken out of senior citizens' accounts—and in many cases their homes—will not be passed on to their beneficiaries. In reality, what that statement amounts to is favouring what this in actuality is: a death duty. But it is a death duty that strikes only the chronically ill, the frail aged and the demented. It is not an across‐the‐board death duty, even if that was to be advanced by the government as an appropriate taxation measure. It is one which discriminates against, hits and strikes the chronically ill and the frail. That is, with respect, a really condemning feature of the government's position in this debate.

The government's assumption that they are going to raise money for sufficient capital works is flawed. The best evidence indicates that at least 50‐60 per cent of people will not be able to afford the nursing home entry bond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Market forces!

—That will be determined by market forces. The experts say it will be close to $88,000 for anything closely resembling quality nursing home care. At least 50‐60 per cent of senior citizens will not be able to afford that, and they will be competing for and negotiating for the 27 per cent of beds which the private homes are required to keep for those who are unable to meet the entry bond.

SPEECH.PARA: This is unquestionably a bill which favours the haves and not the have‐nots. The $5 a day payment for the disadvantaged is an affront. It compares to $19 a day which the nursing homes will achieve from the drawdown of the entry bond. In other words, there is a $14 difference. In addition, the wealthy nursing homes receive the benefit of interest from the capital bond which is paid into their account. As the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association Ltd said:

The Federal Government's announced funding rates for residential aged care seem likely to foster a two tiered system of aged care in Australia. The problem arises because of the Government's completely inadequate supplementary funding for concessional residents who are unable to afford to pay an accommodation bond.
Similarly, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association said:

. . . a shortfall of $14 . . . on accommodation for financially disadvantaged people . . . is totally inadequate. The difference will see these people in multi‐bed rooms in buildings that will reflect the disparity in funding.

So we have a situation where the wealthy private institutions are in demand and, according to market forces, can demand the top dollar, which is predicted to be about $88,000, compared to the charitable organisations, which quite frequently take up to 90 per cent of their residents from disadvantaged groups. You are looking at a situation where nursing homes, for 90 per cent of those patients, will receive $5; whereas the wealthy private sector will receive, for some 73 per cent of their patients, $19 a day from the drawdown plus the interest that they are earning from the entry bond.

If the government's logic is correct and the methodology behind this bill is to provide capital funding for nursing homes, why has the government not struck a figure of $13,000, which is obtained by multiplying $2,600 per year, being the drawdown, over the five-year period that those drawdowns are required? Why hasn't the government frankly said, `This is our reasoning. We will require there to be a $13,000 contribution to capital assistance'? It has not because it is providing a windfall gain for private nursing homes which can benefit from the interest that they are earning from these massive amounts of money that are going to be paid into their accounts.

One wonders whether this whole mechanism has behind it a categorising intention whereby those who have the funds are able to jump the queue and get into the good nursing homes and those who do not have the funds are simply left in those multi‐bed substandard accommodations which, as members of parliament, we have no doubt all entered into. The Executive Director of the Uniting Ministry with the Ageing, Mr Les McDonald, said that the $5 contribution is really a poison chalice and that it is going to result in the charitable nursing homes being second rate, despite their best intentions.

The other issue which is of concern to me, as a result of the member for Dickson's speech, is the government's obsession with picking scapegoats. Senior citizens are being chosen as scapegoats for our health costs, which it is argued are going to fall on younger people. Regrettably, that is something which, if not already, is going to lead to intergenerational conflict.

We are looking at a situation where younger people are not honouring the achievements of senior citizens—what they have achieved through their daily work and what they have achieved in fighting to represent our country in wars. Rather, there is an obsession with looking at senior citizens as a burden. John McCallum, in a recent article in the Australian, analysed this phenomena. He said:
Since the arrival of the Howard Government in Canberra, the ageing of the Australian population is being more generally argued to make unsustainable demands on the health and social security systems.

I will not go through his arguments, but I suggest to any member that it is worth reading. He shows that, while health care certainly is required by senior citizens, usually it is not required until the last year, possibly two years, of their lives. Suggesting that people over 65 are a burden is a gross misrepresentation of the actuality. As John McCallum said:
It is high time we got the story straight. If there is an intent to change health and welfare in Australia it should be argued on its own merits and not attributed to a fictional crisis of ageing.
That is very much what this bill is about.

I mentioned earlier that I have received in my office to date some 4,000 signatures, and I understand I have in excess of another 1,000 signatures, on a petition opposing the government's legislation. It is causing real concern in the community. The government has not done anything to address those concerns. The lack of detail in the bill does nothing. The advice that whether or not someone is going to be compelled to sell their home is to be sorted out by virtue of market forces does nothing for confidence. From my point of view, it actually generates fear.

The government has a really hot political issue on its hands that it is not addressing and which the minister has not appreciated. It is going to do absolutely nothing to increase the quality of aged care. The crux of, and falling back on, the old statement that Labor did nothing is false. Labor spent more than $1 billion over the past decade of its period of office on aged care.

What nursing homes will get out of these provisions from the government is considerably less than that. As the shadow minister indicated, in the 1995-96 budget the Labor government introduced a $7 top‐up in addition to the existing $8 per resident capital grant for any new or rebuilt nursing home, which was a total of $15. That $15 applied across the board to all nursing homes and compares to $5 for the charitable institutions as against $19 for the private institutions, in addition to the interest and the clear profit that the more affluent private institutions will be able to receive as a result of the windfall gained through the use of the interest.

The government has fundamentally changed the way in which we have administered aged care. It has in the past been administered on the basis of need. It is now going to be administered on the basis that quality care is to fall to those who can afford it. It is regrettable that aged care has become like buying a pair of shoes or, indeed, engaging a lawyer—that is, those who can afford to, get it; those who cannot, do not. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus, Christine, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —What a riveting speech from the member for Barton (Mr McClelland), and he is a member of the Labor Party! I remember a time when the Labor Party believed that we should help the poor and the wealthy should pay their own way, but the new Labor Party does not believe that any more.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Labor Party want their system where the wealthy travel at the expense of the poor, where the people who can afford to pay for their own care are subsidised by the taxpayer out there on $30,000 with three children, paying a mortgage and struggling to make ends meet. That is who is paying for nursing home care for the wealthy at the present. This is the system that new Labor endorses. Old Labor would not have endorsed that system, except old Labor actually put this into place, didn't they? They put in a system where the wealthy were subsidised by the poor.

At present, under old Labor's system, which is supported by new Labor, we could have a wealthy widow with $2 million and earning $140,000 a year. If she goes into a nursing home, what does she pay? She pays approximately $180 per week. What do the taxpayers subsidise her? It is approximately $480 a week, yet she has $2 million and is earning $140,000 a year. When she dies, who gets the $2 million? It is not the poor old taxpayer who has been paying the accommodation of this wealthy widow. No, her relatives get it. They say, `Thank you very much' and, as they drive away in their Mercedes, they wave to that poor old taxpayer out there in his 10-year-old car and say, `Hi, we're doing very well, thank you. We just got $2 million. Thank you very much for the $480 a week you have been contributing to granny's care for the last 10 years because, boy, does that make our life so much better now.'

This is the system that old Labor has that new Labor supports. You do not want the wealthy to pay. You want everyone out there on the same level so the wealthy can come in and say, `Good,' and take advantage. That is what you stand for. That is what the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) stands for.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) said he was suffering relevance deprivation syndrome. It is not only him; it is the whole Labor Party because you guys no longer know what you stand for. After 13 years in government, you have thrown away every principle that you ever held as a party. You are out there in the wilderness right now saying, `What is it we believe in? Find us a policy.' But you cannot find yourself a policy because you no longer have a philosophy. So what do you do? You attack because the only thing left for you to say is, `We know what we'll make our policies: whatever the government does, we will say it's wrong and that way we will look relevant.'

But, I have to tell you, you do not look relevant. You just look like a lot of negative, carping no‐hopers. Go away, get yourself a philosophy and then come back into this House. When you come back, have a look at this legislation, which has brought some sense into the aged care industry, and argue then because, when you know what you stand for, you might be able to look at this legislation and say, `Good, it has done some things that old Labor should have done and that new Labor approves of. It has made people who can afford it pay for it.'

What did the member for Jagajaga call it? She called it a tax. She said that making people pay who could afford to pay was a tax. Could the people opposite, the member for Barton or the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), who I believe will be following me in this debate, explain to me what a tax is? I always thought a tax was something the government put on you as a sort of added impost to help run the country. When you paid for a service you actually received; that was not a tax, that was what you were paying for. When I pay rent, or when anybody else pays rent, that is not a tax; it is rent, for heaven's sake. So do not call it a tax. It is not a tax. It is simply asking people to pay who can afford to pay. The people who cannot afford it will not be paying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you say it's rent?

—No, I said, `When I pay rent'. I did not say, `It is rent,' I said, `When I pay rent'. The pensioners out there will not be paying any extra. They will be paying 85 per cent of the pension and they will get care equal to the others. They will be paying 85 per cent of the pension, and those who can pay more will pay. They will have the pension area plus $49 per week free. That is why this is a fairer system. Those who cannot afford to pay do not pay. Those who can afford to pay do pay.
—And get better care.

—They do not get better care; they get the same sort of care. It is the same sort of system that you have in your hostels. Isn't this great? They could do it in the hostels under Labor and that was fine, but now do it in the nursing homes under the government and they say, `That's terribly wrong because what we did was right and what you did was wrong.'

SPEECH.PARA: Get yourselves a philosophy. Get yourselves some policies so you can stand on something and be consistent. Come into this House with something you believe in and pick out what is good in legislation. Then people out there might start to listen to you when you pick out the negatives, because then they will not say, `Oh God, it's just those Labor people again. They criticise everything.' They will say, `They said that was good and that was good, so maybe when they pick out this little bit they could be right.'

At the moment, you are so busy knocking everything that people out there are not listening. Start picking out what is good and maybe the voters will listen to you, and maybe the government will listen to you, because we want good legislation. If you have some constructive ideas, instead of the carping and the negativity, we are going to listen because we want what is best for the Australian consumer and for the people out there.

The member for Jagajaga came in here and quoted her own report, saying what a great system Labor had, what a fantastic system Labor had. Let us have a look at what the Gregory report said about Labor's fantastic system. It said that 70 per cent of nursing homes needed upgrading. Good system! It said that 39 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more beds. Mr Deputy Speaker, is that the sort of nursing home system you want in your country?

What else did the Gregory report find? Small or insufficient bathrooms and toilets, lack of lever taps and shower seats, small rooms, inadequate ramps, lack of wheelchair access, multi-storey homes without lifts—the same multi-storey homes without lifts that the member for Barton referred to and admitted were existing under his government's policy.

The report also found there were insufficient fire standards, toilets not large enough for walking frames or wheelchairs, too few toilets and inadequate heating and cooling—cold in winter and hot in summer. This is old Labor's system of nursing homes, the system that new Labor wants to keep. The report also found rooms with no external windows, and inadequate kitchen and laundry facilities. I especially like this one. The member for Newcastle might like to answer this one and tell me if the nursing homes in his area have this: dirty laundry and food delivered through the same chutes.

That report gives us a really great picture of nursing homes under the Labor government that the member for Jagajaga was so keen to support—getting out her quotes to praise Labor from fellow travellers and also choosing some quotes to condemn the government. But, of course, this is a game we can all play. I owe these quotes to the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), who would have liked to get them in his own speech but unfortunately could not, so I have the fortunate chance of quoting them for him. The first quote comes from the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals. It states:

The introduction of an entry contribution for those that are able to pay such a contribution will overcome the matters long outstanding regarding the need to address the urgent capital upgrading of nursing homes.

That is exactly what we have been saying—that nursing homes under old Labor, nursing homes that new Labor want to perpetuate, were in a terrible state. That is why this government has introduced accommodation bonds, the accommodation bonds that the member for Jagajaga has continually criticised. She almost says that the accommodation bonds this government has brought in are the work of the devil—the same accommodation bonds that the hostels have introduced under Labor. What else does the member for Jagajaga say? She says that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you like her?

—It is of no interest whether I like the member for Jagajaga or not, but I wish she would do her job properly. It would be a great asset to this parliament if the member for Jagajaga would do her job properly. That would get better legislation out there to the people.

SPEECH.PARA: We were talking about the accommodation bonds and how they have been introduced under Labor. We have the member for Jagajaga going around saying, `Isn't this terrible? People might have to sell their homes.' Well, what is so terrible about that? If I move from where I live now and I go into different accommodation, I sell my home. It is what we do when we move on. So what is so terrible about somebody selling their home to go into a nursing home?

Guess what? This is what people had to do under Labor's policy. Under Labor's policy, if you were a pensioner and you moved into a nursing home, do you know what happened? Your home was assessed as an asset for the purposes of the pension. So what happened then? Your pension dropped, you did not have any money to live on or to pay that 87.5 per cent of the pension for that accommodation. So what did you do? You sold your house. Under Labor, you were forced to sell your house when you went into a nursing home, yet it is Labor that is coming out and saying, `This is terrible. Under accommodation bonds they may have to sell their own homes.' It is exactly the same thing they had to do under Labor.

Nobody will have to sell their home if they have a remaining spouse and they will not be required to pay an accommodation bond unless they have more than $20,000 left over. What is more, all they will take down out of that accommodation bond is $13,000. What about the people who do not have money for an accommodation bond? There are 27 per cent of places around Australia reserved for people who cannot pay accommodation bonds. That is the guarantee of this government.

This legislation introduces a system that looks after the poorer people and asks the people who have the money to pay for what they can afford. It is a fair system, it is an equitable system and it is a much better system than that which we have at present. Under the present system, how can anybody deal with a CAM and SAM—that ridiculous system that divided the care, the food and the housekeeping? What a stupid system that was.

We have got rid of that system and all the bureaucracy that went with it. That bureaucracy meant that the staff in the nursing homes, instead of looking after the residents, had to sit down and fill out forms saying, `I clean resident X's teeth today. I scrubbed for two minutes on the right side and I scrubbed for two minutes on the left side.' That was what they were required to do under the bureaucratic system that Labor had in place.

I refer again to the papers that the member for Dickson gave me. I will read another quote, seeing that we are into the game of our quote against your quote. The Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association states:

Reductions in bureaucratic interference and great funding inflexibility in the residential aged care program should provide aged care consumers over time with a greater choice amongst better aged care facilities and service providers.
This legislation should be regarded as something quite revolutionary.

The minister is to be praised for her courage in looking at the system as it was and saying, `This system is bad. Let's start again and make it better.' It is a revolutionary thing to do and a very courageous thing to do. That does not mean that, as time goes by, we will not find some flaws in the detail. That happens any time you try to make things better and you bring about a huge change.

BREAK.PARA: I know that the hostel owners in my area have some concerns. I hope their concerns will be addressed and that in the end they will be totally happy with this legislation, because that is what we are aiming for. We are aiming to get the best possible legislation for all the people in our community, because the elderly people in our community have served this community all their lives. What they deserve in their declining years is proper appropriate care.

They deserve nursing homes where they do not have to lie in beds with four or five other people in the room, some of whom are extremely ill. They deserve to go into homes with facilities other than a cramped corridor with one television. They deserve to go into homes where food and dirty laundry are not delivered in the same chute.

That is what this legislation aims for. It is saying to the people of Australia, `We will take care of you in your old age. If you can afford it, we will ask you to pay, but if you cannot we will not expect you to pay.' At the end of the day, what we will have is a much better system, a much more equitable system that old Labor had that new Labor wants to keep, a much fairer system that old Labor had that new Labor wants to keep and a much simpler system that old Labor had that new Labor wants to keep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very easy to recognise when the government is on a loser: they get shrill, they get hysterical and they filibuster. Quite frankly, I think of the comment about sound and fury signifying nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about old Liberal and new Liberal for a little while. Old Liberal left my electorate with the legacy of a pensioner living on dog food so that he could pay the fees for his wife who was in a nursing home. She had been there for eight years, and every year the fees went up, way above the pension. He was spending $45 to $50 out of his pension to keep her in a nursing home. He was eating dog food because that was all he could afford.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many years ago was this?

—That was old Liberal. I will give a second example. I had a meeting in 1983 with a group of families who had family members in a particular nursing home in my electorate. They came to me to tell me their concerns with the nursing home and its problems. I note that the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) asked a lot of questions but does not wait for the answers. There were a lot of problems with this particular nursing home. These people asked what we were doing about that. As honourable members know, the licensing of nursing homes is a state responsibility. I will come back to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: About a fortnight later, the aunt of one of those people who had come to see me to complain about the quality of care in this nursing home had been taken for a shower and had been put in the shower by a young woman who was on work experience. When she turned on the tap, the hot water tap did not work. So she left the old lady sitting on a chair in the shower with the tap turned on but with no water and went to find some help. Before she came back, the hot water came on. That old woman was scalded and died.

There was a coronial inquest into that case, but the fact is that the young woman cannot be held responsible because she was not a trained employee. She was not a nurse. She was a source of cheap labour. That family had been to me a fortnight earlier complaining about the level of care. That was old Liberal. Old Liberal also put in capital funding for nursing homes. A week or two ago in Newcastle, new Liberal—from the federal department—told a group of carers and concerned residents that the federal government was not responsible for licensing and that any concerns about the quality of care would be a state matter, because licensing of nursing homes was a state responsibility.

There is something in common with old Liberal and new Liberal. They are both now saying that it is a state responsibility. The system of accreditation brought in by the Labor government in an attempt to lift standards had forced standards to rise and the system of controls on costs brought in by the Labor government, which controlled costs and set maximum costs, are both being dissolved by new Liberal and new National. But there is one big difference. New Liberal and new National have cut the money. This is not about nursing home care. We have heard all that nonsense and pap about systems and how much better it was. This should be part of appropriations, not aged care, because it is about money.

Last August the government announced that it was going to save $244 million on capital funding to nursing homes. It also announced that it was going to save $253 million on recurrent funding for nursing homes. In other words, in those two figures alone, there is half a billion dollars worth of savings. Somehow we are being told over here that this is about improving the system and somehow the cutting of those funds will make it better for everybody.

This government in this legislation is ripping half a billion dollars out of the aged community and their families. That is what it is about. This is budget stuff. To come in here and say that this is somehow making the system better is palpable nonsense. It is worse than that; it is deceitful, misleading and totally hypocritical. This undermines and guts what has been a fairly decent system in world terms. Given the increase in the last 10 or 15 years of the number of people requiring nursing home care and given the massive increase in dementia that we have suffered as a society, our system has coped better than most.

We have not had the granny dumping we have seen in America. On a recent visit to Europe, asking the Europeans, particularly the British, about their aged system, they said they were all looking at ours as one of the models that was much better than theirs.

There is another cut which is also important—that is, the $70 million to $80 million cut to home and community care. That is very relevant. Home and community care is a system that helps support people living at home, so they actually have choices. Post‐1982, post the McLeay report, the Labor government introduced a three-tiered system. It was way overdue, but a system driven by the need for more spending and a system driven by the need for differentiated care.

The home and community care negotiations with the states were incredibly complex and it took an awful long time to get all the states to agree to a common system. Even then, there were massive weaknesses in it, partly because of state peculiarities and so on. Since 1984-85 there had been constant difficulties with measuring and monitoring. The parliamentary inquiry that I chaired in the previous parliament, which looked into home and community care, focused on those difficulties and has proposed and recommended a lot of improvements, which, by the way, are all being ignored with the attempt by the current government to devolve all of it to the states. It is not even back to before the old days—it is back to the prehistoric days.

The fact is that with these changes to nursing homes what is going to happen and what is happening right now is that the aged in our community will want to stay at home for longer. They are saying to me now, `I don't want that to happen.' We may get granny dumping but we will certainly get granny squatting—people staying at home because they do not want to go into a nursing home and lose the family home, the home that in so many cases has all their memories. The loss of that is the loss of their life.

We will get granny squatting and we will be looking for more and more in-home services. This government, which is supposed to be improving, is putting more and more pressure on home and community care by discouraging people from going into nursing homes. This is a clever trick, mind you, because the demand for nursing homes will now drop. People will say, `I don't want to go.'

The euthanasia debate has some relevance here. I think all honourable members will know that people are saying, `I will die first.' You know it, Mr Deputy Speaker, and you all know it, because you are all picking it up, which is why you are so hysterical in this debate. It is why we are getting from those opposite the repeating of nonsense and falsehoods, which is so exaggerated.

BREAK.PARA: The demand for nursing homes will drop simply because people will not want to sell their homes and they will feel that the government does not want them there anyway. The sense of devaluation that this legislation is causing is enormous. Do not underestimate it. It is only just starting. At the same time as you are doing that, you are also cutting home and community care funding by close to $18 million as well. So you are putting more pressure on the home support system and then cutting the money. What kind of improvement is this?

In the unanimous report in the last parliament we called for more funding for HACC, not less. We called for better integration between the systems, not less. We called for more Commonwealth responsibility, not less. I should also point out that under old Liberal, old National, pre-1983, the provisions for young disabled living in the community were also inadequate. During the period of the previous Labor government we saw a massive shift of young disabled out of institutions and into the community. When I was first elected the number of young people who were required to live in nursing homes because there was nothing else available and the demand for that was much more than it is now.

But, more important, the de‐institutionalisation programs meant the Commonwealth put funds into housing for the young disabled. Those funds have now been transferred to the state as part of the Commonwealth‐state disability agreement, but do not underestimate that shift. A substantial amount of money that was previously available for nursing homes which were housing the young disabled has been transferred to the states, as part of the disability agreement, where the states are now providing accommodation. Mind you, that will all shift as well with this new regime of getting rid of all responsibility. We will see the Commonwealth attempt to move all responsibility to the states, including that for the employment of young people with disabilities.

When this new system of paying an up-front fee was first announced in the last budget—and the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) talked about it being $26,000— my comment at that stage was that that is a joke, a charade, and that has been my comment ever since. It costs between $70,000 and $80,000 to build a nursing home bed. The idea that somehow people can pay for a bed or that it would be viable to have a $26,000 up-front fee deposit was always a falsehood, was always deceitful, was always aimed to mislead—as was suggesting that it was not really a major problem, that $26,000 was not all that much.

We have now heard the figure of $88,000, but I doubt whether it would be that either—the figure I have always said is between $80,000 and $120,000—for a couple of reasons. One is that a substantial number of people die within six months of going into a nursing home because in many cases they have been discharged from a hospital after suffering a major stroke, for example, or another major medical episode. A substantial number of people die within a very short time, which means the fees are not applicable. So not only is the problem that a number of people have no money; it is also that a lot of people do not live long enough for a nursing home to be able to recover costs.

So, if you are going to take away the Commonwealth contribution—that is, the quarter of a billion dollars in capital being ripped out of the system—as this legislation will do, you will need more than $26,000 up-front, and even more than $88,000. As interest rates go down, the up-front fees go up. Just think through the earning capacity of nursing homes. Firstly, residents have to live for five years for a nursing home to get $13,000, which is the maximum that can be drawn down from the deposit. Only the minority live that long.

Secondly, the interest on the up‐front fees is the only other source of revenue to build new beds—in other words, capital funding. So, as interest rates decline, the up-front fees will in fact increase. So for $100,000 we are talking about $4,000 or $5,000 a year in interest, and that is the only money available. So the capital required to put in a bed will be serviced by the deposits of the up-front fees.

Now the government is talking about a compulsory 27 per cent of people not being required to pay up-front fees, but it is offering $5 a day extra. Five dollars times 365 is $1,800 a year. That is the interest on $50,000 at best. Where will the rest come from? That does not service the cost of putting in a new bed, let alone maintaining it. The fact is this will run down our system. This will degrade our nursing homes. Talk to any nursing home proprietor. Talk to anybody who is actually involved in the system.

When the government announced this proposal it gave the impression that access to up-front fees was going to be an extension of the scheme, it was going to be an enhancement, it was going to be an add-on to what was already there.
