—Mr Speaker, my question relates to the response you gave to this morning's request by the right honourable member for New England that you `advise when and in what circumstances we take two successive divisions without the application of the new procedures of counting'; namely, your reply that, `The honourable member for Dobell actually began to debate the issue and that automatically ruled out a successive division. Notwithstanding the fact that the bells were allowed to ring for one minute, it does require a separate count.' Could you confirm that standing order 200 requires that the doors be closed and locked for the counting of a division after the lapse of four minutes, and the ringing of the bells for one minute is provided for in sessional order 203A which relates only to successive divisions?
—Is she giving you an advisory position?

—Wait a minute. I have waited long enough. Now you can just wait a minute. Since the time for the ringing of the bells for the different types of divisions is mandated by the sessional and standing orders, could you please advise the House why the bells for the division I have referred to were rung for one minute and not four minutes, if it was not a `successive' division? In considering your response to this question, would you please inform the House whether pages 4400 to 4404 of the Hansard for 2 June 1997 and pages 8449 to 8456 of the Hansard for 12 December 1996 might indicate that the conduct of any of the divisions detailed there were out of order? What is the validity of a division which has not been conducted in accordance with the requirements of the House's sessional and standing orders? What are the consequences or implications for matters deemed to have been passed by this House if the conduct of any of the relevant divisions did not conform with sessional and standing orders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moncrieff for her totally unexpected question. Members would realise that the sessional divisions are still in a state of flux. I think that the honourable member for Prospect called the first one within the last 48 hours or so. After the division this morning, we reviewed the circumstances and, while I will not address all of the questions that you have raised—I will take the balance of those on notice—I do have a comment that I would like to make, and I do thank you for your question.

ANSWER.PARA: The trial arrangement for the abbreviated taking of a successive division is set out in sessional orders 203A and 203B and was used for the first time this week. Sessional order 203A provides that, where successive divisions are taken and there is no intervening debate after the first division, the bells for the ensuing division shall be rung for one minute only. Sessional order 203B makes provision for an abbreviated taking of the count for a successive division in circumstances where members are voting in the same way as they did in the preceding division. An example of such circumstances would be where a government motion is closured followed immediately by a vote on the motion itself with the government members voting the same way.

The point at issue relates to the interpretation of the words in sessional order 203A `where there is no intervening debate'. Taken literally, this means that any debate such as the seconding of a motion or the moving of the closure amounts to intervening debate, and the shortened method of conducting the division does not apply. This is the way in which I applied the sessional orders this morning.

I recognise that there may thought to be some inconsistency between my application of the new sessional order in respect of the actual counting and the practice of the chair adopted under the old standing order 200A of frequently, but not always, ordering the bells to be rung for one minute only for a following division. This is a practice which the House has developed over some years.

Because of the newness of the counting methods provided for in sessional order 203B, the House has not yet had an opportunity to develop a practice in relation to the new counting arrangements. I assume from the comments that have been made that it is the wish of members that the new abbreviated counting method be used where there is no debate beyond formal words such as `I second the motion'. In these circumstances, I will be happy to apply the abbreviated arrangements.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's mismanagement of the Australian economy in its first year of office as confirmed by today's national accounts figures.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian manufacturing industry, on today's figures, is in recession. One of the biggest sectors of employment in this nation is in recession. Indeed, if you look at the underlying figures as opposed to the quarter on quarter figures, you will see that it has been in recession for three quarters. It is no wonder the govern ment's performance in question time was so desultory.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Costello) was standing up announcing a growth figure half the level of the year on year figure to March that the previous government left—4.9 per cent down to 2.4 per cent. He defends himself not with reference to his own Treasury figures, which of course now stand in tatters, but with reference to another group which tells him that after three years in office he can look forward to the possibility that the government might well be able to achieve a level of growth that was in place for four successive years before they came into office—a level of growth which they have conceded as absolutely essential before they can make any serious dent on those tragic unemployment figures confronting this nation.

They had no answers to a series of questions as to what they would do about the parlous state of the Australian manufacturing industry and what they would do about employment policy in general, as they stare at an unemployment figure of one million. They had no answers to those questions. There was just a quiet, limp denunciation of the people who at least had a decent record on these matters when we were in office. The best that the government could do was to mislead people with the figures that they put forward.

Let me take just one set of figures. They are very proud of their inflation rate. You would think, if you listened to the Treasurer in here day in and day out, that they had invented a low inflation environment in Australia. `True,' they say to the workers who have missed out on jobs and to industry—manufacturing industry in particular, which is experiencing extraordinary difficulties—`you're experiencing all of that. But think of our wonderful little inflation numbers. Think of those. Think of all that portends from that.' If you listened to them, you would think that they came into office with the sort of galloping inflation that we confronted when we came into office—John Howard's 11 per cent. When we came into office there was 11 per cent unemployment, 11 per cent inflation and a $25 billion budget deficit. That was what Labor confronted when it came into office.

Indeed, if you compared the participation rate then with the participation rate that we confronted on unemployment, you would see that, at the very worst nadir of the recession that we confronted six years ago, we would have confronted not an unemployment level of 11 per cent, which was our inheritance from then Treasurer John Howard, but an unemployment level of eight per cent. We were doing, as the former Treasurer and now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, that double backflip with pike. We were providing millions of new jobs in this country in extraordinarily difficult circumstances, as we confronted a revolution in labour force participation by women and an immigration rate twice the level of that which this government has had to cope with—that halving of that particular rate four or five years before they in fact took office.

Let us go to this business about their one little kernel, that one little part of the nut, that they drag out to defend themselves. They say, `Okay, there's ruination all around in manufacturing industry, unemployment is rising, but we've got a wonderful inflation figure. It's around about one to two per cent.' What were the figures in the four years? One year concluded with a growth rate of 4.9 per cent and all had a growth rate of four per cent or over. What were the inflation figures? They were two per cent, 2.1 per cent, 2.1 per cent and 3.2 per cent. Was it John Howard's 11 per cent? No, it was not John Howard's 11 per cent. It was virtually the same level of inflation they experience now.

All those changes which took place in the labour market were changes that we put in place. We achieved those levels of inflation which you have simply been able to continue with and which have allowed the Reserve Bank to make adjustments to pick up your failure. What has allowed the Reserve Bank to make adjustments to pick up your failure has been the fact that you were left with a low inflation environment by us, thank you very much. That has put the Reserve Bank in a position—and it has more work to do— where it has been able to come in and fill the hole that you have left.

Unfortunately, many other factors, apart from inflation rates, impact upon whether there is confidence in the business community and whether bringing down interest rates will create any opportunities for small business or for the manufacturing industry. Above all, there is the question of confidence. Whatever might be the stage that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister think they strut in this place, there is out there in the community a vote of no-confidence in this government. They are voting with their feet in the shops of the nation. They are walking out of consumption—consumption which is absolutely critical if we are going to see a better performance from business in the next year or two's figures.

Can't you remember the smirking arrogance removed from the Treasurer's face here today for the first time in a very long time in answers to questions? Can't you remember the smirking, but in this case also smarting, arrogance from the Treasurer when he took on board a question related to our last set of growth figures, when we left the nation with a near five per cent growth level and bowed out of the place after 13 years of constructive office?

What he said then was repeated by the shadow Treasurer here today. He got up in this place and leant across with that cat's smile on his face and said: `I have to tell you—expect more of it.' Perhaps he might have said: `Expect the sort of figures that you achieved in a quarter for a year under us.' We do expect more of them. We expect a great deal more of them. We expect a bit of industry policy out of them. We expect a bit of commonsense in relation to job security out of them.

Let me go to the heart of job security in this country. Job security is made up of many elements. One is that people have confidence that the business community is going to keep employing them. There are many factors associated with that. Some of it goes to the sorts of adjustment that have been made in the public sector—30,000 jobs out of the public sector, 20,000-odd jobs out of Telstra.

BREAK.PARA: They take a look around the communities of this nation and wonder where the skilled jobs are going to come from. They wonder where jobs, particularly for middle aged men, are going to come from. They take a look at the decisions of the government. They take a look at the government's priorities and the government's priorities say this: `If you are a public servant we will fire you. If you happen to be in an institution which we want to privatise we will fire you.' That is this government's position on employment.

Then they move on and talk about the industrial relations changes that they made. Remember—the industrial relations changes we made produced two million jobs and produced an inflation level of two per cent while we were in office, which you happen to be building on. That is what our industrial relations policies did. And they produced growth in the manufacturing sector. And they produced a 10 per cent per annum increase in manufactured industry exports, down to a two per cent increase in this last year, or this first year of your period in office. That is what our position produced.

But what has your industrial relations policy produced? Your industrial relations policy has produced fear and anguish in the Australian community as to whether or not people will be protected if they have a job. We have a Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) and a Prime Minister who got out there and said: `Everything sings and dances.' They got out there after the government's industrial relations bill and said: `What a terrific thing this industrial relations bill has been.' `There won't be a second wave', said Peter Reith. `There won't even be a ripple.' Remember the famous last words from the Treasurer: `If this is growth, I have to tell you—expect more of it.' And from Peter Reith: `There won't even be a ripple of a second wave as far as our industrial relations reforms are concerned.'

The Prime Minister says: `This is great news for small business.' What has happened three or four months later? They think that they are going to improve confidence in the community by declaring, `Oh dear. What we thought was so good has been a failure. We are going to have to take it a point further.' That is what they have had to say. What they are saying to people out there whom they are trying to encourage to consume is: `We are going to make it easier to fire you. That is what we are on about here. We are going to make you easier to sack.' What they say to those folk out there is: `We are going to make you work harder. We are going to make you work till you die.'

At the pension end the government will rip the dental benefits off pensioners. They will rip the position out from underneath pensioners in regard to access to their medicine. But they tell them: `Good news, team. You can work for another five years.' This is to encourage other people to feel that this is a government serious about getting additional people into the work force, when they know darned well that those over‐65s compete with what is now the most vulnerable area of the work force in the sense of job security, and that is not kids—though the figures for kids are bad enough. The real problem for job security in this community, which is impacting massively on family income and on community confidence, is, in the main, middle-aged men, in their 40s and 50s. There is nothing for them.

These are the people who are employed in the car industry. These are the people who are employed in the shipbuilding industry. These are the people who, along with their female counterparts, are heavily employed in the textile industry. These are the people the Prime Minister will not go to see at Newcastle. What a statement from the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister says to Ray Martin—he who must be answered—four weeks ago: `I am about to go to Newcastle.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Soon.

—`Soon'. That was four weeks ago. But I will tell you where he is going soon. He is going to Lords soon. He is not going to Newcastle soon. Because what would he confront in Newcastle? He would confront the men that I have been talking about. He would confront the men who were told when we left office that the iron and steel situation was fine as far as they were concerned, from BHP to additional electric arc furnaces—in place a steel policy. The moment the hand is taken off the tiller, off they scupper. The moment a government leaves office with an industry policy and a willingness to use the bully pulpit to keep an industry policy in place, off they scupper overseas—to join the Prime Minister.

BREAK.PARA: What is left? What is left is insecurity. What is left is a trail of bad faith and that bad faith is a product of this government. But will the government talk about job security? The government will not talk about its budget. I do not blame them for that. Will they talk about job security? No, they will not. What is their solution? They come in and say, `You can talk about job security. We'll talk about tax reform.' What? You have had two years in office. Where is the tax reform? You now say you have tax reform on the agenda. What tax reform? What is your proposition?

We are slowly coming up to this ridiculous, bogus proposition that the GST is going to be a solution to employment problems. I can just see it now, the mantra: if you put in place a GST, what you are going to have is job security, more jobs. That is a statement of faith. It is not a statement of argument. It is not a statement of proof. You go and look at the big VAT countries in Europe. They have twice the rate of unemployment of the United States and, even after your paltry record, 50 per cent higher than the unemployment rates here. That is your solution.

We cannot talk about jobs, we cannot talk about job security, we cannot talk about an industry policy—they have no industry policy—we cannot talk about our budget. So what will we talk about? We will talk about tax reform but without an idea, without a single proposition, but a small flirtation back to where we were before. And remember on that GST they promised there would be none of it.

Winston Churchill used to say that it takes courage to rat, but it takes VC standard courage to re‐rat. We have had that from the government on this question of a GST and we have had it from them on employment, a ratting and re‐ratting on the workers of this nation and on the people who want access to the work force of this nation. They stand absolutely condemned by today's figures, and they have not a feather to fly with. (Time expired)

I cannot put it any better than the honourable member for Melbourne when he warned the Labor Party:

SPEECH.PARA: We must avoid becoming economically irrational, lapsing into mindless populism, recycling the policies of the 1950s and defining ourselves by what we don't like.

All we heard for 15 minutes from the Leader of the Opposition was a trip down memory lane, some sort of justification of the policies that Labor had, the policies that led them to oblivion on 3 March last year. They simply want to revisit the failed policies that they had in place when they were last in government.

We heard much from the Leader of the Opposition about doing something for employment. We heard it during question time today. Do the official numbers reflect reality?
They go on to say:
. . . the fact is, the economy this year is, if anything, growing more strongly than it was at the same time last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —John, John!
—You don't want to hear this, do you? You do not like hearing it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the economy is growing more strongly this year than it was at the same time last year when the official growth rate was measured to be twice as fast . . . The economy will grow more strongly in 1996‐97 than in 1995‐96.
Your big year. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) is arguing about the big year for Labor, the last year. They go on to say:

The facts are, they say, that growth is higher this year than last year and they go forward. They argue:
In 1995‐96, when the economy was measured to have grown by this so‐called figure of 4.9%, all of the following occurred—
and they are interesting facts—

BREAK.PARA: Australia recorded the highest level of bankruptcies in its history—
that was Labor's last year, the highest level of bankruptcies in our history—
employment growth came to a virtual standstill—
we know that in six years they managed to get the net figures up by 16,000. Further:
every business survey, with no exception, showed major reductions in both confidence and activity, profitability fell by 16.4%, government revenue was two percentage points lower than forecast.
So quite clearly, on the basis of the independent arbitrators on this debate, the last year of Labor was a complete failure and they are very, very happy with what has been shown by today's figures.

The only argument that the Leader of the Opposition attempted to use in this debate was the figures in respect of manufacturing. Manufacturing was down 2.7 per cent for the quarter. But let us have a look at some of the real growth that occurred in the last quarter: construction, up 5.4 per cent; agriculture, up 3.6 per cent; accommodation and cafes, up 3.2 per cent; communication services, up 2.4 per cent; wholesale trade, up 2.3 per cent; personnel and other services, up 2.1 per cent; finance and insurance, up 2.1 per cent; education, up 1.8 per cent; retail trade—and we heard a little about that—up 1.7 per cent; transport and storage, up 0.7 per cent; and mining, up 0.4 per cent. There was growth in all areas of the economy.

We can argue about the future for as long as we like. The simple facts are that the foundations are in place, as every sensible economic analyst out there will acknowledge. Of course, the only nonsensical economic analysts in this particular debate are on the Labor side of the House.

When you have low inflation locked in and low interest rates locked in—interest rates that have delivered $292 per month after‐tax as a benefit to those who are seeking to purchase a house or to those with the average mortgage at the present time—then I would say to you that that is one of the healthier signs I have seen in all of the time I have been watching the management of the economy, and that is all of my adult life.

What we know from today's figures was very clearly stated by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in his media release today. We have very favourable prospects for the forthcoming year. The economy is very much poised for an acceleration in growth. As I have indicated already, the forward indicators in the housing area—not just based upon the mortgage relief that has been provided in a significant way by the economic policies of this government but on the economic indicators for housing activity—confirm that the housing recovery continues to strengthen.

We have seen domestic final demand in exports grow very rapidly during the quarter by 2.1 per cent and 2.5 per cent respectively. The one downside in today's figures is that there is an indication clearly that stock growth is likely to resume in coming quarters. It is an unreliable indicator, but there is a clear indication that it will return. Even in the event—as the Treasurer said in question time today—that the stocks were unchanged in the June quarter, stocks would still add about one percentage point to GDP(E) growth in the quarter.

We have seen both private and public final demand grow strongly in the last quarter. We have seen equipment investment up some 3.1 per cent. We have seen a sharp rebound in non-residential construction investment—up 11.2 per cent. We have seen a strong private consumption growth—up one per cent. We have seen accelerating growth in dwelling investment—up 5.2 per cent. We have seen, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicated in question time, growth in exports. That is most important for rural and regional Australia, and it contributes so significantly to what is occurring in terms of our growth in this economy.

So the future does look bright. If you go back to the budget, the budget indicates 3¾ per cent growth in the economy during the year ahead. They are the exact ingredients we need to ensure that that growth occurs. We will see very clearly by the end of this financial year a growth of over three per cent.

The member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) continually likes to take one quarter in isolation, but he dropped off the March quarter for last year, which had a growth of 1.7 per cent. That was a high growth quarter. I suspect that confidence and that investment all came with a rush after 2 March 1996 or as an expectation of what was going to happen on 2 March. If you take this particular growth of 0.9 per cent, we are exactly on track for that sustainable growth with all of the right ingredients in place.

That is despite the fact that we have inherited a deficit of $10.5 billion. We have inherited five consecutive deficit budgets from the Labor government. We have inherited an increase in general government debt of $70 billion in that five-year period. We have seen the growth in debt servicing increase from $5.3 billion in 1991 to just under $10 billion by the time the government changed. We have addressed those problems of debt and deficit by turning that $10.5 billion deficit around in the space of three budgets to a surplus of $1.6 billion. We have reduced the reliance on debt to the extent that we have increased national savings with a public sector contribution.

At the same time, we have delivered tax reform to the families of this country. We have given all that we promised and then considerably more in the way of relief, including tax relief, and benefits to the small business sector.

We have indicated very, very clearly that this is a government that will not spend what it does not have. This is a government that will act responsibly in all matters fiscal. This is a government that is not going to throw a bucket of money at unemployment problems, as the member for Hotham did when he was the minister responsible.

This is a government that is responsible to the self-funded retirees and prepared to give those at that age in our community some considerable relief. We have given relief in the context of the threshold in which they have to pay tax. We have given them a tax rebate in terms of their savings.

So we have looked after the needy in the community. We have shared the load equally across the board. We have addressed the debts and the deficits of Labor, the inheritance we received and the disastrous state of the econ omy and the Commonwealth's finances. At the same time, we have put in place those ingredients that will ensure sustainable growth for the years ahead.

Let me now go back to some of the other comments that were made by the Leader of the Opposition. He spoke very passionately—endeavouring as he was to sustain his current leadership, which is under threat—of the fact that there was a need for job security. There was no job security under Labor. Under Labor we saw jobs die. The member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) knows all about this; we saw them simply go out the door in large numbers, year after year, before, throughout and subsequent to the recession.
Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Batman!

—We have seen from the Labor Party the revitalisation of policy in respect of the car industry. We have seen the brainwaves and the populist approach in terms of the steel industry when the General Manager of BHP said that no matter what the government did or who the government was this decision would have been taken. We have seen the support for the textile industry. So the backflips go on. You made a mess of it and now you are going back to what contributed so significantly to the mess you made of our economy and of the Commonwealth's finances in an attempt to try and find some sort of support out there which, of course, is not forthcoming and will not be forthcoming.

BREAK.PARA: This is a responsible government. It will manage the economy and it will manage the Commonwealth's finances very much in a responsible manner.
Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It will do so on the basis of ensuring that we do not spend what we have not got and of guaranteeing to the Australian people that the growth we put in place will be based upon low inflation and upon our contribution to those low interest rates, which will boost confidence in small business and everywhere else.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Batman.

—That confidence and that growth in the economy will continue to gain momentum as we go into the 1997‐98 year. I have absolute confidence, as do all of my colleagues, that the numbers in respect of employment by June 1998 will show the benefit of the change of government and will show why we were chosen to govern this country. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When are we going to see that growth the Treasurer told us we could expect so much more of? When are we going to see that growth the Treasurer said was going to be boosted under the coalition government? When are we going to see the jobs? When are we going to turn that endlessly receding corner? When are we going to get results from this particular government? We certainly have not had any results to date. What we have with these national accounts figures is, for the first time now, at the end of a 12‐month period of this government being in office, the record. It is no longer the prediction, it is no longer the forecast, it is no longer the expectation and it is no longer the possibility—it is the record. And what a record it is. A growth rate over those last 12 months of just 2.4 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer and the Minister for Finance say, `Well, you had to expect it to come back to that because that big quarter you had in March last year dropped out.' That big quarter we had in March last year was the last quarter of the Labor government. What has now dropped into the accounts is the first quarter of your government. What makes up the rest of the 12‐monthly accounts are the second and the third and the fourth quarters of your government. What do those four quarters add up to? They add up to 2.4 per cent. How does that compare with what we achieved in our last year in government? We achieved 4.9 per cent. It is less than half the amount. Of course the quarter of growth that we were last associ ated with has dropped out; that is what happens when the calendar ticks over. Sooner or later you have to bear the responsibility. It is all your own work. Growth of 4.9 per cent was us: 2.4 per cent is all your own work. It is on the record and, my God, have people noticed it. In our last four years in government we achieved four per cent. In your first year in government it was 2.4 per cent.

The government that pledged itself to boosting the economy has flattened the Australian economy. It is even worse so far as manufacturing industry is concerned. You have not just flattened it: you have sent it into recession. Two quarters of negative growth for manufacturing, minus 2.2 per cent for the whole year.

The Prime Minister, who has conceded that we have to sustain growth at four to five per cent if we are going to make a lasting inroad into unemployment, as he says, has presided over an economy growing at just half that necessary rate. Even if, looking to the future, that latest quarter of 0.9 per cent is sustained, that still only annualises out at 3.6 per cent. That is less than the 3¾ per cent that is in your current budget projections. It is less again than the four to five per cent your Prime Minister concedes that you need.

You are not going to make 3¾ per cent for this year. You are not going to make the revised budget forecast that you put down just a few weeks ago. To get that you would have to have two per cent growth in the next quarter. You are not going to get two per cent out of stocks or out of anything else. That is beyond reach. You cannot even meet the growth projections that you revised as recently as five or six weeks ago.

These figures are not just abstractions to give economists their jollies. What we are talking about with these particular figures is what they mean in terms of real human pain and suffering for ordinary Australians and, in particular, for the 800,000 unemployed Australians. What they mean is pain and suffering for the faces that I see in my electorate, in Dandenong and in south‐east Melbourne, and what so many of my colleagues in this place and, indeed, some of yours see. They are not the faces you see in the view from Kirribilli. They are not the faces you see in the view from Malvern or Toorak that the Treasurer enjoys. These are the faces of ordinary Australians who are affected by these policies and by this abominable performance.

The failure of the economy to grow at the pace that it could and should have grown over the last year has meant, as we know, 32,000 more people unemployed under the coalition government. It has meant 30,000 more long‐term unemployed. It has meant a higher rate of youth unemployment. It has meant a rate of employment growth now being projected for the outyear periods that, as the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) so effectively put it today, will mean that you are producing nearly 300,000 fewer jobs over this period of government than we did in our last.

And who is to blame for this lamentable state of affairs? Who is to blame for the fact that the economy is in this condition? The short answer is that it is absolutely nobody but this government. We are not talking about alien forces at work here. This show is not The X‐Files; this show is the Australian economy. And it is the Australian government that is unequivocally responsible for running this show. It is unequivocally responsible for what has gone wrong.

What has gone wrong in the management of this economy is two big things. First of all, a budgetary strategy that has been hopelessly astray. The budgetary strategy over the period the government has been in office—for two budgets now—has been deliberately, designedly contractionary in scope, because you have had an utterly wrong‐headed appreciation of what the economic priorities of this country are. You have moved into a contractionary mode, which has meant half a per cent less growth over last year and this year than would otherwise have been the case. You have moved into a budgetary strategy that has gone about creating jobs by destroying them in the Public Service in regional Australia and everywhere else. You have gone about a budgetary strategy that has deliberately destroyed jobs and prospects in the manufacturing sector, through the removal of subsidies, the decimation of R&D support, the removal of export assistance and the creation of massive uncertainty about the tariff future of a number of key sectors. You are responsible. It is deliberate strategy that has produced this result.

Small business has suffered particularly acutely as a result of this strategy. For small business, the growth that is generated by the economy and by the budget that is so central to economic management is far more than government regulations or taxes or access to bank finance. It is small business that has felt the full brunt of the economic slowdown. Last week's Yellow Pages survey reported that more than 80 per cent of small businesses saw the economy as going backwards or at a standstill, as it affected them. That is reflected in bankruptcy statistics. Do not tell us about the ancient past. Reflect on the fact, Minister for Finance, that bankruptcies have increased 21.3 per cent in the government's first year in office.

The second thing you have done is not just to embark upon a contractionary budget strategy but to go about it in a way that has generated a massive decline in consumer confidence. Instead of generating confidence, you undermined it with all your talk about black holes and the nonsensical strategy that has gone with it. Every month, researchers at the University of Melbourne test consumer confidence, and in the space of just five months last year—I will not go into the details—your government turned strong consumer confidence into widespread pessimism.

That has continued. Last year's retail experience was the worst in a generation. It was the toughest period for sales in a generation. Things picked up a bit in January and February, and there was some hope that we might have been headed for better times, but now we know that all those extra sales were just generated by deep discounting by desperate retailers, many of them in small business. In the last two months retail sales have again declined sharply. This government is incapable of generating the kind of confidence the economy needs.

When confronted with this kind of record of failure—to generate growth, to create jobs, to reduce unemployment, to boost retail sales, to reduce bankruptcy, to reduce foreign debt for that matter and to improve our competitiveness—the government's stock response, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said, is to call upon the strong private investment that has been occurring and the interest rate cuts that have been made possible by sustained low inflation. But these are not the government's achievements. They are the government's inheritance. They are the product of the strength of the economy they inherited. The investment decisions that are made were essentially made and bedded down before you came into office, and the inflationary environment you inherited is not something that just came to fruition in the last 12 months and has created an environment—as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) is trying to say—that made it difficult for business to adjust. The truth of the matter is that in our last five years in office inflation averaged 2½ per cent—right bang in the middle of the Reserve Bank's target range. That was our gift to you. That was the economy that you inherited. This is the economy that you are now in the process of making an unholy mess of.

Let there be no mistake, no misunderstanding: the economy is potentially still in an unholy mess. The world economy gives some ground for confidence out there, but there are many dimensions of the economy as we see it that show real cause for concern, and the record of performance of this government does nothing other than to generate continuing alarm in many sectors of the economy about whether things will in fact pick up.

If the economy does pick up, as we all hope it will, it will not undo the damage that has been done to the economy in this first year of office. If there are better economic prospects next year—and, my God, we all hope there are, because all our constituents depend upon that—that does not change the fact that tens of thousands more Australian workers are unemployed today than was the case this time last year and thousands of small businesses are struggling to survive—even more than was the case last year—because of one reason only. That is this government's appalling, grotesque mishandling of the economy in its first 12 months in office. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews, Kevin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning in Brisbane the former Labor cabinet minister and former Labor Minister for Health, Graham Richardson, made a speech to a business breakfast in which he made some interesting remarks. When members of the former government leave office, then you see some truthfulness in what they have to say which is not necessarily reflected in what might have been said while they were here.

SPEECH.PARA: During the course of his remarks, the former Senator Richardson said that Paul Keating had wanted to be viewed as a statesman overseas, but had failed, because he did not address domestic problems such as native title issues, links with Asia and Australia's foreign debt. `The mishandling of these problems left the last two Labor governments looking awful,' he said.

It is a measure of the awfulness of the past Labor government that we were left inheriting a $10,500 million Commonwealth debt. It is a measure of that awfulness that the foreign debt of this country is running at some $180 billion. It is a measure of that awfulness that the former Labor government left this country with unemployment running at over 8 per cent—in reality much higher—in the fifth year of recovery, unemployment that reached over 11 per cent under the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) when he was Minister for Employment.

It is also a measure of that awfulness that unemployment, according to the current Leader of the Opposition, was ratcheted up in each recession over which Labor presided. It is a measure of the awfulness of the former Labor government that in this country we have an increasing gap between the rich and the poor, as middle Australia has been squeezed from all directions.

It is a measure of the awfulness—which former Senator Richardson referred to about the former governments he was part of—that we had, as the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) has pointed out today, bankruptcies at record levels under the former government. It is a measure of that awfulness that small businesses have been destroyed by the former Labor government because of the record interest rates which were brought to bear by the former administration—record interest rates that reached over 20 per cent and destroyed thousands upon thousands of small businesses in this country.

It is also a measure of that awfulness that national savings collapsed to an all‐time low under the former Labor government throughout their decade‐long reign in this country. It is a record of that awfulness that personal household savings have reached the point of almost non‐existence after 13 years of Labor government. It is a record of that awfulness—to which, again, former Senator Richardson referred about his own former government—that the approach to unemployment under the former government meant churning people through training programs which only served to artificially lower the number of long-term unemployed on the books in this country and which created few real jobs. In fact, as the Minister for Finance has pointed out, it was a net increase in real jobs of 16,000. This, I take it, is the measure of awfulness to which Graham Richardson was referring this morning—the awfulness of the two former Labor governments.

It is also a measure of the former governments that they arrogantly told the Australian people that the recession was the recession we had to have and that there would be a soft landing. Of course, Labor never did bring the bacon home as promised. They are now in limbo as a result.

What the Howard and Costello government inherited was an economy heading towards destruction. We have started to address some of those measures. We have started to address some of what we have inherited. We have turned the Commonwealth deficit into a surplus within the period of one parliament. We have turned a $10,500 million Commonwealth deficit into a $1,600 million surplus in the period of one parliament.

We have encouraged national savings through a program which will give some incentive for people in this country actually to save some of the money they earn; by reducing some of the red tape that exists for small business in this country; by providing a tax reduction for families, particularly those struggling with children at the present time; and, in the larger economic sense, by taking measures that will reduce the debt to GDP ratio and by building an economy based on steady sustainable growth rather than the decade of boom and bust which was practised under Labor.

What do the national accounts actually show, which this matter of public importance is said to be about? Today's national accounts show that the economy grew by 0.9 per cent in the March quarter. This is a good outcome and a pointer to very favourable prospects for the forthcoming year. With the exception of stocks, all of the areas of expenditure contributed to growth.

The composition of activity in the quarter, with very strong growth in final demand and a sharp run‐down in non‐farm stocks, combined with other indicators of activity, suggest that the economy is poised for an acceleration in growth. Forward indicators, for example, of housing activity confirm that the housing recovery continues to strengthen. Last week's ABS stocks and selected industry sales release indicated that manufacturers expect sales in this country to strengthen and that the outlook for business investment continues to be very positive.

Real private consumption expenditure rose one per cent in the March quarter, following the growth of 0.7 per cent in the December quarter. This reflected strong growth in the consumption of retail goods, which rebounded in the March quarter to grow by 1.6 per cent, and strength in the purchase of motor vehicles. Dwelling investments rose by 5.2 per cent in the March quarter, with very strong growth in investment in new dwellings more than offsetting a fall in alterations and additions investment. Private business investment rose by 5.3 per cent in the March quarter, reflecting increases in both equipment and non‐dwelling construction investment, with the latter growing particularly strongly.

The sales to stocks ratio run‐down is something which will be corrected in the coming quarter, and all the indicators are that that is being corrected at the present time. If you look at some of the other breakdowns in terms of these figures, you will be able to see other indicators that this economy is growing in a sustained, steady way, not in the way of the boom‐bust cycle that we had in 13 years under a Labor government.

If you look at manufacturing specifically, which the opposition has referred to today, you will see that employment in manufacturing in the year to February increased by 22,000 positions nationally. You will also see that profitability for manufacturing has also continued to grow.

Rather than listening to the opposition, which has got to come in here and carp about what the government is doing—we know that that is the job of the opposition, and of course they are going to come in here and do it—perhaps we ought to look at what some independent analysis has said about the situation. If you look at the report of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council, you will see some indication of what the experts are saying. They referred to an outstanding economic performance so far as this country is concerned over the past year. They said that 1996 for Australia was a banner year. `A banner year,' said the experts from the Pacific Economic Cooperative Council, so far as their assessment of the Australian economy is concerned.

The opposition come in here and feign concern about the economy at the present time. If they were really concerned about the Australian economy, if they were really concerned about creating real jobs in the Australian economy, then they would adopt a different approach from what they have adopted to industrial relations reform. They would not be so niggardly in their attitude to the unfair dismissal provisions and the changes to the new legislation.

The most feigned indignation was contained in the comments by the Leader of the Opposition on industry policy, in which he said, `We expect an industry policy.' TITLE.XREF: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Kemp, and read a first time.

PARA.TAB: Dr KEMP (Goldstein—Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation) (4.38 p.m.)—I move:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The bill would increase the amount previously appropriated for 1997 under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 by $17.938 million in line with normal price adjustments, taking total funding for 1997 to $909.263 million. In 1997, Commonwealth funding alone is expected to provide 43,000 student places over and above those provided in 1996. This will contribute substantially to an estimated total increase of 55,000 training places this year, as I said in question time today.

The bill would also amend the legislated amount for 1998 to $890.585 million to give effect to the 1997‐98 budget decision to reduce funding for distribution to the states and territories by the Australian National Training Authority by $20 million. The bill would appropriate the same level of funding for 1999.

This budget measure provides an incentive to the states and territories to achieve efficiency gains in vocational education and training operations. The reduction represents about 0.7 per cent of total Commonwealth, state and territory funding for the sector. It should be seen against the background of a 37 per cent increase in Commonwealth funding for the sector since 1992.

At the Australian National Training Authority ministerial council meeting on 23 May 1997, all state and territory ministers supported a resolution noting that the reform of the vocational education and training sector agreed at the meeting has the potential to improve efficiency and effectiveness in the provision of vocational education and training. Indeed, there should be substantial capacity to fund further growth in the sector from efficiency gains, including those resulting from the reforms led by the government.

These reforms are far reaching and demonstrate the government's commitment to vocational education and training. This year's budget has clearly demonstrated this commitment with an overall increase in the allocation for vocational education and training of $144 million, or almost 12 per cent, compared with the expenditure of $1.2 billion in 1995‐96 when the Labor Party was in government.

There has been some re‐allocation of funds to focus on our highest priority—the reform of the vocational education and training system and the establishment of new apprenticeships. About 70 per cent of young Australians do not go from school into university. Vocational education and training has a major role to play in making sure young Australians obtain the skills needed to get them into jobs and in ensuring that Australian businesses can meet the challenges of the global economy. The government is working with the states and territories to establish a training system which is responsive to the needs of industry and business enterprises, while operating within a national framework that is based on national standards and high quality, portable national qualifications.

The centrepiece of the government's reforms to vocational education and training is new apprenticeships. New apprenticeships are being developed to expand the number of training opportunities, especially for young people, into new industries to take advantage of economic growth and employment poten tial. At the ministerial council meeting last month, the states and territories endorsed arrangements to ensure implementation of new apprenticeships. This was a historic agreement to introduce a flexible national system which meets the needs of today's enterprises wherever they may be located in Australia and whether they are large or small. It also maintains a focus on protecting the interests of those undertaking training through simpler but quality assured regulatory arrangements.

The ministerial council agreed that there will be new funding arrangements for off‐the‐job training for new apprenticeships, allowing employers and their trainees to choose the provider to deliver their training. For the first time, we will have a demand driven training system, giving employers an unprecedented opportunity to select the training that meets the needs of their business. More than $500 million a year in Commonwealth, state and territory funding will be available for allocation among public and private training providers under this `user choice' system. This bill provides the Commonwealth's contribution to that funding as well as ongoing support for other aspects of the vocational education and training provision.

The bill provides the solid foundation for building a national vocational education and training system which delivers quality outcomes, especially for young people, more efficiently and with less red tape. It provides a solid foundation for expanding opportunities for Australia's young people and improving the bottom line for Australian enterprises. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1997).

Customs Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1997) which I have just tabled contains alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to give effect to the information technology agreement, ITA, which was signed by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) on behalf of Australia in Singapore on 13 December 1996. The ITA was one of the major outcomes of the ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation, WTO, held in Singapore in December 1996. Negotiations on the agreement were completed on 26 March and it comes into force on 1 July this year.

The ITA represents a package of sectoral liberalisation which, in combination with the agreement on basic telecommunications, establishes the trading framework for the rapid growth of global information and communications infrastructure. Participants to the agreement will, in most circumstances, eliminate tariffs on computer technology and telecommunications products by the year 2000.

The ITA has been signed by 41 countries, including our major APEC trading partners. These counties represent 92.3 per cent of world trade in these products, a trade worth an estimated $750 billion per year. During the negotiations, Australia made clear its requirements for an acceptable and balanced package of liberalisation being achieved and for the participation by a core of our regional trading partners.

Australia stands to gain substantially from the ITA. Australian tariffs on ITA goods are proportionally lower than the tariffs of many other participating countries and the agreement will provide Australian industry with increased export opportunities to help redress the $6.9 billion trade deficit in this sector. It will do this in a number of ways:

. Exporters of electronic components, office machines and telecommunications equipment to the European Union, Canada, the United States and Asia are likely to benefit from the tariff eliminations of the ITA.

. Tariff elimination, combined with other factors such as rapidly expanding economies, large populations, expansion of communications infrastructures, and growing disposable income in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Korea and Taiwan will benefit trade in all ITA products. These countries, all participants in the ITA, represent the largest potential ITA market in the world.

BREAK.PARA: . ITA will ensure greater certainty of access through commitments to bind tariffs at zero.
. The agreement will boost employment in this industry sector, which currently employs 30,000 Australian workers.

Moreover, the ITA will provide Australian firms and consumers with access to information technology and telecommunications inputs at world competitive prices. The ITA is an excellent example of Australian industry and government working together. Industry was kept closely involved during the negotiations from the outset and has strongly supported and welcomed our participation in the ITA. The telecommunications industry believes that the ITA will add up to $400 million a year in new exports. Other parts of the industry believe that exports of their products could at least double by the end of the decade.

Australia could not have secured the market opening achieved under the ITA through direct bilateral negotiations. Working through APEC and the WTO allowed Australia, in coalition with other major economies, to bring our key regional trading partners to the ITA negotiating table.

Australia must now implement its commitment to reduce tariffs on ITA products. These alterations are contained in Customs Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1997) and will come into effect on 1 July 1997. They fully implement Australia's tariff obligations under this agreement.
A summary of the alterations contained in this proposal has been prepared and is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposal to the House.

Customs Tariff Proposal No. 4 (1997) which I have just tabled contains alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1995 which result from Administrative Appeals Tribunal, AAT, decisions. Each of the alterations is techni cal in nature, affecting only a narrow range of goods. I will briefly outline each of them and later provide more detail on each alteration.

Alteration No. 1 reinstates the level of government assistance granted to local manufacturers of surgical drapes.Alterations Nos. 2 and 3 realign the Australian tariff in accordance with our international obligations to the World Customs Organisation, WCO. Alteration No. 4 corrects a recent tariff amendment, narrowing the range of goods entitled to duty free treatment to only those goods so entitled before the amendment.

I will now outline the alterations in more detail. Alteration No. 1 of this proposal will apply a more precise description to goods classified in subheading 4823.90.10. This will exclude surgical drapes from that classification and reinstate the intended level of tariff assistance.

In the second matter, an automotive parts importer appealed against a classification ruling by the Australian Customs Service, ACS, that certain lamps were classified under heading 9405. The AAT agreed with the appellant that the lamps should be classified in heading 8539. Australia is a contracting partner to the harmonised commodity description and coding system, HS, sponsored by the WCO. The WCO has advised the ACS that the lamps in question are classified in heading 9405.

Alteration Nos. 2 and 3 of this proposal insert an additional note in chapter 85 of the tariff, thus realigning Australia's position with that of the HS. The third matter results from a 1991 AAT decision that certain centrally housed ADP power units should be classified to heading 8471 as computer units. The ACS accepted this decision.

In 1995 the WCO, in its four‐year cycle of review of classification matters, recommended that all power units be classified in heading 8504. The ACS instituted this change and provided a new subheading for the goods covered by the AAT decision, thus allowing a continuation of their free rate of duty. The description in that subheading has now been shown to include a broader range of goods than that specified in the original AAT decision.

BREAK.PARA: Alteration No. 4 of this proposal inserts a more precise description of the goods specified in the 1991 AAT decision and limits the free rate of duty to those goods.
