SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This Howard coalition government is mad and bad and dangerous. The evidence for that has been seen just in the last couple of days in terms of the priorities that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has set for federal government action in two different areas. The Aged Care Bill 1997, which we have before us today and which is at issue in the discussion in this House, is an extremely important bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister indicated in the House yesterday what his approach to the next three years might be in terms of what the priorities of this government might be. The Prime Minister could, in effect, be likened to George Bush because what he has introduced into Australia now is the notion that the federal government should take on issues, attitudes and programs for which they have no direct responsibility. Absolutely contrary to the National Commission of Audit, absolutely contrary to what the government has done in the past, it is going to take up state government issues—issues that are the responsibility of the states—and campaign on them.

This Prime Minister announced that tomorrow he will be launching a national campaign against violence and crime in Australia. That will be a three-year campaign in which the federal government will take an active strategic role in relation to trying to monitor and test anti-violence programs within the community, setting those up as models and then getting the states to implement them.

Before George Bush was thrown out of office, he had to be told by the Democrats that, basically, `It's the economy, stupid!' He had not got the point when he was campaigning that the economy in the United States was really in difficulty. We could make that same point here, but we could probably go further and say to the Prime Minister, `It's the society, stupid!' because what this Aged Care Bill does is present a situation where, instead of what had been done over more than a decade to build aged care facilities that reflected the needs of Australian citizens, we have a Prime Minister running around as if he were Crusader Rabbit or Mighty Mouse, launching a campaign against violence in the community in relation to state government responsibilities.

But let us look at the federal government responsibilities that this Prime Minister and his minister are walking away from. This Aged Care Bill is, I believe, a dangerous one. It is dangerous for the aged in this community, it is dangerous for the people in hostel care, it is dangerous for the charitable institutions that run not‐for‐profit hostels and nursing homes within Australia, and it is dangerous because of the steps it takes to undo the aged care strategy which the former Labor government introduced in 1985.

Prior to our coming to office in 1983, the Giles report underlined the condition of nursing homes in Australia. What that underlined was a set of nursing homes, particularly those run for profit, that were entirely run down, where the conditions were deplorable and where people were treated in a manner that did not equate to the dignity that they had or should have been given to them.

Labor, at that time with the agreement of the coalition when it was in opposition, put forward a new program to be introduced over a period of 10 years. We had a situation prior to 1983 where, if people got sick—not dramatically sick; just sick enough that they could not look after themselves in their own home—and their family was not capable of assisting them, they had no choice but to go into one of those depleted and run-down nursing homes.

The strategy that we put in place was a three‐tiered strategy. Firstly, we put Commonwealth government funding into the home and community care program, in cooperation with the states, to allow those people who were still healthy and who had minor problems to be assisted in their own homes for as long as possible and to assist those people who were caring for them and to do so by bringing in community nurses and other community resources to allow them to stay at home.

Also, we built the hostel program. The hostel program under Labor was increased by 15 per cent in real terms year on year. That hostel program provided for people who could no longer remain at home but were not sick enough to go into a nursing home. Labor determined that it was important that there be a halfway house between the home and a nursing home. Labor determined that it was important to realise that people who could still cater for themselves but needed central meal facilities, nursing assistance on the property and the help and assistance of other residents could more profitably spend their lives in hostel accommodation, but they would not be forced to go into a nursing home inappropriately.

The third thing Labor did was to spend capital funds on building new nursing homes. In 1985‐86, the first year of that strategy, the ALP federal government spent $1.2 billion on aged care—that is, on nursing homes, hostels and home and community care. By 1993-94, that had grown to $2.6 billion worth of funding.

That is not going to happen under this government, because this government has identified two crises within the community. The first of those crises is the physical decline of aged care facilities noted in the Gregory report of 1993-94. The core problem is the fact that many nursing homes have declined in terms of their standards and fire regulations and they need to be rebuilt. The second crisis is the fact that our aged care system will increasingly come under greater impact by the ageing of the population.

Using these two notions and putting them as crises, what is the coalition's solution? They knew what the situation was while Labor was in government—a three‐tiered system of appropriate care: care in the home, under home and community care; care in hostels, which met the needs of the clients in the hostels; and, for those people who became quite dramatically sick, the much more expensive nursing home beds. The coalition should realise that the cost to the then federal government was less because it had that three‐tiered system. They should realise that it was not only appropriate but also cost‐effective for the then federal government.

But they noted the Gregory report, they noted the run‐down nature of nursing homes in Australia and they noted that it would cost about half a billion dollars, in terms of capital funding, to renew those nursing homes. But, because this coalition government do not want to participate in direct service delivery to the Australian people, they do not want to provide capital funding. They have come up with an entirely new way of going about it and have misrepresented it as just simply cloning Labor's position on hostels.

What is particularly dangerous to the people who need those appropriate services in the community and to the not‐for‐profit charitable institutions who run nursing homes and hostels in Australia is that this coalition government has merged two types of aged care—nursing homes and hostels. No longer will any individual who is not appropriately sick enough have a choice about whether to go into a hostel or to go into a nursing home, because people will be forced into nursing homes. They will enter an aged care centre where hostel accommodation and nursing accommodation will be as one. In terms of the capital needed in those facilities, it just so happens that this bill determines that the standard of the building of hostel accommodation has to be exactly equivalent—I think it is level 9—to nursing home accommodation.

In my electorate of Blaxland we have a number of hostel places that have been built up over the past decade. Those hostel places have been very important to the people in Blaxland. They have provided appropriate care for them. A number of those hostels are run by the Bankstown City Frail Aged Persons' Homes Trust, a not‐for‐profit organisation. I have with me a letter from the general manager of that trust, Mr Terry Madden. I wish to read out a number of parts of that letter because it details the direct impact of the Aged Care Bill on the nursing homes and hostels in Bankstown and how their welfare and the welfare of the people they serve will be directly affected by this misguided bill.

The hostel beds that we presently have in Bankstown are at level 3. They are not nursing home beds, they are not nursing home institutions, they are hostel institutions. The frail aged trust faces this simple situation: the people who came into those hostel places did not pay an entry fee. More than 60 per cent of the people using the hostels and nursing home places in Bankstown are concessional. They are pensioners; they do not have the funds. This not‐for‐profit organisation allowed them to enter the hostels without paying an entry fee.

Under this bill, the hostels and the trust have been told that they have to provide for a rebuilding of those hostels. They have to either renovate and bring level 3 up to level 9 or consolidate on one site. Effectively, it means this trust that has nursing home places on a site on Birdwood Road and hostel places spread throughout the municipality of Bankstown will be forced to upgrade dispersed hostel places. But this bill requires the trust to provide, effectively, nursing home care at those hostel places to not only bring the quality up to that building standard but also provide the same kind of care in that institution.

I think they will be effectively driven to rebuild entirely. All of those hostel places built with capital funds provided by the former Labor government will have to be rebuilt at standard 9. It is not only dangerous but also mad and bad. It is not good public policy. We have that infrastructure in Bankstown now. To duplicate it and then to not be able to run the existing infrastructure as a hostel program does not seem to make much sense.

This frail aged persons homes trust has never had to borrow money from a bank in order to run the trust, to run its nursing homes, to run its hostels. It has been funded by the local people of Bankstown. It has been funded by the registered clubs, such as the Bankstown District Sports Club and the club of the year, the Revesby Workers Club. It has also been funded by RSL clubs within the community. The people in Bankstown know and understand that they have to look after the aged. They know that the frail aged cannot remain at home.

So what is the impact of this aged care legislation? The minister, having announced that these changes would be made in the budget last year, from day one has not had a blind clue about what the implications of what her plans would be because the plans were not fleshed out. She did not really understand them. All she could do was to rhetorically say: `It is just the same as Labor's hostels program.' It is not. This will coalesce nursing homes beds and hostel beds. Mr Madden says this:
Those deemed able to pay the accommodation bond will pay around $88,000 entry fee for an average nursing home bed in Sydney.
He supplies an article from the Daily Telegraph indicating that 80 per cent of service providers in the charitable sector will fix their nursing home entry fees at around $88,000:
Charities will have no choice other than to set the fee because the Commonwealth Government has abolished capital grants at the same time it is introducing accommodation bonds for nursing homes.
He further says:

The average cost to build a nursing home bed in New South Wales is between $90,000 and $100,000. To build therefore a 50-bed nursing home will cost an organisation around $5 million. That means the organisation needs to have about $250,000 a year put aside to rebuild after 20 years.

Changes in technology and the fact that the buildings will be run down means that an organisation will need money to rebuild. If you take inflation into account over that period he points out that you would need closer to $300,000. So from all of the sources of funds from what used to be capital input for the charity to get those nursing home beds built in the first place, Bankstown will be in the situation where for the first time ever it will have to borrow. It will have to borrow $5 million straight up in order to duplicate those hostel beds. Mr Madden looks at the way in which money under this bill can flow into a charitable trust such as Bankstown's. He says:

The following shows the effect this mix would have on any charity running a 50-bed nursing home. If a resident is taken into care as a concessional resident and the charity is paid $5 per day then in a year they would receive $1,825. If a resident is taken into care and pays an accommodation bond of $88,000, then the charity can deduct $2,600 per annum for a maximum of five years, (or $13,000) from the bond, plus the interest it gets off the bond. Presuming 5 per cent interest per annum on $88,000 ($4,400) and adding to that the $2,600 gives the charity $7,000 per annum if a person pays the full bond. This represents $19.18 a day.

The equations are that if you have a 50-bed nursing home with an accommodation bond of $88,000, that generates about $350,000 per annum for the charity. If, however, you have 30 per cent concessional residents, it is about $272,000. If you have 40 per cent, it is down to $246,000. If you have a 60 per cent intake it is $194,750. If you need $300,000 income and you are only getting $220,000 or $194,000, then your deficit will grow year by year over those 20 years.

The government in this bill has indicated that all nursing homes should take in concessional patients, but it should be based on socio‐economic factors. In Hunters Hill, as an example given by the minister, they should take about 10 per cent of concessional patients. They would have to forgo $25,875 per annum. But in Bankstown if they had to take 30 per cent of concessional residents they would forgo $77,625 a year. So over 20 years, Bankstown's frail aged trust would be out of pocket by more than $1½ million. It would be that much less able to rebuild its nursing home.

Mr Madden puts this proposition: he does not think that this bill is equitable or non‐discriminatory because of that absolute effect. He suggests this system to make the situation more equitable between different providers, between the charitable institutions and the for‐profit providers who provided so much of the input to the minister in relation to these changes. Mr Madden says this:

A far better system would be for all service providers who receive any form of government subsidy to have a flat rate of concessional residents of, say, 20 per cent and that for those residents the government would pay $5 per day. However, for any residents in excess of 20 per cent, regardless of what socio‐economic area they came from, the government should pay the same rate per day the organisation would get if a person was a full accommodation bond paying resident, and that is $19.18 a day. This would be equitable, it would not be discriminatory and it would be uniform across all socio‐economic areas. An organisation would not be penalised because it is trying to provide care in a poorer area compared to another charity trying to provide the same accommodation to the same standard in a more wealthy area.

I started this debate arguing that in relation to this Aged Care Bill 1997 the coalition government is mad and bad and dangerous. It is dangerous because it has taken a tripartite program that worked exceptionally well for more than a decade and broken it into small pieces. It has coalesced nursing home and hostel beds. It has got out of the game of providing capital funding. It has heaped that on the heads of the individual citizens of Australia because this coalition government does not believe in supporting the people of Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —`What is this talk about paying to get into a nursing home? I have just visited an old mate in a home and I wouldn't live there if you paid me.' This was the opening of a conversation I had with a Dunkley elector on the subject of the government's aged care accommodation reforms. He had seen the product of Labor's regime and, to quote the terms used by the member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton), `the three‐tier regime'. Let me tell you, member for Blaxland, for one of those tiers, nursing homes, the tears were everywhere. They were about people contemplating moving into some of them. The three‐tier system has one big problem and we have got one good plan to fix it.

SPEECH.PARA: This Dunkley elector had applied the ultimate test of asking himself whether he would like to be accommodated in parts of the system, particularly in some of the nursing homes that Labor left in such a parlous state, with soul destroying living conditions that some elderly people were forced to endure while the former Labor government looked the other way and with low standard premises failing the care needs of the frailest of Australians. Labor had no plan to address these problems and the elderly people in substandard aged care accommodation had no prospect of their living conditions improving.

My constituent experienced the sharp end of the problems the Labor Party ignored and that the coalition government has a plan to fix. The problems are real and warrant being publicised. The need for change is evident and compelling.

The Gregory report in May 1994 estimated the scale of the need to upgrade the building fabric to be a $520 million challenge—and the Labor Party turned their backs on the people affected by that challenge.

BREAK.PARA: From a sample of 150 nursing homes, the deficiencies that impeded the proper care of frail residents included: 75 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Australian design standards, 70 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Commonwealth outcome standards, and, for the benefit of `Mr Dangerous Mad and Bad', the member for Blaxland, 13 per cent of homes did not meet fire authority standards—and that is dangerous. And 39 per cent of residents were in rooms of four or more beds.

The practical care needs of residents were found to be compromised by poor access and mobility difficulties created by narrow doorways and poor building designs, bathrooms that impeded nursing assistance when bathing and insufficient heating and cooling. These were the problems and Labor had no plan to fix them, certainly not the half billion dollars that were required under the model that has just been advocated by the member for Blaxland. The Gregory report concluded:

The lack of incentive to maintain good quality nursing home stock is a result of the funding system, under which nursing homes receive a set amount for each resident, based on resident frailty, which is the same regardless of the age and condition of the building.

The government's aged care accommodation reforms, which it seeks to enact through the Aged Care Bill 1997, not only introduce the type of incentives Gregory was looking for to maintain the quality of nursing homes, but they put into place positive obligations on the proprietors of substandard facilities to lift their game. The reforms provided through this bill directly deal with my constituent's concerns about the quality of accommodation, as well as securing affordable access on a fair and sustainable basis.

The government is changing the aged care arrangements because people's expectations have changed. As my earlier example demonstrates, a higher quality standard of care is demanded from those in the Dunkley community currently enjoying what can be very exciting times as senior members, but they are contemplating a future possibly in aged care accommodation. No longer are shabby, run‐down nursing homes acceptable when two in every five residents have to share a room of four or more beds. No longer is it right that we deny old people the same number of accommodation and lifestyle choices that we give to young members of our community.

Most importantly, the coalition government wants to give older Australians the dignity, comfort and security in their lives that is so necessary for them to feel valued members of the Australian society. Times have also changed in the aged care sector itself. Half of the existing hostel residents are frail enough to qualify for nursing home care. Yet, under the current system, a hostel resident gets an average annual Commonwealth subsidy of under $10,000, compared with almost $29,000 if the same person were in a nursing home.

Aged care is one of the most important issues facing the community of Dunkley by the bay. At the 1991 census, Dunkley had around 18,000 residents aged 60 or over. Senior citizens are an especially large proportion of the population in Mornington where, in 1991, they comprised almost 23 per cent of all the residents. Contrary to popular impressions, there was then a higher proportion of people aged 60‐plus in Frankston at 17½ per cent, compared to Mount Eliza at 16.4 per cent. In Seaford, 14.1 per cent of the residents are aged 60 or over and it is only in two areas that I represent—Frankston North and Langwarrin—that the aged are not as numerically significant as in these other areas. Ten per cent and five per cent respectively of the general population are 60 or over in these communities.

Hostels in Dunkley such as RSL Park, which I have had the pleasure of visiting with the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and Milpara Park, where I officially opened an upgrading of their facilities just in the last week, play an important role in Dunkley. So do nursing homes such as the George Vowell Centre in Mt Eliza, which the minister has also inspected in one of her numerous tours around Australia.

The key objectives of the Aged Care Bill 1997 are quite straightforward. High quality care for everyone regardless of a person's income or location is first. More choice and flexibility follows. Safe, appropriate and comfortable accommodation for everyone is a key aim. It is also important that providers have the time to care, instead of being occupied trying to cope with red tape and paperwork. Unification of the hostel and nursing home sectors, and the introduction of a fairer, simpler subsidy system are also key goals.

The implementation of arrangements that are affordable, but nonetheless seek a fair and reasonable contribution from residents who have the ability to pay, is a further objective. But perhaps most importantly, as I have suggested previously, are consumer protection measures that ensure accommodation bonds and the standard of care are up to scratch. They are very important parts of this package.

Consumer protection is a central plank of the coalition's plan. A prudential scheme for accommodation bonds will be established. Contrast this with Labor's inaction. While we listen to the bleatings of the Labor shadow minister for scaring, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), we might well ask why, during Labor's 13 years in office, they failed to produce a single element of consumer protection for the entry contributions paid by people in hostels. Why have things suddenly changed in the 14½th year?

The coalition is also for the first time actually mandating—making it compulsory—for aged care accommodation providers to set aside a guaranteed percentage of beds, a national minimum of 27 per cent, for concessional residents, those financially disadvantaged people who do not have the means that some other members of our community have. If the need is assessed as being greater than this figure in Dunkley, this figure will be adjusted. Labor never did this either.

Concessional residents will also attract an additional subsidy of $5 per day, whether they are in a hostel or a nursing home under the new unified aged care system. Again, this is better than Labor's approach, which offered $3 for people in hostels as an extra subsidy.

In the parliament last year, I called on the government's new aged care assessment instrument to take account of sensory impairment and multiple disabilities. I have since been very pleased that the Minister for Family Services has granted $320,000 from the aged care support fund to the Association for the Blind, with $200,000 of this going towards a telephone support service allowing the association to promote and extend its services to all people suffering sensory loss. The government has also provided $100,000 to the National Centre for Ageing and Sensory Loss and a further $20,000 as a one-off grant for a study to investigate the future role of the centre.

I was hopeful of a more overt expression of the importance and the care implications of sensory loss and multiple disability in this package, but I have been assured that sensory impairment will be taken into account when the single classification instrument is applied. I am very encouraged by that.

The single classification instrument is one of the other important changes of the government's reforms. Put simply, this means that residents with similar care needs will be funded equally no matter what type of facility they live in. For the first time, dementia care needs will be properly identified and resourced. Currently, people with dementia are cared for in hostels and attract less funding than in nursing homes, even if their needs are similar.

Hand in hand with the introduction of a single residential classification unit is the coalition's move to a new quality assurance system. I endorse the minister's comments that giving the industry greater responsibility for its own quality assurance is the most appropriate way to achieve improvements. This is not a matter of taking an immediate big stick to the industry; rather providers have to shape up or ship out.

Working with aged care providers and developing realistic expectations to be implemented through the new Aged Care Standards Agency from January 1998 are good ways to achieve better quality in aged care accommodation. Of course, the government has flagged in its fact sheet that, unless accreditation can be delivered, Commonwealth funding will not be forthcoming into the future. It is a pretty impressive incentive to address some of those problems and the sorts of perceptions I shared earlier from my constituent.

As Professor Gregory indicated in his seminal review of the structure of nursing home funding arrangements, nursing home infrastructure has been in decline. To use the word `crisis' is no exaggeration.

To charge an accommodation bond under the government's proposals, services will need to meet the standards of building and care quality embraced by the accreditation system. The government is not imposing a $26,000 entry contribution, as those opposite seek to assert at times. This is nonsense. What is actually happening is that a non-compulsory accommodation bond may be asked of residents who can afford it, to be drawn down by not more than $2,600 a year for five years. For the residents who can afford it, they must be able to retain $22,000 of their own assets for a single person or $45,000 for a couple after they have been charged an accommodation bond they have agreed to. That is five times the amount of the annual pension.

The non-compulsory accommodation bond cannot be asked for unless the facility has reached prescribed standards. Residents who are in nursing homes on 1 July will not be asked for this accommodation bond, and short stay, non‐permanent residents of up to six months cannot be asked to pay a bond, although a means tested service charge may apply.

Current hostel residents remain subject to the arrangements in place before 1 July, with some caps on outgoings. For residents who leave a nursing home or pass away, they or their estates will receive any balance of the accommodation band that is owing to them.

People who move from one aged care accommodation facility to another will not have to pay a second bond. A set number of concessional residents to be accommodated within these facilities has been established.

I might add that it was this area where I probably had the most objection from a resident in my community. He was a fairly young man—I like to say that because he was around my age—who came in to my office and was quite appalled that the government would be seeking accommodation bonds from people who were able to afford them. As we talked around and the semantics were being shared about the basis of his concern, he finally shared with me what he was worried about. He was worried about the impact on his inheritance. That was more important to him than ensuring that his parents had the sort of care and support they needed. It was an appalling example of some of the sentiment that is behind objection to the accommodation bonds.

Entry contributions have worked well in hostels since 1988. Financially disadvantaged people have a higher than average chance of getting into a hostel and have so in the past. This gives the lie to Labor's claims that the coalition's changes will make it hard for people with few assets to obtain a bed in a nursing home. As was said by Labor's Gary Johns, a former minister, in his now famous letter to the Australian on 19 September last year:

. . . why should Kerry Packer be able to enter a nursing home for free? The fact is that the system already applies to hostels, so why not extend it to nursing homes? . . . the residential home is not an asset if the partner remains in it, or for instance if a disabled child needs it. . . the resident must always be left with an asset of at least 250 per cent of the pension, which is around $22,000.

Labor allowed millionaire nursing home residents to pay fixed, flat low fees. If the same person was in a hostel, they usually received less care but would pay more for it. The coalition believes that it is time to unify the different types of aged care facilities and make sure those who can afford it make a reasonable contribution towards their care. The two‐thirds of nursing home residents who receive the full age pension will pay no more in minimum daily fees than they pay now.

One other important issue is the security of residents' contributions in nursing homes. It would not be unnatural for older Australians who lost their life savings in the Pyramid Bank collapse to be concerned about how those funds were being managed. I welcome the minister's assurances that a mandatory prudential scheme will be introduced to protect residents if an aged care service provider experiences financial difficulty.

I am delighted that the industry itself recognises that standards have to improve. The National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals stated, in August 1996, that the government's changes will:
. . . overcome the matters long outstanding regarding the need to address the urgent capital upgrading of nursing homes.

The distinction between CAMs and SAMs will end from 1 July. This will help nursing home proprietors to spend more time on providing quality care and less on paperwork. However, to guard against misuse of public money, the validation program will continue until the middle of 1999.

Quality care for the aged is a priority of the coalition government. In 1997‐98 more than $3.7 billion is being spent: an increase of almost seven per cent—way above the predicted inflation rise over this next year.

When the minister visited Dunkley I reminded her of my interest in offering our senior citizens more choices. That is why I am so pleased that, in implementing the aged care structural reform package, the minister has listened and consulted widely. The four working groups she established comprise consumers, providers, staff and technical experts as well as academics. The date of implementation for aged care changes is fast approaching. On 1 July new doors will be opened for Dunkley's older citizens.

I would like to share with you the sorts of reactions I am getting from my local providers as I talk to them about the changes. I know my friend and colleague the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) has been busy consulting with his aged care facility providers also. Mr Frank Hoff, the Chief Executive Officer of George Vowell Home and Day Care Centre in Mount Eliza said:

At Brighton, the Association for the Blind already has a hostel . . . it has worked quite well . . . The trade‐off is that, with the entry contributions, we can provide facilities that we couldn't in any other way . . . The families at Mt Eliza are concerned as to how the new system will go.
We have been keen to provide them with additional information. To continue:
In 12 months time, people will understand the benefits of more staff and facilities while the Centre is still catering for the (concessional) residents.
Mr Brian Fitzpatrick from Benlynne Private Nursing Home in Nolan Street, Frankston, who is also Vice President of the Victorian Nursing Home & Extended Care Association, said:
The industry is absolutely looking forward to the changes . . . We are looking forward to the proper accreditation and professionalism that follows.

These changes will help the aged care sector to be more focused on outcomes rather than processes. The bill provides the foundation for senior citizens of our community to enjoy enhanced levels of security, dignity and comfort over the years to come. I congratulate the minister for her outstanding work in addressing another Labor problem left to us and I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill attempts to introduce dramatic change to the provision of aged care in our community. As is being seen in other social policy areas, this government's philosophical approach is being hidden in what I would call a smokescreen of financial gobbledegook. The reality is this: people generally do not choose to live in a nursing home. The comparison continually put before this House between nursing homes and hostels is quite misleading. A bed in a nursing home is a health requirement. Other alternatives at that point in the individual's life are not available.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister and members opposite can continue with these silly remarks of scare campaigns—and silly they are—for as long as they like but the community out there see through that lightweight, weak response. If you choose not to believe us, that is fine. But if you continue to choose to ignore the aged care sector, you do so at your peril. It is important that the records show the comments and the concerns coming from this area of important service delivery. I intend to do that.
I received a fax today from Aged Care Australia and I would like to quote some sections from this fax:

Despite six months of discussions, ACA still cannot confirm details of the application of the proposed Resident Classification Scale and therefore cannot determine the recurrent funding which will be available to a facility for the care of residents. The costs of Prudential arrangements are still unknown. The cost of the Accreditation Agency is unknown. The cost of Certification of existing buildings is being carried almost entirely by providers.
Further on it reads:

ACA also cannot support the Government's proposal that $5 per resident per day should be paid to providers as a so‐called incentive to provide access to low income residents. This subsidy is provided to enable providers to carry out needed improvements to the quality of buildings but this amount cannot possibly achieve this objective. Given the other changes which have been made to the funding mechanisms for aged care, this proposition is completely unacceptable.
It continues:
The concerns listed above are compounded by the fact that the final draft of subordinate legislation critical to implementation has not been sighted.
And finally:
As of today we have insufficient information about certain critical elements of the proposals and we cannot support the Government's proposal for the Concessional Resident Supplement.

I would now like to refer to a service provider very close to my own electorate. In fact, many of my residents have a great deal to do with Mirinjani Retirement Village at Weston. I received an urgent letter from them two or three days ago. It reads, in part, that Mirinjani Retirement Village wish:

. . . to express our deep concerns with the Government's announcement on Tuesday of the proposed recurrent supplement to be paid for concessional residents in residential aged care facilities. This daily rate will only be $5 a day and will place not‐for‐profit providers in an extremely difficult situation of being able to provide for this vulnerable group of older Australians. . . .

The amount of $5 a day equates to $1,825 a year, which is less than the allowable retention rate from an accommodation bond of $2,600. The concessional subsidy is not comparable with the accommodation bond.

This funding arrangement for aged care organisations has the strong potential to see the development of a two‐tiered care system, where one group will have access to modern facilities, and the other group housed in older and inferior accommodation.
It goes on:
This needs to at least equate to the accommodation bond retention rate of $2,600 per year. This would need to be $7.20 a day—
for the not‐for‐profit aged care organisations. That is from Mirinjani Retirement Village in Weston, Canberra, which is a multifaceted service provider for our aged.

BREAK.PARA: Another group that has come to my attention in the last week is the Australian Catholic Health Care Association. They have sent us a paper on behalf of the Alzheimers Association Australia, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, Baptist Care Australia, Churches of Christ Network of Aged Care Services, the Salvation Army and Community Services Australia—Uniting Church. The covering note from the Catholic Health Care Association includes this quote:

. . . the groups' concerns focus on people who are elderly and frail being further disadvantaged by being denied access to high quality services due to their income and asset limitations. The Aged Care Bill offers little guarantee that with the use of accommodation bonds older people on low incomes will have their right of access to quality residential aged care places.
Within the paper accompanying that and representing the group whose names I have just read out, under the heading `Impact on equity', they state:
A strong feature of the current system is its horizontal and vertical equity. Nursing home residents have equal access to the system regardless of income or assets.
They go on to say:

Under the new system, whilst income will not be a barrier other than entry into Exempt facilities (to be called `extra service places'), assets—or, in other words, the capacity to pay an Accommodation Bond—will.
