I have a couple more quotes, and I want to preface them by saying that it is terribly important that in this House we have the opportunity to put these things on record. This is not scaremongering from the opposition. These are comments from people—a lot of them fairly conservative groups in the world—who really have a view about what this Aged Care Bill is attempting to do to the care of our aged in our community.
I now have a paper in front of me dated 3 June from the Aged Services Association of New South Wales and the ACT Inc. I quote:

The Aged Services Association of NSW & ACT (ASA) today called on all Federal Members of Parliament, who will be debating the Government's proposed Aged Care Bill tomorrow, to argue for at least $12 a day in funding to support the care of those frail aged Australians who are financially disadvantaged.
They go on to say:

While ASA has welcomed the Minister's deferral of the introduction of the Government's major reforms to aged care from 1st July to 1st October, the Government's intention to debate the new legislation in the Lower House in the absence of the subordinate legislation and without knowing whether the model can be viable means that there can be no informed debate.

We ask all Federal MPs to ask Minister Moylan for details on the new prudential arrangements, the guidelines on the new classification scale, the cost of funding the new accreditation process, and how she will honour her commitment to review the effectiveness of the reform process.

The last paper I want to refer to today is from the Churches of Christ Homes and Community Services Inc. This is a fairly detailed paper sent some two to three weeks ago. They say at the beginning, `We plead with you to read the contents of this letter.' The writer of the letter is the Chief Executive of the organisation, Wayne Belcher. He says:
My fear for my residents and staff is that these changes will hurt many frail, dependent residents across Australia, their families and carers. These people live and die in your electorate.

He says that to the MPs to whom that letter is addressed. A further objection to this bill follows from the untargeted nature of this $5 per day subsidy. Labor's capital funding was targeted. It was directed at those institutions that needed it most and those people in the highest need. Under this bill, if no upgrade is required, or if the proprietor simply chooses, these taxpayer dollars—or proceeds of the sales of the pensioners' homes—need not go into capital upgrades. They can be taken as profit. Under Labor, capital funding for new and replacement not‐for‐profit hostels—90 per cent of hostels—was provided according to a targeted formula called variable capital funding. The emphasis was on enabling hostels to provide places for financially disadvantaged people. The proportion of financially disadvantaged people to be accommodated actually determined the level of capital grant payable.

In 1994, each FDP place attracted a build ing subsidy of $50,550 and a land subsidy of $7,300. The funding of non‐FDP places was linked to the funding of FDP places. Thus, as the number of FDP places increased, so did the number of other places funded. As for the allegation by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) earlier this week that the Labor government stubbornly refused to inject more capital into the aged care sector, I refer him to the department of health annual reports which show that up until 1995 Labor invested $1.2 billion dollars into capital expenditure on aged care.

To give but one direct piece of evidence to further illustrate that point, the Reverend Harry Herbert, Chair of Community Services Australia, in giving evidence before the recent Senate committee of inquiry into aged care, said:

. . . in the last two years, the Uniting Church in NSW has received for the construction of hostels, $7,736,750—a large sum of money. None of these projects in regard to hostels would have proceeded without those capital grants.
Please note, Prime Minister—capital grants. The Reverend Herbert went on to say in his evidence:
This legislation—that is, your Aged Care Bill—ends all those capital grants.

Labor believes that nursing home care should be available to all Australians on the basis of clinical need and not on the basis of how much money you have. The capital for nursing home upgrades should come from general revenue and be applied on a needs basis. If the government can give $2 billion in tax breaks to the wealthy, give itself a $1.4 billion re‐election slush fund in the form of the Natural Heritage Trust and give another $1.7 billion in health insurance tax breaks to wealthy people, it can afford the money which the aged care sector say is all that is needed to overcome their current problems.

I close by saying this: for the sake of our older Australians confronted by the need to enter a nursing home at the most vulnerable time of their lives, and that of their families, please rethink this and stop your economic madness. Pass the amendments which will be moved by the shadow minister and which have been foreshadowed. Do it for the sake of my electorate and the people in my electorate who have come to see me—individuals who have sat in my office, individuals with whom I have had conversations with in the supermarket, everywhere—and who are saying to me that the impost it is going to bring to their families is just over the top.

I do not think the government really realises to what degree the level of disappointment and dismay is now perpetrating out there amongst particularly our older people and our families in general. We should not be putting our families up for bartering for the sake of money. As I said a moment ago, entry into a nursing home should have nothing to do with that primarily. It should have a lot to do with whether or not you clinically need to go into that nursing home and, if you do, you should be able to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the changes that the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) is introducing with the Aged Care Bill. I think it is long overdue. After having listened to the previous speaker, I can only think that those in opposition are living in a different world. There are many sensible and significant changes being proposed in this bill. One of the main and symbolic ones is that we are going to merge, for the first time, hostels and nursing homes—put them under the one roof, so to speak—over a period of time. I think that will be very beneficial indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: It has many side benefits. I see cases where a married couple are both in a hostel. One deteriorates in health and has to move to a nursing home. The couple has to be split up because one has to be moved away. That is very tragic. There is no logic to it. That will cease under this bill. We also have the situation in my electorate where many hostels have in them people who should really be classified as needing to be in nursing homes. There are high percentages of them. This artificial barrier, which is long overdue to be changed, will break down. That is a good thing.

The instrument that will drive this is the new residential classification scale, which means that people will be funded according to their care needs rather than their means. There will be eight funding categories and people can be upgraded as their health deteriorates over a period of time. That is the logical way to go with patients.

One of the most exciting things in the new package is the way the minister is dealing with dementia care. This has been a long‐neglected area. Those with dementia have been funded in the past according to their overall physical health, which is often good. These people are ambulatory; they can move around. But in a hostel or nursing home situation, they can cause great disruption.

Under the assessment of these people, the weighting given to dementia will effectively double. I think it moves from eight percentage points up to about 18 percentage points. I am told this will mean that, in practice, funding for dementia patients will increase by 30 per cent or more. This will mean that some aged person accommodation facilities will be able to specialise wholly or partially in dementia care. If they do so partially, for example, they can put on a dementia wing so that these types of people can be contained within that wing and not interfere with other patients in the facility.

The accommodation bond, or the old entry fee, has received a great deal of criticism from the opposition as they have run their scare campaign over recent months. That is unfortunate, and to some extent it is hypocritical. Entry fees for hostels have been introduced by the Labor Party for almost a decade in this country. Because we are putting hostels and nursing homes under the same roof, we are just extending this entry fee to nursing homes. There is nothing remarkable about it at all. In fact, entry fees—now to be called accommodation bonds—have worked very well in hostels. They have worked very well for the providers as they have given them some capital to keep hostels upgraded. You have only to compare the standard of most hostels with nursing homes to see the difference that the fees have made.

In the 12½ years that I have been a member of parliament, I have never received one complaint from one constituent about entry fees into hostels. In fact, I was curious to see what was charged. In my main centre of Dubbo, I asked all the providers about that. The entry fees that were charged for hostel accommodation ranged from zero to $200,000. So, if people are well‐off, they pay something; if they cannot afford it, they still get accommodation anyhow. It worked very well. It was supported by the Labor Party and it was supported by the coalition. Nobody batted an eyelid about it. Now we are extending it to nursing home type patients and suddenly the sky is apparently going to fall in. It is totally beyond me as to why this would be. I can only put it down to a misleading scare campaign.

Apparently there is now charged across Australia an average entry fee into hostels of $26,000. If that is going to be the Australian average to get into an aged care facility in the future, for most people absolutely nothing changes whatsoever. I stress that, in respect of nursing home type patients, under the new arrangements for anybody who is in a nursing home now the arrangements will not change at all. You will not be charged an entry fee. So those people will be quarantined from any fee.

Also, anyone coming into a nursing home type situation will not have to pay anything for the first six months. So, if you move out, or if you pass on, obviously no payment will be made in that area. To that extent, it is more lenient than what has existed for people who have entered hostel accommodation over the last decade or so in this country.

Also it is a fee that the government does not impose on anyone. It is purely up to the provider as to whether they charge it or not and there will be some very strict rules put in place as to how it will be administered. An amount of money roughly equivalent to 2½ times the pension must be left in the patient's bank account. At the moment, for a single pensioner that is about $22,500 and something close to double that for married couples.

Nobody at all is going to be forced to sell their home. So, if you have a spouse still living in your home, that spouse can continue to live in that home. If you have a carer or a close relative who has been looking after you for a period of time, they may stay in that home. But, if it is obvious that you have the means to make a contribution towards your upkeep in aged person's accommodation, you will be expected to pay something. That is only fair and just when there is such a shortfall in the funding that is needed for aged person accommodation facilities. That has been the case, as I say, with hostels for the last decade or so. It has worked very well in the past and it will continue to work very well in the future.

Of any accommodation bond that is paid, only $2,600 a year can be drawn down permanently for the use of the owner or provider of the aged person accommodation facility, and then only each year for a five‐year period. So a maximum withdrawal would be $13,000 over five years. It would actually be over 5½ years because you are not charged for the first six months. So, after you leave the facility or you pass on, the remaining amount is returned to your estate. It will be protected by strict prudential requirements.

It is interesting, and unfortunate, that the average stay in nursing home accommodation is in the order of only three years. So, if you did not pay anything for the first six months, after 2½ years only $6,500 would have been taken out of any accommodation bond that was paid anyhow and the rest would be returned to your estate. So these are quite modest sums indeed. Of course, the providers of the facility would have the use of the interest on the accommodation bond to upgrade and maintain a higher standard that has existed in the past for you, the patient, to live in.

So it will be your money being spent for your benefit. Again, I think that is the only logical way to go because, as has been stated earlier in the debate, and it is worth stating again, there is a capital funding crisis in nursing home type accommodation now in Australia: 11 per cent of them are not up to speed as far as fire standards go, 15 per cent of them are behind on health standards and 40 per cent of the facilities have four or more people in the same room.

Professor Gregory, who did the study initiated by the previous government, said that you would need an injection of capital fund ing in the order of $125 million a year to bring the upgrading up to the standard it should be before you even think of providing for extra places. Apparently, the previous government's response to this was to provide $10 million a year, which obviously is totally inadequate.

There are other changes that we are proposing too. Under the old system, there was far too much red tape and bureaucracy and the acquittal procedures were far too onerous. Providers had to account for virtually every staff minute of every day. Those will be simplified greatly, and I am sure that will be welcomed by the providers of these facilities.

We also look at financially disadvantaged people, who are going to be called concessional residents. On average Australia-wide, there are 27 per cent of these people in such facilities. So we will make it a requirement that each facility has to take, on average, 27 per cent of concessional residents. Obviously, this will vary from region to region and the percentage for each region will be set.

We will be giving an extra $1,825 a year, I believe, which will go towards the upkeep of these residents over and above what the providers will be getting from the government otherwise. I think the previous government was giving something in the order of $3 for those in hostels, nothing in nursing homes. We will be giving $5 in the first instance, and I hope that will be extended in future years to everybody. So I think that is very good indeed.

One section in this bill which I am particularly pleased to see is the viability funding. Small services in remote and isolated areas will receive a viability subsidy. This will be paid in addition to the care subsidies. For facilities in isolated areas that have 15 or fewer places, that will work out at $16.25. For those with up to 29 people in their facility, that will be reduced to $10, and so it goes down a scale whether you are in an isolated area, a remote area or a rural area outside the large centres. It varies between $1 and $16.25. It will make those viable. In addition, we are also providing $40 million over four years in capital grants so that rural and remote areas can upgrade, which I think is very good indeed.

In the time remaining to me, I want to make some comments particularly pertinent to my electorate about the formula of how areas are allocated places. The present formula as it exists is 100 places allocated for each thousand of population over the age of 70 years. Those 100 places are broken up into 40 nursing home places, 50 hostel places and 10 community aged care packages.

Because nursing homes and hostels will be going under the one roof, that figure of 40 and 50 will become 90 and that will give the facilities much more flexibility. They can have all nursing home type patients if they wish; they can have all hostel type patients if they wish; they can have dementia patients if they wish. That will be a great assistance.

What I want to raise over and above the issue of the viability funding and the capital funding for rural and remote areas is a particular problem that exists in country areas. If you are an aged person that needs to go into such a facility in the city, in your suburb, and there is not a place available for you, what happens? You go out to the next suburb that can accommodate you—which may be five or 10 or, at the most, 15 or 20 kilometres away—and you look there. If you work through half a dozen suburbs, eventually you will find a facility that can accommodate you. So, sure, you may not find a place exactly where you live, but you are not that far away—only 10 or 15 kilometres—and your relatives can still visit you, and the system works very well indeed. But if you are in the bush, that is not so.

If you live in a town like Cobar, for example, in my electorate and there are no places available—as there are not at the moment in Cobar—the next available places happen to be in Brewarrina, which is several hundred kilometres away. To ship people out of a country town hundreds of kilometres away to another town when they are in the twilight of their life, in a frail condition, when their health is failing, is a cruel and distressing thing to do. Even though Cobar has a population of 7,000 people, it happens to have 14 nursing home places and 14 hostel places. Because it has a low number of people—not much in excess of 200—over the age of 70, the number of places they have got makes them about 35 per cent over quota. So in all conscience I, as the local member, cannot ask for more places.

Nyngan, which is only a hundred‐odd kilometres away, does not have any nursing home places at all. People from Nyngan have to be next on the list for when places become available. It means that they have to be shipped several hundred kilometres away. It is almost a sentence of death. Their relatives are not able to visit them as much as they could if they could get a place nearby. These people pine, they do not do well. It is a great problem. In Broken Hill, it is even worse. The nearest place to go to is Adelaide, 550 kilometres away; Sydney is 1,200 kilometres away. So there is no easy solution. If you come from Tibooburra, which is 330 kilometres from Broken Hill, you have got an even greater problem. What do we do about this? How do we overcome it?

In a lot of country towns, if there is a hospital with spare beds, they put these people in that hospital on a temporary basis until a position falls due in one of the aged care facilities. That is not totally satisfactory, but it is better than being shipped out several hundred kilometres away. That is all very well. But in many instances these people are clogging up the hospitals. In Nyngan, for example, where there are no nursing home facilities, 50 per cent of the hospital is full of these people.

In Broken Hill, which has 111 nursing home places—that is slightly over quota for the number of nursing home places—30 per cent of the hospital is full of aged care people. There is nothing wrong with that, in a sense, except that it is messing up the surgical list. It is very difficult to attract surgeons to Broken Hill as it is, let alone to have their surgical lists constantly disrupted because there are not enough beds in the hospital. So there is a problem there. Again, I say, `How do we overcome it?'

You could probably have a situation whereby health board areas were allocated a number of bed places which could be moved from town to town according to a town's need. You will usually find that shire councils are willing to make available, at a cost to them—no cost to the taxpayer—the capital funding to provide these places. The Commonwealth would only be up for the recurrent funding which, for a nursing home type person, is in the order of $30,000 a year. So instead of moving a person out from Cobar to Brewarrina, they could stay in Cobar. There would be no greater cost to the government, because if the person went to Brewarrina the Commonwealth would still be up for the recurrent funding. But even that is not totally satisfactory.

I think we have to have a proper debate in this country, to get more funds for aged person accommodation places. To shift that formula of 90 places per 1,000 people over the age of 70 is going to be incredibly expensive indeed. Just to lift it from 90 to 100, let alone from 90 to 110, with the ageing population we have in this country and the greater expectation for these sorts of beds, hundreds of millions of dollars would be needed. Hundred of millions of dollars are not there in the budget. So we either have to have increased taxes or a special Medicare levy or a rejigging of the priority of spending in this country. It is going to be a major shift, but it has to be done and it will have to be faced up to in the next five to 10 years in this country, if not immediately. I would like to flag that debate in this country. We have to have it. For too long we have flick‐passed this responsibility that we have. If we are going to call ourselves a civilisation, we have to look after the elderly, who have given us the standard of living that we enjoy. We have to ensure that they can be looked after in a proper manner in the twilight years of their life.

TALK.START.PARA: —In no other area of policy yet presented by the Howard government have we seen displayed such a flawed proposal based on flawed ideology as we have seen in these proposals for nursing home care. Even though I describe this as a flawed proposal, matters are compounded by the fact that it is being implemented with such flawed methodology.

BREAK.PARA: In fairness to the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), this morning the House had an opportunity to give her time to take this bill away and to ensure that answers could be given to a number of matters that remain unclear in the government's proposal. Some of these matters that were mentioned in the motion that was defeated earlier today were: consideration of the prudential arrangements that would be put in place to safeguard the residents' up‐front entry fees; details of the classification instruments; consideration of an independent body to monitor the numbers of concessional residents and exempt beds that would be provided by regions; consideration or explanation of mechanisms for accountability for the use of the funds; and a rethink on the proposed $5 per day capital subsidy for concessional residents. I know that it is against the standing orders to reflect upon a decision of this place, but the opposition tried to give the government an out, an opportunity to consider these matters.

Another aspect of this debate that has concerned me is the galling notion from those opposite that the Labor governments under Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating had neglected aged care; that the `crisis' of nursing home care is an indication of 13 years of neglect under Labor. The past 15 months have taught me a lesson. When you are in government for 13 years, you have a record. When you have been in government for 13 years, in some areas you can have form. If you have been in government for 13 years, in some areas you can have pride. But in aged residential care there is nothing that Labor should be ashamed of about its achievements in government.

Another thing I was careful to do was to reflect upon other contributions that I have made over the years about aged care to ensure that in my contribution to this debate today I did not trip up by contradicting myself. One of the interesting things I found in doing this investigation was that in 1986, when I first spoke on aged care in the House of Representatives, aged care was in a parlous state. There were inequities that revolved about the way in which residential care was provided to aged people and people with disabilities.

There had been a series of inquiries that established and benchmarked where we were at at that stage. There was the expenditure committee report under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). One always has to mention the honourable member for Watson, the Chief Opposition Whip. I do not wish to blatantly curry favour, but in this regard the McLeay report was very much an important aspect of the debate at the time.

In the Senate there was the Giles report and there was a review conducted as a result of an initiative by the then Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes. In the contribution I made in 1986, I referred to the nursing homes and hostels review. I want to mention a couple of things about the state of this sector at that time. I quoted the review stating:
Government, deficit‐financed and participating non-profit homes predominate in low socio‐economic areas.
The report further stated:
. . . there are considerably more participating‐for‐profit homes in high status areas.

My great fear is that the brave new world of aged care envisaged by the present government will return us to this type of situation; that as the years go on, if their version of aged care is implemented, we will have yet again developed a two-tier system.

This piece of legislation perhaps more than any other represents the mean‐spiritedness of the government. It has been condemned by a wide range of groups involved in aged care in Australia. For instance, just today Aged Care Australia announced that it cannot support the passage of this legislation. Aged Care Australia, the largest provider group of residential aged care services in Australia, representing 1,300 hostels and nursing homes, states that:
The government has provided insufficient information for our members to be confident that the proposals are viable . . .
This is from an organisation which admits that it might support the thrust of the government's changes. Aged Care Australia goes on state:
ACA can only give its support for the Aged Care Bill when we have full knowledge and understanding of the proposals, and when we are confident about the provision of appropriate funding.

That goes directly to the heart of my comments about the implementation being a flawed methodology. The ACA statement indicates the widespread dissatisfaction with this piece of legislation, whether it be due to its flaws or because of the injustice it represents. The government still has not framed any arrangements to protect people's entry contributions. The legislation is before us, and there is no framework yet in place.

The government has still not worked out what the auditing procedures to formally monitor the quality of care in nursing homes will be. The bill does not mention the ratio of paid beds to concessional beds. There is nothing about the classification instrument used to determine the rate of residential care subsidy. The government is treating the parliament with contempt by asking the House to consider this legislation with so many unanswered questions.

In the absence of all this information, there is a great deal of concern in the community. Despite this, the government has the cheek to call the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) the shadow minister for scaring because she has been vocal in pointing out the deficiencies in this legislation. However, it is the uncertainty created by the government's own contradictions in the legislation that has concerned and even scared people. The injustices in this legislation are glaringly obvious. The government claims that no-one will be forced to sell their homes, yet the legislation specifically includes the family home as an asset.

The government cannot have it both ways. If it wanted to guarantee that no-one would have to sell their homes, it could have excluded them from any assets test. However, the minister and the government members themselves cannot seem to agree on the implications for the family home. Since the entry contribution was announced, a string of government members have stood in this place and guaranteed that no-one will have to sell their homes to get into a nursing home. Then today in this debate the member for Hind marsh (Mrs Gallus) asked whether it would really be so bad if the family home had to be sold. I can assure her that, to the majority of constituents in my electorate, it would be. Later in the debate the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) said that no-one would have to sell their homes, but then added that it was not really the family home any more because no-one lived there.

The minister and government members who have stated publicly that no-one need sell their homes must be aware that the opposition will hold them to this guarantee. They will be called to explain themselves when the first sales occur.

The sale of the family home is not the only injustice in this bill. The government fails to fundamentally understand that hostels are completely different from nursing homes. Hostels are an accommodation option. Nursing homes are about care. This issue is about access to care. If the government is so concerned about the condition of Australia's nursing homes, why did it decide to slash around $577 million from aged care in the 1996 budget? The government's primary concern was to reduce funding for aged care and transfer this to the users of the nursing homes. It should not be deceitful and claim that it does this to upgrade buildings or to provide services.

If we look at the proposal that is contained in this policy, we see that there is no upper limit on the size of the entry contribution. There is really no idea how much a place in a nursing home will cost. The government argues that there is a crisis in nursing home capital stock and that this is the justification for the entry fee. Yet the legislation does not even require this. In addition, the interest earned on the entry fee is kept by the nursing home and can also be taken purely as profit.

It is these contradictions in this poorly thought out bill that are causing angst in the community. The government should not try to put this one on the opposition. The community concern is justified and has been created entirely by the government. The government has been putting out this furphy that their nursing home policy is simply an extension of the previous Labor government's hostel policy. The government says this as if hostels are interchangeable with nursing homes. One of the essential ingredients of their policy is the amalgamation of nursing homes and hostels into a single care institution.

While there are people in the aged care sector who have little objection to such an amalgamation, it is the proposal that the hostel funding system can be simply transferred over to apply to nursing homes that is really at the heart of the opposition's objections.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has alleged that Labor should be supporting the bill because it is `modelled on one of your measures'. In other words, we should support this because the system of nursing home entry will be the same for nursing homes as we introduced for hostels. As has been explained time and again but has still been ignored by the government, nursing homes and hostels are different in the way people come to enter them and in the type of people who live in them. They were created separately and set up with different funding mechanisms for this reason.

As I have said, hostels are about accommodation. The government has that much right. But nursing homes are about care. People take months to decide to move into a hostel and make all the arrangements to do so. But nursing home entry is not about choice; it is about getting care and, in some cases, getting it fast in days or even hours. It is out of necessity. More than of 60 per cent of those entering nursing homes come from an acute hospital after a serious illness such as a stroke. Many are also suffering from some degree of dementia. A less appropriate condition for engaging in negotiations over the size of entry fees and the sale of one's house is hard to imagine.

I stress that access to nursing homes is not a choice. It is based on need. At the heart of the opposition's concerns here is the government's proposal that much of the regulation and operation of the aged care sector be left up to market forces. There is absolutely no way that Labor would have adopted the uncapped entry fee and market forces model of the government.

Like Professor Gregory, Labor believes that market forces are inappropriate regulators of care. The inquiry that is referred to quite often by government speakers and the minister is the Gregory inquiry, which investigated the capital funding needs of nursing homes. The government fails to mention Professor Gregory's comments about vehicles for raising the funds. One of the vehicles that Professor Gregory has said was not appropriate was the type of up‐front entry contribution that the government will now be putting in place. Why champion the factual information about the need for capital improvements against the indication that a model that has been suggested for getting some form of additional funding is flawed?

To understand why the government has fallen into this minefield of its own making, it is necessary to understand the real motivation behind the bill. In the first place, the Howard government's major and overriding interest in aged care is to reduce the amount of money spent on older Australians. The 1996 budget cut more than half a billion dollars—$577 million—from aged care over four years. Here the savings were made by: reducing outlays on capital commitments, $244 million; reducing subsidies paid to nursing homes for care, $253 million; and introducing user charging for HACC, $72 million. Thus, it must be stressed that the Howard government's primary consideration is saving money, not necessarily concern for building upgrades or provision of services for older Australians.

The philosophic underpinning of the government's policy on aged care can be found in the report of the National Commission of Audit. This report raised concerns about the pressure on government expenditure resulting from the ageing of the population, especially expenditure on health care, nursing home care and the age pension. The commission recommended greater reliance on user charging, introduction of more competition and devolution of services to the states. The report suggested that that last point alone will save 10 per cent. The report also recommended the introduction of entry and exit fees for nursing homes.

But the National Commission of Audit report gives no explanation about the basis to the conclusions that that audit came to on nursing homes. It is a very scant document which is very silent about the methodology that was used by the audit to come to the conclusions. Even worse, because of the government's decision not to make a formal response to the National Commission of Audit, there has been no explanation as to why the government has adopted this proposal contained within the National Commission of Audit report. As I have said in relation to issues other than nursing homes, in the absence of a formal response to the National Commission of Audit report the government is just successively, especially in budgets, implementing some of the suggestions that were placed in the National Commission of Audit report.

The desire to cut government spending on aged care and to follow the edicts of the National Commission of Audit are behind this bill—not the spurious claims of the Minister for Family Services that there is some crisis in aged care that must be addressed. As Professor Gregory puts it:

Entering a nursing home is a time of considerable vulnerability and little choice for most people . . . market forces could do little to ameliorate the psychological impact of being forced to consider an entry contribution at the point of entering a nursing home.

Other aspects of the amalgamation of hostels and nursing homes need to be considered. For instance, what happens when a person living in a stand-alone hostel, which is predominantly what we have in my electorate, is properly assessed as requiring a level of care akin to what we now would understand to be nursing home care, which requires a level of formal nursing intervention in the care of a person? How does the hostel go about supplying that level of care for a particular individual who might be one out? How does a stand-alone hostel make the adequate changes to the capital infrastructure of that hostel to cater for people who live in the hostels but move to that level of care requirement? These types of questions need to be answered by the government before this procedure is implemented.

We also need to know the answer to, as the shadow minister put it, the catch-22 situation of aged care centres getting certain classifications. An aged care centre has to be classified in a certain way to be allowed to charge the up-front entry contribution in the form of an accommodation bond but, if it is in need of capital infrastructure improvements to get that classification, it will not get the classification and it cannot charge the accommodation bond. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are few things that this government is doing that make me more proud to be a member of it than this. I went into public life for a number of reasons. I have an unfinished agenda, you might say, but not far from the top of it was substantial reform in the way that Australia's aged residential care sector is financed.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that in many ways our country, despite changes in the last year, is still at five minutes to midnight. To put it into perspective, just under five per cent of us will eventually need some form of residential aged care. In the absence of a cure, about eight per cent of us over the age of 75 will eventually suffer from dementia. At the moment, about 13.3 per cent of us are over the age of 65; by the year 2050, almost a third of us will be older than 65.

Referring, as the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) did, to the National Commission of Audit report produced by Professor Bob Gregory—a report I commend to all honourable members—at the moment the aged dependency ratio in Australia is 5.3 to 1. That means that there are 5.3 Australians between the ages of 15 and 64 for every person over the age of 64 or under the age of 15. Over the next 40 years that ratio will go, according to the present population growth, to 2.6 to one.

Last year, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, there were 7.8 million Australians who were working and paying taxes to support 6.2 million Australians who were relying, most through no fault of their own, on some form of social security benefit. In the absence of some change in the way that we raise finances, as I said in the Main Committee only a short time ago, and also in the way in which we structure our essential expenditures in health, education and welfare, those trend lines will cross within a decade.

This reform that the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and the government are introducing and are determined to see to an end is about vision. It is about where Australia is going to be in the year 2030. It is about ensuring that we have a sustainable, affordable residential aged care sector and one in particular in which you, I or any other member of this House would be quite happy to live.

This reform is also about changing cultural expectations, and this is where I think many on our side differ from those on the other: we are saying to younger Australians, people perhaps in my generation, that they cannot blow all their money on holidays and nice cars; they actually have to start making some provision and giving some thought to who will be financing their care when they reach an age where perhaps they are going to need it. That, in a broad sense, is what the principle, the philosophy and, I dare say, the need for this kind of legislation are all about.

In government, the Australian Labor Party went to the 1996 election with a policy on care for older people. There were 210 words on Australia's future in residential aged care. I am not normally one that engages in ideological invective, but I will quote that policy directly. It says:

Labor recognises that there are some issues to be addressed around hostel funding and the classification system in relation to dementia care needs. Labor will pursue structural reform of the hostel sector to improve funding for dementia care in particular and higher care needs generally to be implemented from 1996 to 1997.

For those of us who are accustomed to reading political party policies—as I am, both from the outside of the parliament and indeed from inside it—that is code for the fact that the ALP, if it had been returned to office, would have done very much what we are doing now. Whilst many of the honourable and decent members, like the member for Scullin, would disagree with that, I have little doubt that it was on the agenda for most of those who are knowledgeable about what is required in aged care.

Before I turn specifically to some of the details of the bill, perhaps I ought to remind the House that, in the budget, the government actually increased the amount of money available for aged care by just under six per cent. Home and community care funding was increased by just over six per cent. But members are quite right to point out that we are introducing a user‐pays system on a means tested basis for those who can afford it. That money can be spent only on the care of the people who will be contributing to it.

The government is introducing a rigorous planning system which will cover services to people in their own homes, services in residential care for people with low care needs and people with high care needs. I suspect, from reading the 210 words in the Labor Party's policy platform, we are also unifying the residential classification instrument, which means ageing in place and allows for the capacity of providers to either provide a range of services or specialise in particular areas, such as dementia.

Concessional residents are people who do not have to pay an accommodation bond, or at least would not be eligible for consideration of paying a bond, and full‐time or part-time pensioners who have not owned their home in the past two years and who have assets less than $22,500 a year. For a married resident, only half of the couple's combined assets are to be counted.

There are also to be assisted residents, and they are those who can pay only a small bond, for which a higher daily subsidy will be paid by the government. Providers who do not meet the quota for concessional residents will face deductions from their subsidy. In other words, funding will not be provided for places that concessional residents should have occupied.

Vulnerable concessional residents will be protected, more so than they are now under the present system. Aged care assessment teams will assess and prioritise prospective residents in a multidisciplinary manner on the basis of need. No-one is going to go into a care institution on the basis of anything other than need, because the ACATs, as they are known, will continue to fill the role that they currently do. People who cannot afford a bond will not be asked to pay a bond and those who are eligible have no compulsion placed upon them to do so.

Referring to the Labor Party model introduced into the hostel sector in 1988, 40 per cent of eligible people—people who were eligible to pay a bond—have not paid a bond. The resident going in and their family, or their lawyer, or whoever they may choose to negotiate on their behalf, have up to six months to negotiate that bond. That bond may be paid within that six‐month period and go into some prudential trust arrangements, which I will cover in a moment. That bond may be paid as a higher weekly, fortnightly or monthly payment or it may be taken as a debt against the estate of that person should they pass on.

At the moment, the reality of the situation is that only four per cent of people in nursing homes return home, in most cases to die. A person may negotiate a situation where the family home is maintained, they maintain ownership of it, and the bond, or at least the necessary draw down and interest that would have been paid on that bond, is paid from that person's estate once they have passed on. As I said earlier, it is worth remembering that there will be people eligible to pay a bond who will not in fact pay one at all.

The third thing is that there will be a quota of 27 per cent applied to concessional residents. Importantly, in applying that quota, there will also be regional variations. So in some parts of Australia where it is clear that a higher quota may be required the department will negotiate with providers and state government agencies to allow for a higher quota. There will also be a higher daily payment of $5, about which we have heard so much, that will be paid for concessional residents.

Understandably, there are those who say, `If a draw down is $2,600 a year, six months in arrears, that would amount to $7 a day. So why isn't the government paying a concess ional subsidy of $7 a day?' The answer to that is, firstly, that they are working on the assumption that everyone will pay an accommodation bond, and they will not. Secondly, the assumption put by the opposition, and some people in the aged care sector who should know better, is that everybody will be paying a maximum draw down of $2,600 a year. In fact, there will be residents who will pay only a very small bond and their drawn down will be considerably less than $2,600 a year.

The daily level of capital depreciation, as calculated by the department, is $4.62 a day. I think $5 is quite a reasonable and an adequate level at which to commence concessional payments. We should also keep in mind that the entire bill and its implementation is the subject of constant review and negotiation between providers and those who represent the interests of older Australians and those of us who are getting there. Eligible smaller services in regional Australia will receive a viability subsidy and may be eligible for a viability subsidy on top of the concessional resident subsidy in recognition of the higher costs that they incur and the economies of scale that they do not enjoy.

Prudential arrangements are important and they are enshrined in this bill to protect accommodation bonds. There are three components to the prudential arrangements. Firstly, the facilities must maintain a minimum level of assets in a liquid form so that bonds can be repaid as residents leave. Secondly, an industry fund will be established into which providers will pay a proportion of bonds to act as a lender of last resort should a provider's liquidity prove to be insufficient. Thirdly, insurance will provide coverage against particularly large claims and prevent the fund from becoming eroded.

Specialist financial, actuarial and legal expertise is now developing the detail, with the government constantly also seeking the views of provider organisations and consumers. I do not think any legitimate provider or consumer organisation in this country could nominate an area of government activity that has been the subject of more rigorous and constant feedback by government than this one.

The bill also provides for ministerial discretion for approving alternative prudential arrangements in exceptional cases, which may involve some of the church and charitable organisations. Whilst I have a very high regard for that sector, I think that most of us in modern society are aware that not every organisation is necessarily beyond these kinds of prudential arrangements.

The prudential costs will present some cost to providers, but is that not part of the responsibility that is attached to the privilege of being able to charge accommodation bonds? I do not think it is unreasonable that providers pay a small amount and have a financial interest in seeing the prudential arrangements work, and work well.

In regard to the resident classification instrument, at the moment about 40 per cent of hostel residents have care needs that should see them in a nursing home. Under the current arrangements neither they nor the provider is reimbursed adequately for their care. The new instrument, which has been trialled with 20,000 residents in 400 facilities, will not only more equitably finance what have been hostel and nursing home services, now leading to their amalgamation, but it will also enable ageing in place to occur. So if someone has been in a nursing home for three or four years and suffers a stroke or some other intellectual or physical disability and is then required to relocate to a nursing home, under these proposals, once they go into the institution, whatever happens to them, they will be able to remain there. Equally, if not more importantly, when a husband and a wife go in after 40, 50 or even 60 years of marriage it means that both of them can stay in the same institution and neither will be required to move.

The legislation will also allow long overdue increased funding for dementia. Providers will now attract appropriate funding for those people suffering from dementia and currently cared for in hostels. All existing residents already in an aged care facility when the bill takes effect will remain on their existing classification and only when that expires will they be assessed under the new scale. This will be after 12 months for nursing home residents and after six months for those currently in hostels.

BREAK.PARA: There are eight care categories in the new resident classification instrument. All but level 8 will attract a level of funding. Two broad bands will exist, the lower care level category being from categories 5 to 8 inclusive. Twenty-two questions will lead to the allocation of a waiting and subsequent classification of the resident. This is nothing new for those who run and work within nursing homes. ACATS will not be involved in classification but those aged care assessment teams will be involved in the reassessment of those in lower band categories for whom it is considered re‐allocation or reclassification may be necessary.

Training will be and is being provided to providers. All 3,000 residential aged care facilities across Australia will be offered training in a number of locations around the country. One day sessions will be offered on aspects of the reform, but in particular the new RCI, a home study kit being sent in advance.

Importantly in this bill we are also establishing the Aged Care Standards Agency. This has involved providers, consumers and government in its development. Independent assessment of quality of care will be provided and monitored by ACATS. There will be regular publishing of reports on issues of quality and access and waiting times.

For the first time in the nursing home sector we are now going to have residents and their families, and perhaps their lawyers, standing at the door of a nursing home being asked to pay an accommodation bond if they are eligible. They will be saying: `If you think that I am going to pay a $20,000 or $30,000 accommodation bond to come into this institution you have got another think coming.' In other words, the families, whom I have found have had a very real interest in the financial affairs of their ageing relatives, will be saying: `I do not know if this is the sort of place I want my mother to be in. I don't know whether she should invest $30,000 in this and possibly be subject to a means tested daily fee.' In other words, the consumer is going to have a very real financial interest in the quality of what is being provided, as well as the Aged Care Standards Agency.

The way to ensure proper nursing care, by the way, is not through any structural or legislative program, but rather a program that ensures that standards are being met. Action will be taken against those who reduce levels of care. Apart from anything else, they will not be able to charge an accommodation bond. Amounts derived from bonds have to be used, can only be used, on the care of the very person who is paying the bond. It can only be spent on improving and maintaining the capital of the home in which that person is living.

The bond can only be charged by a facility which has been accredited, which has met the necessary standards. The standard will be raised progressively over time. That will mean that providers will have to keep investing in their building to make sure that he or she can continue to charge a bond. Labor, in contrast, did not stop hostel providers under their system from charging accommodation bonds for substandard accommodation.

These changes are about the future. Governments, I think justifiably, are frequently accused of thinking only in terms of short-term political cycles. Those on the other side who are engaged in political opportunism at the moment need to hose themselves down a little and have a think about the kind of Australia that we are all—Labor or Liberal—going to be living in in 2020. If the government of the day does not have the political courage and intestinal fortitude to implement these reforms and do it now, then we are abrogating our responsibilities to the next and subsequent generations.

When you look at Bob Gregory's report in 1994 and you consider that we then had to spend $1 billion bringing nursing home capital up to fire, health, outcome and design standards, when you consider that almost 40 per cent of residents in residential aged care institutions at the moment live with at least three other people, when you consider the demands of the generation behind them who have been accustomed to a standard of living that those currently in homes did not enjoy—those who lived through the Depression and went to wars and did other things to make this country what it currently is—and when you consider what the next generation's expectations are, you realise that these reforms should have been made in 1988 when the Labor government, to its real credit, introduced reforms into the hostel sector.

Also, the point ought be made that, if this government were only about populism, do you think we would be doing this? If we were simply about appealing to primitive electoral instincts in people, don't you think that we would succumb to some of the populist nonsense that is being spread by some on the other side? Instead, the government is about making sure that we have a future in which older people get the care that they deserve and expect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) as the Labor Party has serious reservations and grave concerns about the impact of this particular piece of legislation. First of all, to understand what this legislation is all about, you have to understand when it was announced and what it is really intended to do. It was announced on budget night last year. It is all about cutting back federal spending on aged care by half a billion dollars because the forward estimates produced in last year's budget show that in the first four years the budget will save $577 million as a result of the changes announced in this particular package of legislation and in one other change announced in last year's budget which also reduces federal spending on aged care.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is driven not by some intention to upgrade the standard or quality of our nursing homes, as every government speaker has claimed in the debate; it is about trying to cut back federal expenditure on providing quality aged care for elderly Australians. I will explain that in some detail later in my speech. The government says that it is about trying to cut back government spending. So why isn't the government quite open and honest about its intentions? I think there would perhaps be greater acceptance in the wider community if the government was open and up‐front about admitting what is really driving these reforms. It is not about improving the quality of nursing homes; it is about saving Mr Howard a few dollars so that we can package up some nice election promise come the next election.

When you realise that the failed savings rebate—which gives the directors of BHP $450 and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) $450 in this year's budget—would more than pay for the cutbacks that will be implemented by this legislation, and, if redirected into aged care, would obviate the need for all of this, then that makes it quite clear that the government's priorities are quite misdirected.

These measures introduce two major changes. The first is the imposition of the up‐front entry fee or the up‐front accommodation bond, as the government calls it. The imposition of this uncapped, new, up‐front entry fee is going to mean that wealthy people who can afford to pay very large up‐front fees are going to have access to the best nursing homes beds. It is going to mean that those people who are less well off and are not able to provide that accommodation bond, that up‐front entry fee, are going to be relegated to the back of the queue. They will be the elderly Australians who are left with the poorest level of care in the poorest quality nursing homes.

The second measure that is implemented with this legislation is the imposition of additional daily fees for nursing home residents. The imposition of this new fee means that residents will be paying an extra 25c in the dollar for every dollar over the pension‐free area. This might sound reasonable to some of the hard‐hearted accountants on the government benches. We even had the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) proudly boast that full rate pensioners would not pay this additional impost on their pension. Thank God full rate pensioners do not pay, battling as they do on that very modest sum of money that they receive from the government for the years of working and paying taxes for all of their lives.

If an aged pensioner or a service pensioner earns $1 more than $50 a week, then this government says that they are going to impose an additional tax on those people. It will not be imposed on high income earners, it will be imposed on people who are earning $51 a week, which is a very modest sum of money these days when it has to meet the cost of part of their medication, their upkeep and their clothing. Fifty one dollars a week is a pitiful level at which to bring in this new, additional 25c in the dollar rate. That is in addition to some other ways that the government seeks to whack elderly Australians.

I have done a bit of work on the imposts that are placed on a pensioner in that position, where a part pensioner earns a little bit of money above the free rate. They not only get hit with income tax; they get hit with the Medicare levy, they get hit with withdrawal of that pensioner rebate and, as a result of this change, they are going to be hit with the 50c in the dollar reduction in their pension because of the social security means test and this new 25c in the dollar means test as applied to cover the cost of their daily nursing home fees. The all‐up cost of this is that the effective marginal tax rate, the effective withdrawal rate—the equivalent of the effective tax rate for these part pensioners—is going to be up in the range of 78c to 91c in the dollar.

We certainly suspect the Mr Packer does not pay 91c in the dollar. I suspect Rupert Murdoch does not even pay 78c in the dollar. So how could we expect part pensioners on very modest sums of money to be paying effective rates of tax of between 78c and 91c in the dollar? That is what the government will deliver as a result of the imposition of this new 25c in the dollar means test on the daily nursing home benefit. It is outrageous that the government is seeking to impose these new imposts on people who are on very modest sums of money.

The other point I would like to make is that there is a bit of a split in the government. Usually they stick to one particular line—I will concede that—but there are two groups within the government speakers on this legislation.

One group claims that no-one will have to sell their home. The other group is typified by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), and I made some notes from her contribution earlier today. She said, `What is so terrible about selling your home? If I move, I sell mine. What is so terrible about having to sell your home to move into a nursing home?' That is what the honourable member for Hindmarsh said. I do not know if that is the view shared by other Liberal members who are in the chamber at the moment, but I think that sums up the feelings of a group of government members who are speaking in this debate.

It is okay for the honourable member for Hindmarsh to say that. If she sells her home, she can negotiate the purchase of a new home, unit or property. But how do you think people seeking entry to a nursing home—often people who have been in hospital or have had a stroke; often people whose families are under enormous pressure at this time in their lives—would cope? I think it is quite unfair for the member for Hindmarsh to equate her circumstances with that of the family of a person who is trying to decide whether he or she should reside in a nursing home. In the words from the mouth of the honourable member for Hindmarsh, there is nothing so terrible about someone being required to sell their home.

The government says, `It's optional. It is not compulsory. This is just market forces. It's up to each person considering being admitted to a nursing home to reach agreement with the owner of the nursing home.' The problem the government faces is that it does not understand what the Corporations Law is going to do. We have some very competent officials in the advisers' box tonight, I am sure. They take very copious notes, and I would ask them to pass our concerns about this on to the minister so she can answer this question—a question we have raised in this House before—in her summing up to this second reading debate.

Under the Corporations Law, if there is a for‐profit nursing home being run by a private entrepreneur—especially one that might be listed on the stock exchange—the directors and the management of that company have to do all they can to maximise the returns to the shareholders. That is their obligation by law. If that for‐profit nursing home has one spare bed and it has to choose between a person who can afford to pay $200,000 for the up- front fee, a person who can only afford to pay $88,000 for the up-front fee and a person who is disadvantaged and cannot afford to pay any up-front fee, the Corporations Law says the nursing home has to give the bed to the person who can afford $200,000, otherwise the directors of the company breach their fiduciary duty to their shareholders.

Let us just put the $200,000 to one side. Let us say there is a nursing home on the Central Coast that has decided they will charge everyone—whatever their means, however rich they are—$88,000 as their up-front fee. If a person is disadvantaged, the government will say, `Don't worry. We'll put in a bit of extra money per day.' That was fine until we found out last week that the generous sum of money the government is going to offer is only $3 a day. There is no way that $3 a day can make up to a for‐profit nursing home the amount they can earn from having an $88,000 bond in a bank account somewhere earning interest.

The question I put to the minister is this: does she deny that the Corporations Law will require a nursing home proprietor in those circumstances to deny the disadvantaged person that bed? We have asked the minister that before, but this time we hope to get an answer. Because of the Corporations Law, the introduction of market forces with nursing home accommodation will mean that a lot of low income Australians, elderly Australians, will be very severely hurt by these changes.

Government members delight in referring to Professor Gregory's review of nursing home accommodation. They then go on to claim that Professor Gregory's findings on the capital needs of the nursing home sector justify the imposition of this market forces approach. The problem for the government is that, in chapter 5 of Professor Gregory's report, he particularly went out of his way to discourage the Australian parliament from heading down this approach of market forces. I would like to quote from what Professor Gregory said in chapter 5:
The circumstances under which clients seek access to nursing homes are considerably different from hostel clients.
Approximately 60% of nursing home admissions are from hospitals. This is one indicator of the fact that nursing home entry is often urgent, motivated overwhelmingly by the need for nursing care.
The sheer size of entry contributions and the impact on a client's life of having to agree to sell assets to receive care would be a considerable barrier to entry.
He then goes on to describe it as a measure which seems too harsh.

It is completely misleading for members of the Liberal and National parties to claim that in some way Professor Gregory endorses the introduction of up-front fees. He does not. It is certainly wrong for Liberal and National Party members to say that in some way Professor Gregory supports or justifies the imposition of this new 25c in the dollar means test on part‐pensioners who earn only $51 a week. Someone of Professor Gregory's background and concerns would never argue that low income Australians should be targeted in that way.

When the honourable member for Hindmarsh referred to the concerns that have been expressed by many of those involved in the charitable sector of aged care, she dismissed these people as `fellow travellers'. We presume she was not referring to them as being fellow travellers of the Communist Party—the old expression of the 1950s. We presume she meant they were fellow travellers of the Labor Party because they had had the temerity to criticise the government's decision and to express concerns about the impact the government's decision was going to have on low income Australians.

It is pretty hard to believe that an organisation such as Community Services Australia, the national body for community services in the Uniting Church, is in some way aligned to any side of politics, when it says that the government subsidy of $3 a day is:
. . . an insult to our elderly and a slap in the face for charitable service providers.

It is pretty hard to challenge the view of the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association who said, on 27 May, that this will inevitably result in a two‐tiered aged care system. They said:

BREAK.PARA: The problem arises because of the Government's completely inadequate supplementary funding for concessional residents.
We have the Australian Catholic Health Care Association who said that they cannot support funding changes because:

. . . under the proposed changes the government will provide a capital regeneration subsidy of $5 a day per bed for financially disadvantaged people while the payment of an accommodation bond will generate an average of $19 per bed per day for non‐financially disadvantaged Australians.
If the government is picking up the measly subsidy, then it is clear that you are much worse off.
Mr Jull interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister at the table is grumbling away there but I am sure he would not describe this group as being in any way associated with our side of politics. On 11 May the Alzheimers Association of Australia, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association again, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, the Baptist Community Care, Churches of Christ, Community Services of Australia and the Salvation Army aged care services issued a joint paper expressing their concerns about the impact of the aged care legislation on Australians with low incomes. All of these are being dismissed by government members as fellow travellers when these are organisations and individuals that have put enormous resources and an enormous amount of their own time into trying to look after elderly Australians and trying to make sure that disadvantaged elderly Australians in particular are not left behind as a result of the changes that this government is seeking to implement.

BREAK.PARA: My other concerns in many ways have developed after I had a number of discussions with a person who lives within the electorate of Robertson. This gentleman's name is Mr Neville Boyce and he appeared before the Senate committee. Anyone who lives on the Central Coast knows that Neville Boyce is the former Chief Executive of the Central Coast Area Health Service. He very bravely attacked Labor and Liberal ministers for health over many years of distinguished service looking after the area health service. I would like to read a few quotes from Mr Boyce's submission to the Senate committee. On page 1 he says:

Having read the Aged Care Bill 1997 I would have believed, if the act had not come from the government, that these pages were written by the nursing home industry as they are so skewed to benefit the provider.
He goes on to say:

The proposed changes will cause great distress to the elderly and their families. How can the present government, without a mandate, introduce means testing and a capital contribution at the end of one's life span when entry into the public hospital system is almost free to the richest people of the country?
Mr Boyce goes on to make the point that on the Central Coast we are very fortunate to have high quality nursing home beds available to people.

The danger that Mr Boyce has raised is that, if you allow the market forces approach, disadvantaged elderly residents of the Central Coast will be priced out of the market. Of course, it does not take long to drive from the electorate of Bradfield to the Central Coast and we can imagine that, before long, residents of the northern suburbs of Sydney will be able to pay very large sums of money for access to the beds of the nursing homes on the Central Coast.

This a concern which has been raised by Mr Boyce in his submission to the Senate and it is a concern that I think should cause the member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) to seriously rethink his strong support for this particular legislation. If that does not cause the member for Robertson to rethink his position I would encourage him to attend another meeting of the Self‐funded Retirees Association at the Gosford Central Coast branch who, I know, have grave reservations about the impacts of these changes on elderly Australians on the Central Coast.

The crucial point is that the Labor Party's position is that we think nursing home care should be available equally to all Australians on the basis of clinical need rather than on the basis of their financial circumstances. It should really be considered the same as hospital care. If people need to be admitted to a hospital they are admitted. If people need to be admitted to a nursing home they do not do it by choice; they do it because of medical need and because they are assessed by the aged care assessment teams as having certain clinical conditions that require them to have that 24‐hour nursing home care.

The final point I wish to make is that we expect that, unless something unusual happens in the Senate, this government legislation will pass in the not too distant future. The opposition will do all it can to try to persuade a majority in the Senate not to approve the legislation because we think it is unfair and it is going to hurt elderly Australians. But if, at the end of the day, we are wrong then we give every Liberal and National Party member of this House an assurance that elderly Australians in your electorates will hold you accountable in future days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm starting to think you don't like her. I'm starting to think you don't like her.

—The opposition simply aims at scoring points for the next election. They are in for a really bad result. They have total disregard for what is responsible long‐term policy. This bill has been introduced by the minister for caring, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan). Amendments have been moved by the shadow minister for scaring, the member for Jagajaga, who has since her election to this place made it an absolute art form to scare the wits out of the most vulnerable in our society—the elderly people in our community. We have heard much misinformation from the opposition—both within this place and also out in the general community—about the aged care reform being undertaken by the government. It is a shame that the opposition have sought to score cheap political points from the government's genuine and necessary attempt to provide a framework for the future of aged care so that we have the best available sustainable provisions for the elderly today and in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears the opposition would rather Australia's aged live in deteriorating conditions without the funding that is required so desperately. They do not want to support this bill, but they offer no alternative as to how to provide for our ageing population. Nor do they explain how a Labor government would fund the provision of residential care and other services for the aged. Their opposition indicates they want Australia's aged to suffer in their final years in deteriorating accommodation without the significant funding necessary to maintain nursing homes. I should not need to remind the House that we are living in an ageing society and, as such, our policy focus should be on providing the infrastructure and resources that cater for their needs both today and in the future. If we do not address these policy issues today, the burden will be on future generations to make the tough decisions in the years to come which will meet the demands of the aged and provide the necessary funding so urgently required now.

This bill is a responsible bill. It ensures appropriate provision of residential accommodation for the aged which safeguards their quality of life. This bill addresses the key issues, ensuring access to residential aged care is based on need, ensuring entry contributions operate consistently and fairly and introducing effective and fair income testing arrangements to support all these measures.

The bill ensures that those who can afford to make a contribution to the accommodation costs do so. Too often I hear people say that, while they desire a service from the government or someone else, they do not believe that they should be required to contribute to the cost of it. This bill requires those who can afford to make a contribution to do so. It is responsible legislation which provides for residents to take up their responsibility.

The contribution that will be made by those who can afford to is called an accommodation bond, and the bond will be given to the residential care provider. From that bond, the provider can draw down a maximum—as the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) emphasised here earlier today—of $2,600 per annum for a period not exceeding five years. That is a total maximum of $13,000. The balance will be refunded to the resident or their estate on departure. It is not an exorbitant contribution by any standards, but it is a contribution which will provide for the upkeep of the residents over time, without the burden being placed predominantly on the government. I cannot see why someone who can afford to provide for their own accommodation should not.

Those residents who are required to pay an accommodation bond will also be provided with alternative payment methods: as a lump sum or on a periodical basis or as a combination of both. Further, those who pay the accommodation bond will have their bond protected via the provision in the legislation for prudential safeguards. This will allow residents to enter residential accommodation without fear of their contribution being lost in the event of the provider experiencing financial difficulty.

Notwithstanding that, those who cannot afford to contribute will be protected by this legislation. As the minister has said previously—and repeatedly—financial disadvantage will not affect a person's ability to get the care they require. This legislation provides for income testing to determine one's ability to pay. That is the right course of action to take. Every residential care facility will be required to provide a minimum number of places for concessional residents—that is, full or part pensioners who have not owned their own home in the past two years and who have assets worth less than 2½ times the single aged pension. The target will be 27 per cent of nursing home and hostel residents nationally, but the actual numbers will be calculated in each region, according to their local need.

Another important aspect of this legislation is that it provides strategies for ensuring that the rights of aged care recipients and the quality of care are maintained and strengthened. The essence of the bill is to provide aged care recipients with the same rights as all other Australians. The burden will be on the provider to meet a basic standard of care in the interests of the residents.

The legislation we are debating is timely. It will meet the needs and requirements of our elderly in the near future and beyond while ensuring their accommodation needs and standards of living are more than adequate and are funded appropriately. Older Australians deserve better than they received under 13 negligent years of Labor. This bill provides it. I commend it and the minister for caring—as opposed to the shadow minister for scaring—to the House.
