TALK.START.PARA: — Tonight I wish to read into the Hansard record some quotes from the report Bringing them home of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families. In doing so, I wish to highlight a point that was made in the inquiry that these practices were known to many people, that `People did know, but the warnings went unheeded.' On page 44 of the report, in talking about institutional life, there is this quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Institutional life is prejudicial to a healthy development of character and the rearing of children as good and useful men and women. The one fatal and all‐sufficient objection to the massing of children together under the necessary conditions of barrack life is, its utter variance from the family system recognised by nature in the constitution of human society as the best suited for the training of the young.
That is a quote from the 1874 Public Charities Commission of Inquiry. Another quote I wish to read into the record appears on page 123 of the report:
There is not and never should be occasion for the Children to be taken away from their parents and farmed out among white people.
That was written by J.C. Genders, editor of Daylight magazine, in 1924. On page 140 of the report, there is a quote from the 1930s:
I know many stock breeders who would not dream of crowding their stock in the way that these half‐caste children are huddled.
This was a quote from John McEwen, Minister of the Interior, after visiting the Half‐Caste Home in Darwin in 1937.

The thing that struck me in particular was that this practice was nationwide and continued for a considerably long time. A case that really struck home to me was the case of Paul, who in evidence said, `For 18 years the state of Victoria referred to me as state ward No. 54321.' Paul was born in May 1964. My youngest sister was born in September 1963. In the evidence he gave, Paul said:

My Mother and I lived together within an inner suburb of Melbourne. At the age of five and a half months, both my Mother and I became ill. My Mother took me to the Royal Children's Hospital, where I was admitted.

Upon my recovery, the Social Welfare Department of the Royal Children's Hospital persuaded my Mother to board me into St Gabriel's Babies' Home in Balwyn . . . just until Mum regained her health. If only Mum could've known the secret, deceitful agenda of the State welfare system that was about to be put into motion—18 years of forced separation between a loving mother and her son.
Early in 1965, I was made a ward of the State. The reason given by the State was that, `Mother is unable to provide adequate care for her son'.
He went on to say:

When my Mother came for one of her visits, she found an empty cot. With the stroke of a pen, my Mother's heart and spirit had been shattered. Later, she was to describe this to me as one of the `darkest days of her life'.
Paul then described how he went to a foster family. He said:

When I'd say to my foster family, `why am I a different colour?', they would laugh at me, and would tell me to drink plenty of milk, `and then you will look more like us'. The other sons would call me names such as `their little Abo', and tease me. At the time, I didn't know what this meant, but it did really hurt, and I'd run into the bedroom crying. They would threaten to hurt me if I told anyone they said these things.
Paul, in speaking about his mother, said:

She wrote many letters to the State Welfare Authorities, pleading with them to give her son back. Birthday and Christmas cards were sent care of the Welfare Department. All these letters were shelved, the State Welfare Department treated my Mother like dirt, and with utter contempt, as if she never existed. The Department rejected and scoffed at all my Mother's cries and pleas for help.
Subsequently, Paul was discharged from state wardship in May 1982. Paul described what the officer said upon his discharge. He said:

. . . his Department's position was only to protect me and, `that is why you were not told these things before'. He placed in front of me 368 pages of my file, together with letters, photos and birthday cards. He informed me that my surname would change back to my Mother's maiden name of Angus.
Confidential submission No. 133 says:
When Paul located his mother at the age of 18 she was working in a hostel for Aboriginal children with 20 children under her care. She died six years later at the age of 45.

I think that this is a shameful period of our history that should be better known. I am pleased that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, which was in government in some state jurisdictions, has apologised on our behalf. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to commend the government for its announcement today of a three‐month extension of drought relief payments for farmers who have been suffering from exceptional drought. For several years much of eastern and northern Australia has been in drought. It took a long time to persuade the previous government that the drought was serious, that there was a crisis in the bush. Eventually, the former government could ignore the problem no longer, and all of Queensland and much of New South Wales was declared to be in the grip of an exceptional drought.

SPEECH.PARA: A range of emergency measures were put in place that have helped many farmers to survive. There was a full range of rural adjustment scheme measures. Also, the access to social security benefits was eased.
This has indeed been an exceptional drought. It has not just affected the marginal areas but, indeed, those that are normally more secure.

Following fairly general rainfall, the exceptional drought status was lifted from much of Queensland and New South Wales. All of my own electorate was declared free of exceptional drought except for one shire last year. The new government recognised that it does not rain cash, so they extended the eligibility for some of these measures to give farmers time to recover. An extra $160 million was provided to extend access to social security benefits to 10 December and then to 10 June.

These benefits do not pay farm bills, but they have enabled many farmers to keep food on the table and have enabled their children to go to school respectably dressed. These benefits would have expired in less than a week. But, with today's announcement by the government, this vital assistance will continue.

The drought, sadly, has not ended, with rainfall drying up in many parts of southern Queensland. In the first quarter of this year, most of south Queensland has recorded rainfalls in the 10 per cent historic low range. The Queensland government is again declaring shires in my electorate drought stricken, including Kilkivan and Murgon shires which have rarely been drought declared in their history. With the end of the wet season now upon us and winter frosts arriving, the prospects are indeed poor. Cattle prices are appalling, grain prices are low and the weather bureau is now forecasting with, sadly, some degree of confidence that El Nino is returning and the prospects for good winter rainfall are poor.

The government announced a new $198.9 million integrated rural package in the budget. This will replace the old rural adjustment scheme, which has been terminated following an unflattering review of its performance. The government intends to announce details of the new measures in this package later in the year, but this interim announcement today will help keep farmers afloat until the new measures are announced. Around 5,800 farm families are expected to benefit. Had this announcement not been made, their lifeline would have ended next week.

For these growers, for these farmers, the government has acted with compassion. It has provided interim relief and they will now be looking forward with some more confidence to what this new integrated rural package will contain. I hope that it will provide not only measures to assist farmers with the management of their property but also access to some kind of welfare assistance as a safety net whenever emergencies arise in the future. No farmer wants to live on welfare. They do not expect to be able to access it every day, but there should be a safety net in place to assist them, as there is for other sectors of the community, when disastrous circumstances befall them.

They also need counselling services. I call on the government to provide continuing funding to support the rural counsellors who are in place to ensure that they can assist farmers through these difficult times and, when there are those who need to leave the industry, provide them with the sort of advice and help they need so they can have an honourable exit.

The government's decision today recognised the serious plight confronting many people in rural industry. It is only an interim measure, but hopefully the measures to be announced in the integrated rural policy package will secure the future of the rural sector and guarantee hope for farmers for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to commend the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Ronald Wilson, for the report Bringing them home , which was the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families. It is a very heart‐breaking report, and I commend all of those associated with it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one particular case that I have been reading in this report that I would like to have in the Hansard record tonight, and that is the case of Millicent, who was taken from her family in 1945 when she was four years of age. Her parents were half-castes, she was one of seven children and they lived very happily together, but five children were taken away. They were taken to a protection area and, as she called it, to Sister Kate's, as the home was known. They had a very trying life, a very hard existence. The children lined up to have their parents come to visit them. Their parents did not come, and they were told their parents did not come because their family did not care.
It then describes how she went through hell as a very, very young child. But, worse than that, it goes on further on page 116 where she said that, no matter what she had when she was young:
The worst was yet to come.

While I was in first year high school I was sent out to work on a farm as a domestic. I thought it would be great to get away from the home for a while. At first it was. I was made welcome and treated with kindness. The four shillings I was payed went to the home. I wasn't allowed to keep it, I didn't care. I was never payed for the work I did at Sister Kate's so you don't miss what you didn't get, pocket money etc.

The first time I was sent to the farm for only a few weeks and then back to school. In the next holidays I had to go back. This time it was a terrifying experience, the man of the house used to come into my room at night and force me to have sex. I tried to fight him off but he was too strong.

When I returned to the home I was feeling so used and unwanted. I went to the Matron and told her what happened. She washed my mouth out with soap and boxed my ears and told me that awful things would happen to me if I told any of the other kids. I was so scared and wanted to die. When the next school holidays came I begged not to be sent to that farm again. But they would not listen and said I had to.

I ran away from the home, I was going to try to find my family. It was impossible, I didn't even know where to go. The only thing was to go back. I got a good belting and had to kneel at the altar everyday after school for two weeks. Then I had to go back to that farm to work. The anguish and humiliation of being sent back was bad enough but the worse was yet to come.

This time I was raped, bashed and slashed with a razor blade on both of my arms and legs because I would not stop struggling and screaming. The farmer and one of his workers raped me several times. I wanted to die, I wanted my mother to take me home where I would be safe and wanted. Because I was bruised and in a state of shock I didn't have to do any work but wasn't allowed to leave the property.

When they returned me to the home I once again went to the Matron. I got a belting with a wet ironing cord, my mouth washed out with soap and put in a cottage by myself away from everyone so I couldn't talk to the other girls. They constantly told me that I was bad and a disgrace and if anyone knew it would bring shame to Sister Kate's Home. They showed me no comfort which I desperately needed. I became more and more distant from everyone and tried to block everything out of my mind but couldn't. I ate rat poison to try and kill myself but became very sick and vomited. This meant another belting.

After several weeks of being kept away from everyone I was examined by a doctor who told the Matron I was pregnant. Another belting, they blamed me for everything that had happened. I didn't care what happened to me anymore and kept to myself. All I wanted now was to have my baby and get away . . . My daughter was born [in 1962]—
and, I might add, my twin daughters were born in 1961—
at King Edward Memorial Hospital. I was so happy, I had a beautiful baby girl of my own who I could love and cherish and have with me always.

But my dreams were soon crushed: the bastards took her from me and said she would be fostered out until I was old enough to look after her. They said when I left Sister Kate's I could have my baby back. I couldn't believe what was happening. My baby was taken away from me just as I was from my mother.

Once again, I approached the Matron asking for the Address of my family and address of the foster family who had my daughter. She said that it was Government Policy not to give information about family and she could not help me. I then asked again about my baby girl and was told she did not know her whereabouts. In desperation I rang the King Edward Memorial Hospital. They said there was no record of me ever giving birth or of my daughter Toni. Then I wrote to the Native Welfare Department only to be told the same thing and that there were no records of the D. family because all records were destroyed . . .

It shows this woman's desperation both as a child of the hell she went through and as a mother when she tried to redeem her child. She went to South Australia. She went back many times to Western Australia. The final part of this story is as follows:

Defeated I finally returned to Adelaide. In my heart I believed that one day everything would be alright and I would be reunited with my family. My baby was dead. (That's what I was told). I didn't even get to hold her, kiss her and had no photographs, but her image would always be with me, and I would always love her. They couldn't take that away from me.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Confidential submission 640, South Australia: WA woman removed in 1949 . . . A woman born in 1962 was searching for her birth mother. This was Toni, Millicent's daughter. The two have since been reunited.

SPEECH.PARA: I would commend this report to everyone not only here in this parliament but throughout Australia. It is worth reading and it is action we must take. More and more we must stand up and be counted. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The death yesterday of Mr David C.S. Hong should be mourned by all Australians. David Hong was a great man. My deepest sympathy goes to his wife, Linda, his family and his colleagues, both here in Australia and back in Taiwan. His role as representative of the Taiwanese government to Canberra was one he relished and his efforts in promoting stronger cultural and economic ties between both nations were producing great dividends for both countries. David was just 59 years old. He was a career diplomat with service including as Consul‐General in Cape Town, South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: David Hong died in the line of duty for his country. His death yesterday morning in Melbourne, following a stroke, has certainly shocked me and many others in this place. We shared dinner just a few days ago—the annual dinner of the Australia‐Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group—and warmly bade each other goodbye, secure in the knowledge that we would no doubt see each other again soon.

David was one of the first people who welcomed me to Canberra, making a courtesy visit to my Parliament House office a year ago. This gesture summed up David Hong for me. He was a gentleman, a fine diplomat, a great representative for his country, and a strong advocate for both our nations. David and I met each other on countless occasions here in Canberra and also in my electorate of Moreton.

It is certainly worth reflecting on the difficult post which David Hong held. Australia, like most Western countries, has a one‐China policy: we do not officially recognise Taiwan. David Hong could not be called ambassador for his country. Here he was called the representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office. He was like a rock in the middle of a raging torrent—the torrent being the maelstrom of mainland China, ever checking our adherence to our one‐China policy. David reflected upon this in his speech to the parliamentary friendship group just last week. I, like many others in this place, share his frustrations.

David Hong represented a nation of 21 million people, proudly democratic and aggressively free enterprise. He constantly tried to do things to improve the situation of official dealings between our two countries. It must have been frustrating to him last week to read headlines about the PRC ruthlessly working to suffocate Taiwan's links with Australia.

No other country should tell this country who our friends should be. Given that Taiwan has the largest foreign exchange reserves in the world and is looking for places to invest, it is very much so in Australia's interests to promote strong ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan as well as with the People's Republic of China.

Last April I was privileged to be a guest of the Taiwanese government as a member of a delegation from this parliament's friendship group. Along with colleagues from both sides of politics, including Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I met with key legislators, bureaucrats and, importantly, the captains of industry in Taiwan.

There are many major Australian companies with operations in Taiwan—Readymix, Transfield, CSR and many others. China Motors is affiliated with Mitsubishi Motors in Australia and Japan and they now order 2,000 Australian made Diamante luxury cars for the Taiwan market each year. These cars are made in South Australia and are the top of the range of China Motors' fleet. This is another example of Australian jobs being created by the economic ties with Taiwan. In the southern industrial port city of Kaohsiung, there are strong links with Australia, particularly with people from my own electorate.

The delegation visited the headquarters of An Feng Steel, coincidently on the day that local newspapers reported that the Howard federal government was giving the go‐ahead for a joint venture between An Feng Steel and an Australian company, Kingstream, to construct and operate a steel smelter at Geraldton, Western Australia. This is a multi‐billion dollar project which is going to earn a lot of money for Australia. The success of this project will trigger even more investment by other Taiwanese companies. Taiwan's `look south' foreign investment policy is very much so focused on Australia. This is important and good news. It is also part of the work done which was done by David Hong.

The Moreton electorate has more people of Taiwanese origin than any other electorate in Australia. So there are many people whom I represent in this place who share the grief that I have for the passing of David Hong. David Hong supported and encouraged the efforts of groups in my electorate to promote friendship and understanding between all Australians, especially over the past difficult year as some have tried to raise racial tensions. Those groups include the Taiwanese Friendship Society of Queensland, the Taiwan Women's League and the ROC‐Australia Business Association.

I am pleased to be part of a government which supports Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organisation, in tandem with the entry of the PRC in the near future. The goodwill that is between Australia and Taiwan will strengthen in the years ahead. With closer economic and cultural ties comes more understanding and more cross‐pollination of people and ideas and capital. Australia needs a friendship with both Chinas.

Australia has lost a good friend in sudden and tragic circumstances. I am greatly saddened by the death of David Hong. Taiwan, though, will continue to have many goods friends in this place and throughout Australia, as we as a nation have in Taiwan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to raise the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families. The stolen generations inquiry, as it has become known, has brought to light the continuing devastation of the lives of thousands of indigenous people in this country as a result of policies and practices which shamefully continued until very recently in our history.

SPEECH.PARA: For any of my colleagues in this House who have any lingering doubts about the morality or context of these policies, I recommend that you read the report. The report details many excerpts from evidence given to the inquiry by witnesses who suffered under these policies. Let me give you examples, firstly, from a Western Australian woman removed from her family at the age of 10. In her confidential evidence, No. 821, she told the inquiry:

I was at the post office with my Mum and Aunty [and cousin]. They put us in the police ute and said they were taking us to Broome. They put the mums in there as well. But when we'd gone [about ten miles] they stopped, and threw the mothers out of the car. We jumped on our mothers' backs, crying, trying not to be left behind. But the policemen pulled us off and threw us back in the car. They pushed the mothers away and drove off, while our mothers were chasing the car, running and crying after us. We were screaming in the back of that car. When we got to Broome they put me and my cousin in the Broome lock-up. We were only ten years old. We were in the lock-up for two days waiting for the boat to Perth.
Further on, on page 204 of the report, she outlines details of what happened to her after she was taken. She said:

I was taken there because I was `half‐caste'. I started thinking, `Why do I deserve to be treated like this?' But as the years went by, I sort of accepted all that. We were treated differently to white and black people. We weren't allowed to go down to see our Aboriginal people, or go into the houses where the white people were. We just had to live around the outside of the house. They made us feel like we weren't allowed to do anything: no freedom of movement, even to think for yourself. They had to tell you what to do, and how to think.

We were locked up in the dormitories, and had to go and ask for anything. We had to go and ask if we could go and see our people. We were more or less like slaves, I think. We didn't think that was wrong. We just thought it was our duty. We did what we were told.

Years later, when we were grown up, our own boss—by this time we were married and having our children—we were having families and still couldn't go up and ask the managers if we could get married. They had to tell you who you had to marry. We didn't know what was their plans for us. We just lived and did what we were told.

I was almost ashamed to be half‐caste sometimes. I had no confidence in myself, or how to make up my mind what to do . . . When I was growing up I wanted to be a teacher or a nurse. But you couldn't say that because you had to go to school and go out and work in the house, do domestic duties. That's what they said. We lost much of our culture, our language and traditional knowledge, our kinship and our land.
Mr Speaker, this report represents the cultural genocide of a whole generation or generations of people. I certainly recommend it to you.

Dealing with these issues does not mean adopting personal guilt about past actions. The view that making a decent response to this issue somehow confers this guilt on white Australians is a furphy being bandied around by extremists like the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and, unfortunately, more sensible people like the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in an attempt to cloud the issue and somehow try to justify their position of not having the leadership and the guts to make the right decision and properly compensate indigenous people.

This cannot be brought down to dollars and cents. This is about the morally right thing to do. The fact that today's comments by Jose Ramos Horta and Mick Dodson have been criticised for bringing criticism on Australia I think is absolutely ironic. They cannot ignore this report. We as parliamentarians cannot ignore this report. People should not exacerbate the damage which has been done by condemning people for speaking out on these facts.

It is unfortunate that Australia's reputation will be damaged unless we do the right thing by offering an appropriate apology, a full apology on behalf of our nation, just as Tony Blair has made an apology for the Irish potato famine. If that is good enough, why is it not good enough for us when we are talking about events which occurred as recently as the 1970s? That is step one. Step 2 is to offer proper compensation for indigenous people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt the report mentioned by the previous member, the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), is of concern to all members of parliament and has been treated with all the compassion and sympathy that this government can offer. I commend the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and cabinet in relation to that report. Its recommendations will certainly be considered in the normal parliamentary process.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise tonight with a grievance from J.K. Williams Contracting Pty Ltd, which is a small company in my electorate which is having trouble with the Australian Taxation Office. The Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 introduced the investment allowance to kick‐start Australia out of the economic recession. At the time, unemployment was in double digits, economic growth was stagnant and the Australian economy was in dire trouble. Australia was in the worst economic recession for 60 years.

The government asked Australian businesses, particularly small businesses, such as J.K. Williams, to help boost Australia's economic prospects. It offered a major incentive—the investment allowance—to provide an appropriate carrot for Australian businesses to invest in capital equipment. J.K. Williams duly heeded the government's call and invested substantial capital sums in equipment—two caterpillar scrapers from Gough and Gilmore.

Were it not for the investment allowance, J.K. Williams would not have bought the equipment because J.K. Williams could not otherwise afford it. Therefore, in the terms of the government's policy, J.K. Williams did exactly what the government wanted it to do. J.K. Williams's actions were pro-business, pro‐Australian and should be commended. But, alas, J.K. Williams has become a victim of the ATO's obsession with legal form.

In acquiring the equipment, J.K. Williams was careful to ensure that it complied with the highly complex investment allowance provisions. As you will appreciate, like all small businesses with limited resources, complying to the letter of the law is extremely difficult. However, J.K. Williams did 100 per cent of the things in accordance with the spirit of the law and sought as best as it could to comply with the strict letter of the law. In fact, only a person highly trained in contract law would even begin to think that there may have been a technical failure to comply with the letter of the law.

J.K. Williams entered into a written contract with Gough and Gilmore before 30 June 1990, which was the last date on which contracts could be entered into in order to qualify for the investment allowance. The equipment was delivered before 30 June 1995, which was the last day on which the equipment had to be installed and ready for use in order to qualify for the investment allowance.

J.K. Williams met with the National Australia Bank before 30 June 1994, and the NAB agreed to fund the acquisition. However, because of the time delay between the making of the contract with Gough and Gilmore and the delivery of the equipment, the NAB and J.K. Williams agreed to finalise the form of the financing—be it a loan, be it a hire purchase agreement, a bank overdraft or a mortgage. It was not considered that it would do this until 10 months time.

J.K. Williams, Gough and Gilmore and the National Australia Bank have signed letters unequivocally stating there was a binding contract for J.K. Williams to acquire that equipment prior to the end of June 1994. The NAB at no point owned the equipment. The contract was with J.K. Williams and Gough and Gilmore to purchase this equipment.

The Australian Taxation Office has found that 10 months later a new contract appeared out of thin air. Somehow NAB entered into a brand new hire purchase agreement to provide these scrapers to J.K. Williams. That seems an incredibly pedantic and tight interpretation of the law which is exactly at odds with everything the legislation was introduced to do.

J.K. Williams entered into the contract in good faith. Where a major tax incentive is introduced such as the investment allowance and where hardworking honest small business taxpayers such as J.K. Williams comply with the spirit of the law and seek as best they can to comply with the letter of the law, should as a matter of administrative practice the ATO seek to defeat the government's policy? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege to be able to speak to the 1997‐98 budget of the Australian government. This budget builds on last year's budget, the first budget of the current government. Far from it being a series of disjointed activities placed as an annual event, what is happening here is a series of measured practices and initiatives taken to achieve a result that has been the focus and target of the government since its election.

SPEECH.PARA: The targets that the government set itself prior to its election, and has followed subsequently, have been to reduce the deficit to get the huge interest payments that the Australian government and people are required on an annual basis to pay to foreigners and others off the agenda so that more resources can be devoted to the real needs of the Australian people; to focus on the needs of Australian families, especially those with children; to look at the needs of small business and ensure that the small businesses of Australia are allowed to flourish; to create a safer environment; and to take care of those people in need, particularly the aged. It is a very simple agenda and one that was the clear focus during the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —No jobs though.

—The employment factor is raised and rightly so. Of course, the job generation process, we believe, does not come from the expenditure on training programs or churning people through training, job club, new work opportunities and then back onto unemployment benefits. The real growth in jobs comes from the productive activity of real businesses—not government business—and particularly the small business sector. The focus on small business really relates to the creation of opportunities for young Australians. So that process, as you rightly point out, is a priority and thank you for reminding me that it is a priority of the government. But it is not focused in the direction determined by the previous government; it is focused in the direction of long‐term prospects and permanent opportunities for people to achieve employment.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of this strategy, which is not an annual disjointed event but a series of measures designed to achieve a certain goal, I have outlined the goals that the government has set itself in its first term of office. The process is being given emphasis in the current budget by a series of significant highlights.

The first highlight that I would like to mention is the prospect of rebuilding savings: the savings in the public sector, the savings I have already mentioned that result from a substantial program of debt reduction—getting rid of the deficit, getting those huge annual interest payments of $9 billion or $10 billion that go annually out of the Australian budget and out of the system. It is a burden people and future generations do not want to carry. The strategy of almost halving the underlying budget deficit for this year and turning that deficit into a surplus for next year—the 1998‐99 year—is heading in the right direction.

BREAK.PARA: We are making possible the rebuilding of savings by encouraging individuals to save. The savings rebate initiative is a very significant initiative and it will give people the opportunity of gaining a tax benefit if they want to save. It is providing a central place for people to deposit any spare funds, whether it be superannuation contributions, part of a net income process, or investments that people want to make to be able to use that tax rebate. That is a substantial encouragement to savings.

There are also the changes to superannuation which have been at the upper end of the superannuation hierarchy, but I think they were significant nonetheless. I do not believe it is the government's intention to revisit superannuation on a regular basis. There is also the deferred pension bonus plan, which is another encouragement for people to save. So we have a savings strategy.

We are setting the right priorities by establishing a fair safety net for those people in need by implementing employment and training programs that are realistically based. My experience in my own electorate is that the programs which are now being implemented have every prospect of working very successfully. We have high community involvement in the electorate of Mitchell and we have a large number of people participating. In fact, 52 organisations participate in creating job opportunities and they are improving business prospects for the local community. I think that the government programs are going to work rather well. Some of them will need refinement. But, all in all, we have been able in our area to take advantage of the CES program which deals with people who are unemployed for 18 months or more—a very difficult client target. We have been able to deal with that very successfully.

As for the environment, with the proceeds from the partial sale of Telstra we have established the right priorities for the care of the environment. As for culture and heritage, the federation fund will encourage the expression of Australian heritage towards the centenary of our Australian federation. There are also assistance programs for small business, which I would like to deal with in greater detail shortly. There is an emphasis on rural and regional Australia to provide opportunities for people living away from Australia's capital cities. All of these processes are designed as part of a continuum of activity.

I find it very interesting when I look back over the period since the release of the budget. The national media spent a total of three days examining the budget and then reverted to its complete and absolute obsession with Wik and Aboriginal affairs. That was purely a matter of spectacularising the news.

Could I say to members of the Australian Labor Party that I am perfectly content with this process because while you guys are focussing on those headline issues, what is happening is that our measures are going into place. Our substantial changes to the Australian economy are being put down, block by block. One day these guys are going to wake up, if I may say so, Mr Deputy Speaker, and they are going to find they are facing an election where the commitments of the opposition of 18 months ago have been fulfilled in practice and promises completed and programs concluded.

The Australian people will then say, `I wonder where the opposition has been all this time?' They will realise you have been focused on peripheral issues, issues that are unrelated to the main needs of the Australian community. When the facts are laid out, come an election, your frenetic attention to apologies or saying sorry, question time after question time, and your frenetic attention to the images on television of a night—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are also—
—No, that is not what you are running. You are not running any of those issues.
—I am not running anything. You will address your remarks through the chair.
—I know, but if you were I know you would do it extremely well.
—The members on my left are on the speakers' list for today. Restrain your remarks until you get there.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. They are very encouraging to me, though. It is wonderful in this intimate environment to see they are so far off track. It is amazing to see that the Australian Labor Party has lost the plot. We are looking to a newer generation to generate within the Australian Labor Party new ideas and new prospects, but there are words like treachery flowing around the place today from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) who is saying, `This is treacherous behaviour that people should have ideas and have ideas different from mine.' But that is a side issue.

BREAK.PARA: They will battle away on those things, which I think are peripheral issues, while the government is laying down the foundation on things like small business reform, change in opportunity, job creation through that process, opportunities for Australian families and redressing the deficit.

These are the things that really matter to Australians, not the stuff that you are carrying on with. It is amazing that the Australian media have been so misled in this process that they have focused, as if in a feeding frenzy, on things which look good on television. I acknowledge that the pictures of nice Aboriginal people or angry meetings and all of these sort of things are very good television, but in fact they are unrelated to the real needs of most Aussies. Most Aussies are focused where the government is focused, and the government is focused very centrally on these issues.

I just want to outline briefly for the House some of the advantages of the current budget because I think that in some instances they need to be restated. Australian families will benefit by tax savings from 1 July, which is an excellent thing. Families with children and modest to low incomes—the very group that the Australian Labor Party neglected when they were in office—will be really gaining the benefits.

What are these rebates going to be? Up to $450 per year on savings interest or personal superannuation contributions will go straight into the pockets of nearly six million Aussies. Faster Medicare claim processing and the introduction of electronic lodgment will make it simpler and easier for families. From 1 July a $450 rebate on the cost of private health insurance will be available to low-income people. There will be 28,000 outside school hour care places created in the next four years. That is in place as well as opportunities for families to exercise choice in the form of 44,000 child-care places.

These are the things that we are doing while the Australian Labor Party is focused on Wik and Mabo and all of those things—the legal battles and the legal contests that will go on. Most people do not understand those and, in fact, those who have a partial understanding of them feel threatened.

There will be greater Austudy access; $17.4 million over five years for improved health services in rural areas; a 25 per cent increase in domiciliary nursing care benefits; and carer payment for those who are looking after aged relatives or disabled relatives in their own home. What more empathetic and compassionate scheme could there be than this one which acknowledges the time given for the care of a relative, or somebody who is in need, in their own home? I acknowledge that there is certainly a benefit to the government in this process. But to pay tribute and to understand the day‐to‐day application that a carer must have to the needs of others is a wonderful thing for this government to do. There will be $54 million extra for additional accommodation to support people with disabilities over four years.

Those are the right focuses for the Australian government: tax concessions for families and better health opportunities, allowing people of modest to low incomes to maximise their benefits. We are even having newspaper reports now of women who are currently working saying, `If I weigh it all up, I have now got a real choice of whether I work or stay at home.' The goal of the government is to give women—particularly women—the choice of whether they will take part‐ or full‐time work, or whether they will stay with their children and families.

Most women prefer to stay with their families, but economic necessity has created the need for them to do part‐time work. The government is giving people real choices in their lifestyles. I think choice in that area is the key to a successful and healthy nation, because our families are going to be based on proper decisions and not forced decisions—forced by some ideological concept of what a family should be.

Small businesses also are boosting job opportunities and encouraging savings. They are providing a certainty of growth for the years ahead. One only has to look at the capital expenditure over the last quarter to realise that there is an engine revolving steadily and strongly to drive the Australian economy forward. The record expenditure on capital is going to improve productivity and opportunities in businesses.

There are changes to fringe benefits tax for small business and exemptions have been proposed. Changes to capital gains tax rollover will mean that a person, at the end of their working life, will be able to reinvest in superannuation, in proper savings, with no capital gains tax if they change their businesses or sell their businesses. People in small business can now develop their whole career. They can keep building up and selling small businesses and then use the proceeds of their final sale for their retirement. That is a real incentive for small business; something that has never been there. At the end of the day most small business proprietors say, `The value of my business is my retirement benefits.' The government has acknowledged that and has extended relief from capital gains tax to the small business area.

There is more flexible industrial relations—and even more flexible industrial relations ahead, if the Australian Labor Party will understand what we are really doing and acknowledge that the common law does provide protection for employees. We are not about removing protection, but the crazy unfair dismissal processes for small business are crippling for employment, crippling for small business and denying them opportunities. You have to take the shackles off. I would like to be able to get into the Senate and tell senators how damaging their attitudes are to the future of Australia. Narrow‐minded pettiness and obstructiveness are occurring in that chamber. I know I should not reflect on the chamber, Mr Deputy Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a strange ambition to want to get in there, too.

—I would want to go there and tell them how wrong they are, and come back immediately to the real world of the House of Representatives. I do not think there is a consciousness of the relevance of what they are doing to the rest of Australia. They need to be enlightened as to how damaging this is. It could be that the place they live in is so lofty and so remote that day‐to‐day contact with the average citizen never occurs. I worry about that. If they had that contact they would not be making the decisions they are making.

BREAK.PARA: The reduced taxation compliance burden from 1 July is another initiative. The savings rebate that I have already mentioned is excellent stuff for small business, because they can invest in the savings rebate. So, all in all, this budget, which has been received quietly and without controversy, is a budget that builds on last year's budget. It builds for the future with another significant block in place in the areas of savings, opportunities for families, small business and job creation of a real kind. I think it is a very significant document.

I am rather pleased that the budget has not attracted a lot of attention. If it was a weak budget it would attract a lot of attention. But people have not been able to lay a glove on it. My friends from the other side of the chamber have not been able to lay a glove on it. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that if you were to venture down to the more lowly area where we are, you would find that nobody could lay a glove on it down here either. So neither at lofty levels in the press, nor at the lower levels of crass politics can people lay a glove on it.

What we see in place is a building block, building for Australia's future, with another budget to come before the next election which will be even better. We are seeing the complete trilogy of the first three years of the Howard government. That will be the first three years of many subsequent years of the Howard government. The plan is developing. People are starting to see that we deal with the problems as they arise, but the underlying necessities were the necessities that we annunciated when were in opposition and which we are now putting in place and building on. The Australian people are recognising the progress that is being made on their behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to take part in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. During the time I have been in the federal parliament, I have seen many budgets come and go, but I have never seen one quite like this one. I have never seen a budget sink so rapidly from the public spotlight as the budget delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 13 May.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and his valiant attempt to justify it and say why it has sunk, as I have listened to many members on the government side talking about how good this budget is. It has sunk without interest. The government wanted to get it out of the headlines and that was why the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) raised the spectre of the GST.

The honourable member for Mitchell said that the opposition was raising questions about Wik and things like that, but who was it, when the flak came in about the budget, that was so desperate to get the budget away and buried? It was the Prime Minister who raised the spectre of the GST on the Sunday program. The media, being the media, ran with that.

We are delighted that the Prime Minister has raised the question of the GST. Even in today's paper, the Treasurer is talking about a tax on every part of the process. I was in Canada earlier this year, and I have seen that tax. Believe you me, we will be highlighting to the people of Australia just what this government has in store.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would well know, Paul Keating as Treasurer would always wrap up a budget with a memorial line. He used to get derided for it, whether that was right or wrong. In presenting the 1988 budget, I well remember, as many will, his saying, `This is the one that brings home the bacon.' This 1997‐98 budget, the second of the Howard‐Costello government, brings home absolutely nothing. It is truly a directionless, shapeless and hopeless policy program.

While the budget is not as dramatic in that there are not as many cuts as last year, with a hack of $8 billion cut away so ruthlessly from public expenditure, the devil is in the detail. It continues the assault on most Australians. Pensioners, students, the unemployed, migrants, families, workers, businessmen, the sick, the disabled, our youth and indigenous Australians do not walk away bloodied, as they did last year, but they certainly walk away with a severe and very noticeable limp. They have all been taken to again by a Prime Minister who promised so much and delivered so little.

After just on 16 months in office, the Howard government has made Australians frustrated and angry—a far cry from being comfortable and relaxed. Australians are frustrated that economic growth has slowed; that unemployment has increased; that essential government services like Medicare, CES, tax and social security offices are to close; that industry assistance has been abolished; that labour market programs no longer exist; that elderly people will be forced to pay incredible up‐front fees to gain entry into nursing homes—something like $80,000; that students will need to fork out $100,000 to get a university degree; and that working families will be forced to pay increased child‐care fees to have their children looked after while they work, just to make it over the line each week.

This budget fails to address the problem of unemployment. Unemployment, as the government continually reminded Labor when in opposition, is Australia's most overwhelming economic and social problem. Since the coalition has been in office, its record on jobs and unemployment has been dismal. Virtually no full‐time jobs have been created. The number of unemployed people has increased by 31,500. Long‐term unemployment is at its highest level for two years.

The only so‐called solution the coalition has is limited to the work for the dole scheme—a con which went through numerous reincarnations before it was framed in proposed legislation. Work for the dole proposes to establish 70 pilot projects catering for 10,000 places in the 18‐ to 24‐year‐old bracket. It is a con program which will do nothing to reduce unemployment, especially youth unemployment.

The government laid its marker when it told us that its unemployment record could be judged after it had been in office for 12 months. In the first year of the Howard government, total employment grew by 89,000. In Labor's last year of office, total employment grew by 176,000. Male full‐time employment has fallen by 12,600 in this government's first year. Under Labor, it grew by 57,000. Long‐term unemployment fell by 45,000 in Labor's final year, while it rose by 44,000 in the coalition's first year.

The coalition clearly does not have the answers. Last year's budget, which axed public sector jobs, abolished labour market programs, cut schools training, slashed industry assistance and deserted regional and rural Australia, proves it. Instead of changing its responses in this budget, it is exactly the same response: cut, cut and cut again.

I have said before that there must come a time when this country's economic advisers in Treasury and in the corridors of this place must accept that Australia cannot go on the road of doing more with less. The paper clip counting mentality which dominates the cabinet, the major economic departments and the board rooms needs to be, and must be, shelved.

Last year's budget and this budget are smokescreens for this government's attempts to imitate Thatcher's Britain. There is no need to try and imitate either Thatcher or Gingrich. Both Thatcher and Gingrich have moved on. Australia does not face an economic crisis. Australia has the lowest government expenditure in the industrialised world. It has a low level of government debt and a low budget deficit. We do not need to achieve a balanced budget, or a surplus, by needing to destroy essential public programs, without slowing economic growth and destroying services in regional and rural Australia.

The people of Throsby can expect nothing from this budget. They have been savaged and attacked in the areas of job creation, regional development, local government, education, Austudy, social security, child care and aged care. It is interesting that this conservative government targets the most disadvantaged regions for some of the most savage cuts. So much for governing for all of us. A most vicious assault occurred in the most ethnically diverse area in my electorate, Warrawong. Within a week, the people of Warrawong and the surrounding areas of Port Kembla, Berkeley, Lake Heights and Cringila were asking themselves what they had done so terribly wrong. What had they done to be so punished by this government? Within a week, two offices had been announced for closure. Warrawong will lose its Medicare and social security offices—a double whammy from this caring government!

During the last election on one full day of campaigning, my Liberal opponent, who is a chicken farmer—the chicken man—came down from Liverpool where he has a chicken farm. He spent a day in my electorate. He came to Dapto and promised the people of Dapto that if he was elected—this chicken man—the Howard government would establish a Medicare office in the area. He was right to make this promise, in one way, because the Dapto area is experiencing enormous population growth. I have long been involved in a campaign, along with a group from the Dapto Senior Citizens Centre, to have a Medicare office established there. During or before the campaign, I spoke of the need for a Medicare office in Dapto. I spoke in this parliament; I arranged deputations to see various health ministers; I arranged for bureaucrats to come over there; and a lot of work towards the Dapto Medicare office was done in my office.

Much was made of the promised Medicare office. Remember when the Illawarra Mercury said that if the Liberals were elected, Dapto would get the Medicare office? So says the chicken man! History records that the Howard government was elected on 2 March 1996. History will also record, however, that the promised Medicare office at Dapto did not eventuate. Instead, they have taken two Medicare offices out of our area, one out of my area in the electorate of Throsby and one from my colleague the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin). The Liberals promised that if they were elected, we would get one extra Medicare office in the area. What did they do when they were elected? They took two out of the area.

That they have taken the Social Security offices out of Warrawong can only be described as an act of monumental stupidity. Pensioners, young families, the unemployed, workers, students, the sick and disabled, will all be affected by these closures. These people were all on tight household budgets of their own before, but now the Howard government will force them to travel further to either central Wollongong or Shellharbour Square in the south to lodge their forms for the pension, unemploymeny benefit, child care and Medicare rebates, or just to ask for advice or information.

It was the same response when, following last year's budget, the government closed the immigration office in Wollongong. No matter that the Illawarra is, perhaps, the most ethnically diverse part of Australia. No matter how many people use the office and the services that are provided. Just tell them to hop onto a bus or train and take a two‐hour trip up to Rockdale in Sydney. This government does not care about individual circumstances. It does not care that people will be forced to travel further or wait longer to access the services that Medicare and the Social Security offices provide. The people of Warrawong will not give up without a fight, I can tell you that. There are plans to fight this closure, and a fight there will be.

I find it very interesting that this government, more than any other, enjoys official openings and blowing its own trumpet—and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would appreciate this. And no‐one can hold a candle to Defence personnel for official openings, especially of a building—as you and I both appreciate. I have been through the budget papers because there is a little program that I am particularly interested in, and I notice that there is no mention of the Holsworthy Military Hospital complex. As a former chairman, and now the deputy chairman of the Public Works Committee, I have been eagerly awaiting the arrival of my invitation to attend the official opening of the $20 million state‐of‐the‐art medical complex. The invitation is yet to arrive and I suspect—unless, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have got yours—that it never will.

The government has been very quiet about the Holsworthy Military Hospital. It has recently been brought to my attention that the hospital has been, in fact, opened and operating for some months. The Holsworthy Military Hospital had been opened ever so quietly without the usual fanfare, as a contrast to the official opening of a similar complex at Enoggera in Brisbane where the Minister for Defence, Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) claimed all the credit for the medical facilities there.

The Holsworthy Military Hospital which is equally state‐of‐the‐art, and worth almost $20 million at December 1994 prices, however, opened and is operating in near silence. Why is there this silence about Holsworthy? It would not be because a hospital is located almost on the runway of the proposed second Sydney airport, right under the flight path of screaming jets as they make their way to the runway of the proposed Sydney second airport. It is no wonder that the Howard government has kept the operation of the hospital a near state secret. It is no wonder that the Minister for Defence, Industry, Science and Personnel is seen nowhere near the place, and that there has been no official opening. It is almost like the situation faced by the New South Wales government in the opening of the M2 motorway. If the proposed second Sydney airport is sited at Holsworthy, then the hospital would be sure to close and $19 million of taxpayers' money will have been totally wasted. Is it any wonder that that is not mentioned in the budget papers?

When you manage to get the 2UE's Alan Jones offside in an editorial you know that you have made a blunder. The morning after the budget on the Today show Alan Jones revealed that the centrepiece of the budget was a crazy con. The savings rebate was talked about for only 48 hours after the budget because the Prime Minister then began to talk about the introduction of the GST. This rebate is for the wealthy end of town and is not for the battlers. So much for the member for Mitchell when he came in here and said that we had brought up Wik to divert attention. It was the Prime Minister who diverted attention from this by introducing the question of the GST.

The maximum rebate is $450 per person per year. High income couples will easily qualify for the full amount, but the battler will, if he or she is lucky, get a massive 29c per week. In the majority of cases, the battler will get nothing at all. I can tell you that there are not too many people in the Throsby electorate who will be getting the $450. The Prime Minister was so embarrassed by the savings rebate that he said that he would not be claiming it, despite the fact that this rebate was introduced instead of Labor's superannuation contribution, which would have increased national savings and provided workers with adequate retirement incomes.

We promised to make the rebate go where it should go: to the battler. Again, the Prime Minister is opposed. There is nothing but bad news in the savings rebate for retirement incomes. Workers now in their mid‐30s on average weekly earnings will lose around $110,000 from their retirement packages. Under this budget, people will also be forced to choose their illnesses, because this budget introduces a tax on medication.

In the last few minutes available to me, I would like to briefly touch on the question of aid. Especially considering the massive cuts in last year's budget to aid, the cut this year of one per cent—which, in real terms, is about three per cent—in the aid budget is totally indefensible. Just as this government is sending the wrong messages on human rights, so it is sending the wrong messages on aid. The Simmons report on the aid program, to which the government has so far not responded, advocates an increase in the aid allocation. Yet this government has, in the last two budgets, cut the aid program.

We are now giving the lowest level of aid as a percentage of GNP since the early 1980s. At 0.27 per cent, we are even further removed from the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent. We should be increasing our aid budget, especially in relation to the population program and countries in this part of the world. We make much of talking about sending a message to this part of the world but, when we continue to cut aid, especially to the countries in this region, we are sending them all the wrong messages.

We also send the wrong messages in regard to Radio Australia. We spend millions of dollars with our embassies throughout Asia, keeping them open and so forth. I see that our embassy in Copenhagen and the office in Nauru are closing, saving over $1 million. But the cheapest and most effective way to get to so many people, especially the decision makers in our surrounding area—and, indeed, not only in our surrounding area but in all parts of the world—is through Radio Australia; yet we are going to cut that. I cannot see the economic sense of that.

We can argue about very many issues—and there are, rightly, different points of view on various issues—but I do not think there could be any argument about the benefit of Radio Australia; and from an economic point of view it is very much cheaper than embassies. Anyone who has been to those embassies will have seen the endless staff there and the millions and millions spent. I never advocate cutting the staff at embassies; but, if money is so tight, we could take a few people out of a few embassies and have the few million dollars needed to keep Radio Australia. Once it has gone, it will never be replaced. We have built up a tremendous service with Radio Australia that is respected throughout the world; but, for a measly million dollars, we are going to cut it.

I have listened to those on the government benches trying to justify this budget, but I know that their hearts are really not in it. The heart of the honourable member for Mitchell was not in it. I have not yet heard your speech, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I will. You cannot comment from the chair, but I know that government members have not got their hearts in the defence of this budget, because they know that what we are saying on this side is right. They have to justify it. I was a government member for 13 years and I know that you have to come in, and the Whip gears you up and says, `You have to get in there.' `But I don't want to talk on it'. `No, no; you've got to get in there and defend it. Go in there. When you have got a weak point, raise your voice and shout a bit, but defend it.'

The government members' hearts are not really in it. They cannot justify a budget which so cruelly punishes the poor and disadvantaged in our community. This budget lacks a vision for today and tomorrow; it lacks a vision for a more equitable society; and it lacks a vision for Australia's rightful place in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the previous speaker that we do care, that our hearts are in our speeches on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98, and that this government does care about all Australians—not like the previous government, which left many Australians in the lurch. Mainstream Australians can, for the first time, hold their heads up with pride that they are contributing. They are all accepting this budget because of the success of last year's budget. I look forward to the success of this budget and next year's one—which, I am sure, will provide a lot of assistance, help and hope for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The second coalition budget is a major victory for middle Australia, those people that Labor forgot for 13 years. Less than nine months ago, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) brought down the first budget of the Howard government against a backdrop of financial mismanagement and gross neglect. The Howard government was faced with a $10 billion deficit, a huge black hole into which Labor had poured billions of taxpayers' dollars to prop up an ailing welfare system.

Instead of turning tail and retreating to the bunker, the Treasurer took stock and laid down a plan, a plan which will see this government turn around the debt and create a surplus in under three years. It is a plan to secure the future of all Australians, not just the noisy minorities and Labor's union mates; a plan to secure the future for all constituents in my electorate of Bowman and for all Australians who have worked so hard for so long without recognition for their efforts, until now. The Treasurer took it upon himself and this government to fix the mess that Labor had dumped this country into; and now, as we debate the coalition's second budget, we are starting to reap the benefits of this far reaching and inspired plan.

For those who said it could not be done, just look at the facts: for the first time in nearly a decade, the government will not run up debt. In fact, in the coming financial year, we will repay over $5 billion of debt and, for the second year in a row, the Australian public can rejoice in the fact that there is no increase in income tax, no increase in company tax, no increase in wholesale tax and no lifting of the petrol excise. But it gets better. For the second year in a row, the Treasurer introduced a reduction in taxation. As well as this, we have record low home mortgage interest rates and low inflation. All this, from a position just over 12 months ago from which the critics said we could not recover. We have recovered and we will continue to flourish.

Today I wish to focus on a few points, namely employment, business and aged care, three areas in which Labor failed dismally and which we have accepted the challenge to fix. First, let us look at aged care reform. The shadow minister for scare has spent so much time in this House criticising our policy that I am sure she has not had time to look at her own party's record. Under Labor, the nursing home sector steadily declined. Why? Because the problem was too big for Labor to grasp. Again, we are here to clean up their mess. The coalition recognises the urgent need for reform. For this reason, we have introduced into this House an aged care reform package which will get the industry back on its feet.

Our package will provide better consumer protection, protection for those on low incomes, protection for the family and protection for quality of life. Our plan for nursing homes is built around the needs of our aged and their families. It allows a greater diversity of care and more flexibility than Labor could ever manage. Our package will provide better buildings through the input of funds from accommodation bonds. Again, due to the neglect of Labor, many of our nursing homes are in shocking condition. Just look at the statistics. Over 40 per cent of residents share rooms with three or more people; 11 per cent of facilities do not meet fire hazard standards; 15 per cent do not even meet health standards. Why? Because Labor was too weak to introduce real reform.

They cannot claim ignorance. Their own report, written for them by Professor Gregory, told them the state of nursing homes. What was their response? Over a three‐year period, Labor actually cut capital funding for nursing homes by 75 per cent. Yet, the shadow minister for scare sits opposite and protests when we put forward a plan to fix the problem, a plan to provide quality care for our aged population. A population, I might add, that is growing at an alarming rate—a population for which Labor had run out of ideas.

Aged care is of special interest to me. My electorate contains at least 15 aged care facilities offering a variety of care and comfort. All these facilities will benefit from the government's aged care reform package. The population projection for Bowman for people over 70 is over 7,000. By putting a plan in place now, those who will require aged care in Bowman in the future can be assured it will be available.

Another area of gross neglect is that of employment. Under Labor, this country witnessed the highest rate of unemployment since the Second World War. Unemployment rose from six per cent to 11 per cent under Labor, putting more than one million Australians out of work. What was their response? Put the unemployed through endless training courses in an effort to keep them off the unemployment statistics.

Did the revolving door training method work? Of course, it didn't. If it did, unemployment would not be the problem it is today. Why didn't it work? Because Labor doesn't work. What the opposition does not understand is that, no matter how highly or diversely trained your work force is, if business is not working, neither are the unemployed. The coalition understands this and we are doing something about it.

Business, particularly small business, have been unwilling to hire more employees because the Labor Party has had them running scared. Remember the recession we had to have? Remember the unfair dismissal laws? Remember the high interest rates? Is it little wonder that small business retreated into its shell? Only now are they beginning to be coaxed out again. Lower interest rates, reductions in withholding tax, relief from capital gains tax and savings rebates on income earned from a business are all measures introduced to help small business.

Reform in the form of the Reid report addresses many of the issues confronting small business and, once implemented, will provide the environment for small business to grow, employ, expand and invest. Small business is often referred to as the engine room of our economy and I believe the recommendations in the Reid report will give small business the kick‐start they need to start producing.

In addition to this, the government has introduced measures to encourage business to take on more staff. From next January, the government will introduce a new $1,500 completion payment for employers when an apprentice or trainee achieves a certain level of competency. There will also be an increase of $250 in the recommencement payment for this competency standard to encourage employers to take on an apprentice or trainee who has had a previous employment contract terminated.

The government will also fund the work for the dole scheme to the value of $21 million over two years. This fund will provide 70 pilot projects, comprising up to 10,000 places for the unemployed. A recent national survey of businesses showed that three in five businesses would be more willing to employ someone with experience from work for the dole than without it.

I had great pleasure recently telling the members of this House of a program currently running in my electorate of Bowman. Through this program, which is being run by the Redlands Employment Placement Service, participants have identified 105 unadvertised positions with small businesses in two months.

The JUICE program—join us in creating employment—trains participants in the art of cold canvassing and then puts them on their bikes, literally, to seek employment. To date, 41 participants have taken part in the program. These are the types of programs that work and that get Australians back to work.

We have approximately 5,000 businesses in Bowman. We also have approximately 5,000 unemployed. If every one of those businesses could be encouraged to take on just one more staff member, it would solve the unemployment problem in Bowman.

Many aspects of this budget will benefit the Australian community. We have introduced environmental programs, the likes of which have never been seen before in this country. We have announced the $1 billion Federation Fund, which will provide employment and restore pride in our nation. We have introduced discounts for students on HECS, and much more. However, in fairness to my colleagues, I will not take up any more time in this House and I have great pleasure in commending this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this budget debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) somewhat bemused by the antics of the government in its presentation of the 1997 budget. The speech of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) took less than 30 minutes to deliver and yet, in a wide‐ranging search of the budget papers themselves, the opposition has found many hours of unfairness within these documents. Of great concern is the fact that so much of what the Treasurer proposed is for 1998‐99. I wondered on budget night why he bothered to deliver a document at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to give a few examples, the private saving scheme is to be introduced in two stages from 1 July 1998—that is, after the next budget—and 1 July 1999, which will be after the next election. By then, we may well have a new government.

The child disability allowance will be introduced from July 1998. The deferred pension bonus comes in from July 1998. The Federation Fund, which the previous speaker mentioned, which we actually need now to overcome high unemployment, will not commence until 1998‐99. I think we can truly say that, when the 1998 budget comes about, it will really be the deferred 1997 budget.

It would have been simpler to have sent us a letter and delivered it next May. Nevertheless, I believe there are hidden problems within the budget of 1997 that need to be exposed and commented on, no matter when they are due for implementation. The issues that need addressing cover child care, jobs, industry policy, superannuation, the no retirement bonus and pharmaceutical benefits.

BREAK.PARA: I listened intently to the Treasurer on budget night and I am staggered that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) seem to have totally misunderstood the needs of parents in the electorate of Greenway. The budget fails to address the concerns of Australians most in need of assistance—the unemployed, families in poverty, the aged and the working poor.

This government fails to realise that a large number of Australian families are living very close to the poverty line. A significant number of single‐income families with children, have gross household incomes, including income support payments, of less than $20,000 per annum.

The Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association, a trade union that takes a lot of interest in families and working women, has provided some data that indicates that a large proportion of working families with children are living on incomes that are just above the poverty line. Some 12 per cent of single‐wage earners and couples with children have incomes less than 10 per cent above the poverty line, suggesting that a substantial proportion of these families are at risk of poverty. The Brotherhood of St Laurence estimates that almost 200,000 workers are living in poverty.

The federal government's private savings scheme will do little to help these people. It is unlikely that the single‐income earner, on average weekly earnings, with two or three children attending school, with a mortgage to pay, and having to pay fares or run a second‐hand car to travel to and from work, would have sufficient savings to qualify for the maximum tax rebate on savings of $450. Clearly, this scheme is unfair, as the well‐off will be able to claim the $450, while most young married wage earners will not.

The Prime Minister recognised the unfairness when he stated that he would not claim this rebate himself. In press reports only two days after the budget, a number of leading figures in the financial world were very critical about the effectiveness of the savings scheme. The president of the Institute of Actuaries was quoted as saying:
The government missed an opportunity to develop a long term vision to address the significant financial problems arising from an ageing population, increased health costs and rates of savings.
So the proposal fails on two major points: firstly, it is unfair to low‐income people; and, secondly, it fails to boost national savings.

The so‐called savings scheme replaces the co‐contribution superannuation payment which the coalition parties promised prior to the last election. The three per cent plus three per cent co‐contribution scheme would have contributed an extra $400 billion to the national savings pool by the year 2020, according to the shadow Treasurer, Gareth Evans. He has given an example of the effect of the abandonment of this payment on a worker aged 35 years, on average weekly earnings, when he retires at age 65. Under the Labor Party scheme, he or she would have received a superannuation payout of $280,000. Under the coalition policy, he or she will receive $170,000—a loss of $110,000 to that worker and his or her family. The tax rebate scheme hardly compensates for that loss.

At the same time, Mr John Randall, a superannuation partner with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, estimated that the replacement of the co‐contribution with the savings rebate will halve the cost to the government, estimated at $3.76 billion over three years for the rebate compared with $7.43 billion for the co‐contribution payment. Clearly, this coalition government is asking working people to accept a lower standard of living in retirement so that they can balance the budget.

Child care is a major issue in the electorate of Greenway because of the large number of two‐income families who are forced to work to make ends meet. I referred to the previous Labor government's excellent record in this field in my speech on the appropriation bill last year when I said:

Under the previous Labor government the Blacktown local government area was approved as a high need area for new community based, long day care places and outside school hours places. Under Labor, western Sydney had 361 places for every 1,000 children, compared with the New South Wales average of 326 places per thousand. Blacktown also had the highest relative level of long day care supply in western Sydney. Under Labor, the availability and the affordability of child‐care facilities increased considerably.
This good work has now been undone by the government in just two budgets.

In the 1996 budget the coalition government cut child‐care funding by $500 million, and the 1997 budget has seen another $321 million cut—that is, $821 million in just two budgets. Further, the 1997 budget has placed a ceiling on the number of child‐care places at 7,000. The reduction of the operating funding for long day care takes effect from 1 July this year. The reduction in the operating funding for care before and after school hours will cause the same problems for this sector as the withdrawal of the funding from long day care.
