These problems are: fee increases from possibly 25 per cent to 50 per cent; more administration; a reduction in the quality of child care; a loss of qualified staff; a reduction in the standard of vocational care; and failure to meet the needs of children with special needs.

While I understand that a small number of low‐income families will benefit from the funding arrangements in this budget, most families will not. Clearly, the government has abandoned its commitment to working families who need child care. The government seems to have a policy mind‐set in operation that is determined to force women from the work force and families into the debtors court. Does anybody in the government actually care about children and families? Where, I ask, is the evidence for it?

One of the strangest aspects of this budget, in view of Australia's entrenched unemployment, is its deferred pension plan. This scheme is designed to encourage people to stay in employment longer than they themselves intend to and this government is paying them to do so. This means that the jobs that would normally go to unemployed people are not now going to be available because of this government's financial inducement. This is not just some form of social engineering where the government is trying to rule out a particular retirement age. This has already happened where people are now losing their jobs at age 50 or over and are then considered unsuitable for further work. I believe this is a total disaster but the government's move in this area is purely an economic move designed to save the government money by stopping people drawing on their pensions and the benefits that are attached to those pensions.

The previous Labor government already had the answer to our aging population with the compulsory superannuation scheme which this government is trying to destroy by not sticking to the pre-election promise to pay the co-contribution payment. My view is that if the government has spare cash to throw around, it would be far better to pay those over-50 people that I have referred to earlier that find themselves unemployed in those years between 50 and the normal retirement age of 65.

These days many people in this age group, which is the golden years of their life, find themselves on the industrial scrapheap with a mortgage still to pay, in many cases with children still to complete their education, with household items and furniture still to be paid for and at the same time are trying to make plans to move into a financially secure retirement. Many people cannot do this.

I now move on to the pharmaceutical cuts. The pharmaceutical support for families and elders has suffered the same fate as child care—two years of massive cuts: $550 million in 1996; $700 million in this budget. I have received more phone calls from my constituents on this particular issue than on any other budget item. Many of the calls that I have received relate to the increased financial burden that these costs place on the elderly. Many new drugs will be placed outside the reach of ordinary families due to the introduction of the new drug tax of up to $20 a prescription. Other drugs have been taken off the PBS, forcing families and pensioners to pay the full cost of their medicines resulting in increases ranging from $2 to $4 per prescription.

If I could then move on to education, we have seen cuts here again. We have seen a $72 million cut from vocational education and training. This is on top of the $183 million cut in last year's budget. But I want to refer to the hidden cuts to the funding for universities particularly in relation to the University of Western Sydney which is within my electorate. We have seen a one per cent cut in operating grants carried out administratively. We have seen the abolition of the Commonwealth industry places scheme. I understand a further one per cent cut to university funding in the years 2000 and 2001 coming on top of the five per cent cut announced last year will mean further difficulties particularly to new universities. For new universities that need growth funds to really get established, these types of cuts are unacceptable and will no doubt be roundly condemned by all western Sydney MPs irrespective of their political persuasions.

Local community organisations and business groups have lobbied the government prior to the budget. The Parramatta City Chamber of Commerce and Industry sent correspondence to Senator Vanstone on 28 April and said in part:

The University of Western Sydney sits right in the middle of an area that contributes 8 per cent of gross national product. We currently have approximately 1.6 million people living in the greater west and this is projected to increase to 2.25 million by the year 2011.

There are already significantly less opportunities for young people and mature age people to access tertiary education in the greater west than other areas such as Adelaide and Perth and we think the university should continue to develop and so serve the community.

The same correspondence from the Parramatta City Chamber of Commerce and Industry refers to the expectation of growing support and particular industry support for this university. However, the letter goes on to say:

Until the support becomes adequate, we urge that the University of Western Sydney be allowed to expand and develop as it has done since 1989 and in so doing serve the huge community of the greater west.
In the same vein, the President of the Greater Western Sydney Regional Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mrs Betty Barrie, also wrote to the minister and I will quote from her letter:

The restricted number of higher education placements in Sydney's greater west forces many thousands of university students to travel long distances into the Sydney C.B.D area. This adversely impacts upon their travel time, their families, employers, personal health, traffic jams, the environment and the rail system that is already strained during peak periods.

It is time that the inequity in higher education resources within the greater Sydney area is addressed (as is now being tackled in the public health system). Whilst recognising that all universities can develop `valid' claims for funding, the case for greater western Sydney is overwhelming—the resources must in future be invested where the need is—where the people are—where the jobs are—where there is long term growth.

To put my interpretation on Mrs Barrie's letter, as the Labor Party is developing the beds for the west policy in respect of health policies in New South Wales, I am saying that we should also move to have university places moved to the west.

To further add to the argument in support of additional funds for the University of Western Sydney, I note that the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research has carried out a study on the effect of financial cuts imposed on the University of Western Sydney. The results of this study are reported in the Australian Financial Review of 23 May. The report makes the following points relating to funding cuts to the University of Western Sydney: that they are likely to have a serious impact on the economic health and employment prospects in this area; that a one per cent reduction in funding would translate to a $3.3 million fall in gross national product; and it concludes that UWS's role is vital in providing higher education in western Sydney and that reducing its budget and student numbers would affect gross national product and widen the existing skills gap between western Sydney and the rest of the metropolitan area.

In referring to these references to the effectiveness of the University of Western Sydney, I am appealing to the coalition government for additional growth funds for this university until it can establish links with business organisations, as the more established and older universities have done over probably up to 100 years that they have been in existence.

I would like to move on to the important role that the University of Western Sydney is providing in the field of Aboriginal education, and the effects that the budget cuts will have on these programs. These are cuts to travel allowance for the Aboriginal students who are attending university. The cuts are very mean‐spirited indeed in the context of the Australian reconciliation conference and of the debate on the stolen Aboriginal children that has been held in this parliament over the past few weeks.

The cuts will make it impossible for Aboriginal students from more remote communities to come to universities such as the University of Western Sydney, according to the Vice‐Chancellor, Professor Deryck Schreuder. He has said:

I am deeply concerned that the cuts announced in this budget to take effect in 1998, will seriously affect the opportunities of Aborigines in distant townships and areas who want and deserve a chance to expand their skills, often so that those skills can be put to work for the benefit of their own communities.

Ann Flood, the Director of the Gool an gullia Centre at the University of Western Sydney Macarthur, has said that the cuts have thrown into doubt the future of the Aboriginal rural education program. This program draws students from New South Wales and southern Queensland. It involves a residential school for Aboriginal students at UWS Macarthur for five two‐week periods during the year, and DEETYA funding is essential for accommodation, travel and incidental costs.

Because of the cuts, many students will be cut off from the scheme with only one year to go after studying for four years. Many more will be cut off midstream. In all, over 150 students will be affected. There are 16 graduates this year—graduates with education degrees who will go back to their own communities to teach. The benefit these graduates bring to the wider Aboriginal community is immeasurable and is a reflection of the commitment by the UWS Macarthur over a period of 15 years. Ms Flood said:
The cuts represent a huge step back on gains made in Aboriginal education in the last 20 years. The rug is being pulled out from beneath their feet.

There are many things that I can speak about in this budget, but I do feel—as do most other western Sydney MPs—that we have to put in a special plug for the University of Western Sydney. I will conclude this part of my submission by referring to a letter from Professor Juchau, Dean of the Faculty of Management at the University of Western Sydney. His letter says in part:
For your information reported graduate ratings (1996) of our courses placed them in the top ten of the 37 universities in Australia. Our property course was rated first amongst its competitors.
Our first class learning facility at our new campus at Quakers Hill—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elson, Kay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to debate the coalition government's second budget as set out in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98, a budget that continues to deliver on our election commitments to families and small business and our promise to future generations to repay the debt that Labor left to them. That is the bottom line in this debate—the legacy of the debt and deficit that Labor left behind.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for members opposite to come into this chamber with their hands on their hearts and decry some of the reductions in government spending that had to be made. No‐one on this side of the House denies that some of these decisions have been tough, but we also say that they are fair. But it is blatantly hypocritical for the opposition to come here and carp and complain about cutbacks that were necessary only because of their own failed economic management.

When Labor came to power in 1983, foreign debt was $23 billion. Thirteen years later, it had grown to more than $180 billion; but they did nothing to address it—nothing at all. The coalition's first two budgets have begun to put us back on track and they have turned a $10.3 billion Labor deficit into a coalition surplus next year. This is the first time for more than a decade that this country and Commonwealth will not run up a debt. This year we will actually start to pay it back and we will repay over $5 billion—and that is without raising taxes. This is in stark contrast to Labor's attitude in government: big spending, big taxing and massive debts, leaving it all for our kids to worry about and pay back in the future.

I am proud to be part of a government that takes a much more responsible approach to economic management. The families and small businesses in my electorate of Forde are certainly enjoying one of the most obvious benefits of the government's economic management, and that is the reduction in interest rates. We all remember Labor's record high interest rates in excess of 17 per cent. It meant a second mortgage for my husband and me, and it saw many families that I knew lose their homes.

It was very gratifying when, in my electorate only last week, a young gentleman in his early twenties came and told me to go down and give Mr Costello a pat on the back on his behalf, because he had been on the verge of losing his house when the interest rates dropped. He now saves an extra $300 a month and he said that that was the only thing that saved him from losing his house. That is what this government is all about: helping our young families get a start and letting them feel and know what it is like to have come true their dream of owning a house and home and starting their families off. We are giving them the best chance of that. So far, since the election in March last year, families with a mortgage of around $100,000 are saving close to $30 per month in interest rates. That is a huge benefit and, as I said before, many of the battling families in Forde asked me to pass on to the Treasurer their thanks for easing their burden.

There are many more benefits to this budget and the government's very responsible and practical approach. One of the benefits I would like to focus on today in the remainder of my speech is the innovative work for the dole scheme. This budget allocates $21 million over two years to fund up to 10,000 places in 70 pilot projects. Prior to the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in February that the government would introduce work for the dole, this was probably the most commonly raised suggestion that I received from local residents. During the election campaign and after, people continually raised the issue. I am very proud to be part of a government that is listening to the community and delivering on what they want.

The bottom line is that work for the dole makes sense. It is not introduced as a panacea for unemployment and we have never claimed it to be. It is a practical and genuine way of involving jobseekers in the community, of giving them hands‐on experience and helping break the unproductive cycles that so many unemployed people, particularly long‐term unemployed, fall into. As the Queensland Premier Bob Borbidge said:
It tackles a very serious problem in our community and it will allow a great many young Australians to seize the work ethic where they have been denied that opportunity in the past.
Even New South Wales Premier Bob Carr said on work for the dole:
Youth unemployment is a curse in our society and anything that provides a ray of hope and a training experience is going to be welcomed by all of us.
As it has been welcomed by the Australian public.

In my electorate, like many others across Australia, I have been inundated with input and interest from local community groups, council and individuals who are very supportive of the plan and anxious to be involved. I have also been lobbying very strongly, on behalf of the communities of the regional townships of Beaudesert and Boonah in my electorate, for these areas to form part of the pilot scheme.

Beaudesert and Boonah were hard hit by a closure early last year of the Australian Meat Holdings plant at Bromelton, following protracted industrial disputes under the previous government. The plant has formed the backbone of the local community for over 40 years. I am very pleased to say that the local community is rallying to attract other industries to the area and promote the many benefits of the region.

On that note, I would like to acknowledge and thank the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) for recently agreeing to an additional $200,000, on top of the $200,000 announced in December last year, to get the Beaudesert small business incubator up and running. The community is very exited about this project and they are gratified that the government has displayed such faith in them. I look forward at a later date to reporting to the House on the centre's success. There is no doubt that regional areas like Beaudesert and Boonah will benefit greatly from the work for the dole scheme.The beauty of this scheme is that it involves whole communities and provides benefits that go far beyond the individual.

As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I have visited a number of secondary schools around the country in the past six months as part of an inquiry into factors affecting youth employment. We raised the issue of work for the dole—and most of the time it was raised by the schoolchildren—and overwhelmingly the majority of the young people have been in favour of the scheme. They recognise that they will be given genuine work experience. Moreover, they believe it will help the younger generation regain the trust and respect of the older generation. I thought this was a particularly insightful comment. They believe that the older generation has lost faith in them and the media image is always that the young people do not want to work for the dole. They believe that this gives them the opportunity to prove their worth to all communities within Australia.

These young people recognise there is a negative stereotype of young jobseekers in some sectors of the community, including many employers, for various reasons. They see this scheme as helping them to dispel the myth and prove that they are worthy members of the community who want to play their part.

Another observation was that the projects they will work on will be community‐based and will help young people to get to know their local areas, build civic pride and feel a sense of belonging that is so much missing today. There is no doubt that long‐term unemployment, especially for young people, leads them to feel very isolated and withdrawn from society. The work for the dole scheme draws them back into their community and lets them know that we value their skill and attitude and that we want them to contribute.

In my view, it has enormous psychological benefits. I know that there have been some people who argue that there must be structured training as part of this scheme. I believe these people are missing the point. Work for the dole is not about training. It does not pretend to be, and the government has committed over $1.7 billion over the next four years for increased apprenticeships and traineeships for our young people. Various training programs remain available to the unemployed and will continue to do so.

Work for the dole is about discipline, commitment and work experience. I have no doubt that many people who participate in this scheme will pick up a variety of skills and there will be an element of training involved along the way. The point of the scheme is not to push people into another training scheme that will heighten expectations and ultimately prove to be futile, as Labor did during their time in office. They operated a system of revolving door training schemes, most of which failed miserably in terms of job placement.

One of my constituents wrote to me recently congratulating the government on the work for the dole scheme. She had been unemployed for the past 14 years and her husband had been unemployed for the past four years, despite completing skillshare training schemes. Of those schemes, she wrote:

It seems to be only providing jobs for the trainers. We've seen the published numbers of people that have been helped, but we do not believe it. We feel the unemployed were being "hidden" while on the training scheme.

This reflects the feedback I have had from many of my constituents who have been directly involved in the scheme and who have become disillusioned and frustrated—especially by the previous government's approach, which was basically to throw money at the problem and hope it went away. On the work for the dole scheme, my constituent writes that her husband has been saying for many years that he wants to do this to keep up his skills and to show employers that he wants to work.

It seems incredible to me that some critics have suggested that the work for the dole should be a comprehensive training scheme. As any employer will tell you, training is only one aspect that makes a good employee. In many cases, employers are happy to offer training themselves for jobs that they have. Of greater importance is the concept of work ethic and the ability to stick at a job, have pride in your work and have confidence in yourself. Sadly, many young people today are not given the opportunities to develop these aspects of themselves. How can they develop a strong work ethic if they have never been able to find work? How can they know the commitment it takes, or the pride in a job well done, if they have not had the chance to go to a workplace and play their role?

Work for the dole does not provide jobs—and we have never promised it would—but it does provide skills, commitment and a sense of belonging right now. Real jobs will be provided in the coming years as the government's economic plan continues to deliver better deals for small business and encourage private sector growth and expansion. But, unlike the previous government, we are not prepared to sit back and let our young people languish on the unemployment heap until that time. Work for the dole gives them a focus and valuable work skills now which help prepare them as jobs become available. As I said in the beginning, it simply makes good sense. It has broad community support, including most job seekers, and many people cannot believe it has taken so long for a government to introduce such a scheme.

Predictably, those opposite have been begrudging in their qualified support for the scheme. They realise that this has widespread community support but, as they have in the past, they want to make it more complex and discuss it some more, and basically delay its introduction. The Australian public do not understand this attitude. But perhaps we can gain an insight into the opposition's attitude if we look at comments by the ACTU President, Jennie George, in the Financial Review, shortly after the announcement of the scheme. She said:
The union movement would be dead against any move by the government to introduce a work for the dole scheme.
`Dead against'. It is clear to see why the opposition's position is so unclear on this commonsense plan. They are shackled by the union movement, once again.

I am pleased that the coalition government has no such shackles. The 1997 budget, with funding for work for the dole pilot, is part of a commonsense approach to meeting the needs of those Australians who are currently unemployed. As I said, we do not pretend for a moment that this is the panacea to the unemployment problem. In the Age on 12 February, political commentator Paddy McGuinness in his column said:

Labour market analysts who have studied the issues have long since agreed that any approach to lowering the rate of unemployment overall must involve not a single policy measure, nor a grand plan, but a whole suite of ad hoc and specially designed measures to deal with different aspects and segments of the larger problem.

Clearly, part of that `larger problem' is the erosion of personal confidence and the difficulty in developing a strong work ethic that occurs when people, particularly young people, have been without a job for some time. In fact, I think the psychological effects of unemployment—many of which can be addressed with an effective work for the dole program—are part of other larger problems such as youth suicide, which is appalling in this country.

As a member of the Family and Community Affairs Committee, I have had the opportunity to examine issues such as teenage pregnancy, family breakdown, juvenile crime and other social problems. Again, the work for the dole scheme will not solve these problems overnight but I firmly believe it will help many individuals and form part of a larger solution to these problems.

I want to reflect again on the record of the previous government on youth unemployment and debt. During its term in office, the youth unemployment rate was around 30 per cent—even higher in some regional areas—and debt ballooned. Labor had no answer except, as I said, to throw money at the problem, increase expectations, and cause a great deal of frustration and resentment. Our work for the dole does not purport to create jobs. Jobs will be created as small businesses grow and expand, as greater confidence is created through the sound economic management of this government, which is what the budget is all about. But, as part of the government's commonsense approach, work for the dole will provide hope, skills and help unemployed people to be more involved and feel a part of their local community.

The young and the long‐term unemployed deserve better than the revolving door training programs of the previous government. They are certainly getting better from this government—as are families, small business owners, and future generations of Australians, who will not have a massive debt to pay back because we are starting to address the problems of debt and deficit in a very responsible way.

On behalf of the people of Forde, I am pleased to strongly support the 1997 budget and to congratulate the Prime Minister for his personal commitment to the work for the dole scheme, as do many other young Australians of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the speaker who immediately preceded me, the member for Forde (Mrs Elson), that my judgment about the budget differs very significantly from her concluding remarks. The three primary objectives of the budget should have been job creation, family security and national savings. It has been recognised in the community generally that the budget sank without a ripple.

SPEECH.PARA: As you well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, a person who represents the electorate of Throsby spoke earlier this morning and made a similar observation. When you refer to the Commonwealth budget, people now ask, `What budget?' The impact of the budget was minimal as far as people's understanding of it is concerned.

The unfortunate thing is that, in terms of the impact of that budget, it will be very different indeed. It certainly will not be minimal. The budget does nothing for the three primary objectives—job creation, family security and national savings. Ross Gittins, an economic journalist for whom I have great admiration, wrote in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 May, following the budget, that, `This budget is a confidence trick.' Ross Gittins was right.

Before referring briefly to the three chief objectives, I suggest that this government is increasingly being recognised as a government that issues high‐sounding rhetoric but is, essentially a government of mimicry, gimmickry, cynicism and hypocrisy. I will give some examples. First of all, to justify that unconscionable sale of one third of Telstra—perhaps yielding a total of $12 to $14 billion—it undertook to establish an electoral slush fund of $1 billion. Some of those funds have already been allocated, but by far the bigger proportion of it remains to be allocated.

I make the observation that, if that money is going to be spread around Australia on various types of environmental restoration and protection schemes, I will be putting in a very strong bid for some of those funds to go to Lake Macquarie, which borders the greater part of my electorate, in order to assist in necessary remedial work in relation to that lake—the largest salt water lake in Australia. It is a magnificent natural feature and an important asset. It is in need of remedial work, and I expect that some of those funds will be applied to it.

The member who preceded me referred to the work for the dole scheme. I find that expression offensive, insensitive and demeaning. Any other type of label could have been attached to it, but to call it `work for the dole' I find particularly offensive. It reflects unfavourably on the government that such an expression should have been used.

Any members and supporters of the government—including the member who preceded me—who are sensitive to many of the social problems and traumas associated with unemployment on the part of these young people will understand why I say that identifying assistance to them as work for the dole is demeaning—and it is demeaning.

And now, of course, we have got packages—a number of important national initiatives appearing under that high sounding title, the Federation Fund. Most of those allocations would have been made, anyway. I am sure that there would have been a package put together that would have contained some of those. Some that have been announced—such as, the national museum and the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies with a total cost, I think, of something like $70 million—I endorse. But out of that total of $1 billion, that still leaves $930 million in that slush fund and we on the opposition side will be observing very closely just what happens to that money. In the Sydney Morning Herald, 14 May, in reference to the federal fund, Tony Wright said, `Bring out the whiteboards,' and we know what message that was supposed to convey.

I said that I wanted to make some brief reference to the question of job creation. The budget forecasts a growth rate over the next 12 months of 3.75 per cent and a reduction in unemployment. Those two figures are incompatible, and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Treasury advisers, and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the government, their supporters and the wider community, know that they are incompatible. If we achieve a growth figure of only 3.75 per cent over the next 12 months, unemployment will grow. Why then, contrary to the advice, and with the material that would have been provided from the Department of Treasury, would those figures have been cooked up in the Treasurer's office, as they quite clearly were.

At the present time there are a quarter of a million long‐term unemployed people. That is the highest level of long‐term unemployed for two years, and the figure is growing. And this was the government which suggested that it would have some beneficial impact on the level of unemployment and, particularly, on long‐term unemployment. As a direct result of that government's budget, there are going to be another 16,500 public service jobs disappear, and that is in addition to the first instalment of 11,500 public service jobs which have already disappeared. The rhetoric of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) at question time has become a tired joke.

Last year the government slashed more than 230,000 training places—and I emphasise the word `training'—by cutting $1.8 billion from labour market programs. But Minister Kemp refers to the work for the dole scheme and that miserable 800 places identified as being provided in the Green Corps scheme as though they herald a new era of grand vision and compassion. Members of the opposition and people in the wider community are not fooled by that.

Before I get on to that savings initiative, I also want to make some very brief reference to the question of family security. It is in this area that the attacks have gone out in all directions. In housing, for example, there are about 230,000 families on public sector housing waiting lists in Australia at the present time. But despite that, this present government has cut the funding by $50 million from the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement.

In the area of health, we know the limits that have been placed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and the requirement for people to take cheap drugs, even though those cheap drugs may not be useful for their particular ailment. And the total number of drugs, of course, has been cut significantly.

In the area of child care, there is going to be the imposition of a limit of 7,000 on new private sector places, and a limit of 20 hours per week for parents who are not working. People, particularly those single parents who are undertaking training courses and who are studying, now feel threatened by this, and they should because they are going to be very seriously disadvantaged.

I now come to the question of national savings. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall the former government's proposal was that the second tranche of its tax cuts would have been paid in the form of a three per cent contribution to superannuation to match an employee contribution of three per cent. Under that compulsory type of superannuation arrangement, that would have represented the equivalent of nine per cent of total wages and salaries going into the superannuation funds. It was intended that that would increase to a total of 12 per cent in the early part of the next century. So that contribution was necessary as one of the steps on the ladder towards the total of about 12 per cent of wages and salaries being paid into superannuation funds. That represents literally hundreds of billions of dollars of national savings.

The present government, despite the fact that at the last election it indicated that it would honour the undertaking that the Labor Party had previously given about the second tranche of that tax cut arrangement, has now repudiated that position completely. That arrangement was one of the great national policy initiatives of the Keating Government. I endorsed it then, supported it then, and I still do. It was doing two things: first of all, it was making it possible, with government support, for people to provide more adequately for their own retirement income, their own retirement security; and, in addition, it was going to make a major impact in the critical area of national savings.

Without a major impact in that area, there is very little possibility, as everyone knows, that we are going to be able to bring down the current account deficit, which is the most intractable problem that the Australian economy faces. The present government's record has been deplorable. As I said, it initially undertook to pay the tax cuts in full, then it repudiated that position. It is now going to use those funds for this crazy savings tax break.

The budget as a whole, as Ross Gittins and others have indicated, is a fraudulent document. In terms of its general forecasts, for example, observations have been made by well‐known commentators, including Mr Chris Richardson, who is a former Treasury forecaster and now a director of Access Economics. He said the government's economic forecasts did not add up. I have already given some reasons why that was the position.

In relation to the tax rebate on savings, we know that the proposal is that $450 per year, on tax day, will in effect be returned to people who have been able to earn interest on $60,000 at five per cent. They do not have to have saved that during the previous 12 months. All they have to do is to have savings equal to, say, $60,000 being held at five per cent and they will then qualify for a straight rebate of $450. Let me say this: there are not going to be many of my constituents who get $450 back, because they have not got $60,000 saved—nor will they.

The tax rebate is not going to encourage savings. You will remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it was supposed to be the cornerstone of the budget. It was the core of the budget. It was the great initiative. It would make inroads into that problem of national savings. Even kids at high school know that savings are not a function of either interest rates or concessional arrangements of that kind. Savings are a simple function of income: if you have got the income, you can save and you will save; if you do not have the income, you cannot save and you will not save—and $450 a year will make no difference. In fact, it will reduce national savings. The point has been made that not only will it not encourage private sector savings, but as a result of the government applying its own revenue to that purpose it will reduce public sector savings. The overall result is that national savings will decline.

The tax rebate was the core of the government's budget: it would `increase national savings'. But it will do nothing of the kind. Even Treasury officials are indicating at the present time that it will not have the effect that it was supposed to have had. In fact, it will have a negative impact on savings and it is going to cost $2 billion over two years. It is also more likely to worsen the foreign debt problem, which is already accelerating under this government—the government that assured everyone that it was going to get the foreign debt under control. It has not done it, and it is not doing it.

The government claims the rebate is a reward for thrift. My constituents can be as thrifty as they like, but they are not going to put away 60,000 bucks at five per cent. And there are some people in the community who could spend as liberally from their income as they possibly could and who would still not avoid putting away in excess of $60,000 in savings. High income earners will pick up the $450 even though they reduce their savings—and yet it is supposed to be a means of encouraging saving. As well, high income earners who have $60,000 put away at five per cent will pick up the $450 on tax day and can then take the $60,000 out of the bank account and go away for a holiday.

If we need any further evidence of the fact that it is not only inequitable but embarrassing to those people who will benefit from it, we had the absurdity of the situation just recently in the House of Representatives where the Prime Minister, in order to avoid embarrassment and to acknowledge the inequity, injustice and disgrace of that particular proposal, said that he would not claim it. Why will he not claim it? Because he would be too damned embarrassed to do so. He knows it is not justified and that it is only those people with high savings who are going to benefit from it.

What this amounts to is that my constituents, who will be paying their tax and not getting the $450, will be the people who are taxed and charged in order to transfer all of those $450 rebates to the high income earners who will benefit from them. To benefit, of course, taxpayers must already hold those savings which are already earning interest; and, to get maximum benefit, a taxpayer would need the $60,000 in savings in order to earn five per cent interest or to provide an interest income during the year of $3,000.

High income earners are unlikely to be encouraged to do any further saving as a result of the promise of $450 each year, and the total impact of that particular provision will be nothing like the government has been suggesting. A taxpayer can also gain that $450 if they contribute $3,000 per year to superannuation; but that still does not include many of my constituents. If, instead of $60,000, they hold $30,000 in investments earning 10 per cent, that still does not include my constituents. In addition, I do not know what immediate impact the measure was supposed to have, because it will not even start to come into operation until 1 July next year and will not be fully implemented until 1 July 1999.

Comments have been made by a number of commentators in relation to the rebate. I have mentioned some of those by Ross Gittins. The 17 May editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald said that the `inequity of the savings rebate has been dramatically conceded', in reference to the Prime Minister promising in parliament that he would not be claiming the rebate and his demand that the Opposition Leader, Mr Beazley, show the same restraint. I notice that the Prime Minister made no such demand against members of his own front bench, and so they can all pick up their $450. Brian Toohey said, in the Sun‐Herald of 18 May, that wage earners—and my constituents are wage earners—`will also be helping to fund the rebate for multi‐millionaires who could easily spend the entire $450 on a single roll of the dice at a casino or on a few glasses of good red wine.'

Mr Deputy Speaker, that whole approach has been nothing short of disgraceful. I have heard the rhetoric in the chamber, I have heard it during question time, I have heard it in debate, I have heard it around the traps in public comments, I have heard it in public statements and in public speeches by this government.

This government introduced a budget which we saw sink without a ripple. People have forgotten the details but now the impact of those details, those elements of the budget, will be brought home to them very, very forcefully. There are those cuts to major social programs and as those cuts become apparent, as they start to bite, as people become disadvantaged by them, as they will be, then increasingly they will know very well the true nature of this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997-98 and to congratulate the government on bringing forward a second responsible budget.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two important themes that this budget builds on from the 1996 budget and they are no new taxes and a budget surplus by the year 1998‐99. It is very positive that we are moving towards a budget surplus because this country can no longer afford to run deficits. The level of government debt is this government's responsibility and we must ensure that we fix up the problems left by the previous government. We inherited a $10 billion current account deficit from them, and that was on top of an accumulated Commonwealth debt which exploded between 1990 and 1996 to $75 billion.

Indeed, this budget is built on the premise that we will move towards a surplus. At the end of the first term of this government that surplus will be a $1.6 billion, and as we move into the next century we will be looking at accumulated budget surpluses of up to $5 billion. That will go towards repaying not only our current account deficit but also go some way towards repaying some of our Commonwealth debt. No individual or group can continue to spend more than they earn be it a small business in Ballina, a pensioner couple retired in Tweed Heads, or a successful accountant in Byron Bay.

One of the purposes of the asset sales that are happening, particularly with this one-third sale of Telstra, is to repay part of that Commonwealth debt that we have accumulated. Likewise, with the privatisation of the FAC—and we are actually retaining title—a lot of those proceeds will go towards retiring debt. No matter how much or how little money you earn, you should not spend more than you earn, and the same goes for a government. Overspending is irresponsible and it only serves to leave future generations with outstanding debt.

I would like to add that it is interesting to note that the New South Wales government at the moment is contemplating privatising the power authority. That is breathtaking in the sense that it is valued at $22 billion. So asset sales are not unique to this government: it is happening with the New South Wales ALP government as well.

Rather than increase tax, which occurred under the previous ALP government, we are actually including tax cuts in the form of a 15 per cent rebate on savings. This is progressive. Lower income earners, contrary to what was said by the previous speaker, have the most to gain because at marginal tax rates, and let us say for people on incomes between $5,400 and $20,000, they will only be paying five per cent as opposed to 20 per cent. So it is far more beneficial for lower income earners on that particular tax scale.

The proposal by the ALP and the Democrats to means test this measure should be condemned. The National Party and the Liberal Party said during the election campaign that they would govern for all Australians. This savings rebate is available to all Australians. This is of particular benefit to the thousands of self-funded retirees who have decided that they will retire on the beautiful far north coast of New South Wales and who rely heavily on interest from savings, and also for people who are on part pensions.

In the area of small business, one of the great things that this government has done, particularly in the budget, is introduce changes to capital gains tax. The actual level of capital gains will now be up to half a million dollars. If you have a company, or if you are in a 50 per cent partnership with your spouse, then you will be able to roll over up to $1 million. This is particularly significant if you are a small business operator at Cabarita Beach, at Alstonville, or a surf board factory at Byron Bay.

Many of those people employ labour. They sacrifice those savings, obviously, to pay superannuation for their employees—which they have to—and they do not provide for their own superannuation. Indeed, their own superannuation is when they come to sell their business. These changes to capital gains will mean that their final nest egg, when they do sell their business, can be rolled over. It is also heartening to know that the change in test has meant that you do not have to just transfer into like businesses; you can transfer into any business or roll into superannuation.

There have been changes, of course, to the FBT regime which was introduced by the previous government. There are no new taxes on taxis or on parking. There are moves to reduce compliance procedures, where businesses paying less than $25,000 per annum in tax can submit tax on a quarterly, rather than on a monthly basis. This goes hand‐in‐glove with changes that we have made to industrial relations, where we have a far more flexible industrial relations environment and, indeed, a much fairer unfair dismissal law.

But the most interesting point with small business and with the mums and dads and families of Australia is the interest rate regime which has brought about the lowering of interest rates over the last 15 months. Indeed, if you look at the average Australian who has a $100,000 mortgage, with the fall in interest rates now, that is currently a saving of $225 per month, or the equivalent—if you want to look at it before tax—of $100 a week pay increase. That is what the $225 savings has meant, and that has come about because of the responsible policies of this government and because of the credit rating that foreign companies and foreign institutions are now giving to this country's monetary policy.

In the area of employment, the coalition sees the success of small business as the key to solving the crisis that has happened not just over the last couple of years, but over the last decade in this country. It was obvious that during those 13 years of Labor you could not help the unemployed by milking business for more taxes and throwing money into unsuccessful training courses. This is not to say that they all were, but the premise was wrong. It was penalising the greatest employment generator, which is small business, at the expense of real long‐term job creation.

Instead of spending billions of dollars on labour market programs, many of which were grossly unsuccessful—particularly new work opportunities which have now come in at four per cent—there is a changing government focus onto apprenticeships. Two hundred and sixty five million dollars will be focused on 100,000 new apprenticeships. This is all part of $450 million going into national apprenticeship schemes.

Changes will be happening next year with the combined service delivery agencies of the CES and the DSS and, of course, with the creation of the EPEs and the PEPEs which will give greater competition to the market and provide not just placement facilities but training. Fifty million dollars will also go to vocational education in schools; $24 million will go to one‐stop apprenticeship shops and, of course, there is the government's plan for the work for the dole scheme—and I do hope that I receive some of those projects on the far north coast.

In the area of education—and this is where we are getting right back to basics to solve our unemployment—we are working to provide better standard of education to the next generation of Australians that are coming forward into the labour market. To this end, this government is spending an extra $152 million, part of $3.75 billion in education for this year. This is part of a $14 billion project over the next four years.

Many schools have already benefited in the Richmond electorate, notably, public schools such as Murwillumbah High School and Pottsville Primary School, and private schools such as St Anthony's in Kingscliff and Shearwater in Mullumbimby. And I do hope to see special emergency funding for Ballina Christian School which I opened last weekend.

But the real focus in education is on improvement in the areas of literacy to give young primary school children those basic skills of reading and writing so that when they leave high school they are equipped and prepared to enter the labour market with adequate life skills. Unfortunately, there has been a deterioration over the last couple of years to an extent now that one in five young Australians who leave school are illiterate. Therefore, $560 million is going to three special programs: $160 million to literacy; $156 million to students with special learning needs, and $54 million to languages. Of course, there is an extra top‐up of $191 million to TAFE.

But it is the elderly that I would like to focus on because, out of 148 federal seats only three seats have a higher elderly population than does the seat of Richmond in the far north of NSW. Pensioners will have their rate of pension locked in for the first time by the Commonwealth legislation at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. In addition, of course, 10,500 veterans will become eligible for compensation for injuries or disease resulting from overseas service. Twelve additional areas of service have been included in the veterans' entitlements. Likewise, for older Australians, we reaffirm that there will be additional funding of $10 million over four years for people with dementia and their carers. Likewise, $14.7 million goes to funding the palliative care program, which is part of, obviously, a rather controversial debate that this parliament had recently.

Government assistance for home nursing will be boosted with a $16.60 per fortnight increase in domiciliary nursing care benefit, which is particularly relevant to the aged population that I represent. Also, 15,800 pensioners and part‐pensioners will receive approximately $110 million worth of federal government money.

In the area of health, I am particularly pleased that there was an announcement of $40 million over four years to support improvements in acute health care for hospital patients. In addition, $34 million will go to hepatitis C surveillance and education, the National Breast Cancer Centre and the national anti‐tobacco campaign. It is particularly important that we are having this debate at the moment in this parliament. Legislation which addresses nursing homes and aged care will be brought before the parliament. We have a huge demand for nursing homes and hostels in my electorate, particularly in Ballina and Alstonville in the south and the Tweed region in the north.

For regional Australia, though, there has been a major plus and this is continuing from last year, particularly for highways. This year, in the Richmond electorate alone, $3 million of Commonwealth money is being spent on the Bangalow bypass; $20 million has already been spent on construction of the Chinderah bypass bridge; $107 million is committed to the Chinderah to the Billinudgel part of the Pacific Highway; $11.8 million is currently being expended on the Ewingsdale to Tyagarah section and $11 million on the Brunswick bypass. Capital infrastructure is pouring into the Richmond electorate at a rate that has not been seen since Federation. The diesel fuel rebate is another icon that has been protected within the budget. Of course, $1 billion will go to the establishment of the Federation Fund.

All of these initiatives within the budget illustrate that this government is looking for a budget which provides consistency, which provides a budget surplus and which can also deliver in the long term to make Australia a more sustainable country.

What is interesting is that there have been no new taxes in this budget, unlike what has happened in New South Wales recently in respect of poker machines. I would like to focus on the New South Wales ALP government's budget decision recently to increase poker machine taxes by a further five per cent to 30 per cent, which is in addition to tax increases already announced this year. This tax will cause the loss of hundreds of direct jobs and thousands of indirect jobs in the Richmond electorate. I am sure the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) will recognise the stupidity of this tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bold decision.

—There is no other way to describe this tax increase than as a blatant revenue grab by the New South Wales Right of the ALP, unlike the Left who are far more responsible in these matters, to fund the Sydney Olympics. It is a fact that the Carr government promised in the last state election that it would not increase taxes or introduce new taxes. Yet, in its second budget, it introduced a whole raft of new taxes: taxes on land, cars, beds and now taxes on clubs.
—Only in Rose Bay.

—Unfortunately, the club industry is not just in Rose Bay. I am sure you will answer for this. But the club industry is absolutely vital to the New South Wales far north coast for its employment, tourism, sporting and community facilities. The Tweed is the home of some of the biggest and most successful clubs in the state, including Twin Towns Services Club, Tweed Heads Bowls Club, South Tweed Heads Bowls Club, Seagulls Rugby League Club, Murwillumbah Services Club and Kingscliff—just to name a few.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Tweed Valley, there are 12 clubs with a total membership of over 100,000 people. These clubs directly employ 1,500 people with a total wages bill of $33 million. In addition, they spend $50 million per annum to suppliers and subcontractors. They donate over $4 million to sporting groups, charities, schools, emergency services and, in particular, to the local hospitals.

In the lead‐up to the ALP state budget, Tweed and Murwillumbah hospitals were in great need of a major increase in funding to help reduce the hospital queues and the strain on our local hospital services. It is therefore ironic that instead of receiving a major funding boost from the ALP, one of the hospitals' biggest benefactors, the clubs, have been put in jeopardy. Even the left wing of the ALP feel that what the New South Wales Right has been doing is absolutely disgraceful. Twin Towns actively donates funds to over 120 different local organisations, such as the Guide Dog Association, the rescue service, Lifeline and the child flight helicopter service. The Tweed Heads and South Tweed bowls clubs donate to another 100 organisations between them, including the Tweed Heads police and the Salvation Army.

The 12 clubs in the Tweed Valley make a combined profit of $4 million after tax. They are already paying $20 million every year to the state government, including $16 million from poker machines. An increase in poker machine tax would take an extra $5 million out of the Tweed and turn this $4 million profit into a $1 million loss. A $1 million loss will result in the loss of 600 direct jobs and 1,500 indirect jobs. Such a level of redundancy would be absolutely devastating to the Tweed, which already has high levels of unemployment. Indeed, it would be devastating for many Labor heartland areas in Sydney.

No population of 63,000 can withstand the removal of $5 million from the local economy or the overnight disappearance of 2,100 jobs. I will certainly hold Bob Carr, Michael Egan and local Lismore based MLC Janelle Saffin personally responsible for any loss of jobs as a result of this tax increase. I call upon some of the movers and shakers within the federal left wing of the Labor Party to show their true influence and reverse this decision.

A couple of the clubs in the Tweed Valley are already at a very vulnerable point. Some have already closed, such as Terranora Country Club and Club Watersports. Seagulls Rugby League Club, which has a voluntary administrator, unfortunately yesterday retrenched over 100 people. My concern now is that this new tax increase could seriously jeopardise the overall viability of Seagulls, one of the icons of the Tweed.

Turning to the southern part of the Richmond electorate, I take this opportunity to mention the turnover and employment generated by Ballina RSL, Ballina Bowling Club, Byron Bay Services Club, Mullumbimby Ex‐Services Club, and some clubs outside my electorate, notably Lismore Workers Club and RSL. All of these clubs have done their sums and found that, between them, they stand to lose over $1.5 million in the Lismore‐Ballina region.

I call on the Carr government to review this budget measure. If they are too politically stubborn to admit their folly and refuse to drop this idea, then I call on the New South Wales Upper House to block this legislation. Lismore MLC Janelle Saffin can play a large role here, as can some of her federal ALP colleagues. If she truly wants to represent her north coast constituents, if she really wants to do anything for the bar attendants, the musicians, the cleaners, the tradesmen, the carpenters, the cooks, the waiters and waitresses who work in these clubs, if she really cares for the thousands of pensioners who love their clubs for the good meals and great entertainment, then she will cross the floor and vote against increasing poker machine taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.

—I will not hold my breath. Her silence has been deafening, as indeed has her representation in the New South Wales Upper House where she has the dubious record of having spoken only 12 times since being elected. This is her big chance to prove her worth for the local community against the New South Wales Right. If the ALP does not have the political backbone to reverse this decision, I join with my state colleague Don Beck in calling on Mr Carr and Mr Egan to implement a buffer zone in the New South Wales‐Queensland border region, just as there is a buffer zone for tobacco taxes and fuel excises.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, this is a most ridiculous tax. The Labor Party will pay for it, not just on the north coast but in their own home seats in Sydney, and particularly the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese). There will be a massive campaign against the state ALP and, if the tax is not reversed, it could happen on a national level, within the federal parliament.

The government's federal budget where there were no tax increases and where there was a responsible aim for a budget surplus is to the contrary of the New South Wales government's big spending, big deficit budget. I call upon this house to condemn the Carr government for the introduction of poker machine taxes, which will jeopardise many hundreds of jobs, not just on the north coast, at Tweed Heads or Ballina, but right across Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my opposition and dismay at the lack of substance in this federal budget. It is significant that the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony), who had his 20 minutes to speak on the federal budget, could only mount a defence of the federal budget for about seven or eight minutes and spent most of his time attacking the New South Wales Labor government's budget brought down some one month ago.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant that he did raise the New South Wales budget because there is a very real difference as shown. The New South Wales budget was a Robin Hood budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right—steal from the country and steal from the people.
—The honourable member for Richmond has had his say.

—It was one which took from those who can afford to pay in order to fund increased funding in schools, hospitals and other essential services, unlike this budget which is a budget which gives to the rich and redistributes wealth from those who can least afford to pay, which will result in an increase in unemployment and an increase in inequality in our society. I could say that the direction in which we are headed is a wrong one, but the problem is really that we are not headed in any direction at all under this budget. It is not surprising that the headline in the Sydney Morning Herald was appropriate in the week after the budget. It labelled the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) `nowhere man', because he is indeed providing no leadership for this country, no direction and no vision.

SPEECH.PARA: This vision was shaped in the image of its creators, the directionless and visionless Prime Minister and Treasurer (Mr Costello). I would like to look at the effect of this budget on the people living in the electorate that I represent, an electorate, I dare say, where the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) would feel most uncomfortable.
The electorate of Grayndler is a living breathing example of the success of multiculturalism. It is made up of working people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) knows he should not display newspapers here in the chamber, so he will just not display it.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for drawing to attention the rudeness of those opposite on the government benches. My electorate is certainly made up of working people from over 100 different ethnic groups. When you walk down the main street of Marrickville where my office is located, you will find people from different cultural backgrounds all working together. The thing to emphasise here is that they are ordinary people, because these are the people that the Prime Minister and Treasurer have forgotten in this budget.

SPEECH.PARA: On the whole, my electorate can be seen to be made up of lower‐ and middle-income families and, I can tell you one thing for sure, not many of them will be able to take full advantage of the government's incentives rebate system. Perhaps the member for Richmond, with his background in share transactions and being involved in the finance sector might have mates welcoming the savings initiative of the Howard government, but certainly the average Australian will not benefit. The average Australian has savings of only a few thousand dollars in the bank and this translates to a rebate of less than $1 a week.

Of those people living in Grayndler who are lucky enough to still have a job, close to 90 per cent are wage and salary earners. Not many of them will benefit from the incentives rebate system, unlike the 463 people in Australia with incomes of over $1 million per year with their average interest earnings of $52,000 a year. They are the winners from this so‐called initiative.

But, as Mr Howard so clearly pointed out in this very house a few weeks ago, people who have enough savings to attract the full $450 rebate do not need it. That is why he himself has said that he will not take this fee, but that is a poor excuse for public policy decision making. We now have self‐regulation of the taxation system regarding what rebates will be claimed, because this rebate is of little or no assistance to the bulk of the Australian population. It is of no use to pensioners, to the unemployed, to young families struggling to pay either the rent or the mortgage and to feed and clothe their children.

Let us look to the people who work hard to save money and are therefore eligible for some rebate. What are they going to do with it when they get it as part of their tax return cheque? They are most likely to see it as a bonus and so go out and spend it along with the rest of their tax refund. This is hardly going to help national savings; is it? As Ross Gittins wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 May, the rebate is:

. . . much more a reward for past and already intended saving than it is an incentive to greater saving in the future . . . Mr Costello's incentive involves a certain decline of $2 billion a year in the government's saving, offset by a smaller and uncertain increase in yours and my saving. It's thus certain to involve a net decline in national saving. What it's intended to save is not money, but votes.

Let us talk a little more about national savings because, after all, the Treasurer tells us it is the government's most important economic objective arising from this budget. There is nothing in this budget that promotes national savings. At best, the government's plans will have a neutral impact. However, the most likely outcome is negative. That has been shown this week in the Senate where, in the economics estimates committee, Treasury has pointed out that they cannot guarantee and they do not think it will necessarily lead to increased savings.

The government, to the contrary, has abandoned its previous support for Labor's three per cent co‐contribution to the superannuation of workers. This co‐contribution would have added an additional $400 billion to national savings by the year 2020. Instead of supporting this scheme, which would benefit all workers, the government has substituted for it the savings incentive rebate that will only benefit some people. In other words, it is a reward for the coalition's natural constituency, those people on high incomes. The joke of course is that for these people the maximum benefit of $450 is chicken feed; it is just a gimmick. The government may as well have thrown in a free set of steak knives. Speaking of gimmicks, the pension bonus plan is another one. Here we have a government with no clues about how to address the unemployment problem in this country and yet they are encouraging older Australians to work longer. There is no logic in this move.

The government has also announced that workers earning between $450 and $900 per month will be able to opt out of the superannuation guarantee and take wages in lieu. These are among our poorest paid and most vulnerable members of the work force: they are women, outworkers, part‐time workers and often unskilled workers. Instead of protecting them by ensuring that they will have some retirement income, the government is throwing them to the wolves. From 1 July 1998, these people will be able to opt out of their superannuation contribution but only with the agreement of their employer. It is more likely to be at the insistence of their employer.

Low income workers and part‐time workers are often in a weak bargaining position. Many do not fully understand the superannuation scheme and many are from a non‐English speaking background. They may be told to opt out as it means less paperwork for their employers. They may also be told quite falsely that the extra money in their pay packet is a pay rise. The one thing this proposal is guaranteed not to do is help out national savings. The extra money may go into a bank account but in all likelihood it will be spent because the people it is directed towards simply cannot afford to save additional money.

If this is the plan the government has for its most important economic objective, I shudder to think what plans they may eventually formulate to deal with unemployment and industry. That is of course if the government ever gets around to formulating any plans at all in these two key areas. At a recent community meeting on the budget, held in my electorate, a member of the Australian Business Chamber told the audience that this budget had no vision or game plan to boost economic growth. The biggest missing ingredient was in industry development policy. The Business Council of Australia has said that the budget lacked both a broad national vision and any strategic policy for industry.

The government has shown no leadership over the closure of the BHP plant in Newcastle. The Prime Minister was not even informed earlier of the decision by the BHP board. Obviously he has little standing with this company. And where was the industry minister when this crisis hit? Firstly, at lunch, and then, when he finished his lunch, he could not attend a meeting in Newcastle because he chose to go to the opening of the Crown Casino in Melbourne. There he was, swanning about with the high society from the Melbourne Club down in Melbourne when the workers of Newcastle were having a meeting to discuss their future.

Unlike this government, the Labor Party does have a steel plan. The shadow minister for industry and regional development has provided details of how to encourage value adding and investment in new technologies. Nor does this government have a clue on car tariffs. The fact is that the Labor Party has a plan—which has the agreement of many of the backbenchers sitting across the other side of the room, and it certainly would have the support of my agrarian socialist friends in the National Party—for government involvement to protect jobs and to protect the workers in those industries.

The government's record on unemployment is particularly woeful. The unemployment rate, when Labor left office in March 1996, was 8.5 per cent. The current rate is 8.7 per cent. The average rate of employment growth in Labor's last term of office was 700,000 new jobs created—2.9 per cent. The average rate of employment growth—
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There has been far too much talk. I know there is a certain amount of latitude in this chamber, but I have asked members to remain silent. The honourable member for Richmond has just spent 20 minutes on his feet and the honourable member for Wannon is about to spend 20 minutes on his feet. I suggest that they remain silent and listen to the honourable member for Grayndler.

—Thank you. The fact is that the mob opposite, the rabble interjecting here today, have created only one per cent of employment growth in their first year in office. Since last year's budget, 34,300 full‐time jobs have been lost. Unemployment in my electorate of Grayndler is up 58 per cent since March 1996. Clearly, neither the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, nor the minister responsible have a clue about the need for government involvement in employment creation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer in fact has had to revise down to 3¼ per cent his forecast for growth this year. This was largely due to the government's disastrous policy of slash and burn and contracting the economy which has slammed the brakes right on. It is an economy, I might add, that averaged a rate of growth in Labor's last year of office of 4.4 per cent, and it averaged over four per cent per year every year in our last term. If it is the accepted wisdom that the 3¾ per cent growth forecast for next year is not enough to achieve real jobs growth, then what is this government on about?

The Prime Minister himself at a Liberal Party fundraiser said that the way to keep job growth going was to create economic growth of four per cent, but the budget's own figures suggest not only will that not happen this year but that it will not happen in the lead‐up to the end of this decade. If you look at the last two budgets as part of a larger plan, the outlook is particularly depressing.

Issues affecting my electorate include the government's new drug tax, which may save $561 million over four years but will particularly affect many Australians, particularly the elderly. The drugs affected by this new tax are used for the treatment of high blood pressure, cholesterol, ulcers and depression. People who need drugs for these conditions do not just get one‐off prescriptions every now and then. They are chronic conditions and they require ongoing treatment. People will have to pay more for medication that they need to stay alive. Pensioners in particular will be hard hit. They may be forced to opt for second‐class drugs that are not as effective in their treatment. Once again, we see the emergence of a two‐tiered health system. On top of this, 44 Medicare offices are to close—two in my electorate and one just outside my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —None are closing in my electorate.

—The member for Wannon points out that there are none closing in his electorate. That is the point. The point is that this is a vicious government. This is a government that says, if you live in a working class area that votes Labor, we will shut down your facilities and access to those, but not if you are in a Liberal or National Party area. Have a look at where they have been closed on the North Shore of Sydney—there are very few. But the impact of their closure on the Leichhardt and Marrickville offices in my electorate is not just directly on the health system but is a further drain on the local economy in terms of employment and the access that those offices, which bring people into the local shopping centres, bring in terms of a multiplier effect on local small businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes to public housing will also have negative effects on the most economically disadvantaged. The government has spoken about removing double subsidies in rent assistance. However, the states and territories already take into account the income of all people living in the household and charge their rents accordingly. This change will adversely affect the state's revenue from rental collections, but the big king hit for public housing is the cut to the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement, which will mean that public housing stock will decline.

Once again the government's free market ideology of letting market forces sort things out rears its ugly head. The private sector, particularly in relation to housing, is not motivated by quality and affordability but by profit. Accordingly, there are some areas which simply are not appropriate for the private sector to take over. Public housing, which I grew up in for the first 20 years of my life, is certainly one of those areas.

The government continues its assault on child care in this budget. So far this government has cut $821 million from child care. Child care is now less affordable than it has been for decades. On top of that, you have the changes to the CES where unemployed people will actually be charged through the private employment placement agencies for assistance getting a job. I would have thought that that was one of the primary objectives of government and the minister (Mrs Moylan), in having to apologise for the third time for misleading parliament before the House this week, has shown that she just does not have a clue about the impact of these changes.

On top of that, you have the federation slush fund being implemented which will provide, no doubt, in the coming years an opportunity for the coalition to spend money in marginal electorates, get out the big whiteboard, and that is no substitute for real public policy.

I want to say something also about the impact of this budget on the aged. I will have something to say on the Aged Care Bill later on today. I think that the policy of this government, whereby the elderly will be forced to sell their homes in order to get nursing home care, is an absolute disgrace because for many people going into a nursing home is a very traumatic and distressing time. People who have up to this point been independent must now adjust to their loss of independence and privacy. The reality for most people is that, once they enter a nursing home, they are unfortunately unlikely to be able to return to their own home. However, for many of these vulnerable people, the fact that their home is still there gives them hope.

I fear for people's longevity if they are forced to relinquish the one symbol of independence that they hold dear—their family home. Selling this home is such a final act. The government may as well be nailing the coffin down and saying that is it: your life is over. It is that sort of impact that this uncaring government has towards the most vulnerable in our society which is highlighted by this budget.

I want to conclude by talking about the changes foreshadowed in this budget and since by the Minister for Transport (Mr Sharp) on the insulation program for Sydney airport. The cutbacks are contrary to the government's promise, which was to maintain the previous government's insulation program. It is now saying the insulation will stop at Stanmore Road, Marrickville and some 2,500 people who were promised proper insulation against the impact of noise will miss out under that reconsideration.

The fact is that Sydney airport is still there. There is no funding in this budget for the creation of a second Sydney airport and, under those circumstances, it is just an outrage that this government would take away from people the insulation to which they were entitled and which they were promised. I urge all to campaign against this government budget. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, after listening to the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), I must admit that I was rather disappointed to hear the way he seems to have fallen back into the bad old habit of taking a patronising view towards some sectors of the community and the way he seems to be trying to reinvent the class war—something that I thought Australia was rather pleased to have got rid of. It really is most unfortunate to listen to someone having to resort to going back to things like the politics of envy.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that all honourable members particularly on this side would say—and all the thinking ones from the other side—is that they really could not accept anyone from the Labor Party lecturing us on unemployment. After going out of office after 13 years with 8½ per cent unemployed, I would have thought that all members of the Labor Party would be rather inclined to stay right off that subject with a track record like that. I do not think they would want to be talking about unemployment for a long time.

At the same time he made some comments about the Treasurer revising down the growth figures to 3¾ per cent. Some of us have a reasonable memory you know and it was not that long ago when Labor was in power that the growth figures were actually negative. It was not that long ago and you have been around long enough to know that you only have to go back to the recession we had to have and the growth figures were negative. It is very disappointing to hear someone saying that.

Getting on to the budget, the member for Grayndler seems to have completely missed the point about savings. He talked about the savings initiatives of the government which I happen to think are an excellent development, but he missed the whole point.
