It is all about encouraging people to increase their savings. He was trying to look backwards all the time instead of looking forwards. What he ought to realise is that the reason why the government has brought in this incentive for savings is to actually encourage people to increase their savings. It is not about trying to benefit people who may have savings now. It is all about encouraging those who want to get into savings to start to do so. As has been pointed out many times, it is capped, so in fact it will be of limited benefit to those on very high incomes.

Of course when he raised the question about national savings, he seems to have completely overlooked one of the fundamental changes that have occurred with this government and that is the moving of the budget into surplus. Now what better way is there to improve savings than to move the budget into surplus? Likewise, as a contrast, what worse way is there to destroy national savings than to continue to run budget deficits? This is exactly what this government inherited from the previous government—a $10 billion black hole; a $10 billion budget deficit. Ten billion dollars was eating into national savings as a result of an irresponsible government that was of course rightly thrown out at the last election. It was thrown out by the people of Australia because clearly it no longer deserved the right to govern this country.

Not only is this budget all about building on the work that the Treasurer and the government already started in the last budget to bring this whole budget back into surplus in one parliamentary term, but it also in fact reduces as a percentage of gross domestic product the level of Commonwealth outlays. It reduces them from 27 to 23 per cent over the term of this parliament and it brings the level of Commonwealth outlays to the lowest level since the pre‐Whitlam era. In other words, it is the lowest level as a percentage of GDP in over 20 years. Indeed, that is a tremendous achievement and is something about which all members of the government and all members of the Australian public should be very proud. But in fact the story about the budget gets better.

BREAK.PARA: It is the first time in over a decade that the Commonwealth will not have to borrow a single dollar. That is indeed a great achievement. By the year 2000, the Commonwealth debt as a ratio to GDP will have literally halved from the time that this government came into power. In other words, we are moving away from Labor's approach of deficit funding—of spending today, not worrying about it, just racking it up on the Bankcard and leaving it to the next generation; a `send the bill to the kids' type of approach—to a responsible approach to budgeting. This is something that all Australians should recognise as a very significant achievement.

Of course, this budget also builds on many of the achievements of last year. We saw the family tax cuts that came in on 1 January of up to $500 per family, specifically targeted at the very people that the member for Grayndler said he was so concerned about. I did not hear him talking about the benefits of these tax cuts. These are significant achievements and something that this government is very proud of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was there anything in this year's budget?
—Order! I ask honourable members on my left to refrain.

—I also want to talk about some of the other achievements that this government has already put in place through last year's budget and which this year's budget builds on. If we look at what has been done for self‐funded retirees, as of next month we will see a rebate coming in over two years for self‐funded retirees so that they get the same tax treatment as pensioners.

BREAK.PARA: One of the real achievements of this budget—building again on last year's budget—are the major incentives for small business. Also we have the changes to Austudy for families with two children studying away from home—something that will be of particular benefit to those in regional Australia and something that recognises that people in the country have significantly increased costs in sending their sons and daughters away to study, in most cases because they have no choice but to send them away.

There is more. We can talk about the new savings initiative or we can talk about the Natural Heritage Trust—$1¼ billion going to the environment—which brings environment into the mainstream, something that Labor, after 13 years, could not do; something that we have achieved that will have lasting effect not only for this generation of Australians but for successive generations of Australians.

We also have, in this budget, the Federation Fund—$1 billion dollars to build infrastructure projects of national significance—which is something that again recognises that this government knows how to run a decent budget. This is probably why I can feel very enthusiastic about this budget. It gives, as I was saying, great opportunities for small business. It gives business a chance to get going and that will lead to jobs, which we all recognise is such an important issue in Australia today. In fact, the paramount need is to get unemployment down.

In getting small business going, we have to look at the right ingredients that this government has brought to the task. Firstly, we have got the responsible economic management that I have already spoken about that is getting the budget back into surplus. Secondly, we have got the low inflation rate that we are now working to lock in, and from that we get lower interest rates. We have seen four cuts to official interest rates since this government came in—four cuts that will give the sort of encouragement and build the confidence that is so important in getting business to start to invest and expand—leading to greater opportunities and greater job growth.

When some people ask, `What's this budget all about?' I would sum it up by saying it is all about building confidence: confidence that people will have to start to build their own futures rather than having to forever worry about what the government is going to do next and what the government is next going to get wrong.

When we talk about employment, it is important to note that last year, in the first year of the Howard government, we saw 130,000 new jobs created. When we look at what is expected in the coming year, this will increase to a further 200,000 jobs. So we are in fact tackling this whole issue head on. Unlike the Labor Party, who just threw buckets of money at the unemployed, never knowing how they were actually going to solve the long‐term problem, we have got in place lasting programs that are all about building sustained jobs.

But I will get back to the question of small business. There is a number of important issues that are all about getting small business going. We have already reduced the provisional tax uplift factor. While that may not sound a major change, it does in fact improve cash flow in small business by some $180 million—quite significant, I would have thought. We have also extended the incentives for employee share ownership and will be introducing quarterly group tax remittances for small employers—again, all part of reducing paperwork. That, in itself, is going to be worth $500 million in cash flows to those small businesses that have a group tax collection of less than $25,000 per year.

We have seen fringe benefits tax changes that should allow the paperwork to be completely removed for about half of small businesses. We have seen changes to the industrial relations law, changes which are partly already through and partly still to come, and which will mean massive changes to the way in which small business approaches employment. I believe this will give tremendous encouragement to small businesses to increase their employment.

But the real sleeper in changes has been the capital gains tax rollover provisions. These are something that the editor of Business Review Weekly spoke of in very glowing terms a few months ago when he described it as `probably the most significant change in decades to tax laws affecting small business'. What he was so enthusiastically talking about was that allowing the opportunity for people to roll over their capital gains when they sell one business and buy another was a real incentive for small business to really build up a capital base. If you like, when we talk about national savings, this is just another aspect of improving national savings.

What Robert Gottliebsen was saying, of course, was not just that the provisions are going to change the way small businesses approach their whole operations, because they will be looking now on how to accumulate a capital base; he was also talking about the changes that it will mean to the career paths taken by many of the best and brightest in this country. A lot of people will look at this opportunity and realise that with the change to the capital gains tax—rather than go into a major corporation where, as soon as they get up the management ladder, they very quickly find themselves with a marginal tax rate of 50c in the dollar—they may well be able to accumulate some capital in a much quicker and more effective way.

He also went on to point out that, in the current climate—as we have seen with the changes to many corporations, particularly in middle management, and the takeovers that have been occurring—there are many managers who reach the age of 45, say, and suddenly find themselves out of a job. Once you get past that age, it is not easy to find another job. So, in terms of career paths, Gottliebsen was really saying that the change to the capital gains tax law is going to lead to many of our brightest young people changing their whole career path and going into small business. That is a very exciting development, because we all know that small business is where the new jobs are going to be. When you look at the changes that have occurred already in assisting small business to grow and prosper under this government, you will see a pretty exciting and pretty impressive line‐up.

Of course, we could talk further about the savings initiative. It is a very important element of this budget: not only does it provide incentives for people to save but it also encourages those who choose to increase their personal superannuation contributions by up to $3,000 per year, in that they will also be able to get the 15 per cent tax rebate. But, of course, it also applies to everyone, including self‐funded retirees.

The impact of the initiative will, over time, be enormous. Not only that, but it will help to change the culture in Australia; it will help to rebuild the independence of individual families; it will provide the incentive to save for all the things that families probably want to do but have not been able to in the past, so that they can in fact save for their own futures, their own housing, better health care and better education. In short, not only will it be better for individuals but it will be better for the nation; and, with savings, it will help to attack one of the other major legacies that Labor handed on: the level of national debt.

In the time that I have left, I want to go to another issue that I think is quite fascinating to see unfold: that is, the unravelling of the leadership of the Labor party. It all started just over a week ago with an article in the Australian by Glenn Milne headed `Alternative ALP thinking on tax offers some hope'. The article showed that there are some in the Labor party who are becoming increasingly disgruntled with the direction that has been taken by the old guard leadership. The article mentioned some very interesting comments made by the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). It says:

In a veiled warning to those in the ALP hoping to capitalise on societal unease and insecurity by offering a simplistic return to industry protection, tariff wars and tax subsidies disguised as industry policy, Tanner bluntly warns against a "a trip down memory lane arm in arm with Pauline Hanson".

The article went on to talk about Tanner's paper entitled `Populism and Rationalism' in which Tanner talks about how Labor has to `avoid becoming economically irrational, lapsing into mindless populism, recycling the policies of the 1950s and defining ourselves by what we do not like.' He went on to say, `We cannot afford to return to the 1970s.' Again, it has a very familiar ring with the way some of the old guard are operating in the Labor party these days. Mr Tanner rejects two specific ideas put up by fellow front benchers: Martin Ferguson's proposal for job sharing, and Simon Crean's call for the reintroduction of tax breaks for research and development. I thought that was a fascinating start to what is now seen as an unravelling of the leadership of the Labor Party.

Last Monday we got another article by Glenn Milne headed `Labor's young braves are starting to get restless'. So it is widening. In this article Glenn Milne talks about those who are attacking the leadership. He says:
In doing so they also risk fracturing the dominant forces standing behind Beazley, represented collectively by former Keating ministers and most prominently by Gareth Evans and Simon Crean.

The reason that this article has come on top of the previous one is that the problem is growing. This article talks about the challenge to Labor's leadership group being implicit in Tanner's paper about populism and rationalism, which was talked about in the previous article. It says:

Within the caucus Tanner's views are associated by backbenchers with a number of younger Labor MPs, including future leadership prospect Mark Latham, from the Right, and key Victorian factional figure Kim Carr, from the Left.

The member for Bruce (Mr Griffin) is one of the young future leaders of Labor. I am sure he is interested in all of this and I am sure he has read the article. The article goes on to talk about some of the difficulties that are starting to emerge and says:
While Carr has internal party debts to settle with Crean in his home State, he, along with Tanner and Latham, also sees a new divide in Labor's approach to regaining office.

Note those words, `a new divide.' Clearly the leadership is unravelling. The article talks about Evans and that some are saying that he is doing a wonderful job overseeing this policy development. But the article also says that this is being dismissed in some sections of the caucus as `mere puffery.' And so the article goes on saying that `reversion by the Old Guard to the mantras of industry policy is driven by the union movements' continued preoccupation with a shrinking manufacturing sector.'
What capped it all off was the front page of the Australian today where it says:
Beazley threatens MPs over `treachery'—
It is all coming out—
Kim Beazley has warned his frontbench colleagues that he will sack anyone responsible for "treachery"
It goes on to say:
Beazley gave a far more guarded version of the warning to Caucus yesterday

Obviously, he cannot trust the caucus. He says one thing to the frontbench—yet that still gets into the paper—and when he goes to the caucus he is very careful. Clearly, we are seeing something fascinating. It is a changing of the guard and we will all watch for the next instalment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) mentioned a return to the 1970s, and I have some sympathy for the 1970s. I refer him to the days of the Fraser government as there are some similarities between the Fraser government and the new Howard government. They both had very large majorities, but, unfortunately, as a consequence the debate in the party room has become less and less important to the process.
—How would you know? You haven't been there for a while!

—That does not necessarily mean I do not get to hear what goes on in there. I am saying that debate has become less and less important to the process, as was the case in the Fraser government. The debate is being propelled in the community by people who have been appointed by the previous Keating or Hawke governments to positions of statutory authority heads or other positions. For example, the Chief Justice of the Family Court has been attacking Prime Minister Howard. The problem the government has is that the principal critics of the government are all being paid by the government. The debate is going on out there in the community and the government is getting criticised by the very people it is employing. That is exactly what happened to the Fraser government.

SPEECH.PARA: It means, of course, that the darlings of the media in the ministry get promoted and their views get more and more currency. You see the type of people who are getting a run from the coalition. That will mean, in essence, that there is going to be a policy crisis, a policy freeze. We have some very important issues coming up shortly, including media ownership, the resolution of car tariffs, and textiles. There is also the prevailing issue of the reform of the taxation system.

In speaking today on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997-98, I want to raise a number of related issues for consideration by the coalition government. In laying down the budget the government has essentially sought to determine the direction in which we, as a nation, will head over the next year and beyond. I might also say that the growth figures published today have come in under expectation for the penultimate quarter for 1996‐97 which, of course, is another problem for budgetary forecasts.

Government spending affects the level of delivery of social programs and sets the environment in which all Australians, including both businesses and employees, operate. Fiscal responsibility is an essential element of good government. I applaud the coalition for its work in reducing the damage done to our national economy after 13 years of irresponsible financial mismanagement by Labor. But good fiscal management, however, is not simply a matter of balancing the books, rather, it is doing it in a way that gives us a chance to maintain society's expectations about prosperity, the standard of living and employment.

One of the other features of today's figures on the growth of GDP has been the level of investment. Most of this has been capital investment and capital investment that may have a prejudicial effect on employment prospects in the immediate future.

There are some things which this government has done in the budget for which they deserve praise, and I believe they deserve the accolades they receive from commentators in the media and elsewhere. However, there is a deeper concern that I have which is related to the government's ability to deliver the kinds of policies that are relevant to the community today.

We have all seen the growth of a very definite mood of discontent in Australian society. It demonstrates that people are frustrated with the type of government that has been on offer from the Labor governments under former Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating and in particular under Keating. Those governments were characterised by arrogance and elitism. This frustration is growing as people's expectations continue to be unmet under the current government.

I know members here would have heard from their constituents who say to them, as they say to me, that they do not detect any great difference between the Keating government and the Howard government. Whether that perception is entirely accurate is a matter of debate but the problem is that it is a perception out there, and they would know that that is the case in small business.

The former Labor government was captive to well organised, aggressive and vocal interest groups which were nonetheless unrepresentative of broad public opinion. Over the range of its tenure, Labor has symbiotically utilised these groups to mould public opinion under the broad umbrella of political correctness. The problem the Labor Party now faces is that, once these people run out of other enemies, they will undoubtedly turn on those who have previously been complicit in their activities. This weapon is being used today to tell people who know that there is a problem out there that they should feel ashamed or guilty for voicing their complaints.

In particular, one of the most disturbing aspects of this is that members of parliament are being attacked for representing those views. This has been the prevailing practice over a number of years. Members of parliament have been attacked for representing their constituencies, for representing the views of their constituents, because they have been out of kilter, or so it has been said, with the prevailing political correctness of this umbrella of interest groups that have dominated modern political activity in our nation.

I might give an example. The opponents of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) vilify law abiding citizens and call them racists or bigots because they want to redress an imbalance in our migration program which grew out of control. And they are not my comments—they are the comments of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock).

Some church representatives tell people that they lack compassion when they complain about laws that allow some to gain benefits beyond their needs or the community's ability to pay them. I have even seen the coalition dismissing the views of people concerned at the unexpected economic effects of tariff reductions as belonging to a flat earth society, rather than seriously dealing with their concerns.

Many commentators put Labor's last electoral loss down to the Keating factor and summarise that as arrogance and being out of touch, I suppose. I believe that the ailment is deeper and is specifically traceable to a perception of failure by government to be more accountable to the wishes of the broader community. If this coalition government wants to retain office at the next election, it has a duty to identify the will of the people of Australia and act upon it—not to rule as though it knows what is best for us, or to limit access to policy input to those who are either its biggest campaign donors or, as I previously mentioned, who are actually employed by the government and who are now its most vociferous critics, which in my view is an absolute travesty.

The real Achilles heel for the government is small business. Despite the realisation that small business is a key to the coalition in terms of votes, its non‐parliamentary organisation has preferred to take the reality that donations from the big business corporations, the banks, the telecommunications lobby, the oil companies and so on are more important to the government's ability to actually wage an election campaign. Anybody who does not believe that ought to have a look at some of those donations and match them with the behaviour of the government once it got into office.

We have had the hapless Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) trying to find strategies to boost small business from outside the cabinet, up against more powerful interests who prevailed in the Expenditure Review Committee to preserve the interests of those who are actually acting as a brake on many small to medium enterprises today.

I want to turn, if I may, to law and order and crime. One of the biggest costs to the citizens of this country today lies in the steady growth of crime and our inability to stem it. I do not believe, even with this latest announcement of the campaign against crime and violence, the government has yet made the link between the cost to our community caused by crime and our productivity, because there is no doubt that crime, and in particular the drug trade, is a distortive influence on the economy.

The cost of crime is widespread in the community. It can be evidenced in the budgets of the state and federal police and other agencies that support that fight against crime. It is also borne through the costs of running the Customs Service and the Australian Securities Commission and all those other agencies responsible for law enforcement areas. Higher insurance premiums, security alarms and monitoring systems are all a direct consequence of the growth of crime. Lost productivity and financial losses are caused by burglaries, damage to people and damage to assets. These are just a few of the obvious, glaring direct costs.

But a much larger proportion are the less obvious costs. The funding of our judicial system seems to be under steadily mounting pressure, as is legal aid in criminal matters. The cost of incarceration has grown to a level where the government no longer wants to bear the costs. Privatisation of the prison service is the economic rationalists' solution to the cost of operating gaols.

Another way has been to apply fewer and shorter prison sentences. We routinely return dangerous or anti‐social individuals back into society where they can re‐offend with alarming regularity. We also now have a health system which, of course, because of the demographic changes, is more and more overburdened, but it is now being increasingly required to support the victims of spiralling violent crime and drug abuse.

Drug trafficking and drug abuse in Australia today is at record high levels with no indication that there is anything that is going to slow it down. Children are dying of drug overdoses more frequently than ever before, and we have the minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service trumpeting an inaccurate and inappropriate message that we are actually winning the fight against drugs.

I find it appalling that such an implication can be made when in his own home state heroin is now reported to cost $12 a hit and on average one person is dying per week of a heroin overdose. Last Friday I read an article in the Australian where a visiting US authority on drug abuse, Ms Jane Maxwell, warned that purer heroin was here over the long haul. She estimated that Australian heroin was now 60 per cent pure, compared to 16 per cent a few years ago. This has obviously resulted in more and more overdoses. The face of addiction has been changed by targeting affluent young people. She expected this to lift the rate of addiction and to increase demand for treatment services.

Recent meetings or hearings of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority has heard alarming evidence of the growth in the drug trade. The Australian Federal Police has advised the committee that worldwide profits from drug trafficking are now estimated to be between $200 billion and $300 billion a year, enough to dwarf the gross national product of many smaller nations. Interpol puts it at around $450 billion. Two recent seizures in Australia alone had the potential to return almost $1 billion from street sales.

I will give you a couple of examples. A major recent drug importation was effected as follows: a 600‐ton ship was purchased in a European country by a company registered in another country; the vessel was crewed by a Spanish captain and Filipino and Belgian nationals; the drugs were collected off the coast of Pakistan; a trawler was purchased in Victoria to move the drugs from the mother ship to a landing site in New South Wales; expatriate Australians were recruited from South‐East Asia as crew members for the trawler; and separate command and communication links for the mother ship and trawler were maintained throughout. The wealth, sophistication and international connections of these drug networks make them extraordinarily difficult to combat in any circumstances.

A recent submission to the National Crime Authority inquiry from the Queensland police commissioner indicated that there is an extremely serious drug importation program being run through Western Australia which impacts heavily on drug distribution throughout the eastern states. This had earlier been estimated at worth around $1 billion annually.

The Queensland police representative, Inspector McHugh, gave an opinion that the situation in relation to drugs is no better now than it was three, four or 10 years ago; in fact, it is worse. Similar statements have been made by the police authorities in Western Australia and Victoria. I am sure the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) would have heard the chief commissioner of the Victorian police, Mr Comrie, saying that we are awash in heroin. What are we doing about it?

The government's response to crime and drug‐related crime has generally been to reduce funding to the bodies responsible for law enforcement or assisting in the fight against crime. In the last two budgets we have seen cuts as funding reductions in anticipation of so‐called efficiency dividends. But again, the result has been to reduce the effectiveness of operations run by the agencies. That was the evidence from the National Criminal Intelligence Service. It was also a concession made by Mr Smeaton in giving evidence to the NCA committee the other day at a public hearing.

The only exception to this in real terms has been this increase in NCA funding to deal with fraud and tax evasion against the Commonwealth's revenue raising. Now, that is fair enough. We would like to see that, but of course this can easily be interpreted as a cynical means of improving taxation outcomes, while neglecting organised criminal drug trafficking.

I am aware in my own state of Western Australia that these camouflaged budget cuts have resulted in a reduction in the resources available to the WA and Federal Police as well as NCA activities there. Extrapolation that the Customs Service must be similarly troubled is not unreasonable. I might point out that they do not bother sending over couriers any more; they just send it in containers. You might think for instance that through all of its efforts the NCA is wearing down the huge plantations around the country that were previously cultivating cannabis, but what is happening now is that they just send it in containers from Cambodia. Cambodians are now sending container loads of cannabis to Australia for our consumption.

The Secretary General of Interpol, Mr Ray Kendal, has estimated that only 10 per cent to 30 per cent at best of drugs being illegally trafficked were being detected. That does not necessarily mean being seized, but actually being detected by authorities. Mr Kendal illustrated the problems that are faced by western nations which have deluded themselves that they are winning the war against drugs—rather like the minister responsible for customs—because they are intercepting more drugs.

Unless a nation is able to develop a strategy which complements reduction in supply with reduction in demand, people will always take the risks associated with trafficking. I might tell you that the evidence we have had is that the couriers who still come across from the south‐east Asian countries see it as an occupational hazard coming to Australia with drugs.

Some of them actually write back to their peers in their home countries, inviting them to come across to Australia, pointing out that the accommodation in Australian prisons is much superior to what they might have at home and in fact they get paid while they are in prison. What sort of country are we running when we are actually encouraging people to write to each other, tempting them to come over, bring drugs with them and if they get caught, they will actually have a bit of a holiday in Australian prison and come out with more money than they probably would have earned had they had a normal job in their home country?

Mr Kendall does not believe that legalisation is the answer, but that if you want a society that is free from drug abuse, certain coercive measures much be applied to make sure that people correspond to what the society wants. Legalisation and decriminalisation of drugs of addiction will not reduce demand for these substances. We have this other silly situation where, for instance, if you were to go into a newsagency and you are under 16 and the fellow sold you, inadvertently, cigarettes, he would be prosecuted. But we have got government agencies actually proposing that children under 16 should be able to access taxpayer funded shooting galleries so they can shoot up on heroin. What sort of crazy community are we running when we have those sorts of priorities?

Legalisation and decriminalisation lead to a general acceptance that use of these substances is somehow condoned under certain circumstances. Other means of reducing demand must be explored, with a view to breaking the profitability of drug trafficking in Australia. We have this situation where we know who is bringing in the drugs. If you talk to the agencies, as I have, in questioning them at the NCA inquiry hearings, they will tell you who is responsible. But what are they doing about it? The Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board had a review report almost four years ago. They identified who is responsible for much of heroin importation: it is Chinese triad gangs, and they are distributed to a large extent by subordinate networks of Vietnamese. The problem is that they were identified four years ago and you ask the question: why is it so that this is still continuing?

In view of this, I call upon the government to implement a true war against crime. Not this one that was announced the other day by the Prime Minister at $10 million, and most of that is going into all sorts of alternative programs. It needs to allocate large resources in the order of an additional $100 million each year to address the problem. Let me just say this: it is shown elsewhere overseas that when you start to implement a real fight against crime with all of the ancillary powers of being able to seize the illicit proceeds of drug trafficking and crime, then you can actually bring back resources and funds into the fight against crime by allowing the law enforcement agencies to mobilise those particular resources as part of the effort.

Government needs to give law enforcement agencies the wherewithal to deal with the front end of the problem and social programs of resources to address the deeper social issues. I believe that costs can quickly be recouped by a reduction in the crime related costs in this country. They can also be offset by the stringent seizure and sale of the assets of those convicted. Seizure of assets has a dual benefit of preventing a drug trafficker from being able to use the tools of his trade—assets like a plane, boat or warehouse—from being used for further trafficking. The proceeds of the sale of a seized asset can then offset the cost or subsidise future anti‐drug operations. It is a technique being used with increasing success in other Western countries—in particular, in the United States.

I visited some years ago the police departments in the southern part of Texas which, of course, is an area where there are drug trafficking problems, amongst other things. They use those assets which have been seized very productively. For instance, they are able to use directly light aircraft and vehicles and trucks and other things that have been seized. They put them straight back into the program that they are undertaking to try to halt the trafficking of drugs over the border between Mexico and the United States.

Of course, $100 million is a lot of money. It sounds like a lot and it is. The problem is that a much more substantial cost will be borne by the Australian community if we choose not to wage an all‐out war against crime and, in particular, drug trafficking.

I want to conclude, if I may, Mr Deputy Speaker, by making this observation about this problem. We should not kid ourselves that this is some sort of secondary issue—that it has nothing to do with running the economy. You can see it in the attitude of the ministers when they are answering questions about reductions. It is not a second‐order issue. This is a fundamental problem affecting all levels of our community—from the streets of Cabramatta and the suburbs of western Sydney and Melbourne all the way through to the leafier more affluent suburbs where one would assume that commonsense would prevail to prevent drug addiction or drug trafficking taking place. But in actual fact, it percolates through all levels of the community and, of course, it leads to a gross distortion in the economy.

As a consequence, you have the corruption of the judiciary, the police forces, politicians and the Public Service. It forms an abscess, a cancer in our community that can take an extraordinary effort to cut out. It becomes deep‐seated. It becomes, as we have seen in the Wood Royal Commission revelations, something that is so deep‐seated—so immured in the community—that you can only reveal it and pull out some of the people responsible by pointing a camera at them and showing them in action.

We are faced with a very, very serious problem in this community and I might say that cutbacks up until now have debilitated the campaign against drugs. All I can do is urge the coalition to think again and to wage an all‐out fight against drug trafficking, which is eating away at our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman, Lou, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with much pleasure that I speak today on behalf of the government in respect of the Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1997‐98, the second budget of the coalition government led so ably by John Howard. I am reminded of the words of the song It has only just begun , and indeed it has.

SPEECH.PARA: To be part of a performance government, given a strong mandate by the people of Australia to tackle the urgent issues that should have been tackled by the previous government and to put a stop to the waste and the mismanagement and the excessive spending of the previous government, is a very heavy onus and responsibility on the members of the government. We all accept this with great enthusiasm because we know that if we do our job well we will be able to make a very substantial contribution to improving the future of our children and grandchildren. Also, we will be able to address the urgent needs of the disadvantaged in this country and make our contribution on the world stage in areas where we should.

As I travel around, I find people expressing some frustration and concern that some of the government's policies have not gone far enough or they have not yet felt the benefit of them. That reflects an understandable concern of the community, which has been faced with some devastating performances of the previous Keating‐Hawke‐Beazley governments. People wonder, quite frankly, whether or not governments are up to it and will be able to address the issues that need to be addressed and that they want addressed for their children. My answer to that is to look at what we have done. By all means, mark us and criticise us where they feel they should, but also take into account the enormous frustrations and obstacles that have been put in our way by this current parliament in effecting the urgent changes and reforms that we have a mandate to achieve.

May I briefly remind members that the government went into the election with proposals to reform industrial relations, to bring in a new environmental package to address the urgent and overdue problems of degradation of our rivers and soil and to do a number of other very important things. After our election in March 1996, we proceeded very quickly to introduce legislation to achieve those ends and we passed that legislation quite speedily through the House of Representatives. From memory, it was substantially passed within the first two or three months of the Howard coalition government. You would have thought then that it would have been dealt with quickly by the Senate but, in fact, it was not. We all know that it was virtually the end of last year—December—before the Senate saw fit to allow through the government's legislation for which it had strong mandates.

It was not really until January and February of this year, almost 12 months after the new government took office, that its core reforms in respect of industrial relations were enacted. Those reforms, I remind members, deal with urgent issues that have been stopping people taking risks and taking on new employees, especially young people. They centre on the lack of ability for small business to develop with their employees reasonable arrangements for sharing of profits, for getting on with the job and developing and achieving the mission and the ambitions of people involved in small business in Australia.

The reform of the unfair dismissal clauses was the subject of considerable opposition and frustration by the opposition and its friends in the Senate. Further proposals by the government as part of our small business reform package are to exempt small business in the first year from unfair dismissal claims for employees where the number of employees is 15 or less. That initiative is virtually a probationary system which any reasonable person would accept. If you take on a new employee there ought to be space for the two of you to resolve any uncertainties and ensure that both of you, the employer and employee, are comfortable and are certain that your destiny is to work together in the longer term. Some probationary period should be allowed which is a period in which both parties can terminate their relationship with each other if they find that it is not as they would wish it to be. Remarkably, we find that the Labor Party is still opposing those sorts of reforms and using its mates in the Senate to inhibit small business development and above all the opportunity to give young people a job, the opportunity for them to start off their working life and get out of the unemployment queues.

I say to members and to the community of Australia that this government has done a lot, but there is a lot more to do. We have only just begun. I ask that those in the opposition and in the Senate who are supporting them take on board the need for this country to work together to get out there and do the things that are needed to be done so that we can in fact ensure that our children and grandchildren have a safe and secure future and that we do not have a continuing spiral of youth unemployment and, sadly, in some cases, youth suicide, this country having the fifth largest youth suicide rate in industrialised countries in the world.

I do not accept that we should rest on that and I will not rest until we do all the things that we must do regardless of some of the opposition from some of these people to giving kids a job and the opportunity and a feeling that this country does offer them, as it has their fathers and grandparents before them, a good future and an exciting future.

When we managed to get rid of the last government, we found that this generation was facing for the first time the probability, if the previous government's management and policies had continued, that we would for the first time be a generation handing the country over to our children with them having fewer opportunities than we did. The history of Australia has been that every generation, despite great difficulties and adversity, has always been able to hand over to their children the stewardship of this country with better opportunities for them than they had. Whilst there might not have been great opportunities for everybody, when that process occurred I am sure that all members would concede and agree with me that we are a proud nation and we have been able to give our kids more chances than we had. That is something that we should all continue to strive to do but up to 1993, after 13 years of Labor governments, we were the generation facing the awful prospect of not being able to continue to do that. Why? Because the government had overspent. It had spent more than its revenue and run the country into huge debt. There was a huge deficit of more than $10 billion.

Might I just pay credit to John Howard for his courage in being able, with Peter Costello his able Treasurer, to bring that under control and in our second budget to be able to say to the Australian people that by the time we finish our first term in the third year, we will have in fact removed the deficit totally and will be in a surplus of something like $1.5 billion. That takes a fair bit of work, some pain and some disappointment to people. We have to grapple with the difficult job of assessing priorities and in some cases having to say `no' to some people for programs that you would, if you had the money, like to continue to give support to.

It is a very difficult and painful process, and it is not one that you get a lot of joy out of. But provided your vision is right, your mission is right, you know what you are doing and your priorities are right, you know that in the final outcome the country will be much more prosperous. There will be more opportunities for people and, as productivity, investment and savings increase with this better management, there will be more revenue for governments from that alone, simply by natural growth, and that will enable you to revisit some of the programs where you had wished you did not have to cut, but you had not had the funds to keep on going. So I think that is a very significant achievement and I congratulate John Howard and Peter Costello for their work in that regard.

I also welcome the Prime Minister's courageous step to put on the political agenda the fact that this government, in its first term, will encourage and open up the debate on the reform of our very inefficient and very inequitable tax system. The stories about it are legion. One of them is the fact that you do not have to pay wholesale sales tax, for example, on caviar, but you do on basic food for the family. The anomalies are just unbelievable. There is no way that any contemporary member of the federal parliament, no matter what their politics, can justify the continuation of the horrendously inefficient, inequitable, anomalous system of tax with respect to wholesale sales tax.

Australia is a country where no‐one can truthfully tell you how much tax they have paid through the day, between the time they get out of bed in the morning and when they finally go to bed at night. Sure, they know what their PAYE tax is if they are wage earners; they know what is taken out of their wages each week or fortnight. But they have no idea about the hidden taxes on the food that they use, the floor coverings that they walk on, the cosmetics that they use and the toothpaste and the toilet paper, and all of those things. They hop in the car, or they use other transport, and they find that the bowser price has a tax component, of state and federal taxes, that is more than 50 per cent of the total cost per litre.

In the states, we have a system of payroll tax which means that the more you employ, the more tax you pay. Imagine a young country like Australia sustaining a tax as we go into the next century which says, `Hey, guys, the more people you employ, the more we are going to tax you.' How about that? That is payroll tax. We cannot allow that to continue. Nor can we allow this country to have an inefficient tax system at the same time as we address the urgent issues of tariff reform and industry policy.

I remind members that we are a trading nation. If we said to Australia's farmers and producers that we had lost the trade opportunities for them overseas, it would mean that about 70 per cent of total produce by Australian farmers—in wheat and grain and all the other things—would be lost to world trade, because Australia's relatively small population, of about 19‐odd million, means Australians cannot possibly eat enough and consume enough of the farmers' produce. There are not enough of us to do that. That fact alone means that we have a very substantial part of our economy which produces more than we can eat and consume and which by necessity has to find a purchaser.

The farmers are doing a wonderful job. In the dairy industry, for example, just yesterday in my electorate there was an announcement that a company would spend an extra $30 million in developing new products which eventually will be exported into the exciting Asian market— Malaysia, for example, is about 90 per cent dependent on imported dairy products. We are fighting and jostling with other dairy producers of the world for those huge and growing markets. So we have to understand that we have to have a policy in industry which enables our traders to sell their goods overseas. Therefore, we have to have a policy that enables us to develop and to negotiate with other countries, some of whom have got no wish to help us at all, to ensure that we have access to their markets.

So, if you take the simplistic view and say, `Let us stop them from importing into us; let us put up barriers that stop them coming into our country with their goods', you know what they are going to do because we are such a small player in the world scene. They are going to say, `Thanks, fellah; you won't let us in, or you have put up some barriers against us, so we are going to turn around and do the same to you, only worse.' The net effect of that is, of course, to decimate Australia. It will put many people out of business—many farmers and other people relying on their produce—because there simply will not be a market for our produce.

Similarly, with respect to our manufacturing industries, such as the value‐added dairy industry which I just spoke about and so many others, they want to go out and trade in the world. They are getting better and better at it every year. But they have to have a policy which will enable us to negotiate with our world trading partners a reasonable access arrangement whereby we can say to them, `We have let you into us on reasonable terms so you have to let us in.' So by us becoming part of ASEAN, GATT and other arrangements, we collectively can bring on pressure, even though we are a very small country, to shame and shock them and do all sorts of things to allow us access into the larger world trade scene.

Our government is facing some major decisions in those regards, and we will do a good job in those areas. I look forward with excitement to the announcements on the car policy over the weekend, or perhaps next week and, with respect to the textile and footwear industry, an announcement a little while after that.

I will briefly come back to my own electorate. When I stood for election I made some pledges that I would like to see some improvements in certain projects get off the ground. I will quickly say that I have been able to do that because I am part of the coalition government committed to the development and the future of regional Australia.

For example, we have been able to see the introduction of a very exciting new apprenticeship and vocational training scheme across regional Australia with one‐stop shops, simplified processes and more assistance to employers and employees. We have introduced—and this is a very exciting development—a new form of pathway where kids dropping out of school because they do not like the curriculum can start their apprenticeship training at secondary school, stopping the 30 per cent drop‐out rate which occurs in Australia at the moment.

Those kids will have part qualifications for their apprenticeship trades when they walk out with their VCE in year 12. That will give them greater access to pathways for apprenticeships in small and medium sized business because they will be able to say they have experience and part qualifications and so are able to contribute much more when they start than in the old days. That is a very exciting process which I have had a little bit to do with, and I am convinced it will make a major contribution to many areas of Australia.

The Murray‐Darling has been a very big part of my life, both in state and federal politics. I am very pleased to see the new heritage fund, the $1.25 billion through the Telstra process. In my own electorate, because we are very much a part of the Murray‐Darling region, that will enable us to address some very urgent issues for all of Australia.

In respect to the freshwater research centre which I invite my colleagues from all sides of parliament to visit at Albury‐Wodonga—it is a fantastic set‐up—we have been able to get the funding problems resolved, thank God, so their work can continue for the benefit of Australia. In the defence area, we have capital commitment for new buildings and renovations at Bandiana‐Bonegilla in my electorate. This will reinforce Australia's No. 1 army logistics training centre for the Australian army defence system, and I am very pleased about that.

On a personal level, we struggled for years, both when I was in state parliament and latterly in federal parliament, to get SBS television for my area of Australia. With the assistance of my colleague Tim Fischer, we were able to have it turned on on 14 May this year. Many people rejoiced. Unhappily, I have not yet got it for the whole of my electorate, but I will work on that. It is my wish that all members, whether they be Labor, Liberal or National, should be able to get, under a Howard‐Fischer government, SBS television for their constituents. We are working on that as well, and I think we will be able to deliver that.

We have also have been able to address the urgent issue of not being able to get rural doctors and obstetricians in country areas. We have been able, with Michael Wooldridge's leadership, to introduce a number of very innovative ideas for scholarships and the like, which will help us address that very urgent issue.

In connection with retirees, we have new incentives for them. We have widened the tax rebate for low income self‐funded retirees—a long overdue reform—and I am very happy to report to you that constituents in that category have contacted me and indicated that they really appreciate the small extra assistance which is achieved there. Neighbours with exactly the same income, but with one of them on self‐funded retiree super and the other on a full age pension, now have the same tax base, whereas before they did not. We have addressed that matter, and I am very pleased about that.

I am going quickly because my time is running out; but, with the reform of tax and the small business reforms, we have only just begun—as I said when I started my speech. Watch this space, gives us cooperation, and we will deliver to Australia the reforms that are needed. (Time expired)

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.31 p.m. to 4.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with the budget as contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 is two‐fold. Firstly, I am bound to say that this government is probably the most ideologically driven government that I have ever witnessed. It operates on a series of what are, for it, self‐evident truths. The fact is that the greatest single problem confronting Australia is unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The underlying philosophy and policies of this government are not going to resolve the problem of unemployment; they are simply going to compound and increase it. One only has to look at certain shibboleths which are dropped into the parliament almost automatically. How are they going to solve unemployment? They say they can solve it by their support for small business. Small business is going to be the answer to the problem. It is a pity that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) does not visit my electorate, which is like any inner metropolitan electorate in Melbourne, and see the real problems being faced there by small business.

BREAK.PARA: Something that is always enunciated, particularly by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), is that if you deal with the trade union movement you will solve the problem of unemployment, because you will reduce the terrible things that the movement does to small business. The history of the trade union movement is basically that it has traditionally not had a great deal of impact in terms of small business. Why? Because, historically, the resources of the trade union have always been limited.

It was easier, for example, if you were an officer in the liquor trades union, to deal with and enrol members in the breweries because they were in one spot, in large numbers and in the larger hotels. By and large, it was not possible, given the lack of resources, to deal with the smaller businesses. The unions were not concerned with shop assistants in small shops, employing one or two people. Why? Because they did not have the resources to cover them.

The real enemy and the real problem confronting small business in my community and in many other parts of Australia is big business. It is the larger enterprises, given the nature of the competitive society in which we live, that create trading circumstances which make things increasingly difficult, both for small manufacturers and for small business. You have only got to see the impact of this in a community: there are always arguments going on when small businesses operating in shopfronts are threatened with the advent of a major supermarket and the creation of a major building complex.

Small business does have its own problems. But as for saying that if you solve all the problems of small business you are going to solve the problems of unemployment—when this government, by its very own actions, is compounding the problems of unemployment—no member has to do anything more than walk outside this House to see the problems that confront the people of Canberra, the national capital, and to see the number of public servants who have been dismissed but who started in the Public Service confident of the fact that they had a long‐term future and that they had the capacity to develop and grow in the various aspects of the Public Service and, in so doing, fulfil a major role not merely for the future of Canberra but also for the future of this nation.

Whole areas of departments are being wound back. Within this parliament, functions that have been carried on since the inception of this parliament are going to be privatised and people who have been working here for years are being dismissed. Unless we are very careful, Canberra is going to become a ghost town, not a national capital. You have only got to walk outside and talk to any person who is involved in small business, who is concerned about the future of their children and where they are going to be employed. And what is it all about? It is about this view of how you run the economy, the concept of privatisation: if you privatise something, it must automatically be better. That, of course, is not demonstrated—not demonstrated at all.

Indeed, if you look at privatisation and its operation in that nation much beloved of many members of the government—Great Britain—what has been the impact of privatisation? Has it solved the problems of unemployment? Has it seen that there is a greater equity within that community? Has it rejuvenated the British manufacturing sector? You have just had a demonstration of the confidence of the average Englishman in the impact of privatisation with what was the greatest victory that the British Labour Party has had in its life. Could it be that they are all wrong? Isn't it the fact that they have seen the effects of privatisation? And what have they seen? They have seen the rich getting richer; they have seen the poor getting poorer; and they have seen Hyde Park becoming not full of tourists but full of people finding somewhere to sleep.

Do you think the same concern, the same worry, is not stalking our Australian community? Do you think there is not the same worry if you are a 45‐year‐old employee, or a 45‐ or 50‐year‐old public servant and you are going to be dismissed, not because you have not been doing your job, not because of any measure of incompetence, but because of this odd belief that somehow, if you are privatised, you will necessarily be more efficient; that if you create a general level of job insecurity, then people will work harder?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Commonwealth Bank? What about the power industry in New South Wales?

—What about the Commonwealth Bank? I am the first to admit that I believe the Labor government made many mistakes, and that was one of them. I do not have a problem about that. Very few governments have not made mistakes. Your government is making a terrible mistake in giving this economic rationalist dogma the emphasis that it is when you know that unemployment is stalking this land. Your electorate is no exception to that.
—We are doing something about it.

—What you are doing is putting more people in the dole queue. That is the net effect. Unemployment is rising in Australia and it will be worse before Christmas. All the economic indicators are showing that. But what is important to this Prime Minister is the economic dogma. He is concerned. He is concerned about what might be described as the Hanson phenomenon. But why is it that in areas of Australia this odd parliamentarian—to be polite—can raise the sorts of feelings she has? Because when people are feeling economically insecure, and particularly if you are at the lower level of the economic strata and there is insecurity, it is difficult to blame yourself. It is a lot easier to blame the last migrant off the boat and it is a lot easier to see immigration as the problem.

BREAK.PARA: When my colleagues in the National Party are worried about the impact in some of their electorates it is because there are many problems in rural Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Largely caused by you.
—Well, not me personally. You cannot blame me for that.
—You were part of the previous government.

—You have used that argument for too long. The real question you have to answer in here and in your electorate is how this budget will solve their economic problems. You can wander around to all your sherry parties, you can clap hands, but everybody knows that there is no hope for the average Australian worker, no hope for their future, in this budget.
—That's why they voted you out.

—They voted us out because they were sick of us. We had been there too long. I'll tell you what, I will lay you the odds that you will not last that long, not with this budget. It is not only that aspect, there is no hope for this government so long as it goes down this path.

BREAK.PARA: What fascinates me about our conservative opponents is how they love to wrap themselves in the flag and talk about the monarchy. However, what is the reality? If you look at our universities, we have a Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) who lives in fantasy land. The fact is, and I say it quite openly, I, like many thousands of Australians, could never have attended the university if it were not for the scholarship scheme brought in by the Chifley government. That was because we believed that institutions of higher education ought to be open to any child irrespective of their social class or background, that entry to universities should be on the basis of their ability.

What has happened to our free tertiary institutions, which we need to keep abreast of world developments in technology? If you are good enough you might get a scholarship, but fees are now the usual requirement. It is interesting to note that as a result of this government's policy, students at university courses in science and engineering, subjects which are critical for our future development, pay 50 per cent more in fees up front than those who are doing courses in the humanities. I do not want to knock those who are doing courses in the humanities, but one may well ask, if we are going to have a future in science and technology, why you have to pay more if you are a student.

Of course, then there are the higher degrees. Every one of those has to be paid for in full. There are many people who will tell you candidly—leading scientists, leading engineers and leading medical practitioners—that if they had had to go through that particular structure at the time when they got their education, they could not have afforded it.

Our universities are becoming places for hire, for overseas students who have rich parents, and for borderline students whose fathers are rich and can afford to keep them there. Indeed, we have a minister for education who walks in and boasts about some great new initiative that is going to open up the state schools. How marvellous! There will be all these businessmen and manufacturers coming to the local state school to make important business decisions. What nonsense!

I sat on a school council and there were many dedicated parents working very hard. But if you live in an area where there is a large number of professional people who opt for the state system then you can get a quality of leadership that you will not get in other parts of our community.
If I want to go and buy a block of land at Warrandyte and put a school on it or a building in order to teach kids that the world is flat, I will get a subsidy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense. You know that's nonsense.

—It is true. The problem with many supporters of the government, when confronted with the truth, is that they do not want to believe it. If you are in the state school system in Victoria and have got less than 200 pupils, you have got to fight to keep your school open. In my electorate, a school which was built at the time the very old school in Port Melbourne was erected did not have a proper toilet facility. Teachers had to line the kids up three at a time. There were problems with molestation because the toilet was not inside the school, but of course the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, our esteemed Dr Kemp, would not have visited that. Having fought off a decision by the department that the school ought to be closed and the property sold, what do we get? The state minister for education says, `No problem, you've got to do it. You will do it by getting a portable set of toilets.' The problem with this government is its ministers live in cloud-cuckoo-land.
—There's only one person in cloud-cuckoo-land around here, Clyde, and it's you.

—I will let the interjection pass. One has to be polite to unintelligent members of the government and supporters of the government. The real problem with this budget is it is driven by economic theory. It is not driven by looking at what is happening in Australian communities and Australian society on the ground. If you live in Victoria there is a great fear in our regional centres and in our community of a drought. Many country areas are under enormous strain. Employment is down. These issues have to be addressed.

BREAK.PARA: You cannot cover everything in the budget, I know that. But the underlying thesis of this government is that you will diminish the Public Service, you will put out to the private sector anything that is not nailed down and in that situation you will deplete, over a period of time, your capacity to recruit first-rate people and bring them through the structure. These are the people who believe in the Westminster system and an integral part of the Westminster system is an independent public service. You build up a range of experience. What we are looking at is a situation where you have divested yourself of so much infrastructure that when a member of parliament wants to ask a question on the state of electricity or the water supply, the answer is, `Well, we can't give it to you because it is covered by a contract that says business‐in-confidence.'

The infrastructure of our society which has been built up over the years is being depleted. The ranks of our Public Service—our senior and junior public servants who have an acquired knowledge and capacity—are being threatened. That threatens the institution and the operations of parliament.

This budget fails because it is not directed towards and will not solve the increasing problem of unemployment in our society. That is the biggest single problem which we face as a nation. It depletes the human resources and it depletes the capacity of our young to have hope for the future—they are the biggest single element in terms of unemployment statistics. We are closing our tertiary institutions to all of those except those who are exceptionally gifted or who have parents who can afford to pay.
This is not a budget which will take Australia into the future and it is not a budget which will give our young people hope and belief in the future of this great nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I confess to having a concern at one time, from a purely archaeological standpoint, that history might lose for all time the culture and thinking of the Kremlin in the 1950s, but I am pleased to see that the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) is assiduously keeping it alive.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to begin my contribution to the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 by asking this question: what is the single, pre‐eminent outcome of Peter Costello's second budget? What is the one message—the take‐out, if you like—or the one impression which this budget and the one that preceded it ought to leave in the minds of the Australian people? When you take out the haggling over individual program emphasis and accent, and when you silence the parochialism, the hackneyed rhetoric and the defence of vested interests by its critics, what is the core that remains?

This budget repays $5 billion worth of Commonwealth debt. The budget represents the lowest level of Commonwealth spending as a proportion of GDP since 1972. After inheriting an annual deficit of $10 billion, this 1997 budget, which is building on the frugality of its immediate predecessor, will allow us to actually deliver a $1.6 billion surplus in 1998.

This budget confirms in the most emphatic and incontrovertible fashion the Commonwealth's commitment to fostering a culture of private and public savings. We are leading by example. This budget places Treasurer Costello and this government in a relationship to the private economy similar to that of John the Baptist to Jesus of Nazareth. Like the Baptist, the Treasurer has proclaimed, `He must increase and I must decrease.'

A number of my colleagues have provided an able defence of individual budget measures. I want to take the opportunity that a debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) provides to highlight the contest of ideas taking place behind the budget documents. The budget draws out and crystallises the different world views of the two sides of this chamber. I believe that underneath all the sound and fury there is a contest of key ideas taking place here. As Ralph Waldo Emerson observed, `great men are they who see that the spiritual is stronger than any material force' and, most particularly, `that thoughts rule the world.' I propose to use the coalition's budget strategy to highlight both the differences and the areas of convergence in the fundamental ideas which guide the major parties in this place.

I would like to begin that discussion with an unequivocal affirmation of the principle which we on this side of the House subscribe to: that all our economic goals are proxies for social, personal and community goals. In the long run, it is the private economy and the private community which holds the best hope for redressing inequality, ameliorating human suffering and upholding human dignity. You cannot separate the strength of the domestic economy from the achievement of all the worthy human goals to which members on both sides of the House repeatedly affirm their solemn commitment. In the words of Victor Hugo, `social prosperity means the man happy, the citizen free, the nation great.'

Unless the economy is sufficiently productive to yield a healthy surplus, there is no tax base from which to fund social programs. Unless there is sufficient incentive to reward and foster robust industry, there is no‐one to provide essential services. Unless the economy is growing with appropriate speed and certainty, there is no confidence to take on new employees or to invest in new technologies. This is the first and perhaps most fundamental point of divergence between the major parties.

Members opposite either explicitly or implicitly seem to adhere to the view that the public sector can continue to spend indefinitely without reference to the impact of that spending on the health and vitality of the private economy, and without reference to the mounting debts which accrue. They uphold a rigid bifurcation between economic and social goals. They are fixated on short‐term spending programs, apparently blind to the impact of the government's rapacious demands on opportunities available to the private community.

In the long run, the two realms will always converge. The most powerful evidence of that convergence is the delivery, as a result of decisions of this government, of four successive interest rate cuts. Since March 1996, home loan rates have decreased from 10.5 per cent to 6.99 per cent. For a family with a standard mortgage of, say, $100,000, this equates to almost $300 per month of additional disposable income.

While I applaud and support the specific savings measures in the budget, I regard it as being overshadowed by the benefits which have flowed to the Australian community from our frugality and from the interest rate falls which have resulted. This raises the question of morality, of compassion and of what members opposite so frequently refer to as social justice. These are words which roll off the tongue with a kind of facile ease and are usually coupled in the mouths of the ALP by a righteous indignation at one program or another being reduced in its scale or reach.

I ask the chamber how much compassion is involved in spending the surplus of others? How much of the high moral ground can be occupied by making commitments you cannot fund and passing on debts to those who must follow? How is it socially just to so weigh down the productive elements of the community that they find no incentive to work or to save or to provide opportunities for those who most need them? As Edmund Burke sagaciously remarked, it is a general popular error to imagine the loudest complainers for the public to be the most anxious for its welfare. The ones who suffer the most from our economic mismanagement are those in society with least bargaining power.

The wealthiest 20, 40 or 60 per cent will always have sufficient means to provide for their needs but the young, the unskilled, the new migrants, are the most reliant on what is offered to them out of the surplus of the vitality of the private economy. While we can hide the unemployed in statistical obscurity or recirculate them through a revolving door of ineffectual labour market programs, it is the private economy that will give them real jobs.

While the ALP was in the driver's seat the wheels were spinning furiously but the Australian people increasingly looked out the window and saw that the car was not moving. By contrast, every measure in this budget is directed towards the empowerment of the private economy; the empowerment of the private citizen; the empowerment of the Australian family. It is a strategy which encourages wealth creation—the wealth of the nation, the common wealth.

Mr Deputy Speaker, there has been some discussion in recent times about a convergence of ideas among the major political parties in Australia, and indeed around the world. But I submit that it is more of a conversion than a convergence. Worldwide, the parties of the left that remain viable have embraced the language of reform, of restraint and of productivity. In the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), you cannot proclaim your support for expenditure restraint in general but then resist and oppose every individual act of restraint.

There is plentiful evidence for this conversion at both the domestic and the international levels. The recent election of Tony Blair in England was cited by the previous speaker as being something to provide some encouragement. I suggest it confirms rather than refutes my thesis. The result was only achievable as a consequence of British Labour jettisoning huge chunks of its previous philosophy. In a dramatic shift to the right, the so‐called New Labour has lost all traces of radicalism and much of its former confidence that the state can act with cogency as an agent of positive social change.

A convergence of economic ideas is also reflected in strategic cooperation. Boris Yeltsin made the dramatic announcement in Paris recently that Russia would disarm all its warheads now aimed at European cities. Russia is assiduously courting the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for its defence and strategic future, as are most of the former Soviet states. NATO now faces the extraordinary problem, unthinkable a decade ago, of how to accommodate the large number of former communist states clamouring for membership. Few events could more completely confirm the failure of collectivism and the success of individual freedom and a spirit of enterprise. While I do not equate the ALP directly with communism, I do cite—although the former speaker would cause one to wonder—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 5.00 p.m. to 5.05 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will recall that I was referring to Boris Yeltsin as an emblem of the convergence of ideas and the success and pre-eminence of the private economy and the spirit of enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: It was just a matter of time before communism's philosophical bankruptcy would be matched by its economic bankruptcy. The United States won the Cold War because the domestic economy of the Soviet Union was insufficiently productive to meet the costs of the arms race. That may have been a disappointment to some of those in Spring Street in Victoria, now refugees to the Commonwealth parliament. To me it was something to find satisfaction in. The principle is that if you are going to have an arms race, you must be in a position to win it.

The principle was played out with the same certainty decades before when the Axis powers could entertain their aggressive imperialist ambitions only as long as they did not wake the sleeping giant of American industrial muscle. Ironically, the success of the raid on Pearl Harbor was the beginning of the end for fascist dictatorship. We are free today, speaking English, enjoying democratic freedoms, because America was able to project naval power into the Pacific and defeat our opponents at the Battle of the Coral Sea.

The American soldier was neither bigger, stronger nor more intelligent than his opponent, but he was supported by an economy that was bigger, more productive and more adaptable than those of his opponents. At the height of the Lend Lease program, the shipyards in Delaware, the Great Lakes, Mississippi and on the west coast launched 597 Liberty ships in a 12‐month period because they had to build them faster than the German U‐boats could sink them. In that way the industrial muscle, the spirit of enterprise which has been a feature of the development of the American nation, came to the rescue of the free world.

Defence of the realm is the first and indeed, I submit, one of the few inalienable duties of the state.
