While we now perceive no immediate threats to our sovereignty or territorial integrity, the lesson of history is that this happy state of affairs may be transient. I applaud our government's decision to quarantine the funding allocation to Defence in its first two budgets. I applaud the policy direction of the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) to redirect our resources from the tail to the sting, because the best form of defence is a credible deterrent—and credible we must be.

Returning to my original thesis, we ought not to forget that the freedom of the citizen which flows from a credible defence capability is merely one of the human incidents which are themselves a consequence of economic productivity. There are no short cuts to quality of life. As Margaret Thatcher told the British trade union movement in the early 1980s, `If you want a German standard of living, you have to have a German standard of productivity.' I note that, following the hard years of reform under Thatcher, England now enjoys the lowest rate of unemployment in the European Union. Hundreds of thousands of young Britons are in jobs today because of the hard decisions taken by conservative governments over the past 18 years. By contrast, over the channel, France now labours under the millstone of 13 per cent unemployment, because of the wasted years of complacent collectivism and class division under the leadership of former President Mitterand.

In that connection I salute the reforms introduced by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) in the Workplace Relations Act which, as part of the coalition's plan for a productive Australia, will help the economy to deliver real jobs to those seeking employment in western Sydney and in my electorate of Parramatta. The new age of industrial harmony and productivity highlights the ideological dilemma faced at present by the Australian Labor Party, because the heartbeat of the ALP is the ideas of collectivism and class conflict.

Take away the inevitability of hatred and dissension on the shop floor and you take away the raison d'etre of the ALP. However dressed up in the moderate language of `New Labour', its fundamental premise is class based antagonism. The great conundrum for the ALP and the trade union movement is that so many thinking Australians no longer buy it. Their experience in the workplace is one of teamwork, cohesion and industrial participation. More and more sharing in the fruits of the enterprises, as we become a share‐owning democracy; they are subscribing to popular capitalism. This is the sanguine future reflected in Peter Reith's Workplace Relations Act and the budget's incentive for employee share ownership plans, which is another big tick.

Following the assault on the Australian parliament by the CFMEU and their union cohorts, the ALP has been doing a by now familiar dance of prevarication as the party trashed the Accord and tried to distance itself from a discredited trade union movement. The ALP without the trade unions looks to me very much like one hand clapping—they have all the same voice and force.

The left of the ALP in New South Wales has again been outflanked and betrayed by the Labor Party's economic cross‐dressers who are now selling off the entire electricity generating capacity of New South Wales in a textbook expression of economic rationality. Poor old Mick Clough, your archetypal Labor man, the member for Bathurst: instead of retiring as an elder statesman of the party, he contemplates his future as an independent, presumably fighting the next election against a former ALP colleague whom he once greeted, in the cardigans of the trades hall, as `comrade' and `mate'.

I do not envy even the considerable intelligence of the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) in his task of working out what it now means to be Labor. T.S. Eliot in his poem, The Hollow Man, made the observation that, `Between the idea and the reality, between the motivation and the act falls the shadow'. The ALP is entirely overshadowed by the moribund nature of its philosophy and by the incessant navel-gazing which leads nowhere.

Mr Evans has been asked to unravel the Gordian knot of the ALP's core philosophy. If you just look at the two responses of the leader and deputy leader of the ALP to the GST, you find the deputy leader and shadow treasurer coming out, with a clear statement of openness, to have a dialogue and discussion about major tax reform, immediately to be countermanded by the leader who ruled it out without further consideration.

This reflects this questioning, this unknowing about what it really means to be Labor in a modern world. I note that the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) has suggested that Labor's current regional development strategy can be likened to a road safety program of someone with a red flag walking out in front of motor vehicles. Can I suggest that if you are looking for a candidate—for someone to carry that red flag—the member for Melbourne Ports would be eminently suitable.

Working Australians have evacuated the trade unions in droves, in a haemorrhage of life blood that has left the movement looking wan and bereft of vitality. The workers have voted with their minds, with their hearts and with their feet. In 1976, the proportion of the work force who were union members was 51 per cent; today it is 31 per cent. It has been decimated and continues to decline year by year.

In the words of Ross Gittins, the trade union movement `exhibits all the signs of a sunset industry.' The crisis in the ALP at heart is a crisis of ideas. They committed themselves to an ideological path after the great shearers' strike in the 1890s from which they have never really emerged. They are locked into a straitjacket of philosophical concepts that are as outdated and as useless as the crank on the front of a motor vehicle.

BREAK.PARA: The ALP knows where it has come from: it knows its history, it knows its past, but it has no idea where it is going. As more and more Australians reject the path of tribal division, of confrontation, of bloodymindedness, they join hands with their employers to work for a brighter, more secure and more productive future.

Rather than highlighting the shared opportunities of economic growth, the ALP constantly focus on the inequality of the distribution of income. They say the benefits of economic development are not shared with sufficient liberality or equality, but their cure is always worse than the ailment. All their rhetoric about social justice amounts to nothing more than taking the fruits of the labour of those who earned it and giving it to those who did not.

In the long run it does not work and the hardest hit are those who need a job or those who need to keep a job. Labor rush about erecting further and higher obstacles to employment, savings, investment and growth. In pursuit of a doctrinaire, mathematical equality they reduce the size of the entire economic cake by quashing the spirit of enterprise, of risk taking, of entrepreneurship and of old-fashioned hard work. They destroy the private instincts of philanthropy, of community, and of neighbourly concern by building a Big Brother state with ever higher layers of bureaucratic baggage.

Next year the Commonwealth budget will be in surplus for the first time since the rot began in 1972. That is the take-out of the first two Costello budgets, that is the bottom line. We may haggle over individual program decisions, over priorities, over accent and emphasis, but the fruits of frugality and stewardship are already apparent in the disposable income of almost $300 a month returned to the Australian people.

This budget reflects a holistic, coherent, practical, caring philosophy, which understands the inextricable connection between economic and social goals. In the words of Adam Smith, `Little else is requisite to carry a state to the highest degree of opulence from the lowest barbarism but peace, easy taxes and a tolerable administration of justice.' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr ADAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a pretty interesting bit of rubbish. Let me tell the honourable member—who is only new and has probably just left university by the sound of that speech; it sounded like it came from university—that the Australian Labor Party has renewed itself on many occasions, will renew itself again and will govern Australia again with great spirit and great policies. If it had not been for the great Australian labour movement this century and the great trade union movement of Australia, many people would be a lot worse off than they are today.
—Many are out of a job.
—I will ask the members to direct their remarks through the chair. The member for Lyons has the floor.

—The living standards of most Australians have been improved because of the trade union movement. After listening to the arguments put forward by the honourable member, I would recommend to him that he does some new reading; that he goes out and talks to some practical people. Then he could start to make a contribution—
—Why are they leaving you in droves?
—I call the honourable member for Parramatta to order. You have had your say. The member for Lyons has the floor.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. There are a lot of ideas that need to be considered. By the time you got to your second budget, and after about 16 months in office, you are already looking around for any decent ideas.

SPEECH.PARA: You have destroyed the savings mechanism we had. We were trying to put national savings together in this country. You have come up with the idea of focusing on one lot of people in the electorate, hoping that is going to give you some votes. You have destroyed the whole savings mechanism. Even the best commentators in the country are saying that we will not be adding to the national savings effort by the system that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has brought in.

When I first joined the parliament, I believed that we were elected to help members of our electorates to achieve a better life for themselves. For a short time between 1993 and 1996, I felt that the government was helping to put people back into work, was assisting those who needed more skills before joining the work force, was providing child care, was ensuring the elderly had proper and appropriate services and was getting the economy going. Business was expanding and new ideas were being developed. Now I feel that this current government is taking us nowhere.

The amendment to the second reading motion moved by the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) points out that we are going nowhere. This government is in shambles. I feel totally ashamed of what is occurring in my country.

How do I go back to the constituents of my electorate and say, `This government is looking after your interests' when jobs are going, when health services are closing, when older people are having to pay for their entrance into nursing homes and when creches are being closed or their fees put beyond the average working people's budgets? How can I say this is for a better life? I can't.

When I look at reports in the press of how the government is handling itself in the parliament, I can see that they have got absolutely no idea of what is going on in this country. They have chosen to ignore the disillusionment and the resentment that are being shown in the electorate for these cutbacks—resentment which has thrown into prominence people like the present member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). And when it came time to put these unfriendly and un‐Australian sentiments to bed, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) ran away. He did not want to face up to these ugly people who just happened to have a mouthpiece in the unfortunate member for Oxley.

Then there was Wik and the stolen children report. All over the world, national leaders are offering statements of regret and apology for the misdeeds of their ancestors—Bill Clinton in the United States expressed regret for the many appalling incidents in the history of the Afro‐Americans; Tony Blair has apologised for the English not helping the Irish during the potato famine—not because they are taking all the blame for those acts for the present generation but because they acknowledge the fact that they happened and that many people's lives were very badly affected. We owe them that understanding and we owe them support now. It is a way of indicating that we are prepared to do better and to take a bit of the load that those people have carried because of our intervention and our destruction in the past.

With Wik and the stolen children report, this government has had an opportunity to move closer to reconciliation. But what has the Prime Minister done? He has done nothing. He is running away. It is too difficult and too demeaning for him to say, simply, `I'm sorry.' Is that what he is going to do when half the working population cannot find a job? Is that what is happening when those companies that might be establishing or expanding in Australia take themselves offshore because nobody is interested in them here?

The worst part of this is that the people this government is talking about helping are those people from regional Australia where jobs are hardest to come by. How is the government trying to help them? They have cut the regional development programs totally out of existence. There is no more regional development or infrastructure money. The labour market programs and the business support programs have all gone. They have cut funds to education and tertiary institutions. They have sliced into child-care funding so that many working parents can no longer afford child care. They have knocked off great chunks of funding to local government that could have been spent on infrastructure and other works. That would have involved creating jobs.

That is one thing that this country should be doing—it will have to start spending money to start putting some jobs in place. If you do not want labour market programs, you are just going to have to put money into infrastructure. If the private sector will not do it, then government is going to have to do it. At the moment that is not the accepted philosophy, it is the old philosophy, but that is the only thing I can think of as a way of getting jobs operating.

As I said, this government has knocked off great chunks of funding to local government. In addition, they are selling Telstra without ensuring the continuation of its community obligations. The government has not ensured that people in isolated and remote areas will have the same services as people in the city. I have raised this on many occasions and nobody will give me an answer to it. This government is just going to sell Telstra and the community obligations for the more isolated areas will be forgotten.

This government has put another 31,500 people around Australia out of work, and the people they are trying to appease with all these cuts do not like it either. Many are really concerned that there is no direction, no plan, no strategy to try to cope with the growing unemployment and the increasing dissatisfaction with the current policies.

I was reading an address given last week to the Minerals Council of Australia by Rod Cameron of ANOP. He was commenting on the difficulties that the mining industry was having in gaining public understanding of what they were doing. Rod Cameron said:

Australians are demanding that their leaders produce a plan, a plan for industry that shows them how jobs will be created in the cities where they want them. Sooner rather than later, this government will realise that it must turn its mind to industry policy as the only way of stopping those hard won battlers being lured away by Pauline's siren song.

The only alternative to doing so is substantially to decrease the time before this government is voted out, to be replaced by one which does see a role for governments in interfering with the free market in an effort to recreate industrial growth.

In other words, if it is too hot in the kitchen, get out and let someone else have a go. I think the people of Australia are starting to look at this government and say that maybe it is too hot for them to be able to handle the kitchen.

Mr Cameron is only one of many commentators who are bemoaning the difficulties both industry and the community are facing. What is the good of having a budget surplus, but having no one working, our assets owned overseas and our public infrastructure in tatters? I would submit that that is a pretty silly philosophy to hold, but it seems to be the one that this government and its members have. I call on the two backbenchers who are in this chamber at the moment to take it on board and to try and take it forward because we need to tackle those issues.

My state of Tasmania is heavily dependent on raw material development and export. We have a small population that is further declining and our economy is really devastated. Yet the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith), according to an answer in question time today, is far keener in promoting the help his government has given to the Cocos and Christmas islands than in helping his own island state of Tasmania. When all the cuts to Tasmania were taking place, where was his voice? Where was his voice to intercede? Nowhere—it was found wanting. Tasmania needs a strong and active public sector to ensure that the private sector can get on with their job of developing their industries, their small businesses and their new enterprises with the knowledge that they have all they need to remain competitive, both with the rest of Australia and overseas.

I want to particularly mention the unfortunate cuts to the ABC. In this 50th year of radio broadcasting in Australia, this government has celebrated that achievement by cutting the funding. Of all the measures most likely to impact on regional Australia, the most cruel are the cuts to Aunty. The ABC has been instrumental in getting news, current affairs, information, rural programs, music and the arts out into the areas that are not covered by anybody else. This is somewhat related to what I was saying about Telstra. The new generation of technology which will need to go into regional and isolated areas will be carried by the new technologies, the new cable systems. Without a community service obligation and without government making the marketplace do this, and making sure that it happens, we are going to be left behind. Some of the work that the ABC has done in the past will probably be lost as a result of these cuts. This will be in addition to the lack of service by a privatised Telstra as a result of not having community obligation in place.

I also read with dismay in my local paper that Merv Asher committed suicide. Merv was a props buyer for the ABC for 20 years. His friends were sure that the recent cuts were the last straw for him. It is a very sad exercise. The government is preparing to chop 700 jobs, and in Tasmania this could have some really significant effects as we do not have that many employees anyway. Are we just going to be hanging off Victoria's coat‐tails? We will probably have no programming of our own and we will probably lose our studio. This will be tragic for many loyal and enthusiastic watchers and listeners of the ABC.

Many of their audiences come from country areas, and many listen late at night, either on shift work or lying awake in bed. Some love the programs that go out on Radio Australia. For some, those who are visually impaired and those who are bedridden, it is their only link with the outside world. The most stupidest thing I have seen in government policy for a long time has been reducing Radio Australia's footprint into the Asia region.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should say `most stupid', Dick.

—You can pick up my grammar, good Doctor; I will concentrate on the content of what I have to say. In my times in Asia, Radio Australia was very good to listen to; but it also makes an impact in the Asian region. It is a very good opportunity for us to have our say, to push ourselves out and to get our culture out there and understood. For us to cut this and take most of Radio Australia out of the Asian area and make the ABC sack 700 people just as a mechanism to reach the goal of a surplus budget is silly and illogical to me, when we are trying to promote our industry sectors into the Asian market and our future development and exports in the region, and when we are trying to increase jobs at home.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to touch on the Tasmanian situation. Again, I am greatly concerned for Tasmania because of the sale of the railways. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) is presently in the process of selling Tasmanian Rail. We do not seem to have any plan or idea of having a transport system or strategy which will serve our state in any way. We are going to put parts of this railway system on the market, without understanding how the links work into the ports.

There does not seem to be any idea that transport systems are best coordinated so that they link together, nor that you sometimes need to get trucks to rail or rail to ships and those sorts of things. I think we are heading into some serious difficulties with the way that the process is starting to be put together to sell the railways in Tasmania. I do not think the state minister has any idea where he is going on it, just as long as he does not have to do anything about it. He is basically stepping back and saying, `The federal government owns it and, if they wish to sell it, it is basically their business. Don't blame me.' That is a very bad way of handling his portfolio, in the sense that I believe that it is his responsibility to be saying things about the transport system, if it is not going to be handled correctly.

We need to have the freight equalisation scheme remain to assist Tasmania. We need to have a second ship to transport goods and tourists. We need to stop playing around with local government in Tasmania and let them organise themselves into an economic base where they can achieve and give services to the people of their municipalities. But, with respect to the transport system, I call on the minister to look at Tasmania and the strategies we need to make our transport system work properly and efficiently in an integrated system, with some planning so that we can achieve our goals in the future and therefore create many of the jobs that we will need in the future—especially the ones that this budget is not delivering.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government budget objectives have been framed to achieve joint goals of achieving rising living standards and enhanced employment opportunities. At the same time, there is a commitment on the part of the government to meet its social responsibilities. The government is projecting a 3.75 per cent growth over the coming year and the Reserve Bank is in fact forecasting in excess of four per cent as we move into our seventh year of continuous economic growth without inflationary or current account pressures. The reason this is achievable is the government's extraordinary fiscal consolidation program. The overall budget strategy is to sustain a prolonged period of economic growth, avoiding the boom and bust cycles of the past whereby, certainly according to the Governor of the Reserve Bank, most of the jobs in the last 15 years have been lost.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three basic public policy objectives that we are pursuing. They are, firstly, to maintain a low rate of inflation; secondly, to promote higher levels of public and private sector saving, and that of course is to finance investment and reduce reliance on foreign capital; and, thirdly, to progress economic reform in areas such as transport and communications.

In reducing our need for foreign capital through increasing national savings and financing social infrastructure on income, we reduce our exposure to exchange rate depreciations, which in fact play a far greater role in restraining Australia's exporters than do tariffs. By repaying $5.2 billion in debt, the Commonwealth will not be out in the markets this year borrowing money and will be further contracting the stock of public sector debt. A look at the bond market perhaps tells the best story of reducing supply of scrip—prices being bid up and yields being pushed down.

The March 1996 yield spread between the US and Australian government bonds was almost 300 basis points—it was 290, or 2.9 per cent. The current spread is around 100, which reflects an improvement in our fiscal position. Over the next four years, the underlying budget balance will improve by about three percentage points of gross domestic product. Having inherited a debt of $10.5 billion, we are now returning in 1997-98 to a $3.8 billion deficit. In 1998-99 there will be a $1.6 billion surplus and, by the year 2000-2001 a $10.7 billion surplus—an extraordinary achievement by any measure. Debt accumulated by the Keating government was 19 per cent of gross domestic product at the time of the election last year. Under us, my children will go into the new millennium with their government running a $10.7 billion surplus. Outlays as a proportion of GDP were 27 per cent. By the year 2000-2001, they will be 23 per cent of GDP. To put that into perspective, at the time the Whitlam government came to power, federal government expenditure as a proportion of GDP was 20.5 per cent. By the time Mr Whitlam left power, it was 26.7 per cent.

What I would like to focus on specifically, though, are revenues, which are forecast to drop slightly to 24.5 per cent of GDP, reflecting a cut in the Reserve Bank's dividend from $2.1 billion in 1996-97 to $1.2 billion, due largely to the strength of the Australian dollar over the past year. Again, exchange rate depreciation is having a big effect on Australia's economy.

If you look at the revenue side of the budget, we are forecasting $133.3 billion in revenues. That is composed of gross PAYE tax receipts that will raise $62 billion, of which $9 billion will be sent back to taxpayers in the form of refunds; the Medicare levy will raise $3.7 billion; company tax $18.5 billion, and fringe benefits tax $3.1 billion.

On the expenditure side, estimated to be $127 billion, health will cost us $21.4 billion—a rise, I might add, of 7.3 per cent on last year—going now to 15.1 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays, up from 14.2 per cent the previous year. Education outlays will be $11 billion, down slightly to 0.8 per cent, and welfare outlays will be a staggering $50.9 billion, a two per cent increase on last year. To put that into proper perspective, we will spend more on health, education, and welfare, at $82 billion, than all of the money that will be raised by taxes on income—PAYE taxpayers and company tax—which will raise in the vicinity of $72 billion.

Currently in Australia we are taxing all of the things that we are trying to encourage: employment, productivity and savings, despite some very good initiatives in the budget to encourage it. The present taxation system is inadequate to meet the challenges and the needs for revenue raising for the future.

For the past 20 years taxes as a percentage of GDP have been relatively stable at about 30 per cent. However, major increases in public expenditure on health, education and welfare have not been matched over the last decade or so by revenue increases, but funded instead by the accumulation of debt and asset sales. With expenditure exceeding revenues, national savings have declined and states have been forced to reduce services. I think all of us in our constituencies know the impact that that has had on us, whether it be hospital services, policing, education or any of a number of things.

The top marginal income tax rates have declined from 67 per cent in the early 1970s to 47 per cent by the early 1990s, while the minimum rates of tax on lower taxable incomes have increased to 20 per cent. To put that in plain language that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) may even understand, that means that low‐ and middle-income PAYE taxpayers have carried the burden of Australia's revenue raising. Wholesale sales tax, customs and excise duties were 34 per cent of revenues in the 1950s; they are now only 21 per cent.

Federal government collects about 80 per cent of taxes, but state and local governments provide in excess of 50 per cent of public services, 75 per cent of the public sector work force and 80 per cent of essential economic and social infrastructure.

The problems with Australia's current taxation system and arrangements could be summarised by the following and I know there are more. The first is that our international competitiveness is being significantly restrained by the nature of our current tax arrangements. Wholesale sales tax is levied in only six countries, of which we are one, and manufacturers are needing to pay tax on inputs whilst trying to compete increasingly on global international markets where they cannot simply increase their prices to cover taxes on inputs that are being paid here, nor indeed to cover the cost of tariffs that are being applied on imports which are then going onto input cost in Australia.

Secondly, our current taxation system is inequitable and I think many of the more thoughtful members on the other side would be able to recognise this. In 1994 the Australian Bureau of Statistics report by David Johnson and his colleagues found that the poorest 10 per cent of households spent 22.6 per cent of their disposable income on indirect taxes and that is an increase from 14.2 per cent in 1984. In contrast the wealthiest 10 per cent spent only 5.7 per cent of their disposable income on indirect taxes, a reduction over that decade from 6.3 per cent.

Professor Bob Gregory and Dr Hunter from the Australian National University, in perhaps the most extensive study of income separation in Australia from 1978 to 1991, found that in that period of time, in the wealthiest five per cent of suburbs in Australia income increased 23 per cent, while for the poorest five per cent of suburbs it declined 23 per cent. In EPAC's April 1995 report on income distribution in Australia from 1978 to 1994, the bottom 10 per cent of income earners in Australia had a reduction in their income of two per cent; in contrast, the top 10 per cent increased by 23 per cent.

That anyone could suggest the current taxation system is not inequitable is to defy reality. You will not at the moment pay tax on crayfish, caviar or exotic fruits. You will pay, however, an 11 per cent sales tax on biscuits, ice cream, confectionary and fruit juices. You will pay 22 per cent on soft drinks.

If the current taxation system is inefficient, it is also complex. David Koch, the well-known financial commentator advised me the average tax agent has to read 25 pages of new tax ruling or legislation every day just to keep up. Despite the Tax Pack—which we heard today will increase by 20 pages—70 per cent of Australians use a taxation agent to prepare their returns.

We have a shrinking taxation base, as I said earlier. We are currently taxing income and in a low-inflation environment, with all of the positive things that that brings in terms of interest rate reductions, we do not have bracket creep and that has a negative impact on government revenues.

We have falling tariffs and falling customs duty and of course that means reduced revenue for government. And thanks to the efforts of some Australians, fewer people are now smoking and are more discerning about the alcohol content of alcoholic beverages that they drink, so that we have had a reduced share of household expenditure on products for which we used to rely in no small way for taxation revenue. Wholesale sales tax has been applied to three goods—durables, motor vehicles and beer—and those three things are diminishing as a revenue source for Australian governments.

Until the 10 per cent bed tax announced by the New South Wales Labor government, the services sector currently has not been taxed. The indirect taxation system is complex. If you ask anyone running a business, particularly a small manufacturing business, they will be only too happy to tell you. The tax burden is carried by low and middle income earners. Income tax is minimised by higher income earners, the self-employed and the well advised.

Greenhouse emissions are something about which the world is becoming increasingly concerned. As a nation we are trying to come to terms with the United Nations framework agreement on greenhouse gas emissions. Australian manufacturers and those who have come on board the national greenhouse program, which brings together industry, government and private sector organisations, need to understand that we need to make, for many other reasons as well, Australian manufacturing as efficient as we possibly can if we are going to have, and make, a positive contribution to the world's environment in terms of greenhouse emissions.

We also have a cash economy. The Victorian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in its submission to the tax summit last year estimated that the tax revenue being lost in terms of the cash economy was about $1 billion a year. But, as we have just heard from the Commissioner of Taxation in the last week, it is possibly in the vicinity of $3 billion to $15 billion. Whatever the arguments over the size of the cash economy, it is substantial and it is money that could be used to fund essential services. We have vertical fiscal imbalance also and whilst the states are raising less than half of the money which they are required to spend there is not likely to be major progress made in terms of health and education reform.

Perhaps more than anything else, what is going to change Australia's economic, social and political priorities is the ageing of the nation. A report that I would commend to all members is the National Commission of Audit report produced by Professor Bob Officer's committee last year. You will find in that that the aged dependency ratio in Australia at the moment is 5.3:1. That means that for every person over the age of 64 and under the age of 15 there are 5.3 people between the ages of 15 and 64. Over the next 40 years that ratio will go to 2.6:1.

The ABS figures from last year are that 7.8 million Australians worked and paid taxes to support 6.2 million people who were relying on some form of social security benefit, most of them through no fault of their own. If we do not change the way we produce wealth and the way we tax ourselves, those trend lines will cross in the next decade.

We also know that about 13 per cent of us are over the age of 65 now. By the year 2050, about a third of us will be over the age of 65. In the absence of a cure, seven per cent of us over the age of 75 will suffer from dementia. In other words, we will have a significant number of Australians who will not be in the work force, who will not be paying taxes, but who will have increasing needs for health and welfare expenditure. In fact, Officer's report estimates that over the next 40 years we will have to spend 10 per cent more of GDP above and beyond real growth from where we are currently at just simply maintaining health and welfare services for the ageing population as they have come to expect and, I would suggest, deserve.

The other thing that is causing governments to review and reform Australia's taxation system is technology. I commend to every member of the House the electronic commerce task force report of the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board that was released in March. It is now possible, amongst other things, to run a business from Australia, transfer money overseas through the Internet, have your employees based in countries other than Australia, and buy goods from overseas and not pay excise when they come into Australia. And because of the digitisation of products that are being offered through new technologies, the distinction between goods and services is being blurred, which then makes it very difficult for the taxation department to keep up with tracking the transfer of money.

I would also recommend that honourable members have a look at the European Union Bank's home page which, amongst other things, encourages and invites taxpayers to Caribbean style tax shelters, which it is able to legally offer through the Internet. Australian manufacturers are paying wholesale sales tax on inputs. As tariffs decline, it is cheaper to move operations offshore and to save on sales tax that is payable on inputs. If you look at computer manufacturing, for example, if a regional computer system is located in Singapore, Hong Kong or New Zealand, no taxes will be paid on that computer; but if it is located in Australia, sales tax at 22 per cent is payable in respect of importation or local manufacture of that computer.

The Business Council's use of Access Economics modelling calculated the long run gains from reform of indirect taxes and subsidies to be in the vicinity of two per cent of GDP, or $10 billion. That is almost twice the amount of money that the Commonwealth government contributes to the financing of Australian public hospitals in one year. It is also the amount of money that the government has been forced to save in its fiscal consolidation program, and it would do a lot to fund the kinds of services which the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and other decent people on the other side would like to see funded.

Until Australia's taxation system is simplified, it will be very difficult, if not impossible, for this nation to create more wealth. Until the tax system and tax base is broadened, any responsible government seeking to fund social infrastructure on income, rather than on debt and asset sales, has no choice but to necessarily review essential government funded services. It does not give me and some people on this side any pleasure to have seen some of the cutbacks in some of the areas, but it had to be done if we are not going to continue to indulge the present generation at the expense of our children.

To maintain a welfare system that condemns the poor to permanent dependency and that is financed on debt and asset sales is an abrogation of our responsibilities to the future of our country. The purpose of any taxation system, ultimately, is to finance the establishment and maintenance of social infrastructure, to support and protect those in society who have neither power nor influence, and to enable governments to strategically stimulate those sectors of the economy essential to growth and, with it, the creation of jobs. In essence, it is the poor who should ultimately be its greatest beneficiaries.

Finally, in terms of the phenomenon that has become known as the `Hanson phenomenon'—referring, I presume, to the honourable member for Oxley—I think she and those who subscribe to her views need to understand that the world is currently contracting into three major trading blocks. Whether we like it or not, whatever our hankering for the past and some of the better aspects of it, if we are not a part of it, then my children, our children, will have no economic future at all. We need to understand that our future lies not so much in some of the industries that have characterised much of the latter part of the 20th century, but in knowledge based industries in particular and those that are going to be involved in the development of skills and expertise in the Asia‐Pacific region.

There is legitimacy in the grief and the anger that people are expressing, and they see the member for Oxley as a lightning rod for the expression of that grief and anger about changes that few Australians want, and even fewer really understand. But the policies that are being espoused by the member for Oxley are morally wrong and economically irresponsible. The other point that needs to be made is that whilst the member for Oxley is exercising the right, as she sees it, to freedom of speech, the right to freedom of speech has never really extended to the right to demean, denigrate or alienate any section of this society. I feel that, whether it has been deliberate or otherwise, that has been the effect of many of the things that she has said.

All of us, in coming into the parliament, profess to be leaders of one sort or another. I think when we allow facts to bow to bias and prejudiced arguments to dominate public debate, when we feel that we have to follow populist views rather than lead public opinion, then the nation is vulnerable. I think most of the people who are following Ms Hanson are basically decent people. They are angry, they are hurt and they are grieving about the changes that they have seen, but there is also a section of that membership, of those people following, who are frankly evil.

If we maintain silence, if we do not give Australians a confident outlook on the kind of future that we see ahead, if we are not able to articulate that in day‐to‐day life, then evil has found an environment in which it is likely to flourish. Our challenge is to explain and articulate a vision of Australia. Foremost in that, I would suggest, is a taxation system, and reform of it, to get some of those people away from Ms Hanson. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be following my friend the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1). He always generates interesting topics and ideas in his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: To me, the second Howard budget has disappeared like the proverbial stone that skimmed brightly across the lake, bouncing several times before vanishing without trace. It is a bit like the time when your father took you along to the beach or the lakeside and you picked out a little stone and you energetically flicked it across the lake. It made some splashes and then disappeared.

After the breast beating of the first Howard‐Fischer budget, the rally call to the troops who had finally won a battle and now had someone to blame for all the perceived wrongs of the Hawke and Keating years, there was an expectation out there in the electorate that the time had finally come for some wise and sensible decisions in this second Howard‐Fischer budget. Perhaps there would be something in the way of hope for the many seeking relief from the despair evident in many parts of my electorate—I hate to say this—right across the length and breadth of Tasmania.

In my mind the nation needed some new focus and, more importantly, the hundreds and thousands of long‐term unemployed needed to see that they were not going to be discarded and forgotten. In my mind they have been. Why do I say this? Firstly, because the many programs that were once there in place to enable them to at least have some opportunity to gain skills and some experience have been axed.

Unfortunately, the evidence of the impact this unemployment has on people's lives is evidenced if you ever visit my electorate office. Within less than a kilometre radius, in the Broadacre public housing area, with probably the highest unemployment and the highest youth unemployment in Australia, the evidence is there and the impact is there.

The thing that really gets up my nose—and I am a pretty calm, sane, rational and reasonable person who does not go berserk in this place and does not cast aspersions on people—is the diatribe that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) goes on with. He so despises the programs that we had in place and he does it with such a venom and hatred that I am going to publicly invite him to occasionally come to our Parliamentary Christian Fellowship to share in the spirit and unity of purpose that operates so marvellously in our midst. Perhaps some of that benevolence will flow into his soul and he will see that it was not all bad. It is not all black and it is not all white.

It really annoys me. None of us have all the answers and I publicly admit that we made mistakes in the 13 years—I would be foolish not to say that—but there were some good things. My electorate consists basically of three areas: huge swathes of Broadacre public housing which were built by the state Labor government—for which I continually chastise them because they never learnt after building one and seeing it as a failure, and they kept replicating it; some middle class; then rural and remote areas in Tasmanian terms.

I know for a fact that there were dozens of examples where Working Nation programs were the only opportunity for these people who were generationally long‐term unemployed. Before I came into this House I was a schoolteacher. I focused on working in disadvantaged schools in New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and some overseas areas. It was evident that education was the key, but there were generations of long‐term unemployed.

In our Working Nation programs we did at least get the people out of their houses and say to them, `Here is a challenge, come and at least have a go. You have got some skills. You must have some skills. Refine them. Learn some things. Mix and mingle. Be social. Contribute something to your community.'

I was delighted, the Sunday before last, to go down to the South Arm Community Centre—it is a little community down the narrow neck in the southern part of my electorate—to meet with those people who raised $86,000 from amongst a population of a couple of hundred. They had been raising the money for years in the expectation that they would have a community centre where they could have the doctor visit and physiotherapy and a play group. It would also be a focal point for their young people. Hopefully, they can extend it and have a gymnasium so the kids do not have to be carted miles and miles up the road, and they could re‐focus.

Those people came to us when we were in power and said, `How can we be involved in the Working Nation program? How can we get the state government and the local council involved?' They had this cooperative approach. Well, the evidence was there the other Sunday. We were all there—Senator Calvert, me, Mayor Cathy Edwards, and Peter Hodgman, the minister responsible from the state government.

Everyone said what a wonderful idea it was. The 18 guys who worked there for six months learned how to box for the slab, how to pour the concrete, how to erect the building, how to build doors and frames and all the other bits and pieces. They gained enormously. Quite a few of them, at the end of the program, were able to say, `Here is a photographic record of what I had done in order to have this building up and running.' But if you listen to the minister, these things do not happen. I am sure I am not the only person from amongst the 148 electorates in this part of the world who can get up and say, `I can give you concrete evidence that this has worked.' I can give you dozens of examples of similar things happening.

One thing really annoys me. The thing that is obviously missing from this and the previous Liberal budget is some compassion. When I went to the national prayer breakfast in Washington with John Forrest, the member for Mallee, in February of this year, Bill and Hilary Clinton said that they were working on getting rid of this payback mentality. Hilary said that every morning she used to wake up and think, `Who can I get today?' If we operate on that premise, this country will spend all its time navel gazing and ripping people's arms and legs off while the people that we are here to represent are going to suffer.

So, as I say, I would like the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training to visit our Parliamentary Christian Fellowship and share in some of the things that we do there. He would have loved today when we had a Maori speaker who challenged us all.

The past 12 months of the Howard‐Fischer rule, as far as my electorate and most of Tasmania goes, has had as much impact as the first snowfalls that cover the highest slopes of many of the hills that dominate the southern part of my electorate. It looks pretty spectacular and impressive after the first snowfall but once the winter sun gets out the snow soon disappears from sight.

Why do I say this? I say it because I honestly think it is true. There is little of a positive nature that I can actually point to when constituents say, `Harry, what do you think about the budget delivered by the Treasurer?' I think to myself, `What can I say to them?' Can I say, `Go and work for the dole'? How many in my electorate of 90,000 are actually going to work for the dole? I would be lucky to get 100. I have 30 Green Corps, and a proportion of those do not even come from Tasmania.

I went down to the Green Corps at Franklin in the southern part of my electorate, where there is a huge unemployment problem, especially among young people. I went along and talked to them because I was interested. I asked them, `You are part of the Green Corps: tell us a bit about yourself. How did you get involved? Where did you come from? What's your educational background? How's it all operating?' I was amazed when one bloke said, `I'm from Brisbane.' I said, `What the hell are you doing down here? Haven't they got Green Corps programs in Queensland that could cater to you?' He said, `Oh, I thought I would come down here and experience life in Tasmania.' I cannot believe that we are actually putting into place programs that do not benefit people within their own regions.

Another issue that has come to my notice—and it is one that the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) mentioned today—is that of the ship bounty. We had a real arm‐twisting exercise. We had to stop what we were doing and waste a hell of a lot of time, energy and effort in trying to convince people that we had a legitimate argument. One would think, when you are framing the budget—whether it be our side's or yours—that you would be out there talking to people and trying to understand what you are on about.

You have got six or seven Liberal senators—I am not too sure how many, but I could work it out if I went through their names: there are six of them, at least—and surely they must have told someone that this was the largest employer of people in Tasmania. If that goes, Tasmania—which has the highest unemployment in the country and a population which, it is predicted, will be less than 450,000 in about 30 years time—is going out backwards, and yet you are about to put the screws on to close it down. Where is the logic? This is without doubt the world's best high‐speed catamaran builder, and we are giving him a hard time, quibbling about a small amount of money—in fiscal terms, when we are talking about a national budget.

What about the quarantine issue? I know there has been an increase in quarantine surveillance and the like. But tell that to the Tasmanian apple and pear growers. The fire blight issue should never have happened. What impact has it had? We are the largest exporter of apples. We have been working for years and years. We have cracked the Taiwanese market and we were about to crack the Japanese market. We had a small shipment of Fuji apples ready to go, and what happened? We had convinced the growers, we were about to convince the government and everyone was about to sign off and, suddenly, bang! Up came the quarantine issue. AQIS let us down, despite the increased money, and we are now virtually back to square one. This year's shipment was put on hold, and we have to sell it on the Tasmanian or the Australian mainland market, and we have to wait. If you go down to my part of the world, where we grow almost all the apples in Tasmania, the increased production would absolutely amaze you.

There were some other things in the budget which really impacted upon my part of the world. When people say, `Well, what did it do, Harry?' one thing I need to put on record is the issue of child care. I quote from the Australian of 14 May:
The Government concedes this—
the issue of child care—
could be difficult for low‐income families who will have to pay full fees in advance for the first fortnight of the new system and intends to `develop options' to help those in difficulty.

When we were in government, we had a heck of a time convincing the bureaucrats in whatever the department was called in those days—it is now the Department of Health and Family Services—that there were pockets in Tasmania which needed some flexibility when it came to child care. Because of the make‐up of my particular electorate, which is broadacre public housing and rural and remote areas, we have community based child‐care centres. What did this government do? It took away their operational subsidies.

The child‐care centre within a bull's roar of my office is subsidised by the local council in order to allow it to survive. The one at Cygnet is about to be built and it is almost bankrupt before it starts because of changes to the operational subsidy. The one at Huonville is being bailed out by the local council. The one at Geeveston is about to close. The one at Blackman's Bay, which is one of the best child‐care centres in Australia bar none—it has before school; ordinary child care, long‐term and part‐time child care, and after school child care—is going to lose $160,000 in operational subsidy. That services about half a dozen primary schools for after school care.

So when my people say to me, `Harry, what do you think of the budget?' I cannot be too positive, and I am one of the most positive blokes you would ever find. Whoever thought this child-care thing up is a numbers man.

Another thing that is going to impact is the public housing waiting list. The Howard government cut $50 million from the annual funding of the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement. You come and talk to the people in my part of the world who are desperate for a house. It says in the Australian article on 14 May that the cuts will reduce the amount of public housing being built. It may also force state governments to abandon the refurbishment of old housing estates. I have got heaps and heaps of them; probably a good third of my electorate live in these places. I would invite anybody, with this sort of weather, to come and spend a couple of days in Bridgewater, Rokeby, Risdon Vale, Warrane and Mornington and see the hopelessness and despair. They suddenly say, `The house has not been painted for 10 years. We cannot get ordinary maintenance done. What hope have we got now?'—they are not very positive.

Another little cutting: another 16,000 jobs to be cut from the Commonwealth public service over the next financial year. I know all about this. I think I am one of the few politicians whose wife now works in Canberra. She works for the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services. Her job disappeared in Hobart and the only chance she had of a job was to come up here, so I go home to myself and come up to see my wife. I know what impact that is having on my family. What is it having on other people? At least we have a decent income to survive. We are running four houses and one of my two daughters is at university and the other one is trying to find some work after graduating in Melbourne.

As for the PBS scheme, the cuts there are having an impact especially in the rural and remote areas of my electorate. It sounds fine to say, `Okay, we will have the old generic drugs,' but there are a lot of people who need a specific one and if they need it, why can't we give it to them? Surely to goodness in this day of modern technology we can sort out the rorters, the people who are doctor shopping and the ones who are hoarding the drugs. There ought to be a bit of compassion in some of these decisions. If someone has got problems such as blood pressure, depression, ulcers or high cholesterol, why can't they get the drugs? They have been taxpayers. But it is all down to the numbers game.

I know there are some positive things in the budget. The House of Representatives Committee on Family and Community Affairs—that I am deputy chair of—heard the department today saying about all the wonderful things in the budget. One of them was increased funding of $406,000, I think, to promote birthing centres in rural and remote areas. I thought this was great and I dug a bit deeper. They said they were doing another pilot. I said that was funny because the hospital in Franklin had closed its birthing facilities down. It was a state government decision to force all the mothers to go and have their children somewhere else. There can be snow on the highway and you have to cross the mountain saddles but you have no choice. So the local hospital is now excluding the residents that live in the community and yet the Commonwealth government is supposedly doing all these wonderful things. Who is talking to whom? There needs to be some strategy.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) spoke about restructuring the taxation system. I think we need a better, cohesive, interdepartmental interagency approach to specific areas. I think this budget is framed—in fact, I know it is—with five or six big cities in mind, with the occasional little handout to the rural and remote areas to keep us all happy. I am not happy with it. I have not mentioned education and some of the programs there. To my mind we are focusing our money on the wrong spot. It ought to be down to the early education to give our kids an adequate foundation. We are pouring $32 million into looking at youth suicide—that is fine. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My electorate of Wide Bay has been going through difficult times. The small business environment has not been promising; we have got consistently the highest level of unemployment in the country; there has been drought and declining rural prices; and, particularly in the coastal parts of my electorate, the housing industry has slowed. So I was looking for a budget that delivered for regional Australia, that provided some hope and opportunity for business in my area to invest and expand, and that led the people who live in the region to have some confidence that there would be employment opportunities available in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a budget that delivers for regional Australia. It does offer hope and opportunity, and it has not done it in the Labor way of seeking to buy low unemployment statistics. It has not sought to tax in order to spend. It has not done it in the way in which Labor would normally address these sorts of problems—by running up even more debt. This government knows that it is not governments that create wealth, but the toil of the Australian people and the efforts of individual people in business and industry. If our country is to prosper, it is essential that we provide the incentives and the rewards for people to engage in the kind of initiatives that are necessary to get our economy moving again. The 1997 federal budget provides the kind of economic environment that will encourage the businesses of Wide Bay to invest and expand.

I think the feature of this budget is the improvement in the economic outlook that it offers for the years ahead. We have noticed today, with the improved quarterly growth figure, some further encouragement that there is some brighter future ahead. Interest rates are at historically low levels and we have a low inflation environment. Indeed, many people in the community are now going to have to start getting used to the idea that this country can return to an era of sustained growth and low inflation. That was the history of Australia in the 1950s and the 1960s, but was sadly lost in more recent decades.

Much of the so‐called growth in our country has been artificial—it has just been reliant on inflation. Investments did not have to actually achieve a worthwhile return; they could rely on inflation to build the value of the investment. When we invest in the future with low inflation, not only will we sustain the real value of our investment, but it will be necessary for us to achieve real growth. The only way that can be done is if there is an economy which offers the sort of support and encouragement that industry needs.

The remarkable thing about this budget is its fiscal consolidation. A debt free budget—how long is it since we have had a federal budget which does not add to our growing national debt? The coalition government has turned around Labor's $10.3 billion budget deficit and expects a surplus of $1.6 billion in its next budget. That is a remarkable turnaround and it should be the headlines in the newspapers right across the country. Some people have complained that the budget is no longer on the front pages like some Labor budgets which hung around for weeks and weeks. Well, it is off the front pages because of what it is achieving. It is a budget without the horrors of previous years. There are no new taxes. Again, what a remarkable feature for a budget. How long it is since our country has had no new taxes in a budget?

I know that in the past, Labor governments have gone to the people at election time promising no new taxes—often to be followed by the biggest taxing budgets in history. But this is a budget which genuinely has no increases in taxes and yet has achieved substantial fiscal consolidation and reduced the deficit from $10.3 billion down to $3.9 billion. With the projected surplus next year of $1.6 billion, the government is to be congratulated on its achievements in restoring a balanced budget to our nation.

But that is not all. This budget actually pays back $5 billion of Keating's debt. Now, $5 billion is a very substantial sum, but when you realise that $5 billion is only about one‐twentieth of the total debt, it demonstrates for how long we are going to have to produce budgets of this magnitude and with this kind of repayment of the debt before our government debt is removed entirely. So the pain that has been endured over the last year or two has been worthwhile and all Australians should join with the government in the pride and pleasure of knowing that we are moving towards a balanced budget.

The other remarkable feature about the way in which the government has achieved this balance is that it has not been done by raising new taxes, as would have been the Labor way. In fact, real expenditure is down in this budget for only the third time in 30 years. The underlying outlays are reducing to the sorts of levels that we knew in the 1960s and 1970s. The government is getting its hands out of the pockets of the Australian people and balancing its budget by cutting its own expenditure, eliminating waste, finding more efficient ways of achieving its objectives and, certainly, learning to live within its means—something this country needed to do a very, very long time ago.

This is not a budget without features, without hope and without opportunity. It offers real advances for rural and regional Australia. I want to concentrate my remarks on the benefits to regional areas of the 1997 budget. The budget includes a commitment of $4 billion worth of expenditure in regional Australia. Despite having a balanced budget and despite reducing the call on the nation's gross domestic product, $4 billion is earmarked for expenditure in rural and regional areas. The government is to be congratulated on that recognition.

A tax rebate of up to $450 per taxpayer will be available for interest earned on savings, superannuation and other investments or investments in small business. This measure is likely to assist around six million taxpayers and will reduce our reliance on foreign borrowings. It will also, by providing additional financial resources in this nation, help protect Australian companies from foreign takeovers. It will provide a pool of resources to assist investment in local industry including, of course, local industry in Wide Bay.

There will be Australian money more readily available to assist and support Australian industry. When there is a need for a capital influx in a company somewhere around the nation, there will be Australian funds available rather than having to borrow offshore. When equity is needed, Australians can invest rather than having to sell off our companies to countries overseas and that will be particularly welcome in regional areas.

The expectation in this budget is that unemployment will fall nationally to eight per cent. In my own area, when this government came to office the unemployment rate was 20 per cent. Labor's legacy to Wide Bay was 20 per cent unemployment. A projected lowering of the unemployment rate is very good news indeed and there is $20 million in the budget to assist depressed regions which are experiencing high levels of unemployment.

I have no doubt that Wide Bay will be particularly targeted for projects under the work for the dole scheme, for which $21 million is provided in this budget. Around 10,000 places will be available for young people in the 18‐ to 24‐year‐old age bracket and naturally the scheme will target rural and regional areas with high levels of unemployment. I have at an early stage volunteered my region for some of these pilot programs and I am sure that there are many young people who are looking forward to the opportunity to contribute something to their community for the unemployment benefits that they are receiving.

There is increased expenditure for rural health, another issue of considerable concern to regional Australia. It is quite deplorable that, despite the fact that there are scores of doctors in capital cities who are working below the poverty line or not working in medicine at all, there are regional and rural communities right around the country which cannot get adequate medical staff.

A new Hervey Bay hospital is being officially opened in my electorate in the next couple of days. This is a magnificent hospital and it would be the pride of any private hospital system in the country. You walk through the entrance foyer to be greeted by fountains, gardens and lavish surroundings like those you would expect to see in the most luxurious of hospitals. But this is a public hospital. I would have thought it would be a wonderful place for any doctor to work. But the Queensland health department have had to recruit 11 doctors from England to help staff this hospital, and it has been difficult to attract specialists. We are not talking here about a dusty, dry, remote, rural community. We are talking about a fast‐growing regional city on the beach with a magnificent lifestyle and perhaps the best climate in the country. And yet, doctors will not move from the capital cities to work in an area such as this.

That is why the government's rural health initiatives are so important. They are important not just for remote communities but also for fast‐growing regional cities that have been unable to attract the medical expertise that they surely have a right to expect. There is $17.4 million in this budget targeted for rural and remote area health priorities, including the extension of specialist medical training in rural areas and the development of innovative models for service delivery.

The Medicare offices will stay open throughout regional Australia and there will be 400 new Medicare agencies to provide, for the first time in many country towns, services which city people have taken for granted.

There is particular emphasis on the need to upgrade Australia's quarantine services. There have been many incidents over recent times of lapses in our quarantine barriers. A $76 million boost over four years for quarantine will be warmly welcomed in fruit‐growing areas such as my own, but all Australians will benefit from the protection provided to our unique Australian industry.

We are a remote country and we suffer many disadvantages as a result of having to trade with people far away. Our shipping costs add burdens. The time taken in travelling to promote our products is certainly a liability. But our remoteness has one major advantage and that is that our country is largely free of the pests and diseases which plague so much of the rest of the world. We need to protect that advantage and guard it zealously. This new boost to quarantine expenditure is an important recognition of the new government's commitment to ensuring that our industries remain free from the scourges that are endured by so many people in other parts of the world.
Regional roads will get a significant funding boost with $800 million provided for the national highway system—and around 90 per cent of that money to be directed to rural areas.

I particularly welcome, in my own electorate, the announcement that $14 million is being provided in the budget for the long‐awaited Gunalda Range reconstruction. This has to be the worst part of Highway 1 anywhere in Australia. It is a winding, narrow mountain strip and its reconstruction was promised by Labor more than a decade ago. In fact, they promised it at every election during which I have been associated with the federal parliament. But they have never delivered. They promised it at the state level. They have given I do not know how many starting dates, but they have never delivered. The $14 million provided in this budget will hopefully allow the project to get under way this financial year. This will remove one of the worst accident spots and one of the slowest parts of the national highway anywhere in Australia. So I welcome this commitment to road funding.

There is, of course, much, more included in the budget of particular interest to regional Australia. The regional telecommunications infrastructure fund will provide $250 million to help regional businesses and communities take advantage of the technologies that are available and provide to country people the same sorts of services that cities have taken for granted.

There is another $48 million for the regional forest agreements. That is important, particularly for those states that do not have Labor governments, because it is quite obvious that the New South Wales Labor government has no commitment whatever to the forest industries. It is important that we get these agreements in place in other states, so that there can be security and protection in the long term for those vital forest industries. That is particularly important in an electorate such as my own, which has a very large forest industry and which has been so concerned now for years that Labor governments at state and federal level are likely to remove access to their resource and deny any kind of future growth or maintenance of those industries.

There is $1.2 million for the new regional minerals program to help encourage the expansion of mining ventures and, as I mentioned earlier, a $20 million assistance program for depressed regions. I welcome also the changes to Austudy, which will be of particular benefit to regional and rural Australia. The changes will particularly benefit families with more than one child eligible for Austudy and remove a disadvantage that was present in the rules for larger families.

There is $2.8 million to continue the credit care program to help communities set up credit unions where banks have closed. That, again, is not an issue that is just confined to the remote areas. There are many banks closing in my own electorate, and I have now got a number of towns left entirely without banking services. I welcome the credit care program as a way of providing a means for people in smaller rural areas to be able to carry out financial transactions in their own area. The government's commitment in that regard is warmly welcomed.

It is of interest to note also that this budget commits the government to a new integrated rural policy package. Following the mid‐term review, the rural adjustment scheme is to be phased out later this year. But $198 million has been committed in the budget for the new integrated rural policy package. That is an especially welcome initiative. Despite the efforts of governments in the past, despite the well‐meaning intentions, no doubt, of many, there is still much pain in the rural sector and, particularly, there is much adjustment that will be required to ensure the future prosperity and viability of Australia's farms.

This new package must provide measures to assist farmers with their management, but must also provide assistance to people by way of welfare payments when they face exceptionally difficult times. Farmers do not expect and do not want to live on welfare, but there is a need for the same kind of safety net for the rural sector, for farmers, as applies to others in the community who fall on difficult times. It is also important to provide an effective rural counselling service, because some people have to face, and make, very difficult decisions about the future of their farming operations and sometimes they need some assistance in that regard. I trust that the government will find the necessary funds to ensure that there is an effective network of rural counsellors right through the nation to provide help and assistance where it is needed.

This budget does indeed provide a number of opportunities for new hope and optimism in regional and rural Australia. Naturally, everything cannot be achieved overnight. But I hope that as regional areas start to come to grips with what this budget contains, the potential that is available for them to reinvest, to reinvigorate their business and industries, there will be new hope for the future and that rural and regional Australia will adopt a more positive and aggressive attitude towards their future. Australian regional areas contribute much to the wealth of this country—most of our export income. They contribute to our gross domestic product way beyond other sectors of the community. They are entitled to assistance and recognition of that contribution.

This budget delivers to regional Australia. This budget gives them an opportunity to go on and continue to contribute to our nation. But it also makes it clear to those who live outside the capital city that the coalition government cares and wants their lifestyle to be improved and be in keeping with the rest of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The second Howard‐Costello budget, brought down on 13 May 1997, is a political rather than an economic document. The first budget in August 1996 cut hard and deep but seemed to have been reasonably well received in the electorate. The 1998‐99 budget, the last for this parliament, will be designed as an election sweetener.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a long tradition in Australia that new governments blame predecessors for the horrors of their first budget. `We had no idea,' the new treasurers say, eyes blazing with outrage and sincerity, `how bad the economic situation was when we came in. We had to take desperate measures, which were entirely due to the previous government.'

Labor said it in 1983—coming in after a period when John Howard had been Treasurer—but with good reason. In March 1983, unemployment and inflation both stood at 11 per cent and the deficit in current dollars amounted to $25 billion. The coalition did it in 1996, and keep saying it. Governments generally have a honeymoon period in their first months in office. Tony Blair in Great Britain is currently reaping the benefit of it.

Before turning to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997-98, it is worth pointing out the extraordinary resemblance between the Australian election of March 1996 and the British general election of May 1997, but with party roles reversed. In both cases the incumbent Prime Minister had unexpectedly won a previous election—1992 for John Major and 1993 for Paul Keating. The economic indicators were good but, essentially, the electors had decided they wanted a change and did not listen to the economic good news. Coincidentally, British Labour's 44.5 per cent of the popular vote in a first-past-the-post election was exactly the same as the ALP's two-candidate preferred vote in an election conducted on a preferential system. The ALP primary vote of 38.7 per cent was far ahead of the Conservatives' 31 per cent.

The biggest story in the media coverage of the 1997-98 budget was a 15 per cent taxation rebate on savings, designed to be the centrepiece in a program to encourage national investment. The objective is certainly desirable and necessary. National savings and investment are unusually low in Australia, well behind the OECD average. As the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said:
The rebate will apply to the first $3,000 of taxable income from savings however derived. For example, the rebate would apply to the whole of the interest earned on $60,000 invested at 5 per cent.
Alternatively, the rebate can be claimed in respect of any payment of personal contributions into superannuation up to $3,000. A person who pays $3,000 into superannuation will get a $450 tax rebate.
However, barely three weeks after the budget, the Costello savings rebate is no longer talked about. It has disappeared into the fog.

Dr Vince Fitzgerald, who conducted an important inquiry into national savings, disputed from the start whether the plan could be effective. David Connolly, formerly a Liberal shadow minister, thought it absurd. Some `deep throats' made it clear that Treasury was profoundly sceptical that it could work. When tackled on this in question time the day after the budget, the Treasurer replied, `What the Treasury policy is doesn't matter to the government.'

In Senate estimates on 2 June 1997, the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr Ted Evans, directly contradicted government claims about the savings rebate, saying that it may backfire and lead to lower national savings. He conceded that the $2 billion cost of running the scheme could exceed any increase in savings by individuals. He agreed that the rebate could be obtained in full by taxpayers who had not increased their saving, or had reduced their savings in any given financial year, which is rather an interesting concept of what an incentive is. He also agreed that only a small number of taxpayers might be benefited.

The timing of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in raising the possibility of introducing a GST if the government should be re‐elected in 1999 was universally regarded as a diversionary tactic, a smokescreen, to divert attention away from the now discredited savings rebate, and also from the issues to be raised at the Reconciliation Convention and the 10-point Wik plan on native title and pastoral leases.

The revival of this issue was even odder because it had the potential to damage the Prime Minister who had several times unambiguously ruled out GST as a possibility—it was no longer on the agenda. One of Ted Evans' predecessors as Secretary to the Treasury, John Stone, who had held that position when John Howard was Treasurer, gave a less than flattering review of the budget in the Financial Review of 29 May under the heading `Lame Budget has Howard ducking for cover'. He wrote:

Commentators generally agree that the Prime Minister acted on national television on May 18 to restore tax reform to public prominence in an attempt to divert attention from his Budget failure five days earlier.

Yet taken as a whole, the overwhelming impression of the Government's approach to the taxation system is of an incoherent hodge‐podge of bits and pieces tricked out to appeal to this or that special interest group.
