Wonderful to have friends. The tariff debate, now concentrating on the future of the motor vehicle industry in Australia is taking place in a grossly misleading way. The hard line economic rationalists, very contemptuous of economic nationalism and/or self‐sufficiency, give the impression that Australia is resisting movement towards lower tariffs in a context of rapidly increasing globalisation. But in our region Australia ranks with New Zealand as the most accessible market of all in automotive manufactured products.

The current tariff level for imports is five to 25 per cent and the projected figure for the year 2000 is five to 15 per cent—leaving aside the proposed Moore modification of the Productivity Commission's majority report. Part imports are not linked to local investment.

The US has a five per cent tariff on cars, 25 per cent on trucks and six to seven per cent on parts, with bilateral restraints on Japanese imports, and the benefit of NAFTA. In market accessibility it is in the No. 2 category, behind Australia and New Zealand. Japan is in the No. 3 rank, with no tariffs, but very significant market cartels are, in practice, far more significant than the tariff.

Hong Kong, which has no car industry, is also in the No. 3 rank, imposing a tax between 30 and 90 per cent on imports. Singapore is in the No. 5 rank, with no motor manufacturing, but a tariff of 45 per cent and a tax of 175 per cent. In the No. 10 category, the most inaccessible are China, India, Indonesia, the Republic of Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Taiwan and Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody!

—Everybody in fact. Korea, with very generous access to Australia's markets, does not reciprocate, imposing tariffs, import taxes of between 25 per cent to 100 per cent, import licences, plus an obligation to have local content. China imposes a tariff of 110 to 150 per cent, import licences and local content requirements, while Indonesia's regime differs by only having a tariff limit of 100 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Is this the celebrated `level playing field' that we have heard so much about, also under the previous government? The Treasurer's punchy delivery on television interviews invites parody, especially after the budget when he reeled off a list of areas beneficially treated, he contends, in the budget. `Big winners', he grunted. `Big winners'.

The Appropriation Bill makes it clear that there are significant categories of `big losers'. The ABC?—big loser; Radio Australia?—big loser; Australia Television?—big loser; the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission?—big loser; the Attorney‐General?—big loser; CSIRO?—big loser; energy research—big loser; ATSIC?—big loser; universities?—big losers.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least he was consistent!

—Absolutely consistent. With the pre‐emptive announcement by Senator Alston before the budget that the ABC would lose $50 million, the national broadcaster found itself between a rock and a hard place. In its submission to the Mansfield inquiry, it decided to offer up Radio Australia and Australia Television—a tragic mistake, taken up by Bob Mansfield who admits, with characteristic candour, that he had very little exposure to either.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives a very contradictory signal about Australia's engagement with Asia. Even though Radio Australia has been reprieved, in a sharply reduced form, Australia Television's screen will go black, even though it has a selective, but powerful influence, at very low cost. There seems to be a real determination by the Howard government to cripple the ABC, denounced as an outlet for `political correctness'.
A columnist in the Sydney Morning Herald observed, correctly, that this government did not have an agenda, it had a hit list.

I am mystified about the Prime Minister's main complaint about the ABC, which is that it has a narrower range than the commercial television and radio networks. A narrower range? Can he be serious? The ABC is aiming at the long term, the value laden and, I would hope, the highest common denominator. The ABC's range includes news, current affairs, sport, talkback, serious music, opera, ballet, satire, science, state and federal political reviews, foreign affairs, education, book reviews, rural affairs, theatre reviews, serious films, commentary and critical analysis, and health. Many of those functions are duplicated by SBS, but only the first four are taken up by commercial television networks.

Metropolitan commercial radio has a very narrow range of news, popular music, talkback and sport, wedged in between advertisements. Commercial television, driven by ratings and appealing to the lowest common multiple, rejects the idea of appealing to a diversity of interests and sticks heavily to a formula where night-time television is dominated by imported drama or infotainment series, sport and glorified home videos, such as the hugely successful program on home improvements. This, to the Prime Minister, is a broad range.

One can understand his enthusiasm for offering the Sydney Morning Herald and the Age to Kerry Packer on a platter, because the Prime Minister has no taste for the critical commentary found in the columns of both papers. He is not Robinson Crusoe in that. Every Prime Minister is hypersensitive to criticism and satire, but I think it is something that should be encouraged. Thomas Jefferson wrote in a letter in 1787:
Were it left to me to decide whether we should have a government without newspapers, or newspapers without a government, I should not hesitate a moment to prefer the latter.

I basically agree. GTV9's news on Monday, 26 May perhaps illustrates the broader range of commercial television which the Prime Minister commends. This was the day when the Australian Reconciliation Convention was opened in Melbourne. The first item on the news was the recent accident involving Mr Sam Newman, a Channel 9 sports luminary. The Reconciliation Convention, involving the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), ranked as the sixth item.
The Prime Minister might well concede that this shows the benefit of competition: without competitive pressure, Channel 9 might otherwise have decided to ignore the convention.

How extraordinary that the Prime Minister should be intervening in the affairs of John Fairfax Ltd, talking it down, warning of instability—which turns out to be news to the board and to its chairman, Sir Laurence Street—and retailing the pure, unvarnished Packer line, because there is direct political self-interest involved! In sharp contrast, he refuses to take strong action with BHP over the proposed steelworks closure in Newcastle. Unlike John Fairfax Ltd, this is apparently just another commercial decision.

As I pointed out in last year's budget speech, CSIRO appeared to do well. The Treasurer said then, `The government will provide another $115 million in the budget over the next four years.' In the 1997-98 budget, CSIRO's new allocation rises from $471.1 million to $439.4 million, an increase of 5.3 per cent. Good news? Well, not quite. What the budget documents failed to mention—a regrettable oversight—is that CSIRO suffers from the impact of increased efficiency dividends—based on the fallacy that the pursuit of knowledge is a fixed or finite target, like building a bridge—and a requirement to repay asset sales.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's accountancy.
—Exactly. It is accountancy, but it is certainly not science or technology. Even leaving inflation aside, CSIRO will actually be worse off by 1999‐2000.

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor‐General appears to be on the government hit list for what seems to be the appalling misjudgment of making calls for national unity and justice—not items that appear to be conspicuously high on the government's priorities. Referring to the scandal of Aboriginal health was seen to be in the worst of taste.

The drip method of leaking has been used against him, as it was with his former High Court colleague, Sir Ronald Wilson, Chairman of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. In my 25 years as a member of parliament—five in Victoria and just on 20 years in Canberra—I have never seen parliamentary institutions subjected to so much sustained attack. Many of the wounds are self‐inflicted.

There is a major confusion between democracy and populism which, if continued, could be a threat to the spirit of democracy and to the whole political process. Just as the `Joh for Prime Minister' phenomenon in 1987—which actually damaged the present Prime Minister very badly—caused great but temporary damage to the political process and then disappeared as the mirage that it was, one might hope that this might be true of contemporary phenomena.

I want to say something about the current controversy about Aborigines—the question of a national apology and, of course, the report, Bringing them home. David Marr, in a very passionate piece in the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday, 31 May 1997, made the penetrating comment that perhaps we were congratulating ourselves too much on the passage of the 1967 referendum. Australians, he thought, were pretty good at cheap gestures, actions that did not cost anything but made us feel very good, that did not actually alter power relationships at all. As he said of the referendum campaign in 1967, the aim was:

. . . to bring back black Australians into the Federation. But what followed—land rights, black health, justice for Aborigines—cost white Australia money and a little land. These programs were contested all the way. The politics was tough.

Yet for much of the 30 years since the referendum, a decent compact operated in Canberra not to take party political advantage of the persistent racism that both sides of politics know is out there. All their polling tells them this. We're celebrating the anniversary of the referendum with that old compact in tatters. The Howard Government boasts this achievement as the end of "political correctness".

I want to quote, very briefly, something from the report, Bringing them home , and I want to draw attention to the controversy that has been written about whether the use of the term `genocide' might be appropriate. I notice a number of people thundering away in letters to newspapers, but I think it is worthwhile just reading this part from page 271 of the report. It reads:

Genocide does not necessarily mean the immediate physical destruction of a group or nation. The Polish jurist Raphael Lemkin was the author of the term and the major proponent of the United Nations Convention. He defined `genocide' as `a coordinated plan of different actions aimed at the destruction of the essential foundations of the life of national groups, with the aim of annihilating the groups themselves'

The objectives of such a coordinated plan would be `the disintegration of the political and social institutions, of culture, language, national feelings, religion, and the economic existence of national groups and the destruction of the personal security, liberty, health, dignity, and even the lives of the individuals belonging to such groups'.
Does that sound familiar? The quote continues:

Lemkin defined genocide to include `deliberate separation of families for depopulation purposes subordinated to the criminal intent to destroy or to cripple permanently a human group'. Genocide, he said, typically comprises two phases: the destruction of the cultural and social life of the `oppressed group' and the imposition of the national pattern of the `oppressor'.

If we make the distinction, a very striking distinction, between what we might describe as slow genocide and rapid genocide, we would have to say it is not the genocide that we are familiar with in the period from 1943 to 1945 in Europe with the annihilation of the Jews and some other minorities, but I must say that the Lemkin definition does sound to me to be pretty accurate.

One of the things that I felt more disturbed about as a member of parliament—even more disturbing than some of the noises off from the northern part of the continent—has been the way in which the drip method has been employed against this report, a very deliberate and a very familiar attempt which people on both sides would be aware of, to poison the waterhole. That attempt was made so that when the document comes down, people could say, `Oh well, you can dismiss that out of hand. The people involved in it actually have an emotional feeling related to it. You couldn't take anyone seriously who felt emotionally about it. It was headed by a former High Court judge who gave up his job on the court and devoted himself to the cause of human rights.'

Watch this space! The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has had its budget very savagely cut in this budget and I notice that the term of the chairman expires on 30 June. I would advise Sir Ronald not to be holding his breath for reappointment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Howard government's second budget is good news for the 130,000 residents of Lindsay. It reinforces the fair but necessary measures announced in the 1996‐97 budget that set about restoring Australia's financial affairs after the parlous state in which we found them on 2 March 1996.

BREAK.PARA: The Keating government's legacy to the electors of Lindsay was a $10.3 billion deficit. It was a disgraceful performance of mismanagement and wasted opportunity. With the recession we had to have in 1991 the Labor government spent $11,493 million more than it took in revenue. In 1992, they spent $17 billion more than they actually took in in revenue. In 1993‐94, another $17 billion was spent over and above revenue. That was paid for from assets sales and loans.

To get an idea of what $17 billion means to the average person in the Lindsay electorate, it would take a person on $30,000 a year 566,666 years to pay it off—and that is if they worked from the day they were born to the day they died. In other words, it would take 7,762 lifetimes to pay off a $17 billion debt. And the Keating government clocked that up in one year! The zeros that wander around this building have struck me, in the short time that I have been here, as scandalous and I am determined to see Australia back in the black before I leave this place.

In 1994, $13 billion more was spent than was taken in revenue; in 1995, another $10 billion. Last year, under our 1996‐97 budget, that deficit was reined back to $6.8 billion. This year, with this budget, it will be reined back to $3.8 billion. By the following year, we will be $1.5 billion in the black—for the first time in 10 years. That is an incredibly significant achievement for one term in office. It has taken the Liberal government one term to turn around the finances of Australia from a $10 billion hole to a surplus of nearly $2 billion.

How was that deficit racked up? It was racked up by toadying to union movements and minority and vested interest groups. Labor's arrogance and extravagance had no end. It was basically a matter of, `We won't consult you, we won't listen to you. Don't you worry about that—we know what is good for you. Here it is, you'll love it.' The people of Lindsay did not love it. It was very obvious on 2 March, and abundantly clear by 19 October, that the people of Lindsay had had enough of Labor's spendthrift ways with their money.

It is quite clear to me when I leave Canberra. I drive all the way up the Hume Highway, turn down the northern road into Penrith and there, in the roads, we know where the taxpayer's dollar is going. Thankfully, with our charter of budget honesty, it cannot happen again. The figures for 1996, 1997 and 1998 show that Australia has a bright future and that this government will turn our finances to surplus after just one term in government.

But we are not here for one term; we are here for a long term. Our policies, as announced in this budget and others, are showing a direction for the next 10 or 15 years. We are making long‐term plans. We do not intend to make plans from budget to budget, or from term to term, or election to election. We are settling into a very long and stable period of government, which the electors of Australia desperately need. There is one key statement in the Treasurer's budget speech that I wish to reiterate today because it is the one that hardworking people in the electorate of Lindsay, and indeed all over Australia, fully appreciate.

In the forthcoming year, the government has no net borrowing requirement. In fact, for the first time in nearly a decade, this year the government will not run up a debt because the underlying budget deficit is made up from asset sales such as the one‐third sale of Telstra. In the coming financial year we will repay it. We will repay over $5 billion of debt. That is a significant turnaround and a significant meeting of the trust of the electors of Lindsay. Any further sales will retire debt.

This is unlike Labor, which came to government on a platform of non‐privatisation, huge government industry and huge government involvement in service provision and in industry. Then, when the crunch came and they could not meet their bills, `Let's sell the farm. And let's not sell the farm to pay off debt or to recover from recession, let's sell the farm to spend more money that we don't have, so our future generations can have an even bigger debt to pay off.' I am afraid the logic just did not gel with the electors of Lindsay who, on $30,000 a year, are trying to pay off a mortgage and get three kids through school and give their spouse an option, or choice, of workplace or home based activity.

We need to save; there is absolutely no doubt about that. If your government is not saving, what incentive is there for you to do that either? Herein lies the terrific incentive in this budget, which is a 15 per cent tax rebate on savings. It is an incentive. The idea is that now that it is available, people will actually take that measure of saving, something they have not done in years.

The people of Lindsay are pretty fed up and tired of putting their money in the bank and then seeing any interest they get go in tax, bank charges, fees, transaction costs, government FID and BAD. There is very little incentive for people to save and it is imperative that they do. They save for their retirement, they save for their children's future, and they save to provide a capital base within this country that we can invest with so that we do not have to keep on going offshore for foreign investment or foreign government loans.

The budget measures announced by the Treasurer on 13 May lock in interest rate reductions that have been delivered since this government was elected. For the average person in Lindsay with an average mortgage, their mortgage interest rates have come down $240 a month; that is $60 a week for the average mortgage payer. That $60 a week is an enormous benefit straight away, cash in hand, to the voters of Lindsay.

I would like to discriminate between that and the incentives given by Labor. Labor gives such wonderful incentives as the $50 cash‐back. For each child going to school—regardless of whether they attend Barker College on the North Shore and get driven to school in a Bentley—you will get $50 back. But for the kids out in Lindsay they get $50 back and, guess what? Their parents had to pay the tax so government could then administer it, put it into the schooling system, which is not funded anyway, to deliver these services, and then give them $50 back. If you add it up, Mr Deputy Speaker, they probably taxed them 70 bucks to give them the $50 cash‐back.

Our cash‐backs are based on the fact that we do not take it from you. You get a 15 per cent reduction on interest on your savings. You get rebates back on your private health insurance. You get rebates back where the government does not actually take the money; you do not pay the tax.

The families of Lindsay are predominantly young and hardworking, with a determination to succeed on their own. They are not the sort of people who expect government handouts. They can do it on their own. If the government just leaves them with enough cash at the end of the week to get ahead, they are quite happy to make it alone. They have responded to the fact that the federal government keeps its commitments—unlike the former Labor government, which kept its l‐a‐w promise, or maybe its promise on the M4 tollway! That was a classic Labor promise! In fact, when they delivered on it, only 21,000 motorists of the 1.8 million people who live in western Sydney actually accessed that rebate.

The people of Lindsay respond to the notion of less government interference in their lives. They respond to the fact that this federal government is prepared to live within its means. They are reassured by the fact that taxpayers' funds will be spent wisely—with consideration for those less fortunate in society—and, most importantly, spent fairly—on a needs basis, taking those most disadvantaged first. Middle class welfare and access to aged care when people can afford to pay for it themselves are things of the past. We have to do it tough over these three years. We have to pay for a lot of mistakes that Labor made. We are doing it tough; we are making all the tough and fair decisions. The people of Lindsay are confident of their future and their children's future.

For the first time ever, this government has introduced legislation to maintain the pension at 25 per cent of the male total average weekly earnings. This reinforces the government's commitment to maintain the income of aged pensioners. It will be going up with the CPI. This is unlike the Keating government policy, which introduced a sales tax between 1993 and 1996. In fact, the revenue collected from sales tax by the former federal government between 1993 and 1996 went up by 40 per cent. That was coming out of the pensioners' funds when they trundled along to the supermarket to buy their goods. If the basket of weekly shopping goes up by $10 per week, that has a major impact on a pensioner. They cannot afford that. This measure has frozen all tax rates; they are not going up. And guess what? You actually really do get an increase in your average weekly wage.

With the deferred pension bonus plan, people can actually work past the age of 65. They can work to the age of 70, which again gives people a choice. You are not mandated by government that, at 65 years of age, you are totally useless and are to get out of the work force. It does not compete with people of 18 years of age in the youth market, because generally somebody at the end of their working life is not really after the type of job which someone just starting out is applying for. As long as they can continue in gainful employment for 25 hours per week for five years, they can retain their activity in the community and can contribute and pick up a nice bonus at the age of 70. This is another example of the government providing options for individuals.

Carers also receive a significant boost in this year's budget. The rate of the domiciliary nursing care benefit will be aligned with the child disability allowance from 1 July 1998. This increases the rate of the benefit payable by over 25 per cent. It provides carers who care for loved ones in home based care rather than nursing care with an extra $16.60 per fortnight. That may not seem much to members opposite, but it sure makes a difference to the electors of Lindsay.

Funding of more than $54 million over four years will be provided under the Commonwealth‐state disability agreement. This will allow 500 additional families to access personal care and accommodation support for a person with severe or profound disabilities. People with disabilities have been sorely neglected under Labor, and those wrongs are being redressed in this budget and in future initiatives under this government. It is not something that we can remedy overnight, because there is just not the money to do it, but it is there on the agenda. We plan on 10 to 15 years in government, and those things are in train to look after the most disadvantaged in our society, regardless of race, religion, ethnic background or any other distinction.

It is the vision of the Howard government which is inspiring people today and giving a lot more confidence; the dynamism, the futuristic compassion, trustworthiness, patience—a lot of things we did not hear for a long time under Labor. All we heard under Labor was arrogance, toady, tired, lacking in ideas, ideologues, locked in. Suddenly we have a fresh, new approach—people who are not bound by previous statements and who do not say, `We have to do it this way because we always did it this way.' We have a fresh bunch of new ideas, we have got some visionaries and some futuristic people.

The government's child‐care policy is based on equity and choice. Women at work, in training or seeking work get priority in child‐care assistance. Tens of thousands of new places have been funded for child care and, whether they are private or community based child‐care services, they are all being supported. A tremendous diversity and choice is becoming available in that area.

For the environment, we have the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. We expect $1.25 billion to be available this year, of which $1 million has already been set aside on a grant of trust so that it will come to the Hawkesbury‐Nepean river system. That river system is one of the jewels in the crown of the electorate of Lindsay. It is a fantastic rowing venue. It is a training venue for the Olympics coming up in the year 2000. It has tremendous potential for future tourism for Penrith. However, the extent of river nutrients in the area and the number of exotic plants and other aquatic plant species are damaging the viability of the river system. It is close to one of the biggest cities in Australia and up the river is one of the major water sources for the city of Sydney. It is an important environmental feature that does need funding and assistance to maintain viability.

The $1 million, and probably more, has already been given in terms of a number of projects put forward from the community. The people of Lindsay have said, `Listen, I want to be involved too. I care to go down to my backyard and do some landcare projects, and do something for South Creek, for Werrington Creek, for Mulgoa Creek,' which are all tributaries into the Nepean River in my area.

The opportunities for our region to participate in the 2000 Olympics are also going to be enhanced by the overall economic strength of this budget. Small businesses are well placed to create opportunities to cater for the demands of overseas visitors at this major sporting event. We are already implementing the Greater West Sydney Games as an initiative to get small businesses involved and focused on the potential for that event.

With low interest rates—and if we hold them there, and if we stop a wages explosion and allow growth to keep interest rates down—small business has a chance to just breathe. Unfortunately, it has appeared for the last 12 months as if we have been doing CPR on something that Labor had killed off five years ago. Luckily, there is a spark of life and we are bringing things back to a good healthy future for Australia.

I have previously informed the House of the Greater West Sydney Task Force, which is a group of members of this House—the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), the member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey) and the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett)—who are getting together to coordinate the development of the area of western Sydney. The task force will certainly be putting forward projects for the Federation Fund which will greatly enhance our region, which has been sorely neglected under Labor—as can be seen by Bob Carr's attitude to it, by Keating's attitude to it and by the previous member for Lindsay's attitude to it. Finally, the people of Lindsay have a member who is part of a government that is prepared to do something for them.

I commend the appropriation bill to the House. It has taken the determination of the coalition government to steer a path that assists those in need in our communities, that reduces the impost of government and reverses the years of Labor waste and mismanagement. It is a good budget for Australia and a good budget for the Lindsay electorate. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Health and Family Services: Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many mobile telephones, lap top computers and similar equipment have been provided to the Minister, Parliamentary Secretary and ministerial officers.
(2) What has been the cost of providing the equipment referred to in part (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the office of the Minister for Health and Family Services there are: 4 lap top computers; 2 printers; 12 mobile telephones; and 1 car kit.

In the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services there are: 3 lap top computers; 3 printers; and 4 mobile telephones. Most of these items were transferred to the Parliamentary Secretary from the former Parliamentary Secretary's office.
(2) Costs for equipment in answer (1) are respectively: $25 762.30; $16 037.00

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is his Department purchasing properties neighbouring HMAS Albatross ; if so, on whose behalf.
(2) How many properties are being acquired.
(3) How many are (a) residential properties and (b) business premises.
(4) Are the properties being acquired at market prices; if so, how is the market price determined.
(5) How many owners of the properties accepted his Department's first property valuation and sold to his Department.
(6) How many land valuers has his Department used for the property valuations.
(7) How many properties have had (a) one, (b) two or (c) three or more valuations determined.
(8) Has his Department set deadlines for acceptance of its offer to purchase; if so (a) on which properties have deadlines been set and (b) why.
(9) For what purpose are the properties being acquired.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On behalf of the Department of Defence.
(2) Eleven properties have been identified as possibly being required; offers have been made in respect of nine properties.
(3) (a) All the properties are rural home sites or hobby farms. (b) Available information indicates that one of the properties is also used to conduct a business activity.

(4) Yes. The Australian Valuation Office was instructed to provide a market valuation of the property; each property owner was then given the opportunity to commission a private valuation of the market value. The final price is determined by negotiation having regard to the two valuations.
(5) One. The vendor has agreed to sell, but the sale has not yet been finalised.

(6) Three. (1) The Australian Valuation Office; (2) some landowners chose to have a second valuation, at Commonwealth expense, from the one independent land valuer; and (3) a determining valuation, at Commonwealth expense, where there is a significant difference between valuations under (1) and (2).

(8) Yes. (a) Deadlines have been set for all nine properties for which offers have been made. (b) The deadlines were set to enable the Department of Defence to establish, in a reasonable time‐frame, whether any interest existed in selling.
(9) The Department of Defence has advised that the purchase of land is proposed to support extended operational requirements and provide the necessary buffer zones for base activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: What quantities of (a) imports and (b) exports were handled at each Australian port in (i) each year since 1990-91 and the period 1 July to 31 December 1996 and (ii) total, categorised as (A) twenty foot equivalents of containerised cargo, (B) bulk dry cargo, (C) liquid, (D) break/bulk cargo and (E) general cargo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The amended answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department does not have breakups of vessels by twenty foot equivalent unit for international trade. I have supplied instead the statistics for quantity (tonnes) and value($A). The Department has estimated that an average of 14 tonnes (based on Port of Melbourne figures in Waterline—March 1997)is carried per teu.

Ship categories are different to that requested by the honourable member. This is necessary because of the aggregations that have already been done by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to the data supplied to the Department. This data categories the vessels somewhat differently to that requested.
The tables try to match the vessel categories as closely as possible to those requested.
Ro-ro have been included as a separate category, as these vessels carry both container and break-bulk cargo, as well as vehicles.
